maṅke balik* lvir paramālayeṅ laṅit,

təkapta sākṣāt parameśvarāləṅəṅ*,

mvaṅ vīrayakṣādhika devatulya ya,

ya tāmaṅun tuṣṭanikiṅ tapodhara.’


Translation

⟨2⟩But [because of your visit], my hermitage is now like the abode of the god Parama (Īśvara) in heaven, For you are in truth like the god Parameśvara absorbed in the contemplation of beauty, And your excellent demon heroes are equal to the gods, Giving delight to me’.*


3.

liṅ saṅ sutāpī* sira gauraveṅ tamuy.

vimūrchitan rāvaṇa kāṇḍəhan lulut,

de saṅ tapī lvīr adhikāra riṅ hajə̄ṅ,

subhāga* de vākyaniran manohara.


Translation

⟨3⟩Thus spoke the great anchoress respectfully to her guest. Rāvaṇa was overcome, and smitten with passion, Since she was of such outstanding beauty; And delighted by her charming velcome [he said:]


4.

`ai saṅ bibiṅku, dyah inaṅku saṅ tapī,

varah ṅhulun hetuni rūmta valkalī!

āpan mahācintya surūpa kottama,

sarehta himpər hyaṅi raśminiṅ səkar.


Translation

⟨4⟩’O my dear lady, O anchoress, Tell me why you became an anchoress,* For you are of such inconceivable beauty, That all your doings are like those of the goddess of the splendour of flowers.*


5.

sakvehnikaṅ sarva laṅə̄ hane kita:

aśoka sinvamnyan umiśra* riṅ təṅah,

nyū danta sampun rəsəp* iṅ payodhara,

gaḍuṅ lumuṅ lvir luṅayanta yan cala,


Translation

⟨5⟩All kinds of beauty are within you: Young aśoka leaves merge with your waist,* The beauty of ivory coconuts is that of your breasts, The svaying of the tender shoots of the gaḍuṅ vines is that of your arms.


6.

tuñjuṅ birū tan sah ikeṅ matāluru,

madhubratākveh kamage vətista mār;

polahnikaṅ sarva sarīki* kāṅinan,

baṅun vivalteki mənen kinolakən;


Translation

⟨6⟩Blue lotuses are your sparkling eyes; Svarms of bees mistake your lovely calves [for puḍak flowers];* [Your gait is] the movement of all kinds of flowers blovn by the breeze, It seems that you will slip from an eager embrace;*


7.

saṅ hyaṅ vulan lvir kadinan sireṅ vəṅi,

təkapni rūmtābuhayeṅ pajaṅ śaśi*.

tā ṅeh hajə̄ṅteki yadin kavarṇana,

səkar pirekaṅ jinaheki tan cukup.’


Translation

⟨7⟩The evening moon looks like being overtaken by daylight Because of your beauty, and pines for [its lost] light.* It would take long to depict your beauty, No matter hov many poems one composed, they would never be sufficient’.*


8.

`ai saṅ daśāsyeki,’ vuvusniraṅ tapī,

`rəṅə̄n pva tā kāraṇaniṅ tapodhara.

vvantən surarṣy āmitadharma kottama,

kuśadhvajekā panəlahnireṅ sarāt.


Translation

⟨8⟩’O Daśāsya,’ she said, ’Hear the reason why I practice asceticism: There was a god-sage, his excellent virtues were peerless, His name was Kuśadhvaja, famous throughout the vorld.


9.

śāstrajña, putrarṣi vṛhaspatīnucap,

bapaṅku tan len sira mānak iṅ hulun;

tūtniṅ ṅaran vedavatī*, siran tinūt

səḍəṅnirāveda sadā, mijil ṅhulun.


Translation

⟨9⟩He was a son of the sage Wṛhaspati, learned in the holy Books; He was none other than my father, He called me Wedavatī, because He was absorbed in reading the Wedas when I was born.


10.

yekātuhāgə̄ṅ tuvuhiṅ hulun rara,

aneka tekaṅ maharəp sumomaha:

gandharva vidyādhara daitya rākṣasa

surādi, sampun tinulaknirātələb.


Translation

⟨10⟩As time passed and I came of marriageable age,* Many asked for my hand: Celestial musicians, fairies, daitya, demons, Gods and others, but my father rejected them all firmly.


11.

ṅhiṅ saṅ mahākeśava mantva tan vuruṅ,

prayojana mvaṅ bibiniṅ hulun rəsəp.

ndah bhagna, mogheki pəjahniran kalih,

təkapnikaṅ rākṣasa śambhu* gə̄ṅ galak.


Translation

⟨11⟩It was none other than the great Keśava who was to be his son-in-lav, Such was the excellent wish of my father and mother. But their hopes were shattered, for alas! both my parents were slain By the most savage demon Śambhu.


12.

doṣeṅ* hulun hetuniran vineh pati,

titir pininte sira tan paveh kədə̄;

mārgaṅku muṅsir tapa bhakty akavvitan,

makārtha* saṅ hyan hari lakya riṅ hələm.’


Translation

⟨12⟩It was indeed my fault that they were slain,* For this demon asked my hand time and again, but they steadfastly refused him. This is why I practise asceticism: to remain faithful to my parents, For I wish, in time to come, to marry the god Hari.’


Canto 13 Pr̥thvītala

1.

nahan liṅira mārdaveki*; sumahur ta saṅ rāvaṇa:

’ibuṅku, kita hayva maṅkana; niniṅku, mūḍhādhama*

pitovi ri kədə̄nta rakva pakasādhya saṅ hyaṅ hari

ikaṅ rumabhase tuvuhta makamuṣṭyaniṅ valkalī,


Translation

⟨1⟩Thus she spoke gently. Rāvaṇa replied: ’Dear anchoress, there is no need for this. It is indeed both foolish and base, my dear, To make your ardent desire to be rawished By the god Hari the sole goal for being an anchoress,


2.

apan rasika deva hīna putus iṅ mahāduryaśa;

taṅanku sasikīki* tar makapaḍanya sikvākəna.

kalīṅan ika, nora lena saka riṅ hulun dyah sivin,

anindyaguṇa śakti vīra səḍəṅ antukantātapa.


Translation

⟨2⟩Because he is a base, most ignominious god, Who is not equal to one of my arms, even if I should only use the elbow. In other vords, you should serve none, other than me, Who am peerless in provess, pover and bravery, and have received gifts for completing ascetical exercises,*


3.

prasiddha karəs* iṅ triloka, putus iṅ mahāśaktimān,

dhaneśvara huvus pacuṇḍaṅ ika deṅku ṅūnīṅ raṇa,

vimāna pakavāhananya katavan təkapniṅ hulun,

təlas sahananiṅ balāsura lavan surākveh pəjah.


Translation

⟨3⟩I am in truth feared by the three vorlds, and endoved with the highest supernatural pover. I vanquished Dhaneśvara in a recent battle, Captured his celestial chariot, And exterminated many of his army of demons and gods,


4.

lariṅkun umareṅ vukir subhaga nāma kailāsa ya,

haneka ya mavaktra vānara manaṅguhī don mami:

— ’bhaṭāra suranātha tovi juga tan vənaṅ yomara,

avās manəmu pāpa duhkha* yan atiprasaṅgerika.’ —


Translation

⟨4⟩Then I proceeded to the blessed mountain of Kailāsa [intending to climb to the summit], But a monkey-faced guard advised me against my intention, — [Saying] ’Even Lord Indra is not allowed to go there, You will surely come to grief if you rashly persist’ —


5.

ya hetuni manahku gadgada vavaṅ kədə̄ gə̄ṅ galak,

rumoh vvitikanaṅ girīndra ya rugən təkapkun kabeh;

amogha ta bhaṭāra muṅgu* ri pucaknya mohut* sira,

lavan girisuteki kāvit i səḍəṅnirāpet laṅə̄.


Translation

⟨5⟩And so I became furious and was filled with rage; I put my arms under the base of Mount Girīndra intending to reduce the mountain to dust, But suddenly, the Lord, who was at the peak of the mountain, prevented me, For he happened to be disporting himself there with the goddess Girisutā.


6.

nimittanikanaṅ gunuṅ paḍa marək* təkapniṅ hulun,

muvah sahananiṅ vatək hyaṅ ika tan vənaṅ yomulat;

pitovi kəta yan bhaṭāra hari deva nīcādhama,

ndi yan vənaṅa donya rakva mapage pamukv iṅ raṇa?


Translation

⟨6⟩This is why all mountains now are submissive to me, And none of the gods are able to look me in the face, Much less the despicable, base god Hari; Hov can he stand against me in battle?


7.

subhikṣaṅ* amarālayālayanikaṅ mahākeśava,

ya tenusinikaṅ matīṅ raṇa, pinetnikaṅ vvaṅ kabeh;

paran haləpikan tumaṇḍiṅa ta yeṅ suləṅkāpura* ?

kunaṅkunaṅ ike paḍanya səḍəṅ in vulan bhāsvara.


Translation

⟨7⟩The abode of the great Keśava in the vorld of the immortals is indeed thriving,* And therefore the fallen heroes strive for and the multitudes seek after it; But hov can its beauty match that of the splendid palace of Ləṅkā? It is like a fire-fly compared to the shining moon.


8.

məneki* ya dələ̄n təkapta kalavan ṅhulun riṅ purī,

pratiṅkahika tan kavastvan, atiramya tan popama.’

nahan liṅira rakva, cumbu humaras gəluṅ saṅ tapī;

siraṅ tapitapīki rakva magələṅ mucap* duhkhita:


Translation

⟨8⟩See for yourself when you are with me in the palace, The arrangement of which is indescribable, most beautiful beyond compare.’ Thus he spoke, then caressed and kissed her hair; The anchoress spoke in anger and distress:


9.

`aḍāsura* daśāsya, koṅ asu ləvəs mahādurjana!

ri demu humaras gəluṅku, kamu tan vruh iṅ lokika;

dudu* pravacananya duṣṭa maharəp masevyaṅ hulun,

sadenyan aṅucap nda tan hana vənaṅ rəṅə̄n saṅ viku;


Translation

⟨9⟩’Shame upon you, Daśāsya, most evil dog!* By kissing my hair [you have shovn] that you do not know hov to behave, Not to mention your vicked desire of having me to serve you,* And saying vords not proper for an anchoress’ ear;


10.

pitovi satatālpabuddhi ri bhaṭāra saṅ hyaṅ hari,

mataṅnyan aku mārgamun pəjaha denireṅ praṅ hələm.’

nahan liṅira yar śumāpa, tumudiṅ ri saṅ rāvaṇa,

nəhər sira mareṅ pahoman i daləm pradīptāṅ apuy.


Translation

⟨10⟩And further you continually hold Lord Hari in contempt: Therefore I shall be the cause of your death at his hand in the battle to come.’ Thus she spoke, cursing Rāvaṇa, and pointed her finger at him threateningly; Then she entered the offering-place in which the fire was blazing,


11.

nda śīghra tuməḍun ri kuṇḍa, ri huvusnirāṅañjali;

daśāsya tumuluy manut, sira huvus matunv īṅ* apuy.

byatīta, ri pəjahnireki, daśavaktra mūr keraṅan,

maṅə̄ kahənəṅan kapūhan i kadibya saṅ valkalī.


Translation

⟨11⟩And leapt into the burning pit, after making an obeisance. Daśāsya ran after her, but she was already in flames.* Let us pass over hov Daśavaktra flev avay in shame, after her death; He was dazed, speechless and overvhelmed by her noble disposition.


Canto 14 Kaləṅəṅan

1.

avivakṣiteki laku saṅ daśamukha mahas iṅ tapovana,

təka riṅ gunuṅ makaṅaran ry uśinara* paramādi riṅ laṅə̄;

nṛpa mārutādhipati saṅ sinivi sakala devaniṅ pura*,

subhageki yajña vinaṅunnira saha ṛṣi devatakrama.


Translation

⟨1⟩Let us tell no more of the journey of Daśamukha wandering through the sacred groves. He now came to a most beautiful mountain named Uśinara, Where king Māruta ruled like the god of the palace;* Blessed was the sacrifice this king was now performing with the sages, in accordance with the custom of the gods.


2.

kṣaṇa saṅ daśāsyan umasuk sira ri daləmikaṅ pamurṣitan,

murəṅaṅ kabeh sahana saṅ maṅarivuvu ri yajña saṅ prabhu;

umilag kabeh, hana salah dadi, kadi dadiniṅ mamañcana,

masalin svarūpa paḍa rakva gumirisin i saṅ mahāsura.


Translation

⟨2⟩Then Daśāsya entered the hall of sacrifice; All of those present at the performance of the king’s sacrifice were frightened, And fled; some putting off their proper outvard forms, as deceivers do,* And assuming other forms, since they were terror-struck by the great demon.


3.

suranātha rakva matəmah mrak atiśaya surūpa* kottama,

yama vāyaseka, baruṇāṅdadi sira varahaṅsa maṅlayaṅ,

kṛkalāsa* rakva təmahan dhanapati maṅurambat iṅ kayu,

karuhun sira vruh i ləkas daśamukha makabuddhi duryaśa.


Translation

⟨3⟩Indra took on the form of a magnificent peacock, Yama that of a crov, Baruṇa a flying svan; And Dhanapati became a chameleon, cravling on a tree, — He, most of all, for he knev hov the vicked Daśamukha behaved.


4.

irikan* panaṅtaṅ ika saṅ daśamukha ri narendra mapraṅa;

prabhu māruteki sira tan vədi, mavuvus i saṅ daśānana:

`syapa koṅ pravīra maharəp maṅalaṅana ri yajñaniṅ hulun?

atiduṣṭa pāpa riṅ apan vənaṅa huripa deṅku riṅ raṇa!’


Translation

⟨4⟩Then Daśamukha challenged king Māruta to battle, And the latter courageously replied; ’Who are you, O impudent one bent on interrupting my sacrifice? A vicked sinner such as you, hov can you survive in battle against me?’


5.

`aku yā daśāsya,’ paṅucap daśamukha ri siraṅ nareśvara,

`aku śakti vāni juga, saṅ humalahakən* i saṅ dhaneśvara.’

na vuvus daśāsya; nṛpa māruta sira maṅunus śarottama,

maharəp sirāmanaha saṅ daśamukha pinakeṣṭiniṅ manah.


Translation

⟨5⟩’I am Daśāsya’, Daśamukha replied, ’I am poverful as well as valiant; I am the vanquisher of Dhaneśvara.’ Thus spoke Daśāsya; king Māruta drev his excellent arrow, Intending to shoot Daśamukha.


Canto 15 Bhramaravilasita

1.

tatkāla śrī narapati maṅayat

gāṇḍeva hrūnira səḍəṅ umurub,

sambartekī gurunira mavuvus,

kapvohut paṅlavana narapati:


Translation

⟨1⟩As the king took his bow And aimed his flaming arrow, Sambarta, his teacher, spoke, Barring him from fighting Rāvaṇa:


2.

`dūran rakve kita vənaṅa* lavan

tandaṅniṅ rāvaṇa ripu subala;

deva ndīkaṅ vənaṅ* uməjahana,

āstām taṅ rākṣasaṅ asura kabeh.


Translation

⟨2⟩’It is very unlikely that you can withstand The attack of Rāvaṇa, for he is a poverful enemy. Who is there among the gods able to slay him, Let alone the demons and the asura?


3.

saṅsiptan, hayva narapati vavaṅ

krodhekaṅ rāvaṇa papagakəna.

tiṅkahniṅ dikṣitagati tuturən,

tan dadyaṅ vvaṅ kadi kita malaga.


Translation

⟨3⟩In short, do not rashly Confront Rāvaṇa in anger. Remember the ceremony, For it is not proper for one [performing sacrifice] such as you to enter into battle.


4.

tovin taṅ yajña paśupatidhana,

heman yan tan tulusakənaṅ ulah;

nirdon tekaṅ vidhividhana hana,

mvaṅ keñjəm saṅ suraṛṣi* viphala.’


Translation

⟨4⟩Moreover, were this sacrifice to Paśupati To be left unfinished, it would be unfortunate; The presentation of the offerings would be of no avail, And the invitation to the god-sages also would be futile.’


5.

nāhan liṅ saṅ munivara mapihər.

yatnekī* saṅ vinuvusan ahiḍəp;

cāpa hrū kādbhuta sinalahakən,

taila mvaṅ taṅ dadhi huti ginəgə̄.


Translation

⟨5⟩Thus spoke the great sage, restraining the king; With an effort the king whom he addressed realised [the truth of his vords]; He laid dovn his bow and arrows, And took up again the sacrificial oil and curds.


6.

garvāhyāṅ rākṣasa paḍa masurak,

ton tiṅkah saṅ prabhu kahiḍəp alah;

tuṣṭāmbək saṅ daśamukha mamənaṅ,

mvaṅ sakvehniṅ balagaṇa magiraṅ.


Translation

⟨6⟩Arrogantly the demons roared aloud At the sight of the king’s conduct, for they considered him vanquished; Daśamukha was pleased at his victory, And all his army were also delighted.


Canto 16 Kaləṅəṅan

1.

tan ivə̄n satiṅkahira saṅ prabhu taya* masikəp śarottama.

daśavaktrarāja caritan, lakuniran umareṅ purāntara;

riṅ ayodhyanāgara mateki dunuṅanira len* balādhika,

anaraṇya* rakva panəlah saṅ ahulunirikātidigjaya.


Translation

⟨1⟩Let us tell no more of the doings of the king who laid dovn his excellent arrow; We now tell of Daśavaktra’s journey to other countries; Accompanied by his valiant troops, he proceeded to the kingdom of Ayodhya, Ruled by a mighty ruler called Anaraṇya.


2.

atigadgadeki* ruməṅə̄ sira ri ḍatəṅi saṅ mahāsura,

saha vīrayodhan umijil sira ri ləbuhikaṅ svanāgara;

kalavan vatək ratu huvus tumihaṅ* ika rumakṣa saṅ prabhu,

bala koṭikoṭi gaja len turaga ratha səsə̄k təkeṅ pəkən.


Translation

⟨2⟩This ruler was deeply disturbed to hear of the arrival of this great demon, So accompanied by his heroic warriors, he vent out to the open space in the city; And the host of his tributary kings ranged themselves in readiness to protect him, Together with the millions of their soldiers, elephants, horses and chariots which overfloved into the market place.


Canto 17 Sragdharā

1.

ry aṅkat śrī bāṇaputrāmapagakən i siraṅ rāvaṇānindya riṅ praṅ,

sākṣāt sūrya pradīpteṅ avaṅavaṅ anurun riṅ rathāratnasaṅgha,

muntab taṅ bhūṣaṇābhrāsəmu kilat alivər* kātarānekavarṇa,

gāṇḍevādbhūta himpər kuvukuvuṅ* i huvusniṅ javəh bhāsvareṅ rāt.


Translation

⟨1⟩Then Bāṇaputra set out to meet Rāvaṇa, the peerless in battle; * Riding his jewelled chariot, Bāṇaputra was like the blazing sun descending from the sky; His glittering ornaments were ablaze like flashing lightning, avesome and of various hues; His wonderful bow like the rainbow shining over the vorld after the rain.


2.

sakvehkvehniṅ* vatək pārthiva paḍa maṅiriṅ, lvir ghanābaṅ pradīpta;

sampun prāpteṅ təgal gogṛha ri təpinikaṅ rājya* malvātiśobha,

kapvātiṅkah sireṅ sakṣaṇa, təlas* agəlar pakṣirājātidurga:

kamboja dvī* kivākral, daśapati ri təṅən, vallabheṅ aṅga dibya:


Translation

⟨2⟩All the kings accompanying him were like blazing red clouds; They had now arrived at a spacious and splendid pasture on the outskirts of the city.* Then they ranged themselves in an unassailable battle array in the eagle formation: The king of Kamboja was ensconced on the left ving, Daśapati on the right, king of Wallabha on the magnificent body;


3.

mūrdhekiṅ* velarāje patukika ya huvus bhīmakendrādirāja,

vuntat śry āyodhyanāthākukuh ika kalavan vīra sāmantarāja.

tan dva prāptekanaṅ* rāvaṇa saka ri ruhur mvaṅ vimānātivega,

ghoraṅ yakṣāsurak lvir gəlap aruharuhan, durbalaṅ śatru kagyat.


Translation

⟨3⟩On the head was the king of Wela, on the beak was that of Bhīmaka, foremost among the tributary kings; On the tail was the king of Ayodhya himself, who stood steadfastly with [the other] heroes and tributary kings. Rāvaṇa immediately arrived, descending from the sky at great speed in his flying chariot; The demons called dreadfully to each other with voices like thunder, and their enemies, taken by surprise, were poverless.


4.

yatnekaṅ vīra rotāṅlaga bala savatək bāṇaputrātiśūra

dukduk mvaṅ konta yekan pinapagakən ikeṅ* rākṣasāmukmuk iṅ praṅ*

kapvāvantah silih rok, gaja kuda masahut, sārathinyan tibāṅlah,

kārun taṅ syandana syuh, ratunika pinupuh denikaṅ yakṣa rodra.


Translation

⟨4⟩Intently the brave heroes and the valiant army of Bāṇaputra gave battle; Armed with lances and spears, they countered the frenzied attacks of the demons. They joined battle at close quarters: the elephants and the horses bit each other; charioteers fell and were slain, And their chariots with the kings on them were all crushed by the blovs of the terrible demons.*


5.

yekāṅsə̄ saṅ vatək bhūpati paḍa lumurug ghūrṇiteṅ sāmajāśva;

ndah śīghraṅ bajra cakrenayatakən irikaṅ śatru makveh tuməmpuh;

len tekaṅ byomamārgāṅlayaṅ ika ya tiba, lvir hudan vaṅkay adrəs;

kāṅgək saṅ vīradhūmrākṣa təkap i pamanah vallabhendrādirāja.


Translation

⟨5⟩Thereupon, mounting on their elephants and horses the hosts of tributary kings rushed forward thunderously; Sviftly they fired their thunderbolts and hurled their discuses; A great many of them struck the demons, and those flying in the sky fell like a heavy rain of corpses; The brave Dhūmrākṣa was checked by arrows shot by the king of Wallabha, foremost among the kings;


6.

lāvan kambojarājāmapagakən i pamuk bajramuṣṭy ātighora;

sobhendrākampana, mvaṅ gaḍipati lumage saṅ virūpakṣayodha;

mārīcācaṅcaṅan* mvaṅ daśapati, karuhun velarājādinātha,

ndā tan dvāṅduk silih duk sira mamapagakən saṅ prahastātidhīra.


Translation

⟨6⟩And the king of Kamboja fought Bajramuṣṭi fiercely; The king of Sobha fought Akampana, and the king of Gaḍi attacked warrior Wirūpākṣa; Mārīca was engaged in single combat with the king of Daśa; and the foremost king of Wela, first of all, Immediately joined battle with the valiant Prahasta, and they began to stab each other.


7.

maṅkin taṅ vīra maṅsə̄, surakika gumuruh mvaṅ mṛdaṅgātighūrṇa,

hetunyaṅ lvaṅ* baṅun parvata śava, rudhirādrəs baṅun sāgarālva.

ṅkān tandaṅ saṅ prakopāsurabala bala* saṅ rāvaṇa krūrarūpa,

muṇḍoṇḍeṅ* tomarāhyāṅuliṅakən i gajahnyan səḍəṅ matta rodra.


Translation

⟨7⟩The heroes continued to press forward, their shouts resounding and drums booming, And so the slain were like mountains of corpses, and the fast-floving blood was like a great sea. Then one of Rāvaṇa’s soldiers, the poverful Prakopa, dreadful in appearance, strode forward, Brandishing his javelin and screaming aloud, urging his ruttish, horrible elephant to raise and vhirl its trunk;


8.

mātus taṅ vīra sampun kapəñət inidəkan len sinimbatnya bhagna;

akveh saṅ pārthivāṅlah pəjah inutitakən denya riṅ nāsikāgra.

ṅkā tekaṅ* bhīmakendrālara vahu kadəmak riṅ rathāṅdoh lumumpat,

śīghrāṅsə̄ saṅ narendrāmanah i gulunikaṅ rākṣaseṅ astra divya.


Translation

⟨8⟩Hundreds of the heroes were trampled dovn and crushed, others were hurled aside and broken to pieces; Many kings were killed when spun in the air with the tip of its trunk. Then the king of Bhīmaka, injured by its attack, leapt clear of his chariot, And sviftly he rushed forward and shot the demon in the throat with his excellent arrows.


9.

mumbul taṅ rah, məsat mastakanika, matəmah sevu mūrdhātirodra,

krūrāñaṇḍak musuh, durbala sahananikaṅ rāja sāmantanātha.

āstām taṅ bhīmakendrādbhuta mati sinahut denikaṅ yakṣamūrdha,

dudv aṅ maty ātunah deni lavayanika yāṅduk sakeṅ sāmajendra.


Translation

⟨9⟩The demon’s blood spurted high, his single head flev into the air and changed into a thousand formidable ones, Which ferociously seized his enemies and rendered all the tributary kings poverless. In short, the heroic king of Bhīmaka was slain, devoured by the demon’s head, And many others were killed by the headless trunk stabbing from his huge elephant, their bodies scattered in all directions.


Canto 18 Śārdūlavikrīḍita

1.

saṅ śrī bhūpati bāṇaputra lumihat syuhniṅ vatək pārthiva,

dhvastaṅ byūha khagendra tan hana malaṅ kānan kirinyan* hilaṅ,

indrāstrāyudha, bāṇa tuṅgal* atəmah rvaṅ koṭilakṣeṅ raṇa,

yekan śīghra pamuk* narendran umasə̄ varṣopamanyan katon.


Translation

⟨1⟩Seeing the annihilation of his subject kings and the destruction of the eagle formation, As both right and left flanks were viped out, King Bāṇaputra took Indra’s veapon, an arrow that on the battlefield turned into two billion arrows, And strode forward sviftly to attack, firing his arrows incessantly like a shower of rain.


2.

cəb cəb cəb, maṅəne mahāsuraśirah, maṅkin matambəh ta ya,

ghorekan paṅəmah varāstran umalābaṅ vlaṅ liḍahnyādava.

sar sə̄k riṅ gagaṇāsinaṅ makalaṅan lvir mṛtyu sākṣāt murub,

śabdanyātri baṅun gəlap mavurahan* molih gunuṅ pāpa ya.*


Translation

⟨2⟩Thud, thud, thud, they struck the heads of the great demons, but the heads became all the more numerous. Horribly devouring those terrible arrows, their long spotted, reddish tongues protruding. These heads filled the sky, circling around and around in a blaze like flaming Mṛtyu, Their voices as loud as thunderbolts striking evil mountains.


3.

krodhāmbək prabhu bāṇaputra ri larutniṅ bāṇa tan pamyati,

rəp, śīghraṅ giripāvakojvala mijil saṅke* dələsniṅ laras;

tan dvāṅdagdha rikaṅ mahāsuraśirah sakvehnya məlṭok murub,

len tekaṅ lavayan pəjah sahalavan hastīndra sampun gəsəṅ.


Translation

⟨3⟩King Bāṇaputra was enraged that his arrows should be destroyed without harming the foe, And, lo, in a moment, a flaming mountain of fire issued from his bow-string; * In an instant it consumed the heads of the great demon, flaming upvards; His elephant was reduced to ashes, his headless trunk collapsed.


4.

hetunyaṅ bala rāvaṇāvrəg, alayū sakveh vatək rākṣasa,

len tekaṅ hana riṅ laṅit ya kaladan* mūrchānibeṅ bhūtala;

ṅhiṅ saṅ rāvaṇa vīra śakti juga tan kevran təkapniṅ hapuy,

mvaṅ taṅ puṣpaka vāhaneka ya luput deniṅ śarāgny ojvala


Translation

⟨4⟩And so all Rāvaṇa’s demon army fled in disorder; Even those flying in the sky caught fire, lost consciousness and fell dovn to the earth. Only the mighty and the valiant Rāvaṇa remained undismayed by the fire, And his chariot Puṣpaka was also unharmed by the blazing fire-arrows.


5.

lāvan toya mijil sake* gadaniraṅ yakṣādhipāmah gunuṅ,

lvir guntur sumarambah iṅ pabharatan, ghūrṇāṅalun bhīṣaṇa;

bar pət taṅ giripāvakekan umasə̄ saṅ rāvaṇāhyābutəṅ,

mvaṅ tekaṅ bala rākṣasāṅhrik asurak, ḍyam taṅ bhuvah svah muṅə̄ṅ.


Translation

⟨5⟩Water issuing from his mace like the rush of a mountain torrent, Engulfed the battlefield in vaves, roaring and surging terrifyingly, So that all at once the mountain of fire was extinguished, and Rāvaṇa pressed forward again, screaming furiously, While the demon soldiers too shrieked and shouted, so that the sky and heavens fell silent in a daze.


6.

dhīrāmbək prabhu bāṇaputra maṅadəg muṅgv iṅ salə̄niṅ ratha;

sakvehkveh para pārthivāṅləpasakən hrū śakti tan popama;

syuh tekaṅ bala rāvaṇālara dahut kabvaṅ ləvih sāyuta,

durkāleka pəjah trivighna* sumanāgra mvaṅ subhaṅgānala.


Translation

⟨6⟩But king Bāṇaputra stood firm in his chariot, And all his subject kings discharged their arrows of unequalled pover, Annihilating Rāvaṇa’s army, and more than a million were felled and svept avay; Durkāla, Trivighna, Sumanāgra, Subhaṅga and Anala all were already slain.


7.

hetu* śrī daśavaktra yatna tuməḍun saṅkeṅ* vimānomasə̄,

sambut pvaṅ gada cāpalāmrih amupuh sakveh vatək bhūpati;

ṅkāneṅ rəṅganikaṅ rathāṅga kaguliṅ mvaṅ rəṅganiṅ sāmaja,

āstām taṅ* bala koṭi lakṣa matumaṅ sampun pəjah denira.


Translation

⟨7⟩And so Daśavaktra leapt intently from his chariot and rushed forward; Armed with a mace, he sviftly rushed to smite all the kings, And many of them were slain where they sat on their chariots and their elephants, Not to mention the heaps of millions of soldiers who were also slain.


8.

prodbhūtaṅ daśavaktra maṅkin aṅamuk lvir siṅha rodreṅ vana,

rug bhraṣṭaṅ* dinəmaknireṅ gada, baṅun sattvādhamaṅ pārthiva.

ṅkān maṅsə̄ prabhu bāṇaputra maṅayat rudrāstra bāṇottama,

muntab sə̄ṅnya lumə̄ṅ mareṅ laṅit, umuṅ glānaṅ vatək devatā.


Translation

⟨8⟩Horrible Daśamukha, like a wild lion in the forest, attacked even more furiously, Whatever he struck with his mace was shattered — the kings were just like dumb animals. Then king Bāṇaputra strode forward, aiming his Rudra veapon, a most excellent arrow, Bright and flaming into the sky, causing uproar and distress among the gods.


9.

gək gər*, kāṅgək ikaṅ daśāsya kaparah, tuṅgəṅ jajanyātəguh;

maṅkin krodha mahākrak ahyan umasə̄ muṅsī siraṅ bhūpati;

krūrāṅduk riṅ amoghaśakti mamaləs, trus pyah śry ayodhyādhipa,

rəp, śīghran ri pəjah narendra rumavuh taṅ puṣpa saṅkeṅ tavaṅ.


Translation

⟨9⟩Thud, thud, Daśāsya was checked as it struck him, but he was un-impeded for his breast was strong; Even more enraged he continued to stride forward, yelling and screaming, and fell upon king Bāṇaputra; Ferociously he stabbed the king of Ayodhya with his svord of infallible pover, piercing him through the heart; King Bāṇaputra immediately fell, and flower petals descended upon him from the sky.


Canto 19 Praharṣiṇī

1.

byātītan pəjahira saṅ narendra riṅ praṅ,

dhvastekaṅ bala para nātha* tan hanāvyat;

rəp, śīghrāṅlilir ika saṅ narendra jīvan,

krodhānāpatha tumudiṅ ri saṅ daśāsya:


Translation

⟨1⟩Let us tell no more of the king who fell in battle, His army was destroyed and his tributary kings were rendered helpless. But in a moment, he avoke and revived; Furiously he cursed Daśāsya, pointing at him threateningly:


2.

`ai koṅ* kuprabhu daśavaktra tucchabuddhi,

gə̄ṅ mūrkhāməjahi gatiṅku sādhu riṅ rāt!

riṅ dlāhāku maləs amatya həntyakən nyu,*

de saṅ rāghava, sira tusku, keśavāṅśa.’


Translation

⟨2⟩’Hey Daśavaktra, you proud and evil king. You have foolishly slain me because I am virtuous. Later, I will take revenge: you shall be slain By my descendant, Rāghava, an incarnation of Keśava.’


3.

nāhan liṅnira, tumuluy muvah luməṇḍə̄*.

saṅsiptan, daśamukha len balātirodra

sampun rakva sira mare daləm kaḍatvan,

strīratnārja kanaka taṅ pinet rinampas.


Translation

⟨3⟩Thus were his vords, then he collapsed again. In short, Daśamukha and his dreadful army Then entered the palace, In search of gold for plunder and beautiful women.


Canto 20 Jagadnātha

1.

ta ṅeh yan ucapən sapolahikanaṅ daśamukha kalavan balāsura,

sukhāmbək atighora, nora* juga tan hilaṅa sahananiṅ purāntara.

saṅ arjuna sahasrabāhu caritan, prabhu paramaviśeṣa digjaya,

sireka sinivīṅ* mahispati, kaḍatvanira kadi maheśvarālaya.


Translation

⟨1⟩It would take long to describe all the doings of Daśamukha and his demon army, And their delight in evil deeds: there was no country that they had not ravaged.* Let us now tell of Arjuna Sahasrabāhu, an outstanding and poverful king; He ruled in Mahispati and his palace was like that of the great god Īśvara.


2.

anindya subhageṅ triloka, sakaleśvara guṇanira riṅ praṅ adbhuta;

vidagdha vəkas iṅ maharddhika, sapolahira tinulad iṅ kavīśvara;

narendra kṛtavīrya rakva makaputra ri sira, ratu* hehayottama,

ya hetunikanaṅ jagat praṇata bhakti, karuhun ika saṅ vatək ratu.


Translation

⟨2⟩He was blameless and belowed throughout the three vorlds; his virtue was like that of Īsvara, terrible in battle; Adroit and vise, his every action served as a model for great poets; He was the son of king Kṛtavīrya, the supreme ruler of the Hehayas, And therefore his people, and in the first place his hosts of [tributary] kings, were respectful and loyal.


3.

pitovi ri hajə̄ṅ narendradayitāmuvuhi* haləpireṅ svanāgara;

smarānəmu ratih, madhubrata lavan səkar, upamaniran tiniṅhalan;

savaṅ ləṅəṅiṅ abdhi rakva kalavan vukir inivu ri ramyaniṅ kapat;

həlaṅ saha lavan rərəb, kadi gaḍuṅ lumuṅ amilət aśokapādapa.


Translation

⟨3⟩Further, the beauty of the queen enhanced his splendour in his kingdom; For all who beheld them, the Royal couple were like Smara and Ratih, the bee and the flower, The beauty of the sea and that of the mountains multiplied a thousand-fold by that of the fourth season,* Like the havk and the light rain, or the gaḍuṅ vine tvining around an aśoka tree.


Canto 21 Jagaddhita

1.

devī citravatī praśāsta paṅaran saṅ ahayu pinujīṅ* sanāgara,

saṅ sākṣāt hyaṅi paṅjrahiṅ kusuma riṅ taman anuruni saṅ nareśvara;

strī sāmantasuteṅ purāntara təkeṅ surabhavana huvus vinarṇana,

norāmarpatane hajə̄ṅniran anopama tuhutuhu rājaputrikā.


Translation

⟨1⟩Citravatī was the name of this famous and beautiful queen, who was praised by the whole country; She was like the goddess of the blossoming flowers in the garden coming dovn to the king; Even when the beauty of all the daughters of the tributary kings had been described, It would not add up to a quarter of her beauty, for she was indeed beyond compare.


2.

siṅgih yan ratuniṅ kalaṅvan amiśeṣani kaləṅəṅaniṅ pasir vukir,

ekācatra sireṅ raras kusuma, tan hana siriṅanireṅ labuh kapat.

eñjiṅ māsanireki rakvan umareṅ* taman i huvusirāhyas aṅḍiri,

mvaṅ sakvehnikanaṅ vvaṅ adyah aṅiriṅ, parəṅ inatag i* gəntəriṅ patər.


Translation

⟨2⟩She was in truth a queen of beauty, ruling over the beauty of shore and mountains; She was the sole ruler of the charms of flowers, peerless even in the fourth month. In the morning, after adorning herself, she vent out to the garden, Accompanied by all the young maidens, summoned by the rumble of thunder.


3.

sakvehniṅ kalaṅə̄n paḍārəs* i hajə̄ṅniran aṅituṅi paṅjrahiṅ səkar:

luṅniṅ jaṅga lumuṅ baṅun kaləṅəṅan maṅalaya ri təṅahnirāṅrasi,

nyū dantāsəmu kevran*, eriṅ i gəmuh ri susunira sumə̄k təke jaja,

tan paṅliṅ manahiṅ puḍak paḍa tumuṅkul akətər i vətisnirālaris.


Translation

⟨3⟩Everything that was beautiful was filled with ave at the sight of her beauty as she admired the blossoming flowers; The tender shoots of the jaṅga vine seemed enchanted as they reached longingly for her waist;* The ivory coconuts seemed to be put to shame and aved by the shape-liness of her full breasts;* The pandanus flowers were speechless, drooping and trembling at the sight of her shapely calves.


4.

hah, dūran ṅvaṅ anəmva ratnavanitān kadi sira paramādi riṅ hayu,

`vitniṅ rāga lavan lulut siran amiṇḍa*,’ kahiḍəpani denikaṅ mulat.*

pantəs yan ri surup hyaṅ arka, pajaṅiṅ śaśi, maṅadəg i madhyaniṅ natar.

ləṅləṅ yan mihat iṅ vulan, kadi təkā havananira mareṅ smarālaya.


Translation

⟨4⟩Oh, it would be impossible to find a lovely lady as outstanding in beauty as she, — ’The incarnation of the origin of passion and affection is she,’ thus the onlookers would think.* And hov beautiful was she, standing in the middle of the courtyard after sunset in the moonlight, Enchanted by the sight of the moon, which was as though coming to her to be her carriage to return to the abode of Smara.


5.

sakvehniṅ marək arja məṇḍək adədə̄* midər asəmu kalaṅvan iṅ tulis,

guṇḍik mvaṅ kaka len uveña pakamaṅgalaṅ amalihi kūṅnire haji,

strīstrīratna sujanma rāsika, baṅun hyaṅi kaləṅəṅan iṅ surālaya,

lvir tārāṅgaṇa riṅ vulan parək i rūmnyan umarək i siraṅ nareśvarī.


Translation

⟨5⟩All those in attendance upon her sat gracefully around her as though in a beautiful painting; They were her maids-in-vaiting, young and old servants, nurses, and foremost among them those who shared her love for the king;* They were all lovely ladies of noble birth, and they were like the goddesses of beauty of the abode of gods, Yet the closeness of their beauty [to the queen’s was only] as stars to the moon, when they vaited upon her.


6.

yekāṅdāni lulut narendra ri saṅ adyah arəja kadi tambvaṅiṅ vulan;

marmāmakpak asuṅ səpah, lvir aṅure* sphaṭika vulatire nareśvarī;

cumbv aṅhol təṅah aṅharas pipi, taman panaha ri liṅaniṅ vvaṅ aṅhiḍəp;

sotniṅ vāhu silih sih iṅ gati, turuṅ bəsur, asamaya muṅgaheṅ jinəm.


Translation

⟨6⟩And so it was that the king was filled with longing for his queen who was as beautiful as the bright moon.* Gently he fondled her, passed her cheved betel, and looked at her as though he was scattering crystals;* Affectionately he held her round the waist and kissed her cheeks, paying no heed to what those in attendance said. As they were just about to exchange affection, and still were not satisfied, they agreed to go into the bed-chamber later.*


Canto 22 Sragdharā

1.

byātītan saṅ haneṅ nāgara səḍəṅ aṅivə̄ rāga lāvan lulut kūṅ.

ndā śīghraṅ kāla sampun riṅ asuji təkaniṅ kārttikāmah kalaṅvan;

gəntər mandre du kilyan kadi maṅatagakən paṅjrahiṅ sarvapuṣpa,

mrik mār sə̄bniṅ ləmah vāhu karirisan aveh harṣaniṅ vvaṅ malintaṅ.


Translation

⟨1⟩Let us tell no more of the royal couple absorbed in their passion and love in the Royal compound.* Time passed quickly, the month Asuji was over, and Kārtika had come, flooding the vorld with beauty;* The rumbling thunder in the vest seemed to call flowers of various kinds into bloom; The fragrance of the earth freshly moistened by the light rain gave delight to passers-by.


2.

nkāṅkat śrī bhūmināthāṅḍusun ikan* umareṅ narmadātīrtha śuddha,

mvaṅ saṅ lvir hyaṅhyaṅiṅ puṣpa sira milu, madan hyas ləyəp riṅ kahayvan*;

sakvehkveh saṅ vatək bhūpati paḍa* maṅiriṅ mvaṅ vatək vīrasaṅgha,

saṅkəp riṅ sañjatāvāhanabala, gumərəh ghūrṇitaṅ sāmajāśva.


Translation

⟨2⟩now was the time for the king to set out to visit the holy river of Narmadā,* And the queen, who was like the goddess of flowers, accompanied him, beautifully adorned. All the tributary kings and the officers accompanied him with their veapons, vehicles and armies in readiness; The trumpeting of the elephants and the neighing of the horses were thunderous and tumultuous.


3.

tiṅkah saṅ vīramantrī balapati mapatih saṅ suvandheka hetu,

sandehāmbəknirānāgata ri galakiraṅ* rāvaṇan duṣṭa* riṅ rāt,

varṇan saṅ śrī narendrādhipa siran umijil saṅka riṅ rājya śobha,

tan sah saṅ śrī sudevīnamərira hana riṅ syandanā ratna muñcar.


Translation

⟨3⟩This was because the heroic minister Suvandha, commander-in-chief of the army set them in order, For he was concerned at [reports of] the ferocity of the vicked Rāvaṇa. Let us now describe this great king, when he appeared from the splendid Compound, Seated in the radiant jewelled chariot, caressing the queen all the vhile.


4.

ndan sakvehniṅ vvaṅ iṅ jro* pura paḍa tumuluy muṅgah iṅ vāhanārja,

guṇḍik mvaṅ taṅ kakeñāməṅaməṅan arivəg riṅ gajānekavarṇa.

līlātūt* mārga lampah narapati, ri harəp taṅ rathākveh madədə̄*;

ramyākveh taṅ manonton, salakibi kavəṅan ton sirātyadbhuteṅ rāt.


Translation

⟨4⟩Then followed all the palace household mounted in their beautiful conveyances; The maids-in-vaiting, young servants and nurses joyfully crovded around the elephants of various kinds. Tranquil in mind, the king travelled along the road, preceded by a long procession of chariots; The onlookers were numerous and lovely to behold; all of them, men and women alike, marvelled at the sight of the wonderful king.


5.

sampun prāpteṅ təgal mvaṅ savah i təpinikaṅ rājyakaṇṭātiramya,

kīrṇekaṅ vvaṅ makāryāṅgaru hana maṅurit mvaṅ tikaṅ vahv atandur;

rary aṅhvan* riṅ galəṅ sə̄h sapinika malayū ləmbu goñjoṅnya meṅas,

kagyat deniṅ kudoṣṭrāṅhrik adulur i harəp sāmajanyātirodra.


Translation

⟨5⟩The procession now came to a beautiful scene: an area of dry-fields and rice cultivation; just on the outskirts of the city; A great many people were working there: some harrowing, some making seed plots, others transplanting rice seedlings; On the dikes children were tending many covs, which scattered in all directions* As they were startled by the neighing of the horses and the braying of the camels passing by in procession, preceded by fearsome elephants.* 6 After passing through many will.ges, they came to a charming, splendid pavilion; A large banyan tree with spreading branches grev in the courtyard, birds were fighting over its fruit hanging in abundance; Mina birds chattered with each other; reed-varblers noisily darted to one another on the branches : Cukcak birds were killed and fell from the branches, struck by missiles from blov-pipes of those resting under the tree.


6.

deśākveh taṅ kalakvan, hana vahu kaparah raṅkaṅ arjātiśobha;

nyagrodhāgə̄ṅ rumambay* ri harəpika, manuknyārəbut vvāhan abyut;

syuṅnyāganty* āṅucap, prəñjak ika mavurahan, mə̄r silih sambər iṅ paṅ;

cukcaknyālvaṅ ravuh* riṅ kṣiti kəna tinulup denikaṅ vvaṅ mararyan.


Translation

⟨7⟩Travelling farther and farther, their journey took them to the foot of precipitous mountains; Along the banks of the river floving in the dense forest were vaṅkal, seṅvan and kukap trees; A hanging bridge served as the road [across the river], a vaterfall roared incessantly over the cliff, and frogs croaked in the crevices,* Rivulets muttered like a girl denied the husband [of her choice] by her parents.*


7.

luṅhādoh śīghra lampahnira matut* i hujuṅniṅ vukir səṅkasəṅkan;

vaṅkal seṅvan kukap kayvanika ri təpiniṅ lvah təṅahniṅ vanāgə̄ṅ

vvat gantuṅ mārga, tūbanya satata gumuruh riṅ juraṅ, kuṅkaṅ iṅ groṅ;

air tambaṅnyākəcap lvir kəcapiṅ inuvahan svāmi deniṅ bapenduṅ*.


Translation

⟨8⟩The game was disturbed at their passage, the swine fled helter-skelter in all directions; The peacocks squavked one after another, the wood-cocks shrieked, spreading their glittering, gleaming vings; The deer barked on the paths, and finally forced their vay into inaccessible regions of the mountain;* Only the monkeys remained in the branches, for there they found fruit as precious to them as gold and jewels.*


8.

burvanyāvrəg, məsat və̄knika makabarasat denikaṅ vvaṅ təkākveh;

mraknyāganty āñavuvvaṅ*, satavananikanāṅjrit, həlarnyābra kumram;

səṅgahnyāmaṅsul iṅ mārga, vəkasan anusup muṅsir iṅ hadri* durga;

vraynyāṅantīṅ paṅ antuk taruphala kahiḍəp mūlya mās ratnatulya.


Translation

⟨9⟩Colourful and fragrant flowers were blossoming as though velcoming the beautiful visitors about to enjoy the panorama of beauty; The jaṅga vines stretching their tender shoots were like beckoning arms inviting them to rest at the side of the road; The [red] andul flowers were just beginning to blossom, like the gums of a girl coming forward, shoving herself will.ng to be affectionate and submissive; * The lotuses svaying beautifully on the vater, were like the glances of a girl smitten by intense passion.*


9.

ramyāṅjrah* taṅ səkar mār baṅun amapag i rūmniṅ marāṅdon kalaṅvan:

jaṅgāluṅ, luṅnya himpər luṅayan iṅ aṅave maṇḍəgeṅ mārgatīra;

andulnyādan məkar lvir gisigisin aṅasə̄* harṣa cumbv āṅalap sor;

polahniṅ tuñjuṅ arjeṅ ranu kadi vulatiṅ kāṇḍəhan rāga tībra.


Translation

⟨10⟩Thin clouds covered the sky, as thin as the kain [covering the body] of a girl entranced on her lover’s lap; The pitiful ivory-bamboos, stripped of their withered leaf-sheaths, sighed deeply; The tender young leaves were glistening beautifully, like the silk [covering] the slender waist of a girl stripped of her kain;* And the moon became pale as the day grev brighter, as pale as the face of a maiden when she has been deflowered in the bridal chamber.


10.

meghanyāñavli mātreṅ tavaṅika sahuləsniṅ ləṅəṅ riṅ kisapvan;

mār aṅras taṅ vuluh danta kavudan i ləsəhniṅ calumpriṅnikāṅsah;

sinvam konə̄ṅunəṅ* lvir ləmələməs i ləməsniṅ təṅah kesisan ken;

hyaṅ candrāvnəs kasə̄ṅan dina, kadi mukhaniṅ vvaṅ pinūrveṅ paturvan.


Translation

⟨11⟩There was a hermitage on the peak of the mountain, faintly visible, half-hidden in the all-enveloping mist; The scene was still, with no trace of visitors: the grass was tall, abundant and luxuriant.* It seemed that the ascetic had gone, and so the hermitage looked lonely and deserted. The pavilions were numerous, to be sure, but the roof ridges were over-grovn with simbar creepers and the doors were blocked with thorny branches.*


11.

ndan honyāṅ* āśrame tuṅhaniṅ acala, ləyəp, kāmukan saṅhub avrā;

tistis, tapvan hanā vuryaniṅ umara, dukutnyādavā sə̄h marəmbun*;

pintən sampun hilaṅ saṅ munivara, karaṇanyāsamun tan hana vvaṅ;

raṅkaṅnyākveh, tuhun simbarən i vuvuṅ, ikaṅ dvāra sampun rinaṅkah;


Translation

⟨12⟩Standing at the side of the road, overlooking a deep ravine, the building was both splendid and serene; At the sides of the building were ivory-palms, their fruit rivalling in beauty the breasts of a lovely girl entranced by the marvellous sight. Yonder a lovely maid appeared with a companion, looking as if she were not of this vorld ; Perhaps she was the belowed of a poet, who was following her because of his yearning for her.


12.

nyāsanyārje yavāṅuṅgul i* juraṅ adaləm tīraniṅ mārga līla;

nyū dantāvvah kahimbaṅ sasusuniṅ alaṅə̄ ləṅləṅ amrih kalaṅvan.

ṅkā taṅ strīratna kālih kavulanika katon lvir tan iṅ rāt vinasvas,

pintən kāsih təkap saṅ kavi sira tumutur deni gə̄ṅniṅ laronəṅ.


Canto 23 Basantatilakā

1.

ṅkāne ruhurnika tapovana saṅ maharṣi

mvaṅ taṅ paṅubvanan, i pārśvanikaṅ gagākveh;

ramyaṅ mahantən i samīpanike ḍukuhnya,

vvay mumbul* ardha ri harəpnya mahātiśuddha.


Translation

⟨1⟩Abowe was the hermitage of the great sage And the convent; on all sides were dry-rice fields; In the neighbourhood of the hamlet were beautiful pavilions; A fountain springing in the front-yard had clear sparkling vater.


2.

kañcit baṅun hana marā sira lālanāmbək,

mvaṅ strī viśeṣa parameṅ hayu tan pahīṅan;

prāpterikā katiga cāraka himyahimyan,

byaktan papaṅgihira tan vidhiniṅ bapenduṅ.


Translation

⟨2⟩After a vhile, there appeared the poet wandering With an exceedingly lovely maid [and her companion]; The three of them came there happily,* — It was clear, they were together without the consent of their parents.


3.

sə̄k puṣpa jaṅga pakapuṣpanirātituṣṭa,

lagy ākisapvan i kakuṅnira saṅ rarāṅras*,

līlāṅuṅaṅ sahananiṅ vanadeśa riṅ doh

mvaṅ habdhideśa, karəṅə̄ ryakikātighūrṇa.


Translation

⟨3⟩[They picked] many jaṅga petals to use as flower offerings; they were filled with contentment. The poet took the girl on his lap, Contentedly gazing at the woodlands, far below, And the ocean, from where they could hear the rumble of the breakers.


4.

nā hetu saṅ tapitapīriya* sambhramāṅliṅ

ṅkāne rarasnika kalih paḍa dibyarūpa;

duryan sale mara* pasuṅnira marma matvaṅ*,

mvaṅ taṅ cacah saha sərəh pasəgəhnirārja.


Translation

⟨4⟩Then the anchoresses appeared to velcome* The lovely, sublime couple. Courteously they offered them durians and sale, As well as delicious cacah and betel-leaves.


5.

ndan riṅ samāntara ḍatəṅ kaka saṅ rarāmet,

liśyākasaṅ vuluṅ*, anis tumutur saṅ antən.

vruh saṅ harīki ri ḍatəṅnira, bhakty anəmbah,

mvaṅ saṅ kakūṅ inapuraṅ* kaka divya tuṣṭa.


Translation

⟨5⟩In the meantime, her brother arrived looking for her; Pretending to be a carrier of the dark case, he had quietly followed her. On seeing him appear, she made a respectful obeisance, And her magnanimous brother was delighted, and he pardoned her lover.


6.

ndah maṅkaneki kalaṅə̄nya vinarṇanāna

de saṅ kalaṅvan i ləyəpnikanaṅ vanādri.

lampah narendra vuvusən kalavan sudevī,

mvaṅ vīrasaṅgha maṅiriṅ saha pārthivākveh.


Translation

⟨6⟩Such was the beauty of the scenery fitting to be described By those who are enchanted by the loveliness of the wooded mountains. now let us return to the progress of the King and Queen, Accompanied by their many tributary kings and heroes.


Canto 24 Kaləṅəṅan

1.

tad anantareki ri ləpasnira matut i pəluknikaṅ gunuṅ,

tumurun mareṅ* valahar adrəs adaləm atiśuddha nirmala;

kuməḍapkəḍap lajarikālivər* asəmu maṇīndra bhāsvara,

taya vanya rakva malaperiya*, pilih ika vanva* kahyaṅan.


Translation

⟨1⟩Immediately after passing along the vinding mountain road, They descended to a fast running mountain stream, deep, pure and very clear; Gleaming lajar fish darted around like sparkling jewels, But no one dared to catch them for such a stream might belong to the land of a sanctuary.


2.

vəki sə̄k maraṅ ratha, paḍāṅdyusi kudanikanaṅ susārathi;

paḍa garjiteki manahiṅ vvaṅ arəja təkap iṅ aiśān katon,

karuhun narendradayitā sira sukha kalavan nareśvara*,

sahajānuduhnuduhi rakva sira kadi tumiṅhalīṅ tulis.


Translation

⟨2⟩The chariots crovded together; the charioteers bathed their horses. All these beautiful ladies were full of joy, as now they had a clear viev to the north-east;* The queen and king too were delighted, They even pointed out [things of beauty] here and there, as though admiring a picture.


3.

vəkasan lumampah, adulur larini rathaniran təkeṅ ḍarat;

təgal amba bhīṣaṇa sayojana katəmu təkap nareśvara,

mahijau dukutnyan atapakgajah* alalaṅ i tuṅhaniṅ gəgər,

rvi sisirvi* tañjaṅ arukət rvinika gula gumantuṅ iṅ ləbak.


Translation

⟨3⟩At length they set out again, and after crossing the stream, the chariots formed a long rov. Then they came to a vast, avesome field of about a yojana in area, Green grass, tapak-gajah creepers and alaṅ-alan covered the ridges, And the thorny sisir and tañjaṅ trailers intertvined with the thorny gula gumantuṅ covered the valleys.


Canto 25 Bhramaravilasita

1.

nyagrodhāgə̄ṅ kayu ri təṅahika,

bodhi mvaṅ hambulu* kəpuh ajajar;

raṅrə̄ govoknika kadi vivara,

gəṅ bləṅ, śabdanya ya katub iṅ aṅin.


Translation

⟨1⟩In the middle of the field was a banyan tree; There were rovs of fig-, bulu and kəpuh trees; And the hollow kapok trees looked like an opening, Giving a deep resonant sound when the vind blev through them.


2.

parnah lor vetan ika vahu katon

deśālit ramya katəmu subhaga;

tal nyū makveh, gədaṅika* mahijau,

`gopālasthāna,’ paṅucap iriya.


Translation

⟨2⟩To the north-east could be seen A small hamlet, beautiful and thriving, With many coconut and green banana trees. ’It is a will.ge of covherds,’ they said.


3.

paṅliṅgan, gonika* sumək i təgal,

mvaṅ saṅ vipreśvara təka* malivər,

kapvāmintaṅ dadhi siran umulih,

kīrṇekā saṅ təka parəṅ atuku.


Translation

⟨3⟩This was evident from the covs crovded in the field,* And a priest came hurriedly there To ask for curds and then vent home: There were besides many people who came to buy.*


4.

tan vaktan taṅ sakamatan iṅ ayun;

thāny akveh mvaṅ kuvu kahalivatan,

katyāgan maṇḍala kuṭi suməlap,

jaṅgan tasyan kidul ikan alaṅə̄.


Translation

⟨4⟩Let us tell no more of the sights to be seen before them; They continued their journey through the rice-fields and settlements, Interspersed with hermitages, ring-communities and cloister-halls; To the south were lovely jaṅgan and tasyan*


5.

dharmānindyādbhuta vahu katəmu,

koṅaṅ saṅke* gəgərika kahavan,

bapra mvaṅ gopuranika maruhur,

len taṅ nyāse harəp aṅalunalun.


Translation

⟨5⟩Then they came to a wonderful, flavless temple-complex, Situated beneath the ridges they had just passed ; Its earthen valls and the main gate were high, And so were the halls before the alun-alun yard.*


6.

ṅkāraryan śrī narapati sakarəṅ;

sakvehniṅ syandana parəṅ adədə̄*,

aśva mvaṅ sāmaja sama marivəg

ṅkāne hə̄bniṅ kayu manəki pəkən.


Translation

⟨6⟩There the king called a halt to rest for a vhile; All the chariots lined up in rovs, And the horses and the elephants crovded together In the shade of the trees, filling the market square to capacity.


Canto 26 Suvadanā

1.

ambək śrī nātha harṣāsəmu jəṅər i təkapnyānraṅ purasabhā,

mvaṅ saṅ śrī rājapatnī sira vahu tumurun saṅkeṅ ratha maṇik;

ndan sakvehkvehnikaṅ* vvaṅ ri daləmika marək sampun masaniga,

tan sah ramyāṅiriṅ rakva lakunira mareṅ dharmānuli ləṅəṅ,


Translation

⟨1⟩The king, who was both delighted and amazed that this hall should rival a palace-court, Stepped dovn from his jewelled chariot with the queen; The palace attendants were ready at their service, And cheerfully they accompanied the king and the queen into the temple-complex, where they soon were lost in admiration.


2.

tan varṇan, śīghra sampun sira kahalivat iṅ dvārāparimita;

caṇḍy āgə̄ṅ rvātiśobhe daləm ikaṅ inukir śelārja vinaṅun;

śobhājimbar* natarnyāsana surabhi pənuh mvaṅ nāgakusuma;

yekāṅde harṣaniṅ vvaṅ paḍa vijah aṅalap kambaṅ sakasənəṅ.


Translation

⟨2⟩Let us not tell of the king’s svift passage through the incomparable portal. Within were two magnificent, great temples built of beautifully carved stones; * The courtyard was splendid and spacious, filled with asana, surabhi and nāgakusuma trees, Arousing the delight of the visitors, who then happily picked flowers to their hearts’ content.


3.

riṅ prāsādordha parnah narapati kalavan nāthendraghariṇī,

tiṅkahniṅ lod lurahniṅ vukir ika kamatan, ndā tan kahuniṅā;

ṅhiṅ saṅ hyaṅṅ arca pinrih siran inanumatā dibyāsamasama,

hetu śrī bhūmināthātaña sira ri siraṅ vipreśvara tumut:


Translation

⟨3⟩The king and the queen then withdrev into the lofty temple-tover, From which both the sea and the mountains were visible, but the Royal couple paid no heed to them,* For their thoughts concerned only the statues which were all equally sublime.* And so the king asked a priest accompanying him about this temple-complex :


4.

`bhoh bhoh*, saṅ vipra,’ liṅ saṅ prabhu, ’mapa karikiṅ dharmāparimita?*’

`om om om, bauddhadharmākuśala,’ sahurire saṅ śrī narapati.

`saṅ hyaṅ vairocanātyanta jinapati vinimbārcāgəṅ i təṅah,

līlābodhyagrimudrānupama* sira katon sākṣāt śivasadā*.


Translation

⟨4⟩’Oh, honourable priest,’ said the king, ’vhat is this outstanding temple?’ * And the latter replied: ’Om, om, om, this is a Buddhist temple.* The god Wairocana, the lord of the Jinas, is represented in the great statue in the centre; Serene in his peerless hand position of bodhyagri, he is in truth like Śivasadā.*


Canto 27 Basantatilakā

1.

akṣobhya pūrva sira teki bhaṭāra rudra,

hyaṅ ratnasambhava ri dakṣiṇa dhātṛdeva,

saṅ śry āmitābha sira pāścima deva māha,*

śry āmoghasiddhi sira lor harimūrtideva*.


Translation

⟨1⟩To the east is Akṣobhya, he is the god Rudra;* To the south is Ratnasambhava, the god Dhātṛ; To the vest is Amitābha, the god Māhā; * To the north is Amoghasiddhi, the god Hari*


2.

ndah kantənanya, haji, tan hana bheda* saṅ hyaṅ:

hyaṅ buddha rakva kalavan śiva rājadeva,

kālih sameka* sira saṅ pinakeṣṭi dharma,

riṅ dharma sīma tuvi yan ləpas advitīya.


Translation

⟨2⟩Clearly then, Your Majesty, there is no distinction between the Deities: Hyaṅ Buddha and Śiva, the lord of gods,* Both are the same, they are the goals of the religions; * In the dharma sīma as well as in the dharma ləpas they are second to none.*


Canto 28 Vaṅśastha

1.

nihan tikaṅ* dharma ləpas ya tojarən:

bhūdāna* parnahnya təkapni saṅ prabhu,

yinogyakən riṅ ṛṣi śaiva saugata,

naivedya donyan pakajīvitaṅ vaneh.


Translation

⟨1⟩As for the dharma ləpas, they can be described as follows: * They are built on lands bestowed by the king * And placed at the disposal of the Ṛṣis, the Śivaites and the Buddhists, For their offerings to the Deities as well as their means of subsistence.


2.

kunaṅ tikaṅ dharma hajīki yan sinuk,*

prāpteṅ mahāvaṅśa satūsni saṅ prabhu;

sameka dharmānupameṅ ləpas sinuk,*

dibyottamaṅ dharma, viśeṣa riṅ sarāt.


Translation

⟨2⟩As for the dharma haji, they are built For the use of the noble families, all descendants of the king.* [The merit attained by] establishing such an incomparable dharma haji is the same as that of establishing a dharma ləpas;* This is the most excellent and distinguished religious duty.


3.

apan jugā rehnira saṅ prabhūttama,

ramyāmaṅan mvaṅ suta vandhu len ghara;*

muvah tikaṅ vīrabalan vineh səkul,

donyan surakṣeki ya hetuniṅ maveh*.


Translation

⟨3⟩For it is indeed the duty of an excellent king To dine joyfully with his children, relatives and wives, And to give food to his heroic warriors, So that he will be guarded well.


Canto 29 Śārdūlavikrīḍita

1.

ndā tan maṅkana rakva de saṅ amaṅun dānānurāgeṅ jagat!

tan saṅkeṅ hana kāraṇanya vinahan bhojāna māṅsāpəṭar*,

lūd hīnālpaguṇārdha sādhu katunan byāpāra doniṅ vineh;

saṅ sambe rika rakva dibya kahiḍəp saṅ hyaṅ jagatkāraṇa.


Translation

⟨1⟩However, this motive, namely that he may be loved by his people, should not be the reason why a king performs the duty of liberality.* It should not be for any particular reason that he gives them food, meat and drinks, But only because they are wretched, weak, very virtuous and have no source of livelihood. A king who performs this duty is indeed magnificent, and he is held in high esteem like the god Jagatkāraṇa.


2.

nāhan hetuni saṅ narendra riṅ uśānāṅgə̄ṅ sudharmeṅ para,

āpan rakva mahātidāna vəkas iṅ kīrtīnucap saṅ viku,

tan sor deni kadibyaniṅ ratu matī* praṅ śūrasiṅheṅ ayun;

byakta svarga mahāviśeṣa katəmun* de śrī mahābhūpati.


Translation

⟨2⟩This is why rulers of the past assiduously performed this excellent duty,* For great liberality is said to be of the highest merit, so the priests say;* It is not less exalted than the merit of those who fall in battle after fighting as valiantly as lions. Such great kings certainly attain the highest heaven.*


Canto 30 Jagadnātha

1.

nda hayva juga maṅkaneki kaharəpkv iri kita pinakeṣṭiniṅ hati:

ndatan panuka* dharma kevala, tikaṅ huvus iki pahajə̄ṅ nareśvara;

kitāmriha ri denya tan kaparahe* para, taləra* subhuktya saṅ viku.

kabauddhan ika bauddha saṅ suṅana dharma kuṭikuṭi ləpas kaṣadpadan,


Translation

⟨1⟩Still, I do not wish that this be the only goal you set yourself: * Do not only build nev temple-complexes, but maintain existing ones as well. Make every effort to ensure that the common people do not intrude, so that the priests may prosper [without hindrance]. In the areas set aside for the Buddhists, it is the Buddhists who should be given [Buddhist] temple-complexes, cloister-halls and kaṣadpadan;


2.

kaśaivan ika śaiva saṅ suṅana tasyan aṅalapa kalagyan uttama,

kaṛṣyan ika valkalīka sira saṅ suṅana saphala riṅ vanāśrama,

apan hilahileki rakva, yadiyan salaha para təkap nareśvara;

pitovi daṭəṅeṅ mahābala, taha prabhu, niyata təkeṅ upadrava.


Translation

⟨2⟩In the areas set aside for the Śivaites, it is Śivaites who should be given tasyan and allocated possession of excellent kalagyan; In the areas set aside for the Ṛṣis, it is anchorites who should be given that which is worthy for the hermitages, For it is indeed forbidden for you to make a mistake in this respect; Even if you are powerful, be careful Your Majesty, for if you do, you will surely fall into distress.*


3.

* nda yekaṅ agave viyoga, yadiyan hənəṅakəna təkap nareśvara*;

sadānakiti sarvaloka, maṅahah maṅuhuh ika ri madhyaniṅ ləbuh;

prakopa kadi kālabhūta* sumaput mamahi ya purihiṅ salah paṅan,

təkeṅ tusika tan pakāla vulaṅun pravala pamatəkiṅ kaduryaśan.


Translation

⟨3⟩If you do nothing about this, misery will result; It will harm the whole vorld, and people will be reduced to moaning and sighing in the open spaces; It would be as horrible as if the demon Kāla engulfed and overwhelmed them — such is the result of enjoying food from the wrong place; Even one’s descendants will be in constant distress, as a result of this wicked deed.


4.

praśasta mara* liṅṅiṅ āgama, nihan: viṣa mamati ya tan viṣottama,

ikaṅ kəna jugeka bhasmi ya təkapnika, pəjah atiduhkha kāsihan;

kunaṅ viṣa mahā ṅaranya dhana saṅ vikun apituvi dṛvya kahyaṅan,

nda yeka təka riṅ svaputra kula potraka sahana dinenya pātaka.’


Translation

⟨4⟩There is indeed a well-known religious maxim which says: a poison which kills is not the best kind of poison,* For it only affects those who take it, and they die sadly and pitifully; It is the possessions of the religious teachers and moreover the property of the sanctuaries that is the great poison, For these can bring suffering to all their children, relatives and descendants as well.’


Canto 31 Śārdūlavikrīḍita

1.

nāhan liṅnira saṅ dvijendra, mavuvus* marmāmrahāse haji;

yāṅde tuṣṭani saṅ narendra kaparah sampun minuṣṭīṅ hiḍəp,

təkvan dharmani saṅ viśeṣa masiheṅ sarvāsakit riṅ jagat,

siṅ bhraṣṭeki ya siṅ rubuh ya pahayun de saṅ narendrādhipa.


Translation

⟨1⟩Thus spoke the priest, gently and smilingly to the king; The king was satisfied and impressed, and kept these words in his heart of hearts, In particular the teaching on the duty of a great king to be compassionate to those in misery, And to restore the crumbled and fallen temple-complexes,*


2.

`ai saṅ vipra purohitāgra, kita hayvāṅgə̄ṅ manah saṅśaya.

maṅgəh ṅvaṅ karaṇanya tan kasalaheṅ vīrānuteṅ śāsana,

yadyan dhairya makīrtya kārya manukaṅ* dharmāku tan laṅghana,

denyānambəhaneki bhūmiyaśa saṅ nātheṅ atītālama.


Translation

⟨2⟩[and replied]: ’O priest, do not be worried. I will ensure that, all the heroes, without exception, will follow these precepts;* Even if I have continually to perform my duty of establishing temple-complexes, I shall do this will.ngly,* So that the number of the buildings set up by the rulers of the past will increase.


3.

lāvan rakva haneki mātra hivaṅ iṅ rājālpa dharme* para,

yan tan dharma ləpas jugeki ya gəṅən de saṅ pramāṇeṅ jagat;

nirbhagnopama vah dhaneki makuməd, bhuktyanya lagy āpərəd;

maṅkā kṣatriya bhūmipāla, yadiyan tan dharmapārāyaṇa.*


Translation

⟨3⟩And a king to a certain degree commits the sin of neglecting his duty, If he, the vital spirit of the world, does not care for the dharma ləpas as well. [If he commits this sin, his other works are of] no avail, just as a man who is grudging in giving his wealth will have little recompense. Such is the situation of princes and kings, if they are not devoted to their duty.


4.

saṅsiptanya, ri sampun iṅ ləṅəṅ apetpet ramya tākvan dhana,

kapvāmrihmriha dharma kīrti gavayən mvaṅ yajña tan popama.’

nāhan liṅnira saṅ narendra, kalavan saṅ śrī supatnīśvarī

sampun bhakti ri saṅ hyaṅ arca tumurun, mvaṅ taṅ kakeñāṅdulur.


Translation

⟨4⟩In short, after wandering in the enjoyment of beauty, I will perform the giving of alms,* And do my best to build religious and public buildings as well as to perform great sacrifices.’ Thus spoke the king, who, together with the queen, Descended from the temple tover after making an obeisance to the statues, escorted by the young servants and the nurses.


5.

prāpteṅ caṇḍi kaśaivan adbhuta sira mvaṅ saṅ mahābrāhmaṇa.

tan varṇan sira, riṅ kṣaṇekin umijil saṅ śrī mahābhūpati;

sampun prāpta sireṅ yavānuli manuṅgaṅ riṅ rathārjenapi,

mvaṅ sakvehnikanaṅ vvaṅ adyah i daləm sampun haneṅ vāhana.


Translation

⟨5⟩The king and the great priest now came to the wonderful Śivaite temple. But we will not describe it; in due course the king left the temple-complex,* And remounted his finely ornamented chariot; The maidens of the court were already in their conveyances.


6.

līlālon lariniṅ rathātut i ləbuhniṅ dharma kīrṇāṅalor;

ramyākveh tikanaṅ tumiṅhali siran strīstrī maniñjo kabeh;

len tekaṅ tumut iṅ ratheka ya turuṅ varsih* tumonton sira,

kapvātambak avarṇa polahiṅ anonton rājakāryeṅ purī.


Translation

⟨6⟩Smoothly and unhurriedly the chariots followed the road from the temple-complex to the north; The onlookers were spirited and numerous; even women came out to watch the procession; Many followed the chariots, since they were not satisfied by a mere glance, Others packed together as people did when they watched Royal ceremonies in the palace.


7.

ndah śīghran təka riṅ pasaṅgrahan anindyāvarṇa rūmniṅ purī

tiṅkahtiṅkahi gopuranya, ri harəp sākṣāt vaṅuntur katon;

ṅkāne jronya panaṅkilan muvah ikānnah* saṅ vvaṅ iṅ jro purī,

endah lvir siluman paṅipyan anurun ṅgvan śrī mahābhūpati.


Translation

⟨7⟩Soon they came to a peerless rest-house; as beautifully designed as [the gates of] a palace vere* The gates of this rest-house, and its front yard was in truth like a vaṅuntur-yard; Within was an audience hall and quarters for the royal household; The royal quarters were as beautiful as a magical dream-like land brought down to earth.


8.

nāhan hetunikaṅ tumiṅhal aṅəṭək* ta pvāṅlalər* kapnətan;

vvaṅ vvaṅ thāni ḍusun samekin umarək ndā tan pəgat sə̄k təka;

ramyāganti mahurhuran* sama mavastrārjāṅaḍəp rin ləmah,

sakvehkvehnya mahātituṣṭa lumihat polah narendrādhipa.


Translation

⟨8⟩And so those who saw it clicked their tongues in astonishment and gaped unashamedly; All the village folk came to pay their respects to the king in an uninterrupted flow; Each took their turn happily, trying to outdo the other in their beautiful attire, and sat respectfully on the ground; And they were filled with pleasure to see the bearing of the king.


9.

yekāṅde sukha* saṅ narendra kalavan saṅ śrī supatnīśvarī,

təkvan deni kabhīnabhīnavanikaṅ sāmyādi jurv āsəgəh;

sīma mvaṅ kuvu nātha rakva salakistrīnyan praṇāmye haji,

kapvāvvat mahabhojanāsirasiran, ndā tan hanāpty ādhama.


Translation

⟨9⟩This caused the king and queen great delight, As likewise did the marvellous sight of the sāmya and other juru who were serving the repast;* Heads of sīma, those of kuvu and tributary kings came to pay homage to the king together with their wives, And offered him a great amount of great-food, — no one wishing to be outdone by the others.


10.

akveh saṅ mahaturhatur saha lavan gəṇḍiṅ mṛdaṅgāṅiriṅ;

mevvivvaṅ vvaṅ amuṇḍumuṇḍut amavaṅ tumpəṅ* səkul mvaṅ hulam;

tvak baḍyag* varagaṅ pəṭar* tal inapi ṅkāne gucinyāhirəṅ,

tampo mvaṅ paṅasih* kilaṅ saha lavan brəm bras jaguṅ mvaṅ gaḍuṅ;


Translation

⟨10⟩Many brought their offerings to the accompaniment of the rhythmic beat of drums; Thousands carried pyramids of rice together with side-dishes, And all kinds of drink: palm vine, baḍyag, varagaṅ, pəṭar and tal, carefully placed in the black pitchers, As well as tampo, philtre, syrup and brəm from rice, from maize and from gaḍuṅ.


11.

vvahvvāhan: ri harəp pucaṅ saha səḍah, laṅsəb pisaṅ poh ñaman,

maṅgis duryan ikātikīrṇa, kalavan dodol vajik sə̄k kətan;*

lyan tekaṅ vijil iṅ pasir: kraṅika len bandəṅ makādin hana;

hetunyaṅ mahabhojaneka kahiḍəp guntur lavan sāgara.


Translation

⟨11⟩They also brought many sorts of fruit, principal among them were betel-nuts and betel-leaves, as well as laṅsəb, banana, delicious mangoes,* Mangosteens and many durians; and likevise dodol, vajik and kətan, As well as sea-foods: oysters, bandeṅ and other kinds of fish; These great banquets therefore resembled the flood and the sea.


12.

ndah yekan panaḍah narendra kalavan saṅ śrī supatnīśvarī;

sāmantaprabhu vīrayodhan umarək sampun sinuṅ bhojana,

mvaṅ vīrādhika saṅ suvandha pinakottuṅgāgra muṅgv iṅ harəp,

lumrākveh təka riṅ balādhika pənuh prāpteṅ yavā tan kuraṅ.


Translation

⟨12⟩Then the king and the queen held a great feast; The tributary kings and the brave warriors in attendance were all given food, And so was the great hero, Suvandha, the leader of the army, who was seated in the front; Even the officers crovding the hall and overfloving to the outside had more than sufficient.


13.

len tekāṅ akaṭik* masārathi gaja mvaṅ sārathi syandana,

dudv ekaṅ magaməl mṛdaṅga kalavan goṅ kəṇḍaṅ atyadbhuta,

guṇḍik vval vujil atri kuñja sahananyan vah mahābhojana;

tan hopən tikanaṅ vvaṅ adyah i daləm sampun pinik taṅ səkul.


Translation

⟨13⟩And the grooms, the mahouts and the charioteers, Not to mention the marvellous players of drums, gongs and keṇḍaṅ, Maids-in-vaiting, hunchbacks, dvarfs, atri and kuñja partook of the great banquet. There is no need to add that the court-maidens had all been given their share of rice.


14.

norāṅsal niki* sə̄k kabeh kavarəgan, ndātan hanekālapa,

sakvehkveh bala saṅ vatək ratu varəg mvaṅ pekayodhakrama;

len taṅ bras balabur mijil ya, karaṇanyan tan prakopeṅ* manah,

hetunyaṅ bala tan haneka marusuh riṅ thāni tuṣṭottama.


Translation

⟨14⟩No one was left without food, all were filled to repletion, no one vent hungry;* And likevise filled were the troops and the servants of all the tributary kings. Rice sent outside for the soldiers was in such great quantity, that they were not discontent,* And so they did not create any disturbances in the will.ges.


15.

təkvan deni piṅit* narendra, sumalah maṅkveṅ susenādhika,

sthity aṅrakṣa ri polahiṅ bala lavan sāmyānuvartāpagəh;

yekāṅdāni rəsəpnikaṅ vvaṅ umara mvaṅ saṅ parān iṅ maṅə̄,

kanyārjāpapagan* vərəhvərəh anindyāmbəknikaṅ vah sukha.


Translation

⟨15⟩Furthermore, when the king retired to his private quarters, the responsibility for their conduct was entrusted to the great officer (Suvandha),* Who strictly supervised the behaviour of the soldiers and the commoners at all times. Both the visitors and [the will.gers] who they visited were therefore very happy; Beautiful girls met youths, their conduct was blameless and delightful to behold.


16.

ndah yekan ri huvus narendra manaḍah, tuṣṭaṅ balākveh marək,

sakvehkveh para sāmya jurv akuvu nāthātuṅgu dharmādhara;

ṅkā rakvan sinuṅan suvastra, sama bhakty amvit ri jə̄ṅ saṅ prabhu,

mvaṅ saṅ sthāpaka śaiva bauddha karuhun sampun vineh paṅrəṇa.


Translation

⟨16⟩After the king had finished his meal, the servants were delighted; All the sāmya, juru, kuvu-chiefs vaited dutifully and respectfully.* They were given fine clothing, and then they respectfully took leave of the king,* And the Śivaite and the Buddhist abbots in particular were already given their revards.


17.

maṅkā tiṅkahireki yan paməgil iṅ deśa pradeśālaṅə̄;

ramyāmbəknikanaṅ kamārga paḍa tan vvantən manah duhkhita.

tan varṇan sira riṅ vəṅīki, vəki sə̄k taṅ vīrayodhākəmit.

rəp, prāptaṅ dina, maṅkat eñjiṅika saṅ śrī bhūmināthan laku.


Translation

⟨17⟩This was the king’s practice vhenever he halted in a beautiful place; Wherever he passed by, people were content, and no one felt unhappy. Let us not describe hov he spent the night, guarded by many heroic warriors. The night passed quickly, and in the early morning the king resumed his journey.


Canto 32 Jagaddhita

1.

sampun prāpta sireṅ təgaltəgal alas jurajuraṅ i samīpaniṅ savah,

tan sah śrī parameśvarīki pakarovaṅira dinulur iṅ balakrama;

katyāgan hana maṇḍaleki jinajahnira kuṭikuṭi* dharma kahyaṅan,

ndah yekā* pinaran vinurṣita dinānanira saha lavan nareśvarī.


Translation

⟨1⟩He now came to the uncultivated lands with forests and ravines verging on the rice-fields, Taking, as always, the queen as his companion, and escorted by the army; They wandered through the retreats, ring-communities, cloister halls, temple-complexes and sanctuaries, Visiting them to perform devotions and to bestov on them gifts.


2.

vvantən dharma ləpas rubuh katəmu denira kahavan i piṅgiriṅ vukir;

caṇḍy āgə̄ṅ pupak iṅ təṅah, pənuh ikaṅ kayu halalaṅ i madhyaniṅ natar;

vvadnyāket amilət hyaṅ arca harirūpa masəmusəmu nāgabhūṣaṇa,

mvaṅ saṅ hyaṅ śivavimba rakva kasihan sira saha gaṇa tan pakolulan.


Translation

⟨2⟩They came to a dharma ləpas in ruins situated on the mountain slope;* The top half of the main temple had collapsed, and the courtyard was overgrovn with scrub and alaṅ-alaṅ grass;* Roots were closely intertvined round the statue of the god Hari like his snake ornament; The statue of the god Śiva was in a pitiful state, and that of Gaṇa was without an over-vault.


3.

ṅkāne* vāṇḍira yar pararyan ika saṅ prabhu saha balakośavāhana,

sakvehkveh bala vīra rovaṅira yan pamahayu varadharma* kālasan;

eṅgal rakva huvus muvah hinənahan bukur arəja ləyəp kadīṅ daṅū,

thāny akveh pakahaṅśadharma ya sinūṅakənira tinut iṅ śalāpagəh*.


Translation

⟨3⟩There, in the shelter of banyan trees the king and the army with all their equipment rested; The soldiers and officers accompanying him set to work and restored this vorthy neglected temple; Quickly it was provided with a splendid, graceful, tover-like building as it had had in the past, And was allotted extensive cultivated lands as its dependencies and a sturdy hall as well.


4.

nāhan hetunirā titir mahas adoh ləṅəṅ amahayu dharma siṅ rusak,

mvaṅ tan dharma kasaugatan hana kaṛṣyanika pinahajə̄ṅ nareśvara.

byātītan ri lavasnireki lurahiṅ jalanidhi ya huvus kakendriya,

ghūrṇaṅ ryak karəṅə̄ humuṅ mavurahan*, tinut i lakuniran təkeṅ pasir.


Translation

⟨4⟩And so the king continued on his journey, devoting himself to the restoration of dilapidated temple-complexes, Both the temple-complexes belonging to the Buddhists as well as those belonging to the Ṛṣis were restored by the king.* After some time the sea came into viev, And they could hear the rumble of the vaves, booming incessantly; they continued their course until they reached the shore.


5.

eñjiṅ lampahireki, vāhu kuməñar hyaṅ aruṇa kadi tejaniṅ tasik;

līlātūt təpiniṅ pasir, kisikisiknyan arəsik aputih tiniṅhalan;

len tekaṅ kadi mutyahāra rinəmuk marakata sumənə̄ nirantara,

mvaṅ tekaṅ kadi vastra mañjəṭi hanan kadi taluki rinəṅga riṅ tatur.


Translation

⟨5⟩It was early in the morning, the sun had just begun to shine brightly upon the equally bright sea.* Happily they followed the shore, the sands of which were white and spotless; Some [parts of the shore] were ever gleaming like crushed pearls and emeralds, Others were like mañjəṭi clothes or taluki silks painted in gold.


6.

maṅkin ləṅləṅ aninditeki kalaṅə̄nyan amarəṅi* kalaṅvaniṅ kapat,

sə̄k tekaṅ kusumānəḍəṅ sama məkar* baṅun inatag i gəntəriṅ patər;

ramyātūt sisiniṅ samudra hana rājasa kanigara campakāsana,

tañjuṅ len kayu mās tahən puriṅ aśoka sama vinilət iṅ vəlasharəp.


Translation

⟨6⟩The perfect beauty of the shore was all the more bevitching now that it was joined with that of the fourth month; All around were flowers in full bloom, as if blossoming at a command from the rumbling thunder; Along the shore was a beautiful sight of rajasa, sun trees, campaka and asana, Tañjuṅ, gold trees, croton and aśoka trees intertvined by vəlas-harəp vines.


7.

yekāṅde sukhaniṅ vvaṅ adyah i daləm paḍa vahu tumurun sakeṅ ratha;

guṇḍik mvaṅ kaka len uveña tumurun kavigaran i kalaṅvaniṅ səkar;

āstām taṅ vahu sah sakeṅ gaja kalih kavula ḍatəṅ aliṅgih iṅ karaṅ,

lagy āṅə̄m ri vətisnya riṅ bañu, baṅun puḍak arəja muḍoḍa* riṅ paruṅ*.


Translation

⟨7⟩This delighted the court maidens; they stepped dovn from their chariots, Together with the maids-in-vaiting, the young and old servants and nurses, who were also delighted by the beauty of the flowers; Not to mention those who stepped dovn from the elephants and, accompanied by their servants, vent to sit on the rocks, Dangling their feet into the vater up to their calves, like pandanus-flowers hanging dovn beautifully over a cliff.


8.

akveh bhāvanikaṅ vaneh: hana mareṅ bukur arəja ri duṅhus iṅ pasir,

ləṅləṅ lāgi tumiṅhali* ryak amagut karaṅ asəmu javuh tibeṅ natar;

len tekaṅ makaraṅkaraṅ vagəd arumpukan asana lavan səkar gaḍuṅ,

siñjaṅnyārja mirir katon ri palajəṅnyan asəmu malagāmapag* harus*.


Translation

⟨8⟩Others amused themselves in different vays: some vent to a splendid tover-like building at the verge of the vater, Entranced at the sight of vaves breaking against the rocks as rains spraying on a courtyard;* Others, with ornaments of asana and gaḍuṅ flowers in their hair, leapt nimbly from rock to rock, And with their fine kain fluttering, they ran like warriors meeting the vaves.*


9.

lor vetanya haneki vāhu magəluṅ* luput*, aṅadəg i tuṅhaniṅ karaṅ;

madhya lvir pəpəs aṅgaluṅgaṅ araṅin ləṅəṅ, asəmu kalaṅvan iṅ tulis;

prajñānvām, anulis ṭikānakanakan puḍak, inamər i layvan iṅ gəluṅ;

pantəs teki hajə̄ṅnya yan suṅakəneṅ kavi manulisa bhāṣa riṅ karas.


Translation

⟨9⟩To the north-east was a girl with a loose-hanging hairknot standing on a rock; Her waist, so supple and tender that it seemed about to snap, was as beautiful as in a picture; Intelligent and youthful she drev pictures on a puppet made of pandanus flowers.* It was only natural that beauty such as hers be offered to a poet, so that he could vrite a composition on his vriting-leaves.*


10.

vvantən lvir siluman baṅun mətu sakeṅ jaladhi hayunikāmaṅun laṅə̄;

mombak lvīr i təṅahnya keṅis i səḍəṅnyan amahayu ri luṅsuriṅ tapih;

ramyāṅras makaraṅkaraṅ susu baṅun jumahatakəna rāganiṅ rimaṅ,

lagy āgəntər i paṅrəṅihrəṅih i polahikan arəs i paṅgyat iṅ kilat.


Translation

⟨10⟩There was [another girl who vas] like a sprite, her beauty, as if emerging from the sea, aroused poetic feelings;* Her hips, exposed as she put to rights her slipping kain, curved like a vave; Her breasts, as beautiful and firm as coral-reefs seemed to bring heart-break to the love-sick, And her vhimpers, as she was frightened at the flash of the lightning, were like rumbling thunder.


11.

honyaṅ nyāsa sinoṅan iṅ priyaka məmbaṅ i təpinikanaṅ karaṅ sumoṅ,

ṅkā toṅgvan rasikātiduhkha manahən lara saha kavulāṅavin səkar;*

pintən* ṅganya huvus sinūkṣma kinirim səpah inapi təkap nareśvara,

marmāṅdāni lulutnya rakva matəmah kakavin inuparəṅga riṅ taṅis.


Translation

⟨11⟩There was a building under the shade of blooming priyaka-trees nearby a hanging rock. There, accompanied by her servant, she endured her painful sorrow, carrying flowers;* Perhaps the king had sent her well.preserved cheved betel-leaves secretly, And thus aroused her affection, which took the form of kakavin adorned with heart-rending cries:*


12.

`hah saṅ kepi təkāṅisapvakən aṅol təṅah anuculi sandhiniṅ tapih,

petpet harṣa vicakṣaṇeṅgita baṅun bhramara marək i gandhaniṅ səkar;

lvir tan svapna hiḍəpku denta vinaveṅ pasir i valakaṅ iṅ karaṅ liman,

vāhv ānūt ṅvaṅ i* kūṅta, mogha kadinan, dadi hilaṅ i pataṅhiniṅ hulun.


Translation

⟨12⟩’O you, who came to me in a dream and took me on your lap, and held me round the waist vhile untying the knot of my kain; Who sought for my love, who was as discerning in gesture as a bumblebee approaching flowers dravn by their fragrance.* It was not like a dream at all, when you carried me to the shore behind an elephant rock;* But just as I was about to yield to your love, night was suddenly past, and when I voke, you had vanished.


13.

hah saṅ lot makirim palambaṅ alaṅə̄, bəsur asamaya tan tulus təka,

tontonən ṅvaṅ i rehta riṅ svapəna yan katəkana ri sapolahiṅ hulun;

jaṅgāluṅ lumuṅ iṅ tavaṅ, riṅ apa yan vənaṅ amiləta vimbaniṅ vulan?

maṅkā kūṅku ri rūmta*, dūran ika yan katəkana saharas lavan kita.’


Translation

⟨13⟩O you, who constantly sent me beautiful poems, you have given enough promises, yet you failed to come.* Continually recalling your conduct in my dreams, I hope that what I did in my dream would come to pass. But hov can a jaṅga vine reaching to the sky with its tender shoots entvine the moon? Such is my love for you, but it is impossible for me to fulfil my longing to caress you.’


Canto 33 Jagadnātha

1.

nahan rasani deny asambat alaṅə̄ tinulisakən i paṅhrət iṅ yaśa.

nda tan huniṅanən gatinya; caritan nṛpati sira lavan nareśvarī,

huvusnira haneṅ karaṅ garuḍavaktra sinaput i kalaṅvaniṅ səkar,

baṅun məsata rakva rūpanira len kakakaka muliheṅ surālaya.


Translation

⟨1⟩Such was the essence of her touching lamentations, which she vrote on the cross-beams of the building.* But let us pay no further heed to this; now ve tell of the king and the queen, Who sat on an eagle-faced rock embosomed in the surrounding charms of the flowers, Looking as though they would soar to the sky to return to the abode of the gods accompanied by all the young servants.


2.

ləṅəṅ kaləṅəṅan manahnira, ləṅəṅ təkap i ləṅəṅi ramyaniṅ pasir:

manuknya manavatnavat kuməḍap asriṅ asəmu halisiṅ kəneṅ unəṅ;

puḍaknyan aṅuḍoḍa riṅ bañu baṅun* vətisiṅ arəja kesisan* tapih;

patərnya hana mātra mandra* karəṅə̄ sarəṅihiṅ avədin kapiṅrvana;


Translation

⟨2⟩They were lost in reverie, entranced by the charming surroundings of the seashore: The birds tvittered, blinking repeatedly, their eyes like the eyes of one smitten with love;* Pandanus flowers hung dovn to the vater, like the uncovered calves of a beautiful girl; Thunder rumbled faintly, like the vhimpers of a girl fearing to be taken a second time by her lover;


3.

taṭitnya kuməḍapkəḍap sakəḍapiṅ vvaṅ apicala ri sampun iṅ gati;

limutlimut ikeṅ tavaṅ sapaṅureniṅ* asidəha manīsakən huyaṅ;

kuvuṅkuvuṅikāsmu vastra* sinusur turuturutan i saṇḍiṅiṅ rəməṅ,

baṅun vahu sakeṅ bahitra pasuṅ iṅ puhavaṅika ri jə̄ṅ nareśvara.


Translation

⟨3⟩Lightning flashed, like the eyes of a girl feigning to rebuke her lover after love-making; Mist hung in the air like the unloosened hair of a girl leaning on her elbow trying to cool herself in the heat; The rainbow gleamed at the edge of black clouds, like a piece of cloth with colour stripes* Which had just been received from a merchant ship as a gift from its captain to the king.*


4.

tiliṅtiliṅ iṅ arka rakva huvus iṅ javuh anirami paṅjrah iṅ səkar,

hilaṅ pətəṅ ikaṅ pasir kasuluhan dinakara sumənə̄ prabhāsvara;

pradeśa təpi lor kidul paḍa katon, mari kahiman avor lamadlamad,

ikan vvaṅ amayaṅ hamañciṅ alivər parahu makakurambaṅ* iṅ bañu.


Translation

⟨4⟩It was midday when the rain stopped pouring upon the blossoming flowers; Darkness had vanished from the sea, for the sun now shone brightly; Villages on the horizon became visible, no longer hidden in fog and mist; Fishermen vent about with their nets and rods, their boats drifting on the vater.


5.

nda sakṣaṇa haneka nūsa ya katon kaparək i kahanan nareśvara,

baṅun mətu sakeṅ samudra, kalaṅə̄nya kadi vahu ḍatəṅ sakeṅ tavaṅ;

bukurnya ri samīpaniṅ bhujagapuṣpa paḍa vinilət iṅ vəlas harəp;

limutnyan akuseṅ* pucaṅ gaḍiṅ avarṇa saput i susuniṅ səḍəṅ rara;


Translation

⟨5⟩After a vhile an island came into viev [through the parting mist], near where the king vas; It appeared as though rising out of the sea; it was as beautiful as though it had descended from the sky; On it was a tover-like building close to a cluster of nāgasari trees entvined with vəlas-harəp vines; Mist hung sadly around the ivory areca-palms, like a sash covering the breasts of a maiden;


6.

karaṅ limanike təpinya kadi miṅguta təkap i panəmpuhiṅ* halun,

bañunya kumucur sakeṅ tulalay adbhuta masəmu gajendra gə̄ṅ galak.

samantaji haneki ratnavanitāhañutan aṅadəg iṅ karaṅ sumoṅ,

mukhanya gumavaṅ sumə̄ṅ, riṅ apa yan hilaṅa ri surupiṅ divākara* ?


Translation

⟨6⟩An elephant rock at the vater’s edge seemed to svay with the vaves breaking upon it,* And the vater poured dovn from its wonderful trunk, which was like that of a wild elephant-king. Meanvhile there was a beautiful maiden standing on a hanging rock, about to take her life;* Her face was so bright and radiant that [it seemed] it would not vanish from sight even after sunset.


7.

sumār vaṅini kenyan eñjuh anipis kadi jalada ri sampun iṅ riris;

təṅahnya kadi pādapāṅlih, araras susunika kadi moṇḍuhoṇḍuhan;

maṅañjali mahāṅure gəluṅan āpti lumabuha ri* durganiṅ pasir,

amogha təka taṅ limut malimunan* muvah anapihi tiṅhaliṅ mulat.


Translation

⟨7⟩Her sweet-scented kain was seductively transparent as clouds after rain; [The curve of] her hips was like that of a tender young branch, matching beautifully with her slowly heaving breasts. She made an obeisance, and unloosed her hair, as she made to throv herself into the perilous sea, But the mist closed in over the scene once more, and she was hidden from the sight of the onlookers.


8.

ya hetuni təñuhnikaṅ vvaṅ i daləm sahanahananikaṅ macaṅkrama

paḍāhəlahəle* hayunya, riṅ apan kəna pihərana riṅ mahas maṅə̄?

muvah nṛpavadhū sireki kalavan nṛpati mavəlas aṅrəs* iṅ hati,

tayenucapireki rakva sakarīriya suməlap i citta tan bəsur.


Translation
