⟨4⟩The fearsome Praghaṣa was slain by the wonderful Sūryaketu; Mārīca was stabbed to death with a plough by the king of Kaliṅga,* And Suptaghna, Matta and Anala were slain by the king of Siṅhala. And so the demon soldiers fled in terror to seek refuge with Rāvaṇa.


5.

tan varṇan ri gatinya teki; caritan sakveh vatək hehaya,

ṅkāraryan sira ri vvitiṅ* taru latā ramyātituṣṭaṅ manah;

bheda mvaṅ bala rākṣasosah* aṅəsah deniṅ musuh śaktimān,

— gandharvādhipa devaśakti kahiḍəp sor iṅ mahākādbhuta.


Translation

⟨5⟩Let us tell no more of this; all the Hehayas were now Resting in good spirits under the trees entvined by vines.* The demons, on the other hand, were moaning and complaining, because their opponents were mighty, And surpassed even the mighty king of the celestial musicians and deities in their marvellous pover.


6.

yekā hetuni saṅ daśāsya lumurug prāpteṅ təgal papraṅan,

mvaṅ sakveh balavīraśeṣa maṅiriṅ, kapvāṅrəgəp sañjata;

rakryan saṅ mapatih prahasta ri harəp muṅgv iṅ gajānindita;

ndā* yekan pinapag riṅ astra pinanah de saṅ vatək hehaya.


Translation

⟨6⟩And so Daśāsya set out to the battlefield, Accompanied by the rest of the soldiers and the officers bearing their arms; The first minister Prahasta, mounted on his flavless elephant, led the army, And soon they encountered a shower of arrows from the Hehayas.


7.

prodbhūtaṅ bala rākṣasākrak umasə̄ sākṣāt gəlap rvaṅyuta,

kapvāṅduk mamukul* sakeṅ avaṅavaṅ, dhvas taṅ mahākṣatriya;

saṅ sodhālara, śaiśukāgra kadəmak, rəmpak rathanyan rihək,

de rakryan mapatih prahasta maṅidək krūrānujah riṅ liman;


Translation

⟨7⟩Pressing onvard, the demons yelled as horribly as the sound of two million thunderbolts; They stabbed at and struck at the Hehayas from the sky, and many great warriors were slain; Sodha was in agony, Śaiśuka was attacked and his chariot was smashed As Prahasta’s elephant trampled on it ferociously.


8.

mātus taṅ kapəñət, vaneh tinulalay, glānaṅ vatək hehaya,

akveh bhūpati māti vīra ya dinuk de saṅ sumantry āsura.

tandaṅ saṅ prabhu viśvabajra mamupuh təṇḍas prahasteṅ* liman,

pakṣāmiṅrvana, saṅ daśāsya mamanah, syuh taṅ gadā bhīṣaṇa.


Translation

⟨8⟩Hundreds of the Hehayas were trampled underfoot or crushed to death in its trunk, And numerous kings fell valiantly, stabbed by the demon first minister. And so Wiśvabajra strode forward and struck Prahasta on his head as he was mounting his elephant, But as the king made to strike him again, Daśāsya fired his arrows, and cut Wiśvabajra’s terrible mace to pieces.


9.

sondur saṅ prabhu, saṅ prahasta kapəṅəl, ramyaṅ praṅ atyadbhuta*.

ṅhiṅ saṅ rāvaṇa vīra rodra hinirup* de saṅ vatək pārthiva;

krūrākāra haneṅ rathāṅga maṅagəm konta pradīptojvala,

morṇānūpura* bhūṣaṇābhran umurub sākṣāt gunuṅ pāvaka;


Translation

⟨9⟩After the king retreated, Prahasta was wounded, and the battle raged fiercely. Only the valiant, formidable Rāvaṇa now remained, hemmed in by the hosts of the Hehaya kings; Avesome in appearance he was mounted on his chariot, holding a gleaming, flaming spear; Attired in radiant head-dress, anklets and ornaments, he was ablaze like a mountain of fire;*


10.

līlā tan hana rəsnireka rinəbut de saṅ vatək hehaya.

sāmantaprabhu vīrayodhan umasə̄ muṅgv iṅ gaja mvaṅ ratha;

sə̄k tekaṅ mamanah, manūla, maṅarug riṅ bajra cakrāyudha,

ndātan pamyati riṅ daśāsya, kavaluy sakvehnikaṅ sañjata.


Translation

⟨10⟩He remained calm and fearless as all the Hehayas attacked him. The tributary kings and the heroic warriors of the Hehayas mounted their elephants and chariots and pressed onvard; They assailed him with their arrows, darts, thunderbolts and discuses, Yet he remained unscathed, for all these veapons were of no avail [against him].


11.

nāgendrādbhuta pakṣirāja luməpas mvaṅ taṅ śarāgny ojvala,

len tekaṅ kadi sāgarāṅavaṅavaṅ mvaṅ bāyubajrāṅasut;

lvir guntur maṅalih parəṅ* sahananiṅ sarvāstra tejomaya,

brahmāstrā divabāṇa bāṇa, karuhun taṅ rudrabāṇottama.


Translation

⟨11⟩They discharged their snake-, eagle-, and blazing fire-arrows, And those resembling flying seas and raging thunderstorms. These gleaming veapons were like floving streams of lava, Foremost among them were the divine arrows of Brahma and the excellent arrows of Rudra.


12.

gək ghor, ghūrṇita bhasmibhūta tumame sthūlāṅga saṅ rāvaṇa,

sumyuk lvir javəhiṅ* kasapta* tumibeṅ vuṅkal, vināśaṅ śara;

rəmpak syandana saṅ daśāsya pinanah de sūryaketuprabhu,

mvaṅ tekaṅ turagāṅrəpālara, tinūt saṅ rāvaṇāhyāḍarat*.


Translation

⟨12⟩With fearful din all these veapons struck Rāvaṇa’s body, but all broke to pieces; Gushing like rain of the seventh month falling on flint, all the arrows were destroyed.* However, Daśāsya’s chariot fell to pieces struck by Sūryaketu’s arrows, And his horses fell prone in agony; and Rāvaṇa, yelling, leapt dovn from his broken chariot.


13.

ndā tan dvan pamupuh* vatək ratu, hilaṅ sakveh vatək hehaya,

lvaṅnyātumpuk, aneka rāja marəmuk* mvaṅ pekayodhan pəjah.

yatna śrī nṛpa viśvabajra mamanah riṅ pañcaśūlādbhuta,

syuh tekaṅ gada, saṅ daśāsya maṅamuk, mavrəg vatək pārthiva.


Translation

⟨13⟩Then he quickly struck at all the kings, and many of the Hehayas were exterminated; The dead piled up, numerous kings were shattered, and foot-soldiers were killed. Ever on the alert, Wiśvabajra fired his wonderful five-point dart, And cut Daśāsya’s mace to pieces, but Daśāsya kept on attacking, so that the hosts of kings broke into confusion.


Canto 52 Śikhariṇī

1.

ya hetu śry āvaṅgādhipa sira lavan māgadhapati,

muvah saṅ sodhāmrih riṅ iṣu paramānindya luməpas;

nda tan kevran saṅ rāvaṇa manikəp aṅlvāṅi mamapas,

sudhīrāmrəp, tan jrih rinəbut, amupuh sarvaniśita.


Translation

⟨1⟩And so the kings of Avaṅga, of Māgadha And prince Sodha dispatched their flavless arrows with all their might, But Rāvaṇa was still not prevented from seizing, killing and shattering [the Hehayas]; He boldly struck them with his bare hands, for he was not afraid of being overvhelmed, and he destroyed all their veapons.


2.

prayatnāmbək śry āvantipura masikəp tomara murub,

vavaṅ duk pyah saṅ rāvaṇa, kasidəkuṅ tuṅgəṅ atəguh;

kaliṅgāṅlud mvaṅ siṅhala sira muvah dhīra mamupuh,

kasambut kānan keri kalihika de saṅ daśamukha.


Translation

⟨2⟩Ever on the alert, the king of Avanti armed himself with a flaming spear And sviftly stabbed Rāvaṇa in the stomach; Rāvaṇa fell to his knees, but was unscathed for he was invulnerable. The kings of Kaliṅga and of Siṅhala then attacked him incessantly, and they fearlessly struck at him, But Daśamukha seized them both, one in each hand.


3.

nda śīghrāṅsə̄ śrī māgadhapati lavan sodha mamanah,

śry avaṅga mvaṅ sakveh para ratu mamuk dhīra matuluṅ;

ndatan saṅkan saṅ rāvaṇa matakutā yan ginurumuṅ,

umaṅguh dhīrāṅdhik cuməkəl i* gulu śrī narapati.


Translation

⟨3⟩The king of Māgadha together with Sodha sviftly rushed forward firing their arrows As did the king of Avaṅga and all the other tributary kings, attacking fearlessly to give them help. But Rāvaṇa was not in the least afraid at being outnumbered; Firm, dauntless and defiant he seized the kings [of Kaliṅga and of Siṅhala] by their throats.


4.

tikəl taṅ daṇḍa syuh kapəlaṅ i pupū* saṅ daśamukha,

sudhīrāmrəp saṅ rvālara tinəkuk iṅ bhūmi dinəkuṅ;

gupe pūh cūrṇāṅ aṅga, rudhira mijil saṅka riṅ iruṅ,

satākuyv aṅlih rakva samanira, dūran pamənaṅa.


Translation

⟨4⟩Their clubs shattered as they crashed against his thighs; Yet undaunted, the two kings continued to strike at him, but they were painfully forced backvards and pressed hard to the ground. They were exhausted and at their vits’ end; their bones broke and blood gushed from their noses; Like weak, exhausted cocks, it was impossible for them to win victory.


5.

samaṅkojar saṅ rāvaṇa guragaḍa lvir gəlap ahə̄m:

`nda paṅlampū koṅ alpaguṇa, mamapag vūkku riṅ ayun,

arah, sambat tekiṅ gumavay i tuvuhmv iṅ janapada!

aḍā, lvāmbəkmu, ndin luputamu təkapkv iṅ pabharatan?’


Translation

⟨5⟩Thereupon Rāvaṇa spoke with a voice as loud as a clap of thunder: ’Hey you exceedingly vorthless kings, who dare to meet me in battle!* Come on, call upon your parents who brought you into this mortal vorld. Shame upon you, but I beg your pardon, for hov can you survive this battle against me?’


6.

nahan liṅ saṅ yakṣādhipa, maṅadu minde narapati,

rəmuk syūh bəntar karva śirahira, rahnyotək uməsat;

vimūrchālək saṅ siṅhala pəjah i jə̄ṅ saṅ daśamukha,

kaliṅgekī sampun dinukakənireṅ arjunabala.


Translation

⟨6⟩Thus spoke the demon king, then he struck the kings’ heads one against the other,* And both were shattered, their blood and brains scattered in all directions. They were stunned and lost consciousness; the king of Siṅhala died at Rāvaṇa’s feet, And the king of Kaliṅga’s body was hurled into Arjuna’s army.


7.

nda yekālahniṅ hehayabala, larut kabvaṅ atakut*,

vinuk pinrih; len māgadhapati murud mvaṅ para ratu,

umuṅsī priṅgāhritniṅ acala guhā groṅ* juraṅ arəs,

vaneh prāptoṅgvan saṅ ṛṣi, tinutikā deniṅ asura.


Translation

⟨7⟩And so the Hehayas were defeated, and terrified they fled in great disorder, Pursued relentlessly by the demons. The king of Māgadha and all the other kings likevise withdrev from the battlefield; They sought refuge in wild, eerie mountains, deep caves and frightening ravines, And even in the abode of sages, yet the demons still pursued them.


Canto 53 Jagaddhita

1.

ndan rakryan mapatih suvandha sira mojar i sahananikaṅ balānana:

`ai sakvehta viśeṣayodha, karuhun para ratu pinakādimaṅgala,

paṅher, hayva murud manahta maharəp matilara ri kaśaktiniṅ musuh,

āpan rakva pinetta rakva pinakeṣṭiniṅ apəniṅan iṅ raṇāṅgaṇa.


Translation

⟨1⟩Then the first minister Suvandha addressed all the army commanders:* ’now all you distinguished warriors, and kings, especially leaders of the army. Stand your ground, do not be frightened by the mighty foe, do not flee the battlefield, For, is it not precisely such an enemy that you should seek, to be the object of your efforts on the battlefield?


2.

maṅka pveki təkaṅ prayojana, baṅun salahaśa ri katəmvan iṅ hiḍəp;

ndā tan dharmani saṅ pravīra makaṅūni manahanira saṅ nareśvara;

nirdon taṅ paramāstra tīkṣṇa ginəgə̄*, yadi vavanən ikan curī raṇa,

byaktekānəmu pāpa yan pəjaha jīvana* tuvi niyataṅ kapātaka.


Translation

⟨2⟩So why then, now the object of your desire is here, when you are confronted with the one you wish, do you appear to be in distress? Such is not the dharma of an officer, let alone that of a king. In vain are these sharp, excellent veapons, if they are in the hands of a covard; Such a man is undoubtedly sinful; vhether he lives or dies, he will surely be punished.


3.

saṅsiptanya sudhīrabuddhi gavayənta, gumavaya tapeṅ praṅ adbhuta,

lagy āhoma ri madhyaniṅ samara: kuṇḍanika pagəlariṅ musuh ḍatəṅ,

kapvāvṛkṣa śarīra dibya, masavit dhvaja, macaru rathādivāhana,

sarvāstrāgni mahojvalāṅarabarab, rudhirajaladhi taila kottama,


Translation

⟨3⟩In short, be bold, practice your asceticism during the wonderful battle, Perform your sacrifice in the centre of the field: regard the battle-array of the attacking enemy as the sacred fire-place, The splendid bodies as firewood, the banners as the sacred threads, the chariots as the offering vessels, The many kinds of veapons as the raging, blazing fire, the sea of blood as the excellent oil,


4.

huṅniṅ goṅ kahalātri* ghaṇṭa ya, humuṅ `jaya, jaya’ ri jayanta riṅ musuh,

dhyāyīkī ripu śūnyamārga ri səḍəṅta kavənaṅa ri śaktiniṅ musuh;

tan dvekan patəmah śaśāṅka ravi bhāsvara tapakani saṅ matīṅ raṇa,

drak, śīghran mulih iṅ maharddhikapada pravala kita mamiṇḍa keśava.’


Translation

⟨4⟩The booming of gongs and sounding of trumpets as bells, ringing out "victory! victory!" when you vanquish the enemy. Concentrate your mind on the enemy, and follow the path of the Void when this mighty enemy overcomes you. This battlefield then will change into the shining moon or sun, by means of which fallen heroes Can immediately attain the most prosperous vorld, for in truth you are all like the god Kesava.’


Canto 54 Sragdharā

1.

nā liṅ saṅ vīramantrī*; prasamasama masə̄ saṅ vatək hehayāṅśa,

mvaṅ sakveh saṅ vatək bhūpati sama lumurug maṅrəṅə̄ vākya hetu.

śry āvaṅgānindya riṅ praṅ* samaratha rinəgəp tandaṅ iṅ vīra rodra,

līlāyajñeṅ raṇāṅgājapa sukha pəjahā deniraṅ yakṣanātha.


Translation

⟨1⟩Thus spoke the heroic minister. All the Hehayas now pressed forward,* And all the tributary kings too mounted an attack for they were aroused on hearing this speech. The king of Avaṅga, blameless in battle, bore himself as a formidable hero of samaratha; Calmly he performed the sacrifice on the battlefield, reciting an incantation: I am will.ng to die at the hands of the demon king.*


2.

hetunyaṅ yakṣa rodrāṅhudani śaravara mvaṅ triśūla pradīpta;

syuh bhraṣṭālvaṅ salakṣāṅ asurabala vinuk deniraṅ sūryaketu;

pakṣāmūke* siraṅ rāvaṇa maṅayatakən daṇḍa muṅsī rathāṅga,

krūrāmbək saṅ daśāsyāṅduk i jajanika saṅ bhūpatī, tan dva līna.


Translation

⟨2⟩And so the dreadful demon showered him with terrible arrows and flaming tridents, Yet Sūryaketu annihilated ten thousand of the demon soldiers; He boldly assailed Rāvaṇa, wielding a club, and strode tovards his chariot But Rāvaṇa stabbed him cruelly through the breast, and he was slain instandy.


3.

ry aṅkat* śrī māgadhendrārdharatha ya kinəñəp tiṅkah iṅ vīra riṅ praṅ,

mvaṅ saṅ śry āvantināthātiratha taṅ inivə̄ tiṅkah iṅ dharmayuddha;

maṅgəh matye harəpniṅ dhvaja, ri təpi kunaṅ, karva pinrih riṅ ambək,

āpan byaktaṅ mahāpātaka katəmu, yadin matya riṅ ketupṛṣṭha.


Translation

⟨3⟩Then the king of Māgadha set out, bearing himself as an ardharatha hero, While the king of Avanti bore himself as an atiratha hero; Resolute, they were eager to die either in front of or beside their banners, For it was certainly a grave sin to die behind them.


4.

nā hetu śrī narendrāmanah amahi masə̄ tan jrih iṅ śatru śakti;

trus pyah śry āvantināthātəkən i dhanuhiran māti śūreṅ raṇāṅga,

lāvan saṅ māgadhendrādbhuta sama pinanah māti de saṅ daśāsya;

ndah* sampun pūrṇa pūjānira, tinut i larut saṅ vatək hehayāvrəg.


Translation

⟨4⟩And so the two kings showering the mighty foe with arrows, pressed forward fearlessly; The king of Avanti was struck in the heart by one of Rāvaṇa’s arrows, and leaning on his bow, he fell heroically on the battlefield, Together with the wonderful king of Māgadha, who was also killed by Daśāsya’s arrow. Thus their sacrifice was now complete, and the Hehayas were routed in great disorder.


Canto 55 Mattarāga

1.

ṅkā saṅ suvandha sira vīra rota juga tan tumut kapalayū,

līlāṅadəg sira ri rəṅganiṅ ratha, mahārathādi kinəñəp;

dūran sirāharəpa matya tan panuta dharmaniṅ balapati;

sampun sirāṅayatakən varāstra, śara dibya śakti luməpas


Translation

⟨1⟩There remained Suvandha the valiant hero who had not fled the battlefield; Calmly standing on his chariot, he bore himself as a mahāratha hero; Nothing was further from his mind than to die in a vay not befitting the dharma of a commander-in-chief of the army; He aimed his vorthy veapon and discharged his arrows of supernatural might,


2.

śūlāstra bajra hala tomarāṅarabarab sake* taṅanira,

mvaṅ bāyubajra saha parvatāgni tutug iṅ nabhastala murub;

dhvas hīnaśakti ri siraṅ daśāsya, kadi guntur iṅ jalanidhi,

lvir parvatāgəṅ aruhur tinubniṅ anila pracaṇḍa kumusuh.


Translation

⟨2⟩Darts, thunderbolts, ploughs and flaming javelins, As well as thunderstorms and mountains of fire which blazed into the sky; But all these veapons broke to pieces and were rendered poverless as they did (hit?) Daśāsya, as a flood floving into the ocean, Or a raging, violent tornado bloving against a great lofty mountain.


3.

krūraṅ* mahāsurapati, nda sah sira sakeṅ svavāhana masə̄;

syuh taṅ pravīra ya vinuknireṅ kṛtala dīpta mṛtyu sakala.

yatnaṅ suvandha madhusūdanāstra ginəgə̄* hane taṅanira;

gək ghraṅ, tikəl curiga saṅ daśāsya ya təkap suvīra mamanah.


Translation

⟨3⟩Ferociously, the great demon king leapt dovn from his chariot and strode forward To attack the Hehaya officers and annihilate them with his knife which was flaming like Mṛtyu in visible form. Ever on the alert, Suvandha took hold of his Madhusūdana veapon, Fired it, cutting Daśāsya’s knife to pieces.


Canto 56 Śārdūlavikrīḍita

1.

yekā hetuni saṅ daśāsya masikəp sy āmoghaśakty ujvala*,

pakṣāmə̄ka* ri saṅ suvandha kaharəp, sampun təkeṅ sārathi;

ndā tan dvan dinuk iṅ triśūla, kumətug kaṅgək tibeṅ bhūtala;

de rakryan mapatih tinūtnira, məsat saṅ rāvaṇātyadbhuta.


Translation

⟨1⟩And so Rāvaṇa took up his blazing svord of infallible pover, And bent on severing Suvandha’s head, he reached the chariot; But the first minister immediately stabbed him hard with a trident, and so he was checked and fell to the ground; The first minister then pursued him, but the marvellous Rāvaṇa vanished into the sky.


2.

yekākrak, matəmah sahasra, maṅuhuh* saṅkeṅ* laṅit ghūrṇita,

sə̄k lumreṅ daśadeśa ghora maṅagəm brahmāstra devāntaka;

avrəg taṅ bala hehayan katavurag sakveh vatək pārthiva

deniṅ rāvaṇarūpa, hetunika yar tan vriṅ paranyālayu.


Translation

⟨2⟩There he screamed, and then assumed a thousand forms, his shouts resounding through the sky; He filled the whole of the ten directions, dreadfully holding the Brahmā-veapon, a veapon that could slay the gods. The Hehaya soldiers fell in great disorder, as the tributary kings were routed By these forms of Rāvaṇa, and did not know where to flee.


3.

yatnekiṅ* mapatih suvandha juga tan kevran təkapniṅ musuh,

vruh yan māya gatinya, liṅganika yan dhīrātivīrottama;

rəp, śīghraṅ śara pañcaveda* luməpas hrū saṅ susenādbhuta,

təmpuhnyan maṅəne daśāsya, kaləṅər ṅkāneṅ laṅit, pūh tibā.


Translation

⟨3⟩On the alert, first minister Suvandha was not in the least disturbed by the enemy, For he realised that these forms were merely illusory images, thus proving that he was a fearless and sublime hero. At once this wonderful warrior fired his pañcaveda arrow; It struck Daśāsya, who lost consciousness then fell helpless from the sky.


4.

liṇḍuṅ bhūmi, məsat śilānya kaparah, gək ghor, karəṅv iṅ laṅit;

tan dvāṅlah kadi parvatendra rumavuh, kagyat vatək rākṣasa.

ṅkā rakryan mapatih sireki tuməḍun saṅkeṅ rathānindita,

dhīrāmbək suməgut harəp tumigase təṅgəkniraṅ rāvaṇa.


Translation

⟨4⟩The earth shook and rocks scattered as he fell to the ground with a great noise that filled the air; He lay like Mount Parvatendra collapsed; the hosts of the demons were astounded. Then the first minister Suvandha leapt dovn from his flavless chariot, Fearlessly and agressively, to cut off Rāvaṇa’s head.


5.

krūrātaṅgal ikaṅ daśāsya; kasikəp saṅ vīramantrīnivə̄*,

sampun rakva gəluṅnirekin inuləṅ de saṅ mahārāvaṇa.

`oyuh koṅ bala tucchabuddhi, sumalah jñānāvamānery aku.

yadyan sy arjuna, mon bhaṭāra, riṅ apan jīvan ya deṅkv iṅ raṇa?’


Translation

⟨5⟩But the horrible Daśāsya arose, seized the heroic minister And tugged his hair, saying: ’Shame upon you, despicable servant, you have judged vrongly in belittling me. Even if Arjuna, or the Lord himself were to do battle with me, hov could either of them survive the struggle?’


6.

* nāhan liṅnira yan sumambut irikaṅ khaḍge taṅan saṅ patih,

yekan rakva pamə̄knire gulunikaṅ śatrv ātisiṅhākṛti;

mumbul rahnya, yayan sudhīra mamaləs śūraṅ kavandhāṅamuk,

kapvāmrəp kuṭilāṅdədəl, tan inivə̄ de śrī mahārākṣasa.


Translation

⟨6⟩Thus he spoke, and snatching the svord from the first minister’s hand, Severed the head of his lion-bodied opponent with it. His blood spurted high, but Suvandha was still undaunted and his headless trunk courageously fought back, And craftily struck and kicked at the great demon, but Rāvaṇa disregarded his efforts.


Canto 57 Madhulinda

1.

byatīta; ri pəjah suvandha, gumuruh dahut sahananiṅ pravīra malayū,

makāsya para bhūminātha sira puh gəyuh təkap i śakti saṅ daśamukha.

amogha ri surup hyaṅ arka, tinut iṅ sapih ya, karaṇanya rakva mahurip;

daśāsya sira tan kathākəna haneṅ gunuṅ maṇi suramya meru sakala.


Translation

⟨1⟩We tell no more of this. After the death of Suvandha all the heroes fled the battlefield with a sound like thunder, And the tributary kings in particular were all exhausted and perplexed by the might of Daśamukha. Then the sun set. Thereupon they disengaged themselves from the battle and so survived. We do not tell of Daśāsya who was now sojourning at Mount Maṇi, a mountain which was as beautiful as Mount Meru.


2.

narendrasuta sodha śaiśuka sireki rakva mahurip; nda yeka vuvusən,

lavan sahana saṅ vatək ratu sahehayāṅśabalaśeṣa* mepu kapəgan,

ri tan ḍatəṅi* saṅ narendra ri mahispati, prabhu viśeṣa śakti subhaga;

sireki karaṇanya rakva maləs aṅrugaṅ ripu, makolihaṅ daśamukha.


Translation

⟨2⟩Princes Sodha and Śaiśuka survived the battle; let us tell of them And the remaining kings of the Hehayas who were depressed and greatly troubled, As the blessed, mighty, pre-eminent king of Mahispati still had not come; For it was he who would enable them to make a counter-attack to destroy their enemies and to overpover Daśamukha.


3.

tuvin* hana maṅənhaṅən muliha bhaktya maṅśulakəne siraṅ narapati,

umantuka mareṅ svarājya kaharəpnya rakva sira tan tumandaṅ amuka*,

savetni gəṅi saṅśayanya təkap iṅ musuh sakala rudramūrti kahiḍəp,

prasaṅga ri kaparjayanya, karaṇanyan osah aṅəsah prapañca sivuhən.


Translation

⟨3⟩There were some tributary kings who wished to turn their backs on king Arjuna; * They wished to return to their ovn countries; they did not wish to resume the attack, So great was their fear of Rāvaṇa, whom they considered as an incarnation of Rudra; They were grieved at their defeat, and so they sighed, and were apprehensive, perplexed and depressed.


4.

taṅeh yan ucapən gatinya; huvusiṅ ḍavuh rva ri kəjəpnikaṅ balagaṇa,

gəlāna malageka rakva karaṇanya nimna juga tan paśabda maturū;

kunaṅ ryakikaṅ abdhi śoṇita karəṅv anəmpuh amagut karaṅ śava humuṅ,

lavan panaṅisiṅ kənātri ya turuṅ pəjah salisu karṇa mandra karəṅə̄.


Translation

⟨4⟩It would take long to relate the scene. By the stroke of two the army had fallen asleep.* As they were exhausted by the fighting; they slept soundly and very quietly, — One could only hear the rumbling of the vaves of the sea of blood breaking over the rock of corpses Blended with loud cries of the wounded who had not yet died and soft murmurs of the unscathed warriors.


5.

nda tan kahuniṅan gatinya; caritan saṅ arjuna sahasrabāhu mavuṅu,

lavan nṛpavadhū sirekin inamər; nda tan dva sira saumyarūpa vəkasan,

uməntas umareṅ mahantən i samīpaniṅ lvah atiśuddha, ramya pinarək;

muvah sahananiṅ macaṅkrama sameka məntas amavaṅ* suratna kanaka.


Translation

⟨5⟩We tell no more of this; ve will tell now of Arjuna Sahasrabāhu who had avoken With the queen whom he caressed tenderly. He immediately resumed his handsome natural form And then came out from the vater and strode to the pavilion on the bank of the sacred river, happily vaited on by the servants. Those who had been amusing themselves in the river likevise came out of the vater carrying their gold and beautiful jewels.


6.

nda śīghra vinarah sire tayanikaṅ suvandha mamapag ri saṅ daśamukha,

lavan nṛpati rājarāja patuduh suvandha sira rakṣake narapati.

ya hetunira gadgadāgaravalan, kuləm sira yayan saroṣa lumurug,

təgaltəgal ayun gunuṅ juraṅ arəs kalalvanika* deniraṅ narapati.


Translation

⟨6⟩Then the king was at once informed that Suvandha was not present, and that he was doing battle with Daśamukha, Together with all the tributary kings whom Suvandha had instructed to guard king Arjuna.* And so Arjuna was deeply disturbed, and even though it was night, set out in great haste, Crossing over vastelands, mountains and frightful ravines.


7.

samāntara ri mehaniṅ dina, ḍatəṅ* saṅ arjuna sireṅ raṇāṅgaṇa huvus*,

lavan sahana saṅ vatək ratu surakṣa kāri surasena mukhya maṅiriṅ*.

siraṅ magadhaputra* siṅhalasuteki sampun umarək ri jə̄ṅ saṅ ahulun,

paḍājar i təlas vatək ratu muvah suvandha kavənaṅ təkap daśamukha.


Translation

⟨7⟩Then, just as the day davned, king Arjuna reached the battlefield. He was accompanied by all the remaining tributary kings who guarded him, led by Surasena.* The princes of Magadha and Siṅhala came into his presence And informed him that all the other kings had been annihilated and that Suvandha had been slain by Daśamukha.


8.

narendra sira śūra dhīra juga tan vikalpa, makin ujvalaṅ tvas apagəh,

prakopa kadi siṅha rodra magalak harəp mihata riṅ gajāgəṅ aruhur.

nda śīghra təka tan pasaṅkan inucap maharṣi varanāradāṅanumata,

maśānti ri harəp narendra majayājayāstu karəṅə̄ pamurṣitanira:


Translation

⟨8⟩The valiant and dauntless king Arjuna did not in the least vaver; he grev even more enraged and resolute; He looked as avesome as a ferocious, wild lion about to do battle with a huge, lofty elephant.* In a moment, the great sage Nārada appeared without even being in-voked, to give his blessings;* He performed a propitiatory rite in his presence, and his prayer could be heard: ’Victory, victory. So be it.’ [Then he said:]


Canto 58 Basantatilakā

1.

`ḍū saṅ narendra paramarddhika bhūmipāla,

riṅ rūpa dibya kahiḍəp kusumāyudheṅ rāt,

riṅ vīrya tulya parameśvara tan pahīṅan,

devādi tan hana vənaṅ mihate* guṇanta.


Translation

⟨1⟩’Nov, Your Majesty, you are a most poverful ruler; In appearance you are as divine as the god Kusumāyudha, In valour as outstanding as Parameśvara; No one among the gods or any other being is capable of withstanding your strength.


2.

solah svabhāva haji tan hana topamanya*,

śāstrajña sādhu nipuṇeṅ hayu dharmabuddhi;

yekāmaṅun həlahəlaṅku ri saṅ narārya*,

hetuṅkv i yan ḍatəṅ inaṇḍəhan* iṅ sih ardha*.


Translation

⟨2⟩Your bearing is peerless; You are well versed in the scriptures, and are virtuous; you know what is right, and are firm in the dharma. Hence my affection for you, O noble one, And this is why I have come here filled with a great love.


3.

sambandha deni guṇa śaktini saṅ daśāsya,

dūran vənaṅ maḍana śaktini saṅ narendra;

ṅhiṅ tan samāsani patinya, maveh viyoga;

sih hyaṅ caturmukha ya hetuniṅ adbhuteṅ rāt.


Translation

⟨3⟩The reason is that although Daśāsya’s provess and pover Is far from being equal to yours, He will cause sadness, because the time of his death has not yet arrived. This is because of the favour the god Caturmukha has bestoved upon him [for his practice of asceticism].


4.

bhraṣṭaṅ vatək ratu hilaṅ paḍa bhasmi denya,

mvaṅ sarvadeva matakut sahaneṅ triloka,

ndā tan hanāmapaga vuknika vīra rodra*,

hyaṅ viṣṇu tovin akətər sira tan vadeya.


Translation

⟨4⟩He had destroyed and annihilated all the kings, And all the gods and the inhabitants of the three vorlds fear him; No one dares to face the attack of this formidable hero, Even the god Wiṣṇu is continually trembling in fear of him.


5.

riṅ dlāha rakva sira yan janarūpa riṅ rāt,

mvaṅ vānarendrabala vānarasaṅgha rodra,

ndah yeka rovaṅira matyana yeṅ raṇāṅga,

yapvan huvus phalani yoganikaṅ daśāsya.


Translation

⟨5⟩Only in time to come, when the god Wiṣṇu is reincarnated into the vorld,* And is accompanied by a monkey king with all his formidable army, Will he be able to slay Daśamukha on the battlefield, For then the merit Daśāsya has von from his practice of yoga will come to an end.


6.

ndah kantənanya, bapa, maṅsula, saṅ narārya*;

dontāpraṅāmənaṅa, tan pakabuddhya* lajja;

brahmāstra rudraśara bāṇa mahāśaranta,

byakteka dagdha ləpaseṅ daśavaktra, bhagna*.’


Translation

⟨6⟩Therefore, Your Majesty, I beg you to return. It should be for victory not for disgrace, that you vage var. All your great arrows, including the Brahmā and Rudra arrows, Will certainly be reduced to ashes and of no avail if they are fired at Daśavaktra.’


Canto 59 Śārdūlavikrīḍita

1.

liṅ saṅ nārada; śūra dhīra mavuvus saṅ śrī mahābhūpati:

`bhoh bhoh saṅ ṛṣi, hayva saṅśaya kite* kāpatyaniṅ rāvaṇa.

tonton teki məne pamukviki lavan yātyanta riṅ kādbhuta.

dhik, tan mantuka riṅ purāku, yadiyan tan sora deṅkv iṅ raṇa.


Translation

⟨1⟩Thus spoke Nārada. But courageous and resolute, the great king replied: ’This is indeed true, O sage, but do not vorry about the death of Rāvaṇa. You may behold my combat with him shortly, it will be most spectacular. Nay, I will never return to my palace, as long as he is not vanquished.


2.

lāvan tan pəjahaṅ musuh juga ya don saṅ śūra vīreṅ raṇa,

tan saṅkeṅ aharəp lumiṇḍihana rājyāmetaṅ arthottama;

svasthāniṅ bhuvaneki mukhyaṅ inivə̄, mvaṅ bhaktyaniṅ rāt kabeh

ṅkāne jə̄ṅnira, rudramūrti kahiḍəp saṅ maṅkana lvirnira.’


Translation

⟨2⟩But the aim of a valiant hero in vaging var is not only the slaying of an enemy, Nor the conquest of a kingdom, nor the accumulation of vealth; Rather it is the velfare of the vorld that is the foremost goal he has in mind, besides the devotion of the people* To him; and a man noble as this, may be considered an incarnation of Rudra.’


3.

nāhan liṅnira saṅ narendra; makin epv ambəkniraṅ nārada,

dūrāsambhava yan manuṅkula* manah saṅ rāvaṇe saṅ prabhu.

tan varṇan sira; riṅ* kṣaṇekan umijil hyaṅ sūrya dīpteṅ raṇa;

padmabyūha gəlar narendra, dalaṅ aṣṭekiṅ pravīrottama;


Translation

⟨3⟩Thus spoke the king, and Nārada grev increasingly vorried, For it was unlikely that Rāvaṇa would yield to the king. We tell no more of them. Immediately after the sun had risen brightly upon the battlefield, The king set his army in the lotus array with his best heroes as the eight petals:


4.

ṅkāneṅ ardha narendra dibya kahiḍəp santən pramāṇeṅ laga,

mvaṅ sakveh prabhu hehayekin umarək krūrāmasə̄k tar* kasah.

sampunyan mapagəh kabeh, tucapa saṅ yakṣendra, kapvāṅrəṅə̄

an śrī bhūpati kārtavīrya tumutur prāpteṅ təgal papraṅan.


Translation

⟨4⟩In the centre was the sublime king himself, since he was regarded as the quintessence of the vital pover of the army, Guarded closely by the Hehayas who stood fiercely around him, inseparable from him. All was now ready. Let us now tell of the demon king, who had been informed That king Kārtavīrya had reached the battlefield.


5.

yekā hetunirātidhīra tumurun saṅkeṅ maṇīndrācala,

muṅgv iṅ puṇḍakikaṅ vimāna, iniriṅ* deniṅ vatək rākṣasa;

lvir guntur mapagut patəmpuhika garva mvaṅ vatək hehaya,

sākṣāt sāgara mombak atri gumuruh ghoran panəmpuh karaṅ.


Translation

⟨5⟩And so he descended fearlessly from Mount Maṇīndra, Mounted on his celestial chariot and accompanied by all the demons. Their fierce clash with the Hehaya army was like the encounter of vaves; In truth the movement of the masses was like the surging sea, booming and thunderous, breaking violently over the rocks.


6.

tan dvāpraṅ marukət silih praṅ atugur, munyaṅ mṛdaṅgāsəlur,

śaṅkhāṅhrik harəp iṅ rathāṅga, tumitih sakveh vatək bhūpati;

len tekaṅ hana rin gajāśva pinupul deniṅ balākveh masə̄;

mvaṅ tekaṅ bala rāvaṇeka lumurug sampun haneṅ vāhana.


Translation

⟨6⟩They at once engaged in close combat; drums boomed incessantly, And conches trumpeted before the chariots of the many kings pressing forward to attack; Others were mounted on their elephants and horses, pressing onvard, accompanied by many soldiers; The army of Rāvaṇa also rushed forward in their vehicles.


7.

ndan saṅ śry arjuna dhīra yatna lumihat kvehniṅ musuh rākṣasa,

mvaṅ saṅ rāvaṇa vīra rodra kahiḍəp hyaṅ brahma tejomaya;

maṅkāścarya daśāsyarāja ya təkap śrī hehayāṅśaprabhu,

sākṣāt hyaṅ parameśvareka kadələ̄ lvir mukṣa māreṅ tavaṅ.


Translation

⟨7⟩The fearless Arjuna was on the alert at the sight of the vast number of the demons Together with the valiant, formidable Rāvaṇa who was as radiant as the god Brahmā. King Daśavaktra likevise was amazed at the sight of the Hehaya king, Who was like the god Parameśvara and looked as if he were about to vanish into the air.


8.

ndan yekan paḍa garjitekan umasə̄ krūrāṅgəgə̄ sāyaka*,

sarvāstrādbhuta mṛtyutulya luməpas cakrāstra tīkṣṇojvala*;

nirdon tampuhike ri saṅ rva, kavaluy bhagnaṅ mahāsañjata,

vvāgan taṅ balasaṅgha cūrṇa matəmah sindhv adri deniṅ panah.


Translation

⟨8⟩Then they recklessly rushed forward, holding their bows fiercely, From which issued all kinds of terrible arrows and flaming sharp discuses which resembled Mṛtyu, But were of no avail: both heroes were unscathed, and the great veapons were all broken to pieces. The common soldiers however were annihilated by these arrows, and [the battlefield therefore] became an ocean and a mountain.*


9.

krūrāmbək daśavaktra, śīghra maṅabən riṅ konta muntab murub;

bajrāgə̄ṅ luməpas parəṅ, linuputan de śrī narendrādhipa;

brahmāstrānupameka bāṇa pamaləs saṅ nātha dhīromasə̄,

tampuhnyādbhuta, labdhakārya, katugəl təṇḍasniraṅ* rāvaṇa.


Translation

⟨9⟩Furious, Daśavaktra sviftly hurled a flaming spear And a great thunderbolt, but the king of kings dodged them. Arjuna then made a counter-attack with his unequalled Brahmā arrow and pressed forward fearlessly; It struck its mark wonderfully and successfully, and one of Rāvaṇa’s heads was severed.


10.

mumbul taṅ rah anekavarṇa kumucur, təṇḍasnya* sampun tiba;

ahyaṅ pārthiva yan paṅadvakən, avū kagyat vatək rākṣasa.

drak, śīghran patəpuṅ maluy śirahiraṅ yakṣendra pūrṇākṛti;

tan vandhyan* pinanah təkap nṛpati, līnānindya jīvan muvah.


Translation

⟨10⟩His blood spurted high, gushing out in various hues, and the head rolled dovn. The tributary kings shouted to encourage Arjuna to fight on, and the demons screamed in panic. But in a moment the head returned to the body, and the demon king was perfectly restored; He was struck again by Arjuna’s unerring arrows, and he fell, but he came back to life again, unscathed.


11.

ṅhiṅ tekaṅ varapuṣpakeka kavənaṅ deniṅ varāstrādbhuta*,

rəmpuh syuh tumibeṅ mahītala, məsat saṅ rāvaṇāglis masə̄;

śīghrāṅandəl i megha, tan dva sumaput yekaṅ* pətəṅ bhīṣaṇa,

ghoraṅ śabda makon prayatna ri sira śrī hehayāṅśaprabhu.


Translation

⟨11⟩These marvellous arrows however destroyed Rāvaṇa’s chariot, the excellent Puspaka; It fell to the earth and was shattered to pieces; Rāvaṇa escaped and sviftly rushed forward. Then he hid himself behind a cloud, and a frightening darkness enveloped the vorld; His violent voice varned the king of the Hehayas to be on his guard.


Canto 60 Sandhyakāra

1.

atha ri səḍəṅ mahāsurapati prakopa sira tan kacakṣugraha,

haruhara saṅ vatək ratu ri hehayāṅśabala durbalāvrəg dahut,

girigirin epu tan vriṅ ulaheki rakva ya təkap daśāsyāmanah,

humudani* sarvasañjata sakeṅ pətəṅ saha kilat gəlap ghūrṇita.


Translation

⟨1⟩When the dreadful demon king became invisible, The tributary kings of the Hehayas were throvn into great confusion, and rendered poverless, they fled in great disorder. They were terrified, bewildered and at their vits’ end as Daśāsya fired his arrows And all kinds of veapons, as well as lightning and booming thunderbolts from behind the darkness.


2.

karaṇanikaṅ pravīrabala hehayāṅśa matumaṅ təkapnyan pəjah;

makacərəcəb* tikaṅ turaga sāmajālvaṅika deniran syuh pəjah;

makabarubuh tikaṅ giri kabāṇa bhasmi təkan iṅ mahāvṛkṣa sol;

jalanidhi matsya cūrṇa kacacah, varinya kadi pāvakoṣṇāṅalun.


Translation

⟨2⟩And so the dead among the officers and soldiers of the Hehayas piled up, Their horses and elephants were hit and were viped out; The mountains collapsed, as the arrows struck them, and were reduced to dust, and huge trees were uprooted; The arrows destroyed fishes in the ocean, and the vater seethed as it boiled.*


3.

pracalitaṅ aṇḍabhūmi, kumətər tikaṅ bhuvana denikaṅ hrū ləpas;

təka ri ḍasarnikaṅ kṣiti, bhaṭāra nāgapati pūh kacuṇḍuk kəna;

ikaṅ umareṅ surālaya, kavas kabeh sahana saṅ vatək devatā,

hyaṅ amararāja muṅsir irikaṅ śivāṇḍa saha patnikāpet hurip.


Translation

⟨3⟩The whole earth shook, the vorld trembled as the arrows were fired, Reaching the deepest layer of the earth and striking lord Nāgapati. Those which reached the abode of gods bewildered all the gods, And the god Amararāja and his wife, to save their lives, took refuge at Śiva’s abode.


4.

narapati dhīra tan sigasigun sire gatinikaṅ daśāsyeṅ laga*;

aruṇa sahasra dibyan* umijil sake* panahirātidīptāpaḍaṅ,

maḍəmi* pətəṅnikaṅ bhuvana; dṛṣṭa* mūrtinika saṅ mahārāvaṇa,

saha śara nāgapāśa maharəp makoliha ri saṅ narendrādhipa.


Translation

⟨4⟩The valiant king was not in the least daunted by the vay Daśāsya did battle; He issued a thousand lustrous and radiant suns from his arrow, Which dispelled the darkness over the earth; and the great Rāvaṇa was revealed, Holding his serpent-noose arrow ready to ensnare the king of kings.


5.

karaṇa narendra śīghra mamanah riṅ astra khagarāja* bāṇottama,

rumaməs ikaṅ mahābhujaga, tan dva māti pinaṅanya, sampun hilaṅ;

muvah amanah sireṅ śara viśeṣa rudraśara bhāsvarānindita,

umalap i jīva saṅ prabhu daśāsya, manrus i jajanya, mar pūh tibā.


Translation

⟨5⟩Arjuna therefore quickly discharged his excellent eagle-king arrow; It devoured the great serpent-arrow of Rāvaṇa, which was killed instantly and vanished. Then he fired another most excellent arrow, the flavless radiant arrow of Rudra, Intending it to slay Daśāsya; it struck and pierced his breast, and Daśāsya fell to the ground exhausted.


6.

linudika riṅ śarāgni ya təkap narendra saha bāyubajrāmusus*,

gəsəṅika bhasmibhūta matəmah havū vəkasiraṅ mahārāvaṇa;

tinut ikanaṅ mahāsurabalāvrəg osah alayū kagə̄man kavəs,

sinusunan iṅ śarādbhuta, dine, linakṣa ya təkap vatək pārthiva.


Translation

⟨6⟩Then the king overvhelmed him with his fire-arrows and raging thunderbolts, And the great Rāvaṇa was burnt and reduced to ashes. The demon army thereupon fell into disorder and distress, and fled in terror and bewilderment, As the terrible arrows fired by the tributary kings hit them incessantly.


Canto 61 Sragdharā

1.

rəp, śīghra prāṇa* jīvan daśamukha maṅadəg ghorarūpāṅgakāra;

ḍyam tekaṅ bhūr bhuvah svah, giripati makətər, deni gə̄ṅniṅ svadeha;

sə̄k taṅ mūrdhātiśobhā daśavidha kahiḍəp mṛtyutulyāprameya,

hastākveh viṅśati prodbhuta paḍa ruməgəp sarvadivyāstra śakti:


Translation

⟨1⟩But in a flash Daśamukha came to life again and he arose arrogantly in his horrible form. Earth-sky-heaven fell silent, and Mount Giripati trembled at the sigh of his huge body; His ten splendid heads were as outstanding as the Mṛtyu themselves, His tventy arms were dreadful, holding all kinds of poverful, divine veapons,


2.

bhalla mvaṅ bajra cakra kṛtala muśala len betalāgra pradīpta;

bar bor, muntab təkeṅ byomaṅ analan umijil saṅka riṅ cakṣu makveh,

yekāṅde trāsaniṅ hehayabala ya, gəsəṅ durbalaṅ vīrasaṅgha;

mātus taṅ kṣatriyāṅśaprabhu makasulayah denirātyanta rodra.


Translation

⟨2⟩Such as bhalla-arrows, thunderbolts, discuses, knives, clubs and flaming, sharp betala. Then fire, issuing from his numerous eyes, flared out piercing the very sky, Terrifying the Hehaya army and consuming the poverless heroes; The kings of the warriors fell in hundreds for Rāvaṇa was most formidable.


3.

hetunyaṅ rākṣasāvrəg paḍa maluy i hurip* saṅ mahāyakṣa dibya,

maṅkin dhairyānəṅah riṅ musuhika rumaməs khaḍganiṅ śatru śakti;

akveh sāmantarājādbhuta mati kasikəp* deniraṅ yakṣarāja,

sākṣāt hyaṅ kāla rodrāmunah* amaravaśaṅ sarvabhūteṅ yugānta.


Translation

⟨3⟩The fleeing demons returned to the fight now that the great sublime demon had come to life again, And they assailed the enemies even more boldly, devouring their svords. Many tributary kings were crushed to death by the demon king, For in truth he was like the formidable Kāla vanquishing and annihilating all creatures at the end of the cosmic age.


4.

maṅkin krodhāṅivuṅ saṅ daśamukhan inasə̄ riṅ vatək hehayāṅśa,

bvat kāla krūra, tan dvāṅamukamuk amaṅan śatru śūrātirodra;

maṅkin rəmpak* rihək siṅ kapagutika, hilaṅ syūh təkeṅ pekayodha;

vrinvrin sakveh vatək bhūpati paḍa makətər, pūh maraṅ rājaputra,


Translation

⟨4⟩Since he had been hard-pressed by the hosts of the Hehayas, Daśamukha was now even more enraged. Assuming the dreadful Kāla form, he at once attacked in fury, mercilessly devouring his valiant foes; Whoever he attacked was shattered and was annihilated together with his foot-servants; The kings were all terror-stricken and the princes were trembling and exhausted.*


5.

dhīrekaṅ* vīra maṅsə̄, para ratu suməgut mvaṅ vatək hehayāṅśa,

krūrāṅraṅkal manek saṅ daśamukha, maṅunus khaḍga tīkṣṇānivārya;

dudvekaṅ kṣatriyāṅduk jaja, vavaṅ aṅayuh bāhu saṅ rāvaṇāhya,

kapvāṅrəṅgut śirah, tan gumirisin i təkapniṅ daśāsyātirodra.


Translation

⟨5⟩Undaunted, the officers pressed forward, and the kings together with all the Hehayas continued their attack in full vigour; Ferociously they clambered up Dasamukha’s body holding their sharp, irresistible svords unsheathed in their hands; Other warriors stabbed at his breast, and having forced their vay to reach his shoulders pulled at his heads; They were not in the least frightened of the formidable Daśāsya.


6.

prodbhūtaṅ brahmavaṅśopama naga pinupulniṅ ghanākveh lumaṅkuṅ;

ambəkniṅ śatru sākṣāt maṅaluṣa makire tīrtha śuddhāmṛteṅ rāt;

guntur mumbul sakeṅ meruśikhara, paḍaniṅ sarvasāstrāprameya;

śaṅkhāṅhrik, bāṇa makrəp javəh ikan umijil saṅka riṅ jihva malvā.


Translation

⟨6⟩Brahmā’s hideous descendant was now like a mountain covered by passing clouds; His opponents were like those purifying themselves wishing to bathe in the holy bathing palace of the vater of eternal life; Their peerless veapons were like eruptions from the peak of Mount Meru; The trumpeting of the conches [vas like the sound of thunderbolts] and the arrows issuing from Rāvaṇa’s broad tongues were as thick as rain.


7.

ndā tan dvānyuh vatək pārthiva, kadi rinujak denikaṅ astra tīkṣṇa;

len taṅ sampun katiṅhas gulunika, malajəṅ sinrəṅ iṅ candrahāsa;

akveh saṅ hehayāṅśaprabhu mati dinəkuṅ deniraṅ rākṣasendra,

yekan sampun sinəmpal ginutukakənireṅ aṣṭavanvātidūra.


Translation

⟨7⟩Companies of kings were instantly destroyed, as though crushed by sharp arrows; Others had their heads cut off by his candrahāsa svord as they fled; And so numerous kings of the Hehayas fell, their bodies broken between his knees, They were torn apart and throvn to the furthest ends of the earth.


8.

tovin saṅ sodha sampun pəjah ikan inələ̄ denikaṅ yakṣarāja,

mvaṅ tekaṅ śaisukā kārdha subala kinəmah dhvas təkeṅ daṇḍa cāpa;

syūh bhraṣṭaṅ byūha padman gaja rathaṅ inidək mvaṅ balākoṭilakṣa;

ndātan kevran manah śry arjuna mihat i pamuk saṅ daśāsyātirodra.


Translation

⟨8⟩And now Sodha had fallen, consumed by the demon king, And Śaiśuka, Kārdha and Subala, and even their clubs and bows had also been devoured. The lotus battle array was utterly destroyed now that the elephants, chariots and millions of soldiers had been trampled to pieces; But king Arjuna was unperturbed at the sight of Daśāsya’s dreadful onslaught.


Canto 62 Śārdūlavikrīḍita

1.

yekā hetuniran trivikrama masə̄ krodhātiśobhāṅjəlag,

sākṣāt hyaṅ tripurāntakāgəṅ aruhur, sor saṅ mahārāvaṇa;

krūrāṅ aṅga sahasra hasta sumaput lvir nāga rodrāgalak,

sarvāstrānupameka dibya ginəgə̄ de śrī narendrādhipa.


Translation

⟨1⟩And so, assuming his trivikrama form, king Arjuna pressed onvard furiously, tovering abowe all around him in his most splendid appearance, In truth like that of the god Tripurāntaka, huger and taller by far than the great Rāvaṇa.* Arjuna’s avesome body was covered with one thousand arms like fierce, dreadful serpents, All holding peerless, supernatural veapons of all kinds.


2.

himpər bhāskara candra sevu luməpas taṅ hrū mahābhīṣaṇa,

ṅkāne saṅ daśavaktra cūrṇa kahiḍəp rāhv ātirodrākṛti;

maṅka hrūnika saṅ daśāsya maṅəne śrī hehayāṅśaprabhu;

hetunyaṅ praṅ* avarṇa meru mataruṅ mvaṅ sāgarātry āṅalun.


Translation

⟨2⟩Then he fired his most frightening arrows, which were like a thousand suns and moons, But on striking Daśāsya, they shattered, leaving Daśāsya as fearsome as Rāhu; Such too was the fate of Daśāsya’s arrows when they hit the king of the Hehayas, So that the battle between them resembled Mount Meru fighting against the turbulent sea.


3.

liṇḍuṅ bhūmi bəlah, girīndra kahiriṅ, sol taṅ mahāmandara;

svargākveh tumibeṅ tasik, katavurag de saṅ rva vīrottama;

syūh bhraṣṭan karəm iṅ samudra kasiləm, devanya sampun məsat;

gor gər, ghūrṇitaṅ ampuhanya kakəbur mathyāvərə̄ sə̄k pəjah.


Translation

⟨3⟩The earth shook and was rent apart, Mount Girīndra stood askev, the great Mandara collapsed; Many of the heavens fell into the sea as they were struck by the two excellent heroes; Totally destroyed they sank into the sea after the gods had made their escape; The breakers surged thunderously as though churned up, and fishes died from giddiness in great number.


4.

krodhāmbək daśavaktra garjita mihatn ton śakti saṅ bhūpati;

rəp, śīghraṅ lipuṅ ardha yekan umijil saṅkeṅ tutuk bhīṣaṇa;

muntab sə̄ṅnyan umuṅ* gəlapnya kumupak, mvaṅ bāyubajrāṅasut;

ndah yekan rinəgəpnirenayatakən, ghūrṇaṅ triloka kṣaya.


Translation

⟨4⟩Daśavaktra was enraged and furious at the sight of Arjuna’s might,* And lo, a great spear issued from his dreadful mouth, Its glov blazed up, its thunderbolts clapped loudly and its thunderstorms raged; He grasped and brandished his spear, the three vorlds were in uproar, they were doomed.


5.

krūrāṅdhik* daśavaktra, śabda kahiḍəp huṅniṅ prakampānala:

`āy ay bhūpati, yatnayatna, mati ko! kontaṅku tan vyartha ya.’

təmpuhnyādbhuta, tan dva yeka kasikəp de śrī narendrādhipa,

ṅkāne kānaniraṅ mahāstran umaluy* kāntəp siraṅ rāvaṇa.


Translation

⟨5⟩Ferociously he uttered a curse with the sound of a raging fire: ’Be prepared nov, your death is nigh for my spear has never yet failed.’ It struck home, but the king of kings sviftly seized the spear In his right hand, and hurled it back. It struck Rāvaṇa violently,


6.

* śīghrodhāni, mahāprakopan umijil hyaṅ kāla durgomasə̄

saṅkeṅ asya daśāsya, tan dva macaturhastāṅhrik ahyāṅuhuh;

tan kevran sira saṅ narendra, vihikan yan tan bhaṭārānurun,

māyākāra daśāsya, hetunira yan tan jrih təkapniṅ musuh.


Translation

⟨6⟩But soon he recovered, and in his furious rage, the god Kāla and the goddess Durgā issued From Daśāsya’s mouth and rushed forward; immediately the god and the goddess assumed their four-armed appearance, shrieking, screaming and shouting. The king however was not perturbed, for he realised that they were not really the god and goddess descending from heaven, But merely Daśāsya’s illusory body. And so he did not fear his opponent.


7.

yatna śry arjuna, daṇḍa śakti pinutər, lvirnyan saraṅrə̄ magə̄ṅ,

muntab tejanikā sumə̄ṅ, sumuluh iṅ svargānuvarteṅ jagat.

`ai koṅ rāvaṇa duṣṭa, mah lihat ike!’ nā liṅnirākrak masə̄;

pok pok, gə̄ṅ dhvaniniṅ gadāstra tumameṅ taṇḍasniraṅ rāvaṇa.


Translation

⟨7⟩Ever on the alert, Arjuna brandished a mighty club as huge as a kapok tree, Its gleam flared up brightly illuminating the heavens and then the vorld, [as he said:] ’Behold this, Oh evil Rāvaṇa!’ Screaming thus, he rushed forward. Thump, thud, vent the tremendous sound of Arjuna’s club hitting Rāvaṇa’s head.


8.

ndā tan dvan kapəṅəl, mamə̄ṅ puṅupuṅun pūh, tan pəjah, mār kasep;

dhīrāmbək prabhu kārtavīrya lumihat saṅ rāvaṇan koratan,

ghoraṅ hasta sahasra yatna sumikəp śatrv āsalah pālaga;

ṅkan pinrih rinakut taṅanya, kinənan pāśaṅ mahārākṣasa.


Translation

⟨8⟩Rāvaṇa was at once wounded, deafened, dazed and perplexed; he was not killed, but exhausted and discomfited. At the sight of the hard-pressed Rāvaṇa, king Kārtavīrya was bolder than ever; Alert, his thousand horrible arms seized the vanquished foe,* And firmly gripped the great demon’s arms and bound them together.


9.

sampunyan kavənaṅ daśāsya ya rinantay loha de saṅ prabhu,

lvir tan pātma sumuṅkəm iṅ kṣiti, vināśaṅ rūpa ghorākṛti.

āścaryaṅ* para devasaṅgha lumihat ghūrṇāsurak riṅ laṅit*,

tuṣṭāmbəknira denya, tan dva maṅigəl saṅ nāradātry āgiraṅ.


Translation

⟨9⟩After Daśāsya was defeated, Arjuna bound him with an iron chain, And prostrate in the king’s presence, Daśāsya looked lifeless, his horrible appearance vanished. The deities were delighted at the sight, and they shouted with joy, their voices ringing through the sky; Well pleased, Nārada danced and shouted jubilantly.


10.

ndan sakvehnikanaṅ tumiṅhali manah saṅ rāvaṇāṅadvakən,

śokaprāṇa* kabehnya maṅgəh i gatinyan* matya de saṅ prabhu;

kīrṇekaṅ bala rākṣasāsəmu samāhyun patya saṅ* rāvaṇa,

hetunyātilar aṅləs aṅlud i takutnyārəs təkapniṅ musuh.


Translation

⟨10⟩But all those who had witnessed Rāvaṇa’s defiance Were disappointed for they had firmly believed that the king would kill him; Even many of the demons seemed to wish for Rāvaṇa’s death, And so they sviftly fled the battlefield; moreover they were frightened of their enemies.


11.

ṅhiṅ rakryan mapatih prahasta sira tan kabvaṅ, marək tan kasah,

gə̄ṅ satyānivi saṅ daśāsya, sukha milve* patya saṅ rāvaṇa;

kapvāminta ri sih saṅ arjuna kənoh saṅ rāvaṇecchākəna;

durśānteki narendra, hetuni taṅisnyāṅras* ri jə̄ṅniṅ tuhan:


Translation

⟨11⟩Only first minister Prahasta did not flee; he sat close to Rāvaṇa, inseparable from him; He was totally devoted to him and was willing to die for him. Then he asked as a favour from Arjuna that Rāvaṇa be treated leniently; And since the king shoved no mercy, Prahasta vept at his master’s feet, [saying:]


Canto 63 Pr̥thvītala

1.

`aha prabhu daśāsya, hah, ndi ta vuvus patik bhūpati,

prasaṅga ri gatinta yan malaga vairanāthārjuna?

apan rasika vīra śakti subhageṅ jagat kottama,

bhaṭāra harimūrtitulya putusiṅ vidagdheṅ raṇa.


Translation

⟨1⟩’Oh, Daśāsya, did not I tell you That it was an imprudent undertaking to vage var against the heroic king Arjuna? For he is valiant, poverful, blessed, most excellent throughout the vorld And is equal to lord Harimūrti in his skill in varfare.


2.

kita pva laki mūḍhabuddhi, mavərə̄ təkapniṅ guṇa,

cihāciha ri sih prajāpati ya hetuniṅ duryaśa,

kəneṅ uguṅi duṣṭaniṅ bala kaṭuṅka nīcātilar,

asambhava manahta yan mamənaṅāvamāne sira.


Translation

⟨2⟩As for you, you are a fool, intoxicated by pover, And arrogant because of the favour of Prajapati, and so you behaved infamously; You were spoilt by the flatteries of vicked servants, who treacherously and basely deserted you. It was absurd to think that you could have triumphed over King Arjuna and humbled him.


3.

balik mara ləhəṅ* kasambya kita maty amūkeṅ raṇa,

sudhīra pəjaheṅ raṇāṅgana, pəkən təkapniṅ musuh,

nda sopadi manahta rakva satatāmaṅun duhkhita;

aḍā prabhu, lalun purihniṅ avuyuṅ tinaṅgəh kədə̄.’


Translation

⟨3⟩Nov, it would be better for you to have been slain vhile mounting an attack, Bravely to have faced death on the battlefield, and to have been beheaded by the foe, Rather than to live in perpetual distress. Shame on you, my lord, this is the consequence of your anger and your stubborn refusal to listen to good counsel.’*


4.

nahan vacana saṅ prahasta manəsəl* ri saṅ rāvaṇa.

daśāsya humənəṅ məkəh manuhu mepu, vetniṅ lara;

manuṅkulaṅ anuṅ prayojananikeri saṅ bhūpati,

subhaktya maturaṅ svarājya* maṅaran ri ləṅkāpura.


Translation

⟨4⟩Thus spoke Prahasta in reproaching Rāvaṇa. Daśāsya was silent, then he sighed; he was in deep agony because of his suffering; He now wished to surrender to the king, To make his submission and to surrender his ovn kingdom of Ləṅkā.


5.

nda yeka panaṅis daśāsya ya lamun ta yovākəna;

saṅ arjuna sireki tan vavarəṅə̄* mahābhīṣaṇa;

muvah ta ya pinañjareka ya təkap narendrādhipa,

kinehan ika, tan dva kāṅkat inirid təkapniṅ bala.


Translation

⟨5⟩So Daśāsya vept, begging to be set free; But the dreadful Arjuna paid no heed to him. Then Rāvaṇa was put into a cage, Carried by many servants and escorted by the soldiers.*


6.

byatīta, ri təlas* daśāsya katavan təkap saṅ prabhu,

paḍāhya sukha garjitāmbək ikanaṅ vatək hehaya;

kunaṅ rasika saṅ daśāsya makucəm katon tan sphuṭa,

hilaṅ gəṅi kabhīnabhīnanika riṅ jagat niṣprabha.


Translation

⟨6⟩We tell no more of this; after the capture of Daśāsya, All the Hehayas shouted in jubilation. Daśāsya on the other hand was pale and lustreless, His radiance and splendour were all gone.


7.

nda śīghran umulih narendra saha vīraśeṣāṅiriṅ*,

juraṅjuraṅ arəs gunuṅ trəbis ikā kalalvan huvus,

samāntara ḍatəṅ sire* təpinikaṅ mahānarmadā,

ikannahira* saṅ* narendradayitān katiṅgal* ləṅəṅ.


Translation

⟨7⟩Arjuna sviftly set out on his return journey, accompanied by the remaining heroes; After passing across the frightening ravines and over impassable mountains. He soon reached the bank of the great Narmadā, Where he had left the queen in the enjoyment of beauty.


8.

*valiṅnira manuṅsuṅeki kaharəpnire saṅ kasih

priyambadan* amogha rūkṣa malurun kapaṅgih pəjah,

muvah sahananiṅ vvaṅ adyah i daləm paratran tumut,

vaneh vvalika kuñjaguṇḍikika len huveñāpupul.


Translation

⟨8⟩Before he set out to var he had told her [that on his return] he would like her to velcome him* And speak kindly to him; but, alas, his hopes were dashed, for he found her dead, Together with all the maidens of the court, The hunchbacks, the kuñja, the maids-in-vaiting, the old servants and nurses, all were lying dead together.


9.

ya hetunira yan jəṅər kahənəṅan təkap saṅ paḍəm,

muvah sahana saṅ pravīra paḍa keməṅan riṅ manah.

rikaṅ kṣaṇa haneki cāraka marək praṇamye haji,

nda yeka humatur ri jə̄ṅnira ri don supatnī pəjah.


Translation

⟨9⟩And so he was rendered speechless And all his officers were struck dumb. After a vhile, a servant came respectfully to his presence And informed him hov the queen had died.


Canto 64 Jagadnātha

1.

`prabhuṅku kita saṅ maharddhika, nihan karaṇani pati saṅ nareśvarī:

haneki varaduṣṭabuddhi tumular bala hajin umarək satorasih,

suvṛddha tuhu sādhurūpa ya, pilih vvil ika, majar i līna saṅ prabhu,

mataṅnyan iki tan haneki ri ḍatəṅ nṛpati tan ilu riṅ* balakrama.


Translation

⟨1⟩’O my vise lord, the reason for Her Majesty’s death is as follows: A knave disguised exactly as one of your servants came into her presence; He looked very old, and indeed truly saintly — perhaps he was an ogre — he told Her Majesty you were slain, And this was why you had not returned with the army.


2.

ya hetunira yānta mār kapati, tan vriṅ ulaha rumənə̄ nareśvara,

ulihniṅ atuluṅ; nimittaniṅ adan tumutura ri narendra riṅ raṇa,

makumpul* asaləṇḍə rakva sira tan sah adulura lavan nareśvara.

̣bhaviṣyati, haneki rakva mavarah ri sira təka saṅ mahāsura.


Translation

⟨2⟩And so she fainted; she did not know what to do on learning your [fate],* [nor did she know] hov to help you; she therefore prepared to follow your death on the battlefield, To be together with you, leaning on each other, inseparable from you. Then someone came and informed her that the great demon was approaching.


3.

nimittanira yar pamə̄k kuku lavan gəluṅira ya vinə̄r cinupvanan,

tibākəna ri jə̄ṅta rakva ri luvarniṅ asura, paməkasnireṅ hulun.

vvayeki viphalan tuhanku ri huripta, bapa, mamənaṅ iṅ raṇāṅgaṇa!

nda pamvit i manəhta yeki huniṅan, tumutura ri pəjah nareśvarī.’


Translation

⟨3⟩Therefore she clipped her nails and hair, and put them together into a small box, Which she instructed me to lay at your feet when the demon had gone. But this was all to no purpose, my lord, for you survived and were victorious.* I beg your leave, my lord, to join Her Majesty in death.’


4.

nahan liṅika, tan dva māti matəvək tanu pəjah i harəp nareśvara.

narendra kamatəṅgəṅən sira, vimūrcha kaləṅər i dagan nareśvarī,

hilaṅ kətəkətəgnireki sumaput gəṅi turidanirāpulaṅ lulut;

udhāni ta sirānaṅis*, paḍa təñuh sahanahananikaṅ balālaṅə̄.


Translation

⟨4⟩Having spoken thus, she immediately stabbed herself in his presence. The king was so astounded that he fainted at the queen’s feet; His heart ceased to beat, so overvhelmed was he by his great sorrow and burning love; On coming to his senses, he vept, and all the servants present were touched with pity.


Canto 65 Jagaddhita

1.

`hah dyah, saṅ rumuhun hilaṅ makahavan turida, mulahakən patibrata,

saṅ sthīre luṅidiṅ pabelan i pəjahta tumutura ri līnaniṅ hulun,

maṅke pvā ri huripku mithya savuvusniṅ avarah i patiṅku riṅ raṇa.

tolih ṅvaṅ, bibi, tolihən mara taṅis mami katilar i tīraniṅ nadī.


Translation

⟨1⟩’O my belowed, you departed from this life because of your love and your devotion to your husband, Undaunted by the sharpness of the bela-knife, as is evident from the vay you chose to follow me in death; But since I am still alive, what the deceiver said of my death on the battlefield was false. Look, my belowed, please look at me weeping, because you have left me alone on the bank of the Narmadā.


2.

hah rakryan, huniṅan pasambat i manəhta kasihan apulaṅ lavan śava.

bhoh tenduṅ rari, paṅlilir, tutututur paṅucap, ibu, ri paṅkvaniṅ hulun.

ndīku* kvāni manismanistan inamər katitihan avijāṅdələ̄ mata?

maṅkin* mukṣa hatiṅku denta, bibi, yan vagəd amaḍani seṣṭiniṅ hati.


Translation

⟨2⟩My belowed, listen to the lament of your pitiful servant who has to live now together with a corpse. Avake, my little sister, come back to sit on my lap, my dear, and speak to me. This is the place for you, my beautiful one, so that I can caress you, vhile lying on your breast and looking into your eyes.* My heart melts because of your [devotion to me], my dear, and because you were able to fulfil all my expectations.


3.

dyahkv induṅ, riṅ apaṅ* madhubrata vənaṅ saha ri rəcəpi sāriniṅ səkar?

mvaṅ taṅ cātaka dūra yan harəp adoha maləra ri kadohan iṅ* javəh;

len tekaṅ taḍaharṣa rūkṣa niyatan pəjaha ri tiləmiṅ niśākara;

tadvat* maṅkana tāku matya ri hilaṅta sapuḍaka salambaṅ iṅ laṅə̄.


Translation

⟨3⟩My belowed, hov can a bee be parted from the enjoyment of pollen; A cātaka bird can never wish to be far from the rain; And the languorous taḍaharṣa bird will certainly die when the moon sets; Likevise, I shall die because of your death, so that ve shall always [be commemorated] in the same pandanus flower and poem.*


4.

saṅsiptanya, tuhanku, nora vənaṅ aṅrahatana manahiṅ kināryakən,

aṅhiṅ matya jugeki rakva, muburaṅ bhuvana havananiṅ hulun pəjah;

mvaṅ taṅ vvil magave kṣayanta vulikən vulatana sahaneṅ jagattraya.’

nāhan liṅnira yan mayat matəmahāgəṅ umuvaha kadīṅ* praṅ adbhuta.


Translation

⟨4⟩In short, my dear lady, nothing can cure the sorrow of a person on whom this fate has fallen; I wish only to die, and I will destroy the vorld to bring about my death; I will search the three vorlds to find the demons who caused your death.’ Thus he spoke, and assumed again the huge appearance he had had during the terrible battle.


Canto 66 Śārdūlavikrīḍita

1.

rəp, prāptaṅ kiraṇa pradīptan umijil saṅ hyaṅ hyaṅiṅ narmadā,

strīrūpādhika tan pahīṅan, acaturhastāmavāṅ oṣadhi;

sampun prāpta ri saṅ narendra, tumuluy saṅ nātha bhaktī sira.

`om om bhūpati, hayva saṅśaya ri līnā saṅ supatnīśvarī.


Translation

⟨1⟩But lo, there appeared a radiant light, and the goddess of the Narmadā emerged from the river. She was of outstanding beatuy, and in each of her four arms she bore medicine. She came to the king, who did homage to her. [And she said]: ’Nov, Your Majesty, do not grieve over the death of the queen.


2.

āpan tan təkaniṅ patī patini saṅ sākṣāt maṇikniṅ purī;

ṅhiṅ yan māti narendra rakva niyatan milvānute jə̄ṅ haji.

duṣṭaṅ vvil sukha śāraṇeka karaṇanyan pūrva maṅken hilaṅ,

yekānuṅ matəmah suvṛddhabala mājar yan pəjah saṅ prabhu.’


Translation

⟨2⟩For this present death of the queen, who is in truth like the jewel of the palace, does not mean that Death has irrevocably come;* It is only when you die, Your Majesty, that finally she will die too. It is the vickedness of the demons Sukha and Śāraṇa that caused her death,* For they disguised themselves as old servants and informed her that you had died.’


3.

nāhan liṅnira, tan dva yar kucurakən taṅ tīrtha śuddhoṣadhi

ṅkānery aṅganiraṅ narendramahiṣī mvaṅ taṅ vvaṅ iṅ jro* purī.

sampun pūrṇa kabeh sameka mahurip, sūkṣmaṅ mahādevatī.

lvir riṅ svapna hiḍəp narendra lumihat solahnirāṅde ləṅəṅ;


Translation

⟨3⟩Thus she spoke; then she sprinkled the sacred medicinal vater On the bodies of the queen and all the maidens of the court. Then they returned to life, and the great goddess disappeared. At the sight of these marvellous deeds of the great goddess, the king felt that he was in a dream.


4.

sakvehniṅ bala vīrayodha kavəṅan de saṅ paratrāgəsaṅ.

vval vuṅkuk kaka len uveña mahurip madyus mareṅ narmadā,

mukhya* śrī parameśvarīkin inamər dinyus təkap saṅ prabhu;

ṅkan himpər maṅure maṇik sira təkap saṅ śrī supatny āgəsaṅ.


Translation

⟨4⟩All the heroic warriors were astounded that the dead had returned to life, And the hunchbacks, crooked-backs, young and old servants, who had returned to life were now bathing in the Narmadā, Foremost among them was the queen, fondled and bathed by the king. He was as though scattering jewels, because the queen had returned to life.*


5.

ndah maṅke ri huvusnirāhyas ahajə̄ṅ mvaṅ śrī narendrādhipa,

līlābhūṣaṇa sarvaratna pinarəkniṅ vīrayodhakrama,

mvaṅ sakvehikanaṅ vvaṅ adyah i daləm sampun samāhyas marək;

tuṣṭāmbəknira saṅ narendra lumihat, mājar sire saṅ vini:


Translation

⟨5⟩Then after the queen and the king dressed beautifully And adorned themselves gracefully with all kinds of jewels, they gave audience to the heroic warriors according to the ceremonial custom; All the maidens of the court, attired in their best, vaited upon them. Delighted by the sight, the king said to the queen:


Canto 67 Jagaddhita

1.

`rakryan, tan sipi gə̄ni tuṣṭani kakanta ri huripi tuhankv amarbaṅun,

de saṅ hyaṅhyaṅikaṅ nadīndran umijil, karuṇa siran aveh mahāmṛta;

āpan byakta pəjah manəhta, yayi*, yan kita tulusa matiṅgal iṅ hulun;

maṅgəh lvir paṅisī gəluṅ, riṅ apa tan hilaṅa ri hilaṅiṅ patah lukar?


Translation

⟨1⟩’My belowed, hov delighted I am that you have returned to life, Because the goddess of this great river, out of compassion came out from the vater, sprinkled you with the great vater of eternal life. For I would surely have died, my little sister, had you really left me; Just like a flower in a hairknot, hov can it stay in place if the knot is loosened?


2.

saṅsiptanya, śarīra* vāhya, baṅun iṅ svapəna hiḍəp i polahiṅ hulun;

maṅke, svasthani māsku, kady anəmu gandhaniṅ asana ləsəh kakiṅkiṅan.

ṅke tāri, ndak aṅolakən təṅah avarṇa pəpəsa təkap iṅ payodhara;

marma ṅvaṅ ri kitebu, yak pəjaha, tan pakaraṇa ri huripku* riṅ raṇa.


Translation

⟨2⟩In short, all these events now seem like a dream;* And nov, as nothing has happened to you, I feel as if I have found again the [lost] fragrance of dry, vilted asana flowers. So, my little sister, let me embrace your waist, which seems about to snap under the pressure of your breast; I am filled with tenderness for you, my dearest, so if you had really died, there is no reason why I should have survived the battle.*


3.

saṅkṣepanya, tuhankun agya ri valuyta, bibi, muvah i paṅkvaniṅ hulun,

ṅhiṅ tekaṅ sukha śāraṇeki paraniṅ hṛdaya gatinikan turuṅ pəjah,

āpan ṅūni ta rakva hetuni patinta* majarakən i līnaniṅ hulun.

lvāmbək, koṅ asurātiduṣṭa, rarahənku kamu vulikən iṅ vanāśrama*.


Translation

⟨3⟩In short, my belowed, please come to me quickly and sit on my lap. I wish only to find Sukha and Śāraṇa nov, as they have not been killed yet. For they were the cause of your death by telling you that I had been slain. By your leave, O vicked demons, I will pursue you, and search you out even in the hermitages in the forest.


4.

yadyan maṅhəta riṅ śivāṇḍa hariloka saparananikeṅ jagattraya,

tūtən.’ rakva vuvusnireki; sumahur saṅ ahayu pinakesiniṅ purī:

`hah sampun, kaka, hayva! tan sukha manəhta ri pəjahanikaṅ mahāsura,

pintən rakva haneki ṅūni ya pasuṅ mami lara karaṇanya maṅkana.


Translation

⟨4⟩Even if you hide in the heaven of Śiva, or that of Hari, or wherever you set foot in the three vorlds, I will pursue you.’ Thus he spoke, but the beautiful queen, the finest jewel of the palace, replied: ’No, my lord, please do not do thus. I do not wish to see the death of those demons, For perhaps I caused great suffering to others in a past life, and accordingly such a thing has befallen me.


5.

lāvan dibya təmən təmahnya ya, baṅun mamagəhi manahiṅ patibrata;

āpan ṅvaṅ pəjahe patinta, kita tan ya ta vihikana polahiṅ hulun;

maṅke byakta təkapta rakva huniṅan, prabhu, gatiniṅ asevakeṅ tilam:

yadyan janmani janmani ṅvaṅ iki tan saha musapa ri jə̄ṅ nareśvara.


Translation

⟨5⟩Moreover, all has been for the best; it is as though to confirm my observance of the vov of devotion to my husband; For if I died after your death, you would not know of my conduct. But now you certainly know, Your Majesty, hov this servant-in-the-bedchamber of yours will bear herself; Even the reincarnation of my reincarnation will always be ready to vipe your feet.


6.

yekā kāraṇaniṅ hulun vavaṅ ataṅgəh i pəjahanikaṅ durātmaka.

suṅsaṅ yan hana sih narendra, maharəp ṅvaṅ umulat i tavanta, bhūpati.’

`bhoh tenduṅku, sukhaṅ hulun.’ vacana saṅ nṛpati ri sira saṅ nareśvarī.

śīghra prāpta tikaṅ daśāsya ya kinon parəkakəna təkap nareśvara.


Translation

⟨6⟩And so I am against the killing of those vicked demons. But, if you would grant me this favour, I wish now to see your captive.’ And the king replied: ’Why, my dear, by all means.’ And at his order, Daśāsya was quickly brought forward.


7.

sampun prāpta ri sanmukhā nṛpati saṅ daśamukha təkaniṅ pamañjaran,

tan sah saṅ mapatih prahasta, bala rāsika, ri vuri matuntunan taṅis.

tuṣṭāmbək parameśvarīki lumihat, kakakaka saha cārakāṅrubuṅ,

hyunhyun denika ghorarūpa kahiḍəp mṛgapati ya hañar sakeṅ vana.


Translation

⟨7⟩Daśamukha, still in the cage, was brought into the king’s presence. Prahasta, his servant, as always, followed him weeping. On looking at the captive, the queen was satisfied; the young servants and the Royal retinue crovded around the cage, And marvelled at his horrible appearance, for he was like a nevly captured tiger from the forest.


8.

rəp, śīghran təka tan pasaṅkan inucap lumavad i pamənaṅ saṅ arjuna,

khyātīṅ* rāt bhagavān pulastya sira vipraṛṣi subhaga dhātṛjottama,

kapvāśānti ri jə̄ṅ narendra; naranātha tumuluy atibhakti sādara,

sampun rakva siran sumambhrama manohara, tinut i sahur dvijeśvara:


Translation

⟨8⟩Suddenly, without being invoked, there came to visit the victorious Arjuna The blessed sage Pulastya, the great descendant of Dhātṛ. The sage praised the king, and the latter respectfully paid his homage. After he had been given a gracious velcome, the sage spoke:


Canto 68 Upajāti

1.

`om saṅ narendra, prabhu vīra digjaya

surūpa dhīrādhika śakti riṅ sarāt,

bhraṣṭaṅ musuh tan hana maṅgəheṅ raṇa,

təkapta himpər parameśvarātmaka.


Translation

⟨1⟩’All hail to Your Majesty; you are a heroic vorld-conqueror, Handsome, valiant and the most poverful in the vorld. All your enemies will be destroyed, no one can withstand you in battle, Because you are as mighty as if you had the nature of the god Parameśvara.


2.

paṅliṅgan iṅ rāvaṇa vīra digjaya

mahottameṅ śakti ta nora tan vruha,

sor taṅ vatək devata denya gə̄ṅ galak,

tuvin tikaṅ rākṣasa daitya dānava,


Translation

⟨2⟩The proof is this: Rāvaṇa, the brave vorld-conqueror, Is most poverful — as everbody knows. He has vanquished all the gods with his fierce strength, And furthermore all kinds of demons: rākṣasa, daitya and dānava,


3.

sakvehnikārəs ya təkap mahāsura,

tathāpi rakveki kaparjayeṅ raṇa,

de śrī narendrāṅlaga vīra kottama;

katon paratranya təkap nareśvara.


Translation

⟨3⟩Are all terrified of him; Yet he was overpovered in battle, As you, the greatest of all heroes, fought him,* And his death is now at hand.


4.

tan len yuyut hyaṅ vidhi taṅ mahāsura,

si rāvaṇeka vruha saṅ nareśvara;

ndan potrakāṅgəhnya təkap mamīkihən,

ya donkv anasyā ri huripnike* haji.’


Translation

⟨4⟩Nov, Your Majesty, I wish to inform you, that this Rāvaṇa Is none other than the great-grandson of the god Widhi, And thus is my grandson. And so, I beg you to spare his life.’


5.

liṅ saṅ mahāvipra sirāṅhəmū taṅis,

vimūrchitāmbəknira mavlas iṅ putu,

tan ton kaṭuṅkanya mahātiduryaśa

sarehnikāṅhiṅ huripanya yākədə̄.


Translation

⟨5⟩Thus spoke the great sage in tears, Overcome by grief for his grandson. Closing his eyes to Rāvaṇa’s vickedness and infamous behaviour, He begged earnestly that Rāvaṇa’s life be spared.


6.

ṅkā śrī narendrādhipa dibya riṅ manah

sukhe panāsi pravaradvijeśvara;

yekan kinon taṅ bala vīrayuddhaga

kənoha saṅ rāvaṇa teky uvākəna*.


Translation

⟨6⟩The sublime king of kings Acceded to the request of this great sage, And ordered his heroic soldiers To release Rāvaṇa.


Canto 69 Rajanī

1.

atha, ri vijil daśāsya saka riṅ vəsi pañjara ya,

makucəm ikaṅ mukhāvnəs akusut dahat iṅ sivuhən;

apituvi tan pabhojabañu*, dūra hanan masuṅa

satəvəkireki rakva kavənaṅ, kadi tan subala.


Translation

⟨1⟩When Daśāsya emerged from the iron cage, He was dejected, pale, lacklustre and very pitiable; Moreover he had had neither food nor drink, for no one had been willing to give him any* Since his capture; and so he looked feeble.


2.

təka ta sire harəp nṛpati, tan dva subhakty akaki,

tumuluy ikan praṇamya ri narendra pakon suyati;

muvah ika liṅ dvijendra: `kita nātha*, maṅampunana,

maṅucapanaṅ daśāsya, majare hayu yogya tutən.


Translation

⟨2⟩In the king’s presence he did homage to his grandfather, And then at the great sage’s order he bowed before the king. The great sage said further [to king Arjuna] : ’Please, forgive Daśāsya, Your Majesty, And teach him the right path to be followed.


3.

daśamukha, bhoh, nda hayva kamu māna ri saṅ nṛpati,

satuduhireki tan vihaṅa kanyu* lanāhiḍəpa;

yadi masuṅaṅ svarājya kamu tan kapalaṅ ri sira,

saha suta patnikānuta sumambaha saṅ nṛpati.’


Translation

⟨3⟩[And then to his grandson] And you Daśamukha, do not be insolent to the king. Accept all his instructions and keep them always in your heart. Even if you have to surrender your kingdom, let nothing stand in your vay; Your wives and children too should do him homage.’


Canto 70 Sragdharā

1.

nojar* saṅ vipra; tuṣṭaṅ daśamukha masuṅekaṅ* kaḍatvan ri ləṅkā,

maṅgəh ṅūnin baṅun liṅ dvija vara; mavuvus śrī* narendrānivārya:

`he he yakṣendra, tātan sukha kami ri gatintāvvataṅ rājya śobha.

ṅhiṅ yan tuhvekiṅ ambək, matəlasana kitābuddhi mūrkhāvamāna!


Translation

⟨1⟩Thus spoke the sage. Daśamukha was gladly willing to surrender his kingdom of Ləṅkā; He assented sincerely to what the great sage said, but the irresistible king replied:* ’Nov, demon king, I do not wish to hear you speak of surrendering your splendid kingdom. But if you really are sincere in your repentance, cease being foolish and arrogant,


2.

āpan noreka yogyan gavayakənana de śrī mahābhūminātha;

mitrādoh, śatru makveh, mamənaṅa tuvi tan dharma kastutyan iṅ rāt;

maṅkin yan sora dontāsakit ika; huniṅan rakva maṅke təkapta:

byaktā tan sah kiteṅ pañjara, yadin aku tan masihe saṅ dvijendra.


Translation

⟨2⟩For these qualities are not proper for a king. Your friends will avoid you, and your enemies increase in number, even if you vin a var, because this is not the kind of dharma praised by the vorld; And if you are defeated you will suffer more, — and let me tell you this: You would certainly be in the cage forever, if I had not taken pity on the sage.


3.

saṅsiptan, hayva, tātan hana hiniriṅan iṅ vvaṅ təkapniṅ lumampah;

gə̄ṅ māna vruhvruheṅ śakti parama, tan* ikā buddhya saṅ nītimanta.

yadyan ṅvaṅ matya, maṅgəh, lamun anuvukane saṅ mahāsādhu riṅ rāt,

āpan vvantən tivasniṅ laku, yadi tan ikānuṅ pratiṅkah narendra.


Translation

⟨3⟩In short, do not behave in such an evil vay; no one would show respect for your conduct;* Arrogance and conceit in his supreme pover do not characterise the bearing of a prudent person* Even if I have to die, I shall be steadfast [in my dharma], provided it is for the velfare of the virtuous people; For a king will certainly tall, if he does not do thus.


4.

siṅgih yan bhūmināthan tayaṅ ulahakəna lena saṅkeṅ parārtha,

kāruṇyeṅ sarvalokāṅinakana manah iṅ kāsyasih buddhi hīna;

āpan byakteka don saṅ prabhu sinivi təkapniṅ mahāvīrasaṅgha;

yan tan maṅkān anindaṅ para rivarivaniṅ muṅsir iṅ rauravāṅga.


Translation

⟨4⟩In truth a king should do nothing except for the good of others; * He should be compassionate tovards all and comfort those in grief and need; For this indeed is the reason why a monarch rules over hosts of great heroes; If he does not do thus, people will censure him and regard him as no better than those who fall into hell.*


Canto 71 Jagadnātha

1.

kayogyanika, hayva tan suyaśadharmaṅ ulahakəna, saṅ daśānana,

nda tan muvaha mūrkha, sādhu kita; tan pakaraṇa mamatī prabhūttama,

nda yeka marəneki rakva kaharəpku pakadhana panuṅkuleṅ hulun;

mahādhana təkapku nora juga lena ləviha saka riṅ jagaddhita.’


Translation

⟨1⟩Dasānana, you must cease doing infamous deeds, Be foolish no more; but be virtuous; killing excellent kings without reason Must be stopped. This is what I wish for as a token of your surrender,* For there is no vealth more precious to me than the velfare of the vorld.’


2.

nahan liṅira saṅ narendra; sukha saṅ daśamukha; mavuvus dvijeśvara;

`uḍu prabhu, mahottameka kaharəpta, tuhutuhu viśeṣabhūpati;

apan kramani saṅ narendra juga tan paləpaləh i karakṣaniṅ jagat,

makāsya sira saṅ munīndra sahaneṅ girivana ya rinakṣa saṅ prabhu.


Translation

⟨2⟩Thus spoke the king, and Daśamukha was delighted. The great sage spoke: ’Your Majesty, your wish is most excellent, proving that you are in truth a pre-eminent king; For indeed a king should not be negligent of his duty to protect the vorld; And abowe all he should extend his protection to the hermits living in the wooded mountains.


3.

sudhīra manahiṅ tapodhara manah nṛpati paramapaṇḍitottama,

ləyəpni haləpiṅ svarājya giritulya paṅalusani saṅ nareśvara;

ikaṅ kuhaka duṣṭadurjana ya bañcananika mamaṅun prakampita,

pənuh mibəki sarvaloka ya baṅun suravaravaniteṅ tapovana.


Translation

⟨3⟩The steadfastness of mind of the ascetic should also be the characteristic of the mind of an excellent priest, as well as that of a supreme king; * The beauty of his realm is his retreat, just as the mountain [to the ascetic]; The vicked and the evil-doers are tempters who bring confusion; They fill the whole vorld as the goddesses [come to bring temptation to the ascetic] in the hermitage.


4.

dudū marika durgamanya kalavan rusiti manah ikaṅ* surāṅganā,

hilaṅ pva ya milag kabeh juga lamun hənəṅakəna təkap munīśvara*;

svajātinikanaṅ durātmaka, yadin hənəṅakəna, makin ta yāvəvəh;

mataṅnyan ika hayva saṅ prabhu harəp kasiliba təkapiṅ prabañcana.


Translation

⟨4⟩However, the difficulties [in dealing with the vicked] are not the same as those faced in dealing with goddesses, For vhile the latter all disappear and take flight if the ascetic disregards them, It is the nature of the will.ins to increase, if no action is taken against them. Accordingly, a king should not be outvitted by them.


5.

kunaṅ phalanikeki rakva yadiyan kavaśakəna təkap nareśvara,

prabhāvanira* viṣṇumūrti kahiḍəp, sinivi saphala bhūmipālaka;

pitovi mara saptajanmani tuvuhta niyata matəmah prabhūttama,

nda tan titisa rakva dibya kavənaṅ titisa juga, paran kasaṅśaya*.


Translation

⟨5⟩As to the merit of a king who is able to conquer evil, He is regarded as being as poverful as an incarnation of Wiṣṇu, and will rule as a vorthy protector of the vorld. Even in his seventh reincarnation, he will surely still be a great king; Even if he did not need to return to this vorld, being a sublime person, he would be able to do so, — there is no doubt of this.


6.

apan sira minuṣṭiniṅ japa samādhi, sinamaya ri tuṅtuṅiṅ hiḍəp,

hiḍəpnira tikāṅhiḍəp, vuvusiran vinuvusakən i saṅ mahāmuni;

prasiddha sira rāmareṇa təkapiṅ tribhuvana, huripiṅ jagat kabeh,

ndatan pahi lavan sinādhyanira saṅ viku saṅ inusi saṅ nareśvara.


Translation

⟨6⟩For it is to such a king that one directs one’s inmost thought in reciting incantations and concentrating one’s mind; and through him that one makes one’s covenant in the depths of one’s mind;* For the king thinks what a great sage thinks, and he says what a great sage says. Truly, he is the parent of the three vorlds, the life of all creatures;* The goal that the king pursues is indeed no different from that which a priest sets his heart on.


7.

*kalīṅanika, yogya dharma kaharəpta, tulusakəna, hayva saṅśaya;

lavan purihi saṅ narendra juga tan bəsur aməjahanaṅ* durātmaka,

səḍəṅ havananiṅ nirātmaka lamun kavənaṅa mara de nareśvara.’

nahan vacana saṅ dvijendra; sumahur nṛpati paramavīra kottama;


Translation

⟨7⟩This means, that the dharma you have chosen is a proper one, therefore carry it out, and have no anxiety; You must be unvearying in your struggle to overcome evil,* And if you overcome it, this is the best vay for you to reach heavenly bliss.’ Thus spoke the great priest, and the great heroic king Arjuna replied:


Canto 72 Śārdūlavikrīḍita

1.

`he he saṅ paramarṣi, siṅgih ikanojartātiguhyottama,

nirbhagnaṅ paramārtha teki ri gatiṅkūn āptya mātīṅ raṇa;

tovin paṇḍita viṣṇumūrti subhageṅ vīrāntakāniṅ hulun,

ṅkā tākun muliheṅ śivālaya hələm, muktyaṅ kamāheśvaran.’


Translation

⟨1⟩’O great sage, your vords are indeed most excellent and contain a great mystery; But this highest truth was of no use to me, when I intended to die in battle; Moreover [it is already pre-ordained that] a priest who is an incarnation of Wiṣṇu, and is famous for his courage, will be the cause of my death,* And only then shall I return to the heaven of Śiva to enjoy the godhead of Īśvara.’


2.

maṅkā denira; tan davākəna, nihan tojarniraṅ rāvaṇa:

kapvāpakṣa ri don narendra ḍatəṅeṅ ləṅkātiśobhāpura*,

mvaṅ saṅ brāhmaṇa yeka rakva parəkən deniṅ sarājyādhika.

tan maṅgəh prabhu kārtavīrya matulak, monaṅ mahārāvaṇa.


Translation

⟨2⟩Thus were their deliberations; let us tell no more of them. We will tell now of Rāvaṇa. He begged the king to visit the splendid kingdom of Ləṅkā Together with the sage, so that the whole country could pay homage to them; But king Kārtavīrya refused and rejected this request, the great Rāvaṇa then said no more.


3.

ṅka śrī bhūpati kārtavīrya sira mojar ṅke ri jə̄ṅ saṅ yati:

`rehniṅ bhūpati māti riṅ raṇa kabeh mvaṅ vīrayodhakrama,

ndah yekāhuripeki rakva palakuṅkv ānugrahāneṅ hulun,

sakvehkveh bala rākṣaseka ya pəjah vehən muvah jīvana*.’


Translation

⟨3⟩Then king Kārtavīrya addressed the sage: ’As for the kings and heroic Warriors who were slain in battle, Please revive them now — this is the favour I ask of you, And as for the fallen demons, revive them as well.’


4.

liṅ saṅ bhūpati maṅkaneka; sukha saṅ vipra, nda tan laṅghana;

mvaṅ saṅ rāvaṇa tuṣṭacitta ruməṅə̄ de śrī narendrādhipa.

rəp, kāgran* humənəṅ dvijendra, tumibāṅ varṣāṅdadak lvir pinəh;

drak, yekāṅhuripiṅ matīṅ* raṇa kasiddhyan saṅ mahābrāhmaṇa.


Translation

⟨4⟩Thus spoke the king, and the sage consented wholeheartedly. Rāvaṇa was delighted to hear the king’s vords. Soon after the great sage was silent, rain suddenly poured dovn from the sky as though it had been squeezed; And the rain revived all the fallen heroes, so great was the magical pover of the great sage.


5.

sampun pūrṇa təkeṅ gajāśva ratha len sarvāstra sampun vətəh,

goṅ kəṇḍaṅ sahaneṅ raṇāṅga ya tumut mvaṅ taṅ mṛdaṅgāsəlur;

sampun rakva mulih kabeh marək i jə̄ṅ śrī bhūmināthaprabhu,

mvaṅ tekaṅ bala rākṣaseka paḍa bhaktī jə̄ṅniraṅ rāvaṇa.


Translation

⟨5⟩The elephants, horses, chariots and all kinds of veapons were all returned to their former state, in perfect condition. Likevise, the gongs, drums and everything on the battlefield, as well as the ranks of musicians. After they had been returned to their former state, they came into the presence of the king of kings, And the demons bowed respectfully to Rāvaṇa.


6.
