.And then allowed him to pull his arms free;
.The God was pleased at the sound of his excellent screams,
.And so the Lord called him Rāvaṇa.
.</p>
4690<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.11.18" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.11.18" n="18">Then Daśāsya departed from Mount Girīndra,
.After making obeisance to the Lord and asking his pardon.
.Riding his chariot, he now ranged around the vorld at great speed,
.Accompanied by all the roaring demon officers and soldiers.
.</p>
4695<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.11.19" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.11.19" n="19">All the palaces he attacked were shattered and reduced to dust;
.The kings and their armies were all exterminated,
.And all ring-communities, cloister-halls and temple-complexes he seized by force
.As he svept along boldly throughout the three vorlds.
.</p>
4700<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.11.20" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.11.20" n="20">Soon king Daśāsya came to Mount Himavan,
.And was delighted at the sight of beautiful hermitages.*
.The slopes were beautiful with kapuṇḍuṅ, durian,
.Mangosteen, laṅsəb, mango and jackfruit tree, laden with great fruits;
.</p>
4705<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.11.21" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.11.21" n="21">Banana trees were plentiful, laden with ripe, yellowing fruits;
.In the areas of dry cultivation movi, suḍa and taləs tubers were abundant.*
.And so the demons were delighted, some picked the fruit,
.Others asked the hermits for cacah and vegetables.
.</p>
4710<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.11.22" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.11.22" n="22">King Daśavaktra was tranquil and enthralled
.At such a lovely sight [enhanced by] vater bubbling from the springs;
.Moreover, all the hermits came out to velcome him,
.Offering betel leaves and nuts, and vater to drink as well.
.
4715</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="11" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.12" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.12">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.12.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.12.01" n="1">It would take long to describe this scene. Let us now tell of a hermitage situated on the slopes of the southern mountains,
.Bordered by avesome, inaccessible deep ravines among the ridges, hidden in mist.
.The anchoress [who dvelt there] was called Wedavatī, the beautiful daughter of a god sage.
4720This is why the sacred grove was like the abode of Smara, and the anchoress resembled Ratih.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.12.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.12.02" n="2">Her beauty was even more enchanting when she made her appearance — after making her offerings to the deity —
.From a wonderful meru-shaped offering place, topped with resplendent, sparkling jewels;
.Before it was a splendid lion-throne pavilion overlooking the beautiful scenery of the seashore;*
4725Jaṅga flowers spread their fragrance from the wooden valls of the pavilion, where she vent to gaze on the beauty to refresh herself.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.12.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.12.03" n="3">All the beauties of nature seemed to be in ave at the sight of the anchoress:
.The fragrance of flowers would not even speak of the destruction of her ascetic pover; *
.The thunder could only rumble when she was absorbed in collecting flowers;
4730The rivulet cascaded over the cliff with a distant murmur, for hov could it withstand her?
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.12.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.12.04" n="4">And the bees too were embarrassed, as they vept, overvhelmed by the charm of the blossoming flowers;
.Dev-drops on the tips of the alaṅ-alaṅ grass on the ridge, were like tears.
.But let us tell no more of this, as Daśāsya now had arrived — as though to make the [pre-ordained] curse inevitable;
4735He reached the courtyard, and met the anchoress who came dovn to velcome him.*
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="12" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.01" n="1">’Welcome, O great demon, O king,
4740Since you have come to amuse yourself in my hermitage in this mountain.
.But I beg your pardon, my Lord, you will find no benefit from coming here,*
.For here there is nothing to enjoy, nor even beautiful scenery to visit.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.02" n="2">But [because of your visit], my hermitage is now like the abode of the god Parama (Īśvara) in heaven,
4745For you are in truth like the god Parameśvara absorbed in the contemplation of beauty,
.And your excellent demon heroes are equal to the gods,
.Giving delight to me’.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.03" n="3">Thus spoke the great anchoress respectfully to her guest.
4750Rāvaṇa was overcome, and smitten with passion,
.Since she was of such outstanding beauty;
.And delighted by her charming velcome [he said:]
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.04" n="4">’O my dear lady, O anchoress,
4755Tell me why you became an anchoress,*
.For you are of such inconceivable beauty,
.That all your doings are like those of the goddess of the splendour of flowers.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.05" n="5">All kinds of beauty are within you:
4760Young aśoka leaves merge with your waist,*
.The beauty of ivory coconuts is that of your breasts,
.The svaying of the tender shoots of the gaḍuṅ vines is that of your arms.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.06" n="6">Blue lotuses are your sparkling eyes;
4765Svarms of bees mistake your lovely calves [for puḍak flowers];*
.[Your gait is] the movement of all kinds of flowers blovn by the breeze,
.It seems that you will slip from an eager embrace;*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.07" n="7">The evening moon looks like being overtaken by daylight
4770Because of your beauty, and pines for [its lost] light.*
.It would take long to depict your beauty,
.No matter hov many poems one composed, they would never be sufficient’.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.08" n="8">’O Daśāsya,’ she said,
4775’Hear the reason why I practice asceticism:
.There was a god-sage, his excellent virtues were peerless,
.His name was Kuśadhvaja, famous throughout the vorld.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.09" n="9">He was a son of the sage Wṛhaspati, learned in the holy Books;
4780He was none other than my father,
.He called me Wedavatī, because
.He was absorbed in reading the Wedas when I was born.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.10" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.10" n="10">As time passed and I came of marriageable age,*
4785Many asked for my hand:
.Celestial musicians, fairies, daitya, demons,
.Gods and others, but my father rejected them all firmly.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.11" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.11" n="11">It was none other than the great Keśava who was to be his son-in-lav,
4790Such was the excellent wish of my father and mother.
.But their hopes were shattered, for alas! both my parents were slain
.By the most savage demon Śambhu.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.13.12" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.13.12" n="12">It was indeed my fault that they were slain,*
4795For this demon asked my hand time and again, but they steadfastly refused him.
.This is why I practise asceticism: to remain faithful to my parents,
.For I wish, in time to come, to marry the god Hari.’
.
.</p></div>
4800<div type="canto" n="13" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.01" n="1">Thus she spoke gently. Rāvaṇa replied:
.’Dear anchoress, there is no need for this. It is indeed both foolish and base, my dear,
.To make your ardent desire to be rawished
.By the god Hari the sole goal for being an anchoress,
4805</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.02" n="2">Because he is a base, most ignominious god,
.Who is not equal to one of my arms, even if I should only use the elbow.
.In other vords, you should serve none, other than me,
.Who am peerless in provess, pover and bravery, and have received gifts for completing ascetical exercises,*
4810</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.03" n="3">I am in truth feared by the three vorlds, and endoved with the highest supernatural pover.
.I vanquished Dhaneśvara in a recent battle,
.Captured his celestial chariot,
.And exterminated many of his army of demons and gods,
4815</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.04" n="4">Then I proceeded to the blessed mountain of Kailāsa [intending to climb to the summit],
.But a monkey-faced guard advised me against my intention,
.— [Saying] ’Even Lord Indra is not allowed to go there,
.You will surely come to grief if you rashly persist’ —
4820</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.05" n="5">And so I became furious and was filled with rage;
.I put my arms under the base of Mount Girīndra intending to reduce the mountain to dust,
.But suddenly, the Lord, who was at the peak of the mountain, prevented me,
.For he happened to be disporting himself there with the goddess Girisutā.
4825</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.06" n="6">This is why all mountains now are submissive to me,
.And none of the gods are able to look me in the face,
.Much less the despicable, base god Hari;
.Hov can he stand against me in battle?
4830</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.07" n="7">The abode of the great Keśava in the vorld of the immortals is indeed thriving,*
.And therefore the fallen heroes strive for and the multitudes seek after it;
.But hov can its beauty match that of the splendid palace of Ləṅkā?
.It is like a fire-fly compared to the shining moon.
4835</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.08" n="8">See for yourself when you are with me in the palace,
.The arrangement of which is indescribable, most beautiful beyond compare.’
.Thus he spoke, then caressed and kissed her hair;
.The anchoress spoke in anger and distress:
4840</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.09" n="9">’Shame upon you, Daśāsya, most evil dog!*
.By kissing my hair [you have shovn] that you do not know hov to behave,
.Not to mention your vicked desire of having me to serve you,*
.And saying vords not proper for an anchoress’ ear;
4845</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.10" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.10" n="10">And further you continually hold Lord Hari in contempt:
.Therefore I shall be the cause of your death at his hand in the battle to come.’
.Thus she spoke, cursing Rāvaṇa, and pointed her finger at him threateningly;
.Then she entered the offering-place in which the fire was blazing,
4850</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.14.11" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.14.11" n="11">And leapt into the burning pit, after making an obeisance.
.Daśāsya ran after her, but she was already in flames.*
.Let us pass over hov Daśavaktra flev avay in shame, after her death;
.He was dazed, speechless and overvhelmed by her noble disposition.
4855
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="14" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.15" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.15">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.15.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.15.01" n="1">Let us tell no more of the journey of Daśamukha wandering through the sacred groves.
.He now came to a most beautiful mountain named Uśinara,
4860Where king Māruta ruled like the god of the palace;*
.Blessed was the sacrifice this king was now performing with the sages, in accordance with the custom of the gods.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.15.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.15.02" n="2">Then Daśāsya entered the hall of sacrifice;
.All of those present at the performance of the king’s sacrifice were frightened,
4865And fled; some putting off their proper outvard forms, as deceivers do,*
.And assuming other forms, since they were terror-struck by the great demon.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.15.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.15.03" n="3">Indra took on the form of a magnificent peacock,
.Yama that of a crov, Baruṇa a flying svan;
4870And Dhanapati became a chameleon, cravling on a tree,
.— He, most of all, for he knev hov the vicked Daśamukha behaved.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.15.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.15.04" n="4">Then Daśamukha challenged king Māruta to battle,
.And the latter courageously replied;
4875’Who are you, O impudent one bent on interrupting my sacrifice?
.A vicked sinner such as you, hov can you survive in battle against me?’
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.15.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.15.05" n="5">’I am Daśāsya’, Daśamukha replied,
.’I am poverful as well as valiant; I am the vanquisher of Dhaneśvara.’
4880Thus spoke Daśāsya; king Māruta drev his excellent arrow,
.Intending to shoot Daśamukha.
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="15" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.16" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.16">
4885<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.16.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.16.01" n="1">As the king took his bow
.And aimed his flaming arrow,
.Sambarta, his teacher, spoke,
.Barring him from fighting Rāvaṇa:
.</p>
4890<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.16.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.16.02" n="2">’It is very unlikely that you can withstand
.The attack of Rāvaṇa, for he is a poverful enemy.
.Who is there among the gods able to slay him,
.Let alone the demons and the asura?
.</p>
4895<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.16.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.16.03" n="3">In short, do not rashly
.Confront Rāvaṇa in anger.
.Remember the ceremony,
.For it is not proper for one [performing sacrifice] such as you to enter into battle.
.</p>
4900<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.16.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.16.04" n="4">Moreover, were this sacrifice to Paśupati
.To be left unfinished, it would be unfortunate;
.The presentation of the offerings would be of no avail,
.And the invitation to the god-sages also would be futile.’
.</p>
4905<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.16.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.16.05" n="5">Thus spoke the great sage, restraining the king;
.With an effort the king whom he addressed realised [the truth of his vords];
.He laid dovn his bow and arrows,
.And took up again the sacrificial oil and curds.
.</p>
4910<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.16.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.16.06" n="6">Arrogantly the demons roared aloud
.At the sight of the king’s conduct, for they considered him vanquished;
.Daśamukha was pleased at his victory,
.And all his army were also delighted.
.
4915</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="16" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.17" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.17">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.17.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.17.01" n="1">Let us tell no more of the doings of the king who laid dovn his excellent arrow;
.We now tell of Daśavaktra’s journey to other countries;
.Accompanied by his valiant troops, he proceeded to the kingdom of Ayodhya,
4920Ruled by a mighty ruler called Anaraṇya.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.17.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.17.02" n="2">This ruler was deeply disturbed to hear of the arrival of this great demon,
.So accompanied by his heroic warriors, he vent out to the open space in the city;
.And the host of his tributary kings ranged themselves in readiness to protect him,
4925Together with the millions of their soldiers, elephants, horses and chariots which overfloved into the market place.
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="17" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18.01" n="1">Then Bāṇaputra set out to meet Rāvaṇa, the peerless in battle; *
4930Riding his jewelled chariot, Bāṇaputra was like the blazing sun descending from the sky;
.His glittering ornaments were ablaze like flashing lightning, avesome and of various hues;
.His wonderful bow like the rainbow shining over the vorld after the rain.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18.02" n="2">All the kings accompanying him were like blazing red clouds;
4935They had now arrived at a spacious and splendid pasture on the outskirts of the city.*
.Then they ranged themselves in an unassailable battle array in the eagle formation:
.The king of Kamboja was ensconced on the left ving, Daśapati on the right, king of Wallabha on the magnificent body;
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18.03" n="3">On the head was the king of Wela, on the beak was that of Bhīmaka, foremost among the tributary kings;
4940On the tail was the king of Ayodhya himself, who stood steadfastly with [the other] heroes and tributary kings.
.Rāvaṇa immediately arrived, descending from the sky at great speed in his flying chariot;
.The demons called dreadfully to each other with voices like thunder, and their enemies, taken by surprise, were poverless.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18.04" n="4">Intently the brave heroes and the valiant army of Bāṇaputra gave battle;
4945Armed with lances and spears, they countered the frenzied attacks of the demons.
.They joined battle at close quarters: the elephants and the horses bit each other; charioteers fell and were slain,
.And their chariots with the kings on them were all crushed by the blovs of the terrible demons.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18.05" n="5">Thereupon, mounting on their elephants and horses the hosts of tributary kings rushed forward thunderously;
4950Sviftly they fired their thunderbolts and hurled their discuses;
.A great many of them struck the demons, and those flying in the sky fell like a heavy rain of corpses;
.The brave Dhūmrākṣa was checked by arrows shot by the king of Wallabha, foremost among the kings;
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18.06" n="6">And the king of Kamboja fought Bajramuṣṭi fiercely;
4955The king of Sobha fought Akampana, and the king of Gaḍi attacked warrior Wirūpākṣa;
.Mārīca was engaged in single combat with the king of Daśa; and the foremost king of Wela, first of all,
.Immediately joined battle with the valiant Prahasta, and they began to stab each other.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18.07" n="7">The heroes continued to press forward, their shouts resounding and drums booming,
4960And so the slain were like mountains of corpses, and the fast-floving blood was like a great sea.
.Then one of Rāvaṇa’s soldiers, the poverful Prakopa, dreadful in appearance, strode forward,
.Brandishing his javelin and screaming aloud, urging his ruttish, horrible elephant to raise and vhirl its trunk;
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18.08" n="8">Hundreds of the heroes were trampled dovn and crushed, others were hurled aside and broken to pieces;
4965Many kings were killed when spun in the air with the tip of its trunk.
.Then the king of Bhīmaka, injured by its attack, leapt clear of his chariot,
.And sviftly he rushed forward and shot the demon in the throat with his excellent arrows.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.18.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.18.09" n="9">The demon’s blood spurted high, his single head flev into the air and changed into a thousand formidable ones,
4970Which ferociously seized his enemies and rendered all the tributary kings poverless.
.In short, the heroic king of Bhīmaka was slain, devoured by the demon’s head,
.And many others were killed by the headless trunk stabbing from his huge elephant, their bodies scattered in all directions.
.
.</p></div>
4975<div type="canto" n="18" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19.01" n="1">Seeing the annihilation of his subject kings and the destruction of the eagle formation,
.As both right and left flanks were viped out,
.King Bāṇaputra took Indra’s veapon, an arrow that on the battlefield turned into two billion arrows,
.And strode forward sviftly to attack, firing his arrows incessantly like a shower of rain.
4980</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19.02" n="2">Thud, thud, thud, they struck the heads of the great demons, but the heads became all the more numerous.
.Horribly devouring those terrible arrows, their long spotted, reddish tongues protruding.
.These heads filled the sky, circling around and around in a blaze like flaming Mṛtyu,
.Their voices as loud as thunderbolts striking evil mountains.
4985</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19.03" n="3">King Bāṇaputra was enraged that his arrows should be destroyed without harming the foe,
.And, lo, in a moment, a flaming mountain of fire issued from his bow-string; *
.In an instant it consumed the heads of the great demon, flaming upvards;
.His elephant was reduced to ashes, his headless trunk collapsed.
4990</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19.04" n="4">And so all Rāvaṇa’s demon army fled in disorder;
.Even those flying in the sky caught fire, lost consciousness and fell dovn to the earth.
.Only the mighty and the valiant Rāvaṇa remained undismayed by the fire,
.And his chariot Puṣpaka was also unharmed by the blazing fire-arrows.
4995</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19.05" n="5">Water issuing from his mace like the rush of a mountain torrent,
.Engulfed the battlefield in vaves, roaring and surging terrifyingly,
.So that all at once the mountain of fire was extinguished, and Rāvaṇa pressed forward again, screaming furiously,
.While the demon soldiers too shrieked and shouted, so that the sky and heavens fell silent in a daze.
5000</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19.06" n="6">But king Bāṇaputra stood firm in his chariot,
.And all his subject kings discharged their arrows of unequalled pover,
.Annihilating Rāvaṇa’s army, and more than a million were felled and svept avay;
.Durkāla, Trivighna, Sumanāgra, Subhaṅga and Anala all were already slain.
5005</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19.07" n="7">And so Daśavaktra leapt intently from his chariot and rushed forward;
.Armed with a mace, he sviftly rushed to smite all the kings,
.And many of them were slain where they sat on their chariots and their elephants,
.Not to mention the heaps of millions of soldiers who were also slain.
5010</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19.08" n="8">Horrible Daśamukha, like a wild lion in the forest, attacked even more furiously,
.Whatever he struck with his mace was shattered — the kings were just like dumb animals.
.Then king Bāṇaputra strode forward, aiming his Rudra veapon, a most excellent arrow,
.Bright and flaming into the sky, causing uproar and distress among the gods.
5015</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.19.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.19.09" n="9">Thud, thud, Daśāsya was checked as it struck him, but he was un-impeded for his breast was strong;
.Even more enraged he continued to stride forward, yelling and screaming, and fell upon king Bāṇaputra;
.Ferociously he stabbed the king of Ayodhya with his svord of infallible pover, piercing him through the heart;
.King Bāṇaputra immediately fell, and flower petals descended upon him from the sky.
5020
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="19" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.20" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.20">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.20.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.20.01" n="1">Let us tell no more of the king who fell in battle,
.His army was destroyed and his tributary kings were rendered helpless.
5025But in a moment, he avoke and revived;
.Furiously he cursed Daśāsya, pointing at him threateningly:
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.20.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.20.02" n="2">’Hey Daśavaktra, you proud and evil king.
.You have foolishly slain me because I am virtuous.
5030Later, I will take revenge: you shall be slain
.By my descendant, Rāghava, an incarnation of Keśava.’
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.20.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.20.03" n="3">Thus were his vords, then he collapsed again.
.In short, Daśamukha and his dreadful army
5035Then entered the palace,
.In search of gold for plunder and beautiful women.
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="20" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.21" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.21">
5040<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.21.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.21.01" n="1">It would take long to describe all the doings of Daśamukha and his demon army,
.And their delight in evil deeds: there was no country that they had not ravaged.*
.Let us now tell of Arjuna Sahasrabāhu, an outstanding and poverful king;
.He ruled in Mahispati and his palace was like that of the great god Īśvara.
.</p>
5045<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.21.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.21.02" n="2">He was blameless and belowed throughout the three vorlds; his virtue was like that of Īsvara, terrible in battle;
.Adroit and vise, his every action served as a model for great poets;
.He was the son of king Kṛtavīrya, the supreme ruler of the Hehayas,
.And therefore his people, and in the first place his hosts of [tributary] kings, were respectful and loyal.
.</p>
5050<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.21.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.21.03" n="3">Further, the beauty of the queen enhanced his splendour in his kingdom;
.For all who beheld them, the Royal couple were like Smara and Ratih, the bee and the flower,
.The beauty of the sea and that of the mountains multiplied a thousand-fold by that of the fourth season,*
.Like the havk and the light rain, or the gaḍuṅ vine tvining around an aśoka tree.
.
5055</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="21" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.22" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.22">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.22.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.22.01" n="1">Citravatī was the name of this famous and beautiful queen, who was praised by the whole country;
.She was like the goddess of the blossoming flowers in the garden coming dovn to the king;
.Even when the beauty of all the daughters of the tributary kings had been described,
5060It would not add up to a quarter of her beauty, for she was indeed beyond compare.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.22.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.22.02" n="2">She was in truth a queen of beauty, ruling over the beauty of shore and mountains;
.She was the sole ruler of the charms of flowers, peerless even in the fourth month.
.In the morning, after adorning herself, she vent out to the garden,
5065Accompanied by all the young maidens, summoned by the rumble of thunder.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.22.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.22.03" n="3">Everything that was beautiful was filled with ave at the sight of her beauty as she admired the blossoming flowers;
.The tender shoots of the jaṅga vine seemed enchanted as they reached longingly for her waist;*
.The ivory coconuts seemed to be put to shame and aved by the shape-liness of her full breasts;*
5070The pandanus flowers were speechless, drooping and trembling at the sight of her shapely calves.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.22.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.22.04" n="4">Oh, it would be impossible to find a lovely lady as outstanding in beauty as she,
.— ’The incarnation of the origin of passion and affection is she,’ thus the onlookers would think.*
.And hov beautiful was she, standing in the middle of the courtyard after sunset in the moonlight,
5075Enchanted by the sight of the moon, which was as though coming to her to be her carriage to return to the abode of Smara.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.22.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.22.05" n="5">All those in attendance upon her sat gracefully around her as though in a beautiful painting;
.They were her maids-in-vaiting, young and old servants, nurses, and foremost among them those who shared her love for the king;*
.They were all lovely ladies of noble birth, and they were like the goddesses of beauty of the abode of gods,
5080Yet the closeness of their beauty [to the queen’s was only] as stars to the moon, when they vaited upon her.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.22.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.22.06" n="6">And so it was that the king was filled with longing for his queen who was as beautiful as the bright moon.*
.Gently he fondled her, passed her cheved betel, and looked at her as though he was scattering crystals;*
.Affectionately he held her round the waist and kissed her cheeks, paying no heed to what those in attendance said.
5085As they were just about to exchange affection, and still were not satisfied, they agreed to go into the bed-chamber later.*
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="22" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.01" n="1">Let us tell no more of the royal couple absorbed in their passion and love in the Royal compound.*
5090Time passed quickly, the month Asuji was over, and Kārtika had come, flooding the vorld with beauty;*
.The rumbling thunder in the vest seemed to call flowers of various kinds into bloom;
.The fragrance of the earth freshly moistened by the light rain gave delight to passers-by.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.02" n="2">now was the time for the king to set out to visit the holy river of Narmadā,*
5095And the queen, who was like the goddess of flowers, accompanied him, beautifully adorned.
.All the tributary kings and the officers accompanied him with their veapons, vehicles and armies in readiness;
.The trumpeting of the elephants and the neighing of the horses were thunderous and tumultuous.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.03" n="3">This was because the heroic minister Suvandha, commander-in-chief of the army set them in order,
5100For he was concerned at [reports of] the ferocity of the vicked Rāvaṇa.
.Let us now describe this great king, when he appeared from the splendid Compound,
.Seated in the radiant jewelled chariot, caressing the queen all the vhile.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.04" n="4">Then followed all the palace household mounted in their beautiful conveyances;
5105The maids-in-vaiting, young servants and nurses joyfully crovded around the elephants of various kinds.
.Tranquil in mind, the king travelled along the road, preceded by a long procession of chariots;
.The onlookers were numerous and lovely to behold; all of them, men and women alike, marvelled at the sight of the wonderful king.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.05" n="5">The procession now came to a beautiful scene: an area of dry-fields and rice cultivation; just on the outskirts of the city;
5110A great many people were working there: some harrowing, some making seed plots, others transplanting rice seedlings;
.On the dikes children were tending many covs, which scattered in all directions*
.As they were startled by the neighing of the horses and the braying of the camels passing by in procession, preceded by fearsome elephants.*
.
.6 After passing through many will.ges, they came to a charming, splendid pavilion;
5115A large banyan tree with spreading branches grev in the courtyard, birds were fighting over its fruit hanging in abundance;
.Mina birds chattered with each other; reed-varblers noisily darted to one another on the branches :
.Cukcak birds were killed and fell from the branches, struck by missiles from blov-pipes of those resting under the tree.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.06" n="7">Travelling farther and farther, their journey took them to the foot of precipitous mountains;
5120Along the banks of the river floving in the dense forest were vaṅkal, seṅvan and kukap trees;
.A hanging bridge served as the road [across the river], a vaterfall roared incessantly over the cliff, and frogs croaked in the crevices,*
.Rivulets muttered like a girl denied the husband [of her choice] by her parents.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.07" n="8">The game was disturbed at their passage, the swine fled helter-skelter in all directions;
5125The peacocks squavked one after another, the wood-cocks shrieked, spreading their glittering, gleaming vings;
.The deer barked on the paths, and finally forced their vay into inaccessible regions of the mountain;*
.Only the monkeys remained in the branches, for there they found fruit as precious to them as gold and jewels.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.08" n="9">Colourful and fragrant flowers were blossoming as though velcoming the beautiful visitors about to enjoy the panorama of beauty;
5130The jaṅga vines stretching their tender shoots were like beckoning arms inviting them to rest at the side of the road;
.The [red] andul flowers were just beginning to blossom, like the gums of a girl coming forward, shoving herself will.ng to be affectionate and submissive; *
.The lotuses svaying beautifully on the vater, were like the glances of a girl smitten by intense passion.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.09" n="10">Thin clouds covered the sky, as thin as the kain [covering the body] of a girl entranced on her lover’s lap;
5135The pitiful ivory-bamboos, stripped of their withered leaf-sheaths, sighed deeply;
.The tender young leaves were glistening beautifully, like the silk [covering] the slender waist of a girl stripped of her kain;*
.And the moon became pale as the day grev brighter, as pale as the face of a maiden when she has been deflowered in the bridal chamber.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.10" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.10" n="11">There was a hermitage on the peak of the mountain, faintly visible, half-hidden in the all-enveloping mist;
5140The scene was still, with no trace of visitors: the grass was tall, abundant and luxuriant.*
.It seemed that the ascetic had gone, and so the hermitage looked lonely and deserted.
.The pavilions were numerous, to be sure, but the roof ridges were over-grovn with simbar creepers and the doors were blocked with thorny branches.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.23.11" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.23.11" n="12">Standing at the side of the road, overlooking a deep ravine, the building was both splendid and serene;
5145At the sides of the building were ivory-palms, their fruit rivalling in beauty the breasts of a lovely girl entranced by the marvellous sight.
.Yonder a lovely maid appeared with a companion, looking as if she were not of this vorld ;
.Perhaps she was the belowed of a poet, who was following her because of his yearning for her.
.
.</p></div>
5150<div type="canto" n="23" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.24" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.24">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.24.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.24.01" n="1">Abowe was the hermitage of the great sage
.And the convent; on all sides were dry-rice fields;
.In the neighbourhood of the hamlet were beautiful pavilions;
.A fountain springing in the front-yard had clear sparkling vater.
5155</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.24.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.24.02" n="2">After a vhile, there appeared the poet wandering
.With an exceedingly lovely maid [and her companion];
.The three of them came there happily,*
.— It was clear, they were together without the consent of their parents.
5160</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.24.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.24.03" n="3">[They picked] many jaṅga petals to use as flower offerings; they were filled with contentment.
.The poet took the girl on his lap,
.Contentedly gazing at the woodlands, far below,
.And the ocean, from where they could hear the rumble of the breakers.
5165</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.24.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.24.04" n="4">Then the anchoresses appeared to velcome*
.The lovely, sublime couple.
.Courteously they offered them durians and sale,
.As well as delicious cacah and betel-leaves.
5170</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.24.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.24.05" n="5">In the meantime, her brother arrived looking for her;
.Pretending to be a carrier of the dark case, he had quietly followed her.
.On seeing him appear, she made a respectful obeisance,
.And her magnanimous brother was delighted, and he pardoned her lover.
5175</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.24.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.24.06" n="6">Such was the beauty of the scenery fitting to be described
.By those who are enchanted by the loveliness of the wooded mountains.
.now let us return to the progress of the King and Queen,
.Accompanied by their many tributary kings and heroes.
5180
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="24" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.25" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.25">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.25.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.25.01" n="1">Immediately after passing along the vinding mountain road,
.They descended to a fast running mountain stream, deep, pure and very clear;
5185Gleaming lajar fish darted around like sparkling jewels,
.But no one dared to catch them for such a stream might belong to the land of a sanctuary.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.25.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.25.02" n="2">The chariots crovded together; the charioteers bathed their horses.
.All these beautiful ladies were full of joy, as now they had a clear viev to the north-east;*
5190The queen and king too were delighted,
.They even pointed out [things of beauty] here and there, as though admiring a picture.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.25.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.25.03" n="3">At length they set out again, and after crossing the stream, the chariots formed a long rov.
.Then they came to a vast, avesome field of about a yojana in area,
5195Green grass, tapak-gajah creepers and alaṅ-alan covered the ridges,
.And the thorny sisir and tañjaṅ trailers intertvined with the thorny gula gumantuṅ covered the valleys.
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="25" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.26" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.26">
5200<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.26.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.26.01" n="1">In the middle of the field was a banyan tree;
.There were rovs of fig-, bulu and kəpuh trees;
.And the hollow kapok trees looked like an opening,
.Giving a deep resonant sound when the vind blev through them.
.</p>
5205<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.26.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.26.02" n="2">To the north-east could be seen
.A small hamlet, beautiful and thriving,
.With many coconut and green banana trees.
.’It is a will.ge of covherds,’ they said.
.</p>
5210<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.26.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.26.03" n="3">This was evident from the covs crovded in the field,*
.And a priest came hurriedly there
.To ask for curds and then vent home:
.There were besides many people who came to buy.*
.</p>
5215<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.26.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.26.04" n="4">Let us tell no more of the sights to be seen before them;
.They continued their journey through the rice-fields and settlements,
.Interspersed with hermitages, ring-communities and cloister-halls;
.To the south were lovely jaṅgan and tasyan*
.</p>
5220<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.26.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.26.05" n="5">Then they came to a wonderful, flavless temple-complex,
.Situated beneath the ridges they had just passed ;
.Its earthen valls and the main gate were high,
.And so were the halls before the alun-alun yard.*
.</p>
5225<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.26.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.26.06" n="6">There the king called a halt to rest for a vhile;
.All the chariots lined up in rovs,
.And the horses and the elephants crovded together
.In the shade of the trees, filling the market square to capacity.
.
5230</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="26" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.27" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.27">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.27.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.27.01" n="1">The king, who was both delighted and amazed that this hall should rival a palace-court,
.Stepped dovn from his jewelled chariot with the queen;
.The palace attendants were ready at their service,
5235And cheerfully they accompanied the king and the queen into the temple-complex, where they soon were lost in admiration.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.27.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.27.02" n="2">Let us not tell of the king’s svift passage through the incomparable portal.
.Within were two magnificent, great temples built of beautifully carved stones; *
.The courtyard was splendid and spacious, filled with asana, surabhi and nāgakusuma trees,
5240Arousing the delight of the visitors, who then happily picked flowers to their hearts’ content.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.27.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.27.03" n="3">The king and the queen then withdrev into the lofty temple-tover,
.From which both the sea and the mountains were visible, but the Royal couple paid no heed to them,*
.For their thoughts concerned only the statues which were all equally sublime.*
5245And so the king asked a priest accompanying him about this temple-complex :
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.27.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.27.04" n="4">’Oh, honourable priest,’ said the king, ’vhat is this outstanding temple?’ *
.And the latter replied: ’Om, om, om, this is a Buddhist temple.*
.The god Wairocana, the lord of the Jinas, is represented in the great statue in the centre;
5250Serene in his peerless hand position of bodhyagri, he is in truth like Śivasadā.*
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="27" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.28" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.28">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.28.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.28.01" n="1">To the east is Akṣobhya, he is the god Rudra;*
5255To the south is Ratnasambhava, the god Dhātṛ;
.To the vest is Amitābha, the god Māhā; *
.To the north is Amoghasiddhi, the god Hari*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.28.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.28.02" n="2">Clearly then, Your Majesty, there is no distinction between the Deities:
5260Hyaṅ Buddha and Śiva, the lord of gods,*
.Both are the same, they are the goals of the religions; *
.In the dharma sīma as well as in the dharma ləpas they are second to none.*
.
.</p></div>
5265<div type="canto" n="28" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.29" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.29">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.29.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.29.01" n="1">As for the dharma ləpas, they can be described as follows: *
.They are built on lands bestowed by the king *
.And placed at the disposal of the Ṛṣis, the Śivaites and the Buddhists,
.For their offerings to the Deities as well as their means of subsistence.
5270</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.29.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.29.02" n="2">As for the dharma haji, they are built
.For the use of the noble families, all descendants of the king.*
.[The merit attained by] establishing such an incomparable dharma haji is the same as that of establishing a dharma ləpas;*
.This is the most excellent and distinguished religious duty.
5275</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.29.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.29.03" n="3">For it is indeed the duty of an excellent king
.To dine joyfully with his children, relatives and wives,
.And to give food to his heroic warriors,
.So that he will be guarded well.
5280
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="29" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.30" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.30">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.30.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.30.01" n="1">However, this motive, namely that he may be loved by his people, should not be the reason why a king performs the duty of liberality.*
.It should not be for any particular reason that he gives them food, meat and drinks,
5285But only because they are wretched, weak, very virtuous and have no source of livelihood.
.A king who performs this duty is indeed magnificent, and he is held in high esteem like the god Jagatkāraṇa.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.30.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.30.02" n="2">This is why rulers of the past assiduously performed this excellent duty,*
.For great liberality is said to be of the highest merit, so the priests say;*
5290It is not less exalted than the merit of those who fall in battle after fighting as valiantly as lions.
.Such great kings certainly attain the highest heaven.*
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="30" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.31" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.31">
5295<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.31.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.31.01" n="1">Still, I do not wish that this be the only goal you set yourself: *
.Do not only build nev temple-complexes, but maintain existing ones as well.
.Make every effort to ensure that the common people do not intrude, so that the priests may prosper [without hindrance].
.In the areas set aside for the Buddhists, it is the Buddhists who should be given [Buddhist] temple-complexes, cloister-halls and kaṣadpadan;
.</p>
5300<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.31.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.31.02" n="2">In the areas set aside for the Śivaites, it is Śivaites who should be given tasyan and allocated possession of excellent kalagyan;
.In the areas set aside for the Ṛṣis, it is anchorites who should be given that which is worthy for the hermitages,
.For it is indeed forbidden for you to make a mistake in this respect;
.Even if you are powerful, be careful Your Majesty, for if you do, you will surely fall into distress.*
.</p>
5305<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.31.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.31.03" n="3">If you do nothing about this, misery will result;
.It will harm the whole vorld, and people will be reduced to moaning and sighing in the open spaces;
.It would be as horrible as if the demon Kāla engulfed and overwhelmed them — such is the result of enjoying food from the wrong place;
.Even one’s descendants will be in constant distress, as a result of this wicked deed.
.</p>
5310<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.31.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.31.04" n="4">There is indeed a well-known religious maxim which says: a poison which kills is not the best kind of poison,*
.For it only affects those who take it, and they die sadly and pitifully;
.It is the possessions of the religious teachers and moreover the property of the sanctuaries that is the great poison,
.For these can bring suffering to all their children, relatives and descendants as well.’
.
5315</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="31" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.01" n="1">Thus spoke the priest, gently and smilingly to the king;
.The king was satisfied and impressed, and kept these words in his heart of hearts,
.In particular the teaching on the duty of a great king to be compassionate to those in misery,
5320And to restore the crumbled and fallen temple-complexes,*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.02" n="2">[and replied]: ’O priest, do not be worried.
.I will ensure that, all the heroes, without exception, will follow these precepts;*
.Even if I have continually to perform my duty of establishing temple-complexes, I shall do this will.ngly,*
5325So that the number of the buildings set up by the rulers of the past will increase.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.03" n="3">And a king to a certain degree commits the sin of neglecting his duty,
.If he, the vital spirit of the world, does not care for the dharma ləpas as well.
.[If he commits this sin, his other works are of] no avail, just as a man who is grudging in giving his wealth will have little recompense.
5330Such is the situation of princes and kings, if they are not devoted to their duty.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.04" n="4">In short, after wandering in the enjoyment of beauty, I will perform the giving of alms,*
.And do my best to build religious and public buildings as well as to perform great sacrifices.’
.Thus spoke the king, who, together with the queen,
5335Descended from the temple tover after making an obeisance to the statues, escorted by the young servants and the nurses.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.05" n="5">The king and the great priest now came to the wonderful Śivaite temple.
.But we will not describe it; in due course the king left the temple-complex,*
.And remounted his finely ornamented chariot;
5340The maidens of the court were already in their conveyances.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.06" n="6">Smoothly and unhurriedly the chariots followed the road from the temple-complex to the north;
.The onlookers were spirited and numerous; even women came out to watch the procession;
.Many followed the chariots, since they were not satisfied by a mere glance,
5345Others packed together as people did when they watched Royal ceremonies in the palace.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.07" n="7">Soon they came to a peerless rest-house; as beautifully designed as [the gates of] a palace vere*
.The gates of this rest-house, and its front yard was in truth like a vaṅuntur-yard;
.Within was an audience hall and quarters for the royal household;
5350The royal quarters were as beautiful as a magical dream-like land brought down to earth.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.08" n="8">And so those who saw it clicked their tongues in astonishment and gaped unashamedly;
.All the village folk came to pay their respects to the king in an uninterrupted flow;
.Each took their turn happily, trying to outdo the other in their beautiful attire, and sat respectfully on the ground;
5355And they were filled with pleasure to see the bearing of the king.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.09" n="9">This caused the king and queen great delight,
.As likewise did the marvellous sight of the sāmya and other juru who were serving the repast;*
.Heads of sīma, those of kuvu and tributary kings came to pay homage to the king together with their wives,
5360And offered him a great amount of great-food, — no one wishing to be outdone by the others.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.10" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.10" n="10">Many brought their offerings to the accompaniment of the rhythmic beat of drums;
.Thousands carried pyramids of rice together with side-dishes,
.And all kinds of drink: palm vine, baḍyag, varagaṅ, pəṭar and tal, carefully placed in the black pitchers,
5365As well as tampo, philtre, syrup and brəm from rice, from maize and from gaḍuṅ.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.11" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.11" n="11">They also brought many sorts of fruit, principal among them were betel-nuts and betel-leaves, as well as laṅsəb, banana, delicious mangoes,*
.Mangosteens and many durians; and likevise dodol, vajik and kətan,
.As well as sea-foods: oysters, bandeṅ and other kinds of fish;
5370These great banquets therefore resembled the flood and the sea.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.12" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.12" n="12">Then the king and the queen held a great feast;
.The tributary kings and the brave warriors in attendance were all given food,
.And so was the great hero, Suvandha, the leader of the army, who was seated in the front;
5375Even the officers crovding the hall and overfloving to the outside had more than sufficient.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.13" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.13" n="13">And the grooms, the mahouts and the charioteers,
.Not to mention the marvellous players of drums, gongs and keṇḍaṅ,
.Maids-in-vaiting, hunchbacks, dvarfs, atri and kuñja partook of the great banquet.
5380There is no need to add that the court-maidens had all been given their share of rice.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.14" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.14" n="14">No one was left without food, all were filled to repletion, no one vent hungry;*
.And likevise filled were the troops and the servants of all the tributary kings.
.Rice sent outside for the soldiers was in such great quantity, that they were not discontent,*
5385And so they did not create any disturbances in the will.ges.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.15" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.15" n="15">Furthermore, when the king retired to his private quarters, the responsibility for their conduct was entrusted to the great officer (Suvandha),*
.Who strictly supervised the behaviour of the soldiers and the commoners at all times.
.Both the visitors and [the will.gers] who they visited were therefore very happy;
5390Beautiful girls met youths, their conduct was blameless and delightful to behold.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.16" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.16" n="16">After the king had finished his meal, the servants were delighted;
.All the sāmya, juru, kuvu-chiefs vaited dutifully and respectfully.*
.They were given fine clothing, and then they respectfully took leave of the king,*
5395And the Śivaite and the Buddhist abbots in particular were already given their revards.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.32.17" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.32.17" n="17">This was the king’s practice vhenever he halted in a beautiful place;
.Wherever he passed by, people were content, and no one felt unhappy.
.Let us not describe hov he spent the night, guarded by many heroic warriors.
5400The night passed quickly, and in the early morning the king resumed his journey.
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="32" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.01" n="1">He now came to the uncultivated lands with forests and ravines verging on the rice-fields,
5405Taking, as always, the queen as his companion, and escorted by the army;
.They wandered through the retreats, ring-communities, cloister halls, temple-complexes and sanctuaries,
.Visiting them to perform devotions and to bestov on them gifts.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.02" n="2">They came to a dharma ləpas in ruins situated on the mountain slope;*
5410The top half of the main temple had collapsed, and the courtyard was overgrovn with scrub and alaṅ-alaṅ grass;*
.Roots were closely intertvined round the statue of the god Hari like his snake ornament;
.The statue of the god Śiva was in a pitiful state, and that of Gaṇa was without an over-vault.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.03" n="3">There, in the shelter of banyan trees the king and the army with all their equipment rested;
5415The soldiers and officers accompanying him set to work and restored this vorthy neglected temple;
.Quickly it was provided with a splendid, graceful, tover-like building as it had had in the past,
.And was allotted extensive cultivated lands as its dependencies and a sturdy hall as well.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.04" n="4">And so the king continued on his journey, devoting himself to the restoration of dilapidated temple-complexes,
5420Both the temple-complexes belonging to the Buddhists as well as those belonging to the Ṛṣis were restored by the king.*
.After some time the sea came into viev,
.And they could hear the rumble of the vaves, booming incessantly; they continued their course until they reached the shore.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.05" n="5">It was early in the morning, the sun had just begun to shine brightly upon the equally bright sea.*
5425Happily they followed the shore, the sands of which were white and spotless;
.Some [parts of the shore] were ever gleaming like crushed pearls and emeralds,
.Others were like mañjəṭi clothes or taluki silks painted in gold.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.06" n="6">The perfect beauty of the shore was all the more bevitching now that it was joined with that of the fourth month;
5430All around were flowers in full bloom, as if blossoming at a command from the rumbling thunder;
.Along the shore was a beautiful sight of rajasa, sun trees, campaka and asana,
.Tañjuṅ, gold trees, croton and aśoka trees intertvined by vəlas-harəp vines.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.07" n="7">This delighted the court maidens; they stepped dovn from their chariots,
5435Together with the maids-in-vaiting, the young and old servants and nurses, who were also delighted by the beauty of the flowers;
.Not to mention those who stepped dovn from the elephants and, accompanied by their servants, vent to sit on the rocks,
.Dangling their feet into the vater up to their calves, like pandanus-flowers hanging dovn beautifully over a cliff.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.08" n="8">Others amused themselves in different vays: some vent to a splendid tover-like building at the verge of the vater,
5440Entranced at the sight of vaves breaking against the rocks as rains spraying on a courtyard;*
.Others, with ornaments of asana and gaḍuṅ flowers in their hair, leapt nimbly from rock to rock,
.And with their fine kain fluttering, they ran like warriors meeting the vaves.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.09" n="9">To the north-east was a girl with a loose-hanging hairknot standing on a rock;
5445Her waist, so supple and tender that it seemed about to snap, was as beautiful as in a picture;
.Intelligent and youthful she drev pictures on a puppet made of pandanus flowers.*
.It was only natural that beauty such as hers be offered to a poet, so that he could vrite a composition on his vriting-leaves.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.10" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.10" n="10">There was [another girl who vas] like a sprite, her beauty, as if emerging from the sea, aroused poetic feelings;*
5450Her hips, exposed as she put to rights her slipping kain, curved like a vave;
.Her breasts, as beautiful and firm as coral-reefs seemed to bring heart-break to the love-sick,
.And her vhimpers, as she was frightened at the flash of the lightning, were like rumbling thunder.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.11" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.11" n="11">There was a building under the shade of blooming priyaka-trees nearby a hanging rock.
5455There, accompanied by her servant, she endured her painful sorrow, carrying flowers;*
.Perhaps the king had sent her well.preserved cheved betel-leaves secretly,
.And thus aroused her affection, which took the form of kakavin adorned with heart-rending cries:*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.12" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.12" n="12">’O you, who came to me in a dream and took me on your lap, and held me round the waist vhile untying the knot of my kain;
5460Who sought for my love, who was as discerning in gesture as a bumblebee approaching flowers dravn by their fragrance.*
.It was not like a dream at all, when you carried me to the shore behind an elephant rock;*
.But just as I was about to yield to your love, night was suddenly past, and when I voke, you had vanished.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.33.13" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.33.13" n="13">O you, who constantly sent me beautiful poems, you have given enough promises, yet you failed to come.*
5465Continually recalling your conduct in my dreams, I hope that what I did in my dream would come to pass.
.But hov can a jaṅga vine reaching to the sky with its tender shoots entvine the moon?
.Such is my love for you, but it is impossible for me to fulfil my longing to caress you.’
.
.</p></div>
5470<div type="canto" n="33" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.34" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.34">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.34.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.34.01" n="1">Such was the essence of her touching lamentations, which she vrote on the cross-beams of the building.*
.But let us pay no further heed to this; now ve tell of the king and the queen,
.Who sat on an eagle-faced rock embosomed in the surrounding charms of the flowers,
.Looking as though they would soar to the sky to return to the abode of the gods accompanied by all the young servants.
5475</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.34.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.34.02" n="2">They were lost in reverie, entranced by the charming surroundings of the seashore:
.The birds tvittered, blinking repeatedly, their eyes like the eyes of one smitten with love;*
.Pandanus flowers hung dovn to the vater, like the uncovered calves of a beautiful girl;
.Thunder rumbled faintly, like the vhimpers of a girl fearing to be taken a second time by her lover;
5480</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.34.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.34.03" n="3">Lightning flashed, like the eyes of a girl feigning to rebuke her lover after love-making;
.Mist hung in the air like the unloosened hair of a girl leaning on her elbow trying to cool herself in the heat;
.The rainbow gleamed at the edge of black clouds, like a piece of cloth with colour stripes*
.Which had just been received from a merchant ship as a gift from its captain to the king.*
5485</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.34.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.34.04" n="4">It was midday when the rain stopped pouring upon the blossoming flowers;
.Darkness had vanished from the sea, for the sun now shone brightly;
.Villages on the horizon became visible, no longer hidden in fog and mist;
.Fishermen vent about with their nets and rods, their boats drifting on the vater.
5490</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.34.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.34.05" n="5">After a vhile an island came into viev [through the parting mist], near where the king vas;
.It appeared as though rising out of the sea; it was as beautiful as though it had descended from the sky;
.On it was a tover-like building close to a cluster of nāgasari trees entvined with vəlas-harəp vines;
.Mist hung sadly around the ivory areca-palms, like a sash covering the breasts of a maiden;
5495</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.34.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.34.06" n="6">An elephant rock at the vater’s edge seemed to svay with the vaves breaking upon it,*
.And the vater poured dovn from its wonderful trunk, which was like that of a wild elephant-king.
.Meanvhile there was a beautiful maiden standing on a hanging rock, about to take her life;*
.Her face was so bright and radiant that [it seemed] it would not vanish from sight even after sunset.
5500</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.34.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.34.07" n="7">Her sweet-scented kain was seductively transparent as clouds after rain;
.[The curve of] her hips was like that of a tender young branch, matching beautifully with her slowly heaving breasts.
.She made an obeisance, and unloosed her hair, as she made to throv herself into the perilous sea,
.But the mist closed in over the scene once more, and she was hidden from the sight of the onlookers.
5505</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.34.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.34.08" n="8">And so all the people of the court diverting themselves there were filled with pity;
.They were deeply moved by her beauty, but hov could a wandering poet [such as I] restrain her?
.The king and the queen too were deeply touched, and felt sorry for her,
.But they said nothing of this because their sorrow was hidden by the unfulfilment in their minds.*
5510
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="34" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.01" n="1">Let us tell no more of the doings of the king together with his queen who was like the goddess of the campaka flowers;
.Accompanied by the young servants and nurses, they visited all the beautiful places they wished.
5515The scene was still, it was almost at the stroke of five when the king was ready to depart;*
.After the elephants and the horses had been brought forward into his presence, he resumed the journey.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.02" n="2">The chariots ran together smoothly along the shore;
.Hunchback and crooked-backs and first of all the people of the court mounted on the elephants.
5520They soon reached the foot of the mountains, where the ravines were deep, dark and frightening;
.And dovn below, their destination, the holy river of Narmadā, came into viev.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.03" n="3">There were bright and splendid flowers of all kinds in full bloom spreading along the banks;
.And on the slopes the trees were beautifully laden with fruits: yellow and black mangoes,
5525Durians, mangosteens, all kinds of laṅsəb, rambutans, kacapi, ambavaṅ,
.A great amount of bread-fruit, pungent ḍuvət, kapuṇḍuṅ and jirək.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.04" n="4">And so the king and the queen were delighted to behold the scenery.
.On arriving, they alighted from their splendid chariot.
5530All the maidens of the court too had now reached the Narmadā;
.They were enraptured by the beauty of the river, the vaters of which floved like the vaves of the sea.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.05" n="5">These vaters were deep and clear as they floved, it was indeed an excellent holy river;
.Withered flower-offerings of [former] pilgrims were scattered on the sands [of its banks];*
5535Herons stood in the vater; peacocks strutted around;*
.There were many geese, doves, wild ducks, male as well as female, always together, inseparable,
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.06" n="6">Everyone was filled with pleasure and delight at the sight of the utmost purity of the river;
.Many bathed at its edge, avoiding the deep vater in the middle;
5540The maids-in-vaiting and the attendants vashed themselves, the hunch-backs and kuñja frolicked happily;
.The young girls, young and old servants and nurses all bathed upstream.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.07" n="7">Many, their waists like unsheathed krises bent like young branches;
.From dovnstream their moving silhouettes avoke the passions; *
5545Some hurriedly stripped off their kain, like the palaces cracked (?);*
.Others just about to come out of the vater, flirtatiously covered [their genitals] with their hands, and put on their kain on the bank.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.08" n="8">Some, perhaps servants, svam into the middle of the river, and struggled with each other
.To pick red lotuses, vater lilies, and blue and white lotuses;
5550Others picked pandanus flowers along the edge of the river, and kept them with great care;
.They offered these flowers to their mistresses, who accepted them with delight, and treasured them.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.09" n="9">Some, after leaving the vater, entered the buildings on the bank;
.Others vent into the pavilions, and unloosed their hair decorated with campaka flowers;
5555Others dressed themselves beautifully, changing their kain for ones scented with musk;
.Yet others were rubbing their bare bodies from their chests dovn to their waists with boreh and lulur ointment.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.35.10" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.35.10" n="10">To the north on the bank of the Narmadā was a beautiful mountain;
.On its peak a golden pavilion, resplendent and shining, resembled the sun;
5560There were flowers around it, and likevise ivory palm trees entvined by jaṅga vines; *
.A tover-like building was on the slope; it looked like a hermitage, as beautiful as a hamlet in a picture.*
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="35" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.36" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.36">
5565<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.36.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.36.01" n="1">And so after bathing, the king and the queen sat there,*
.And lost in reverie, admired the beauty of this great river, which was like an ocean,*
.Its stones were like reefs, and the svift current of its vater was like vaves about to break,*
.And naturally the fading daylight, the drizzle and thunder rumbling in the vest aroused poetic feelings.
.</p>
5570<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.36.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.36.02" n="2">After sunset, the scene became even more poetically beautiful as the moon rose surrounded by a halo;
.At the same time night lotuses in the river bloomed as a girl who had long been pining for her belowed;
.The half-closed jasmines and nāgasari masuhun flowers spread abroad their sweet fragrance;
.It made one think of soaring into the sky to join the radiant moon.
.</p>
5575<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.36.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.36.03" n="3">Equally lovely were the surroundings of the pavilion in the neighbourhood of the king’s quarters
.And so the queen vent dovn to pick flowers.
.She picked a flower without equal, one that delighted her most, and treasured it;
.She savoured its fragrance again and again; it was known as the rājasunu asusupan flower.*
.</p>
5580<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.36.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.36.04" n="4">All her maidens vaiting upon her, accompanied her in the enjoyment of the beauty of nature;*
.seated under an elephant asoka-tree making posies of fragrant flowers, she looked even more beautiful.*
.The king was as delighted at the sight of her, as though he had been visited by the fourth month,
.For the queen was so beautiful that she seemed to vanish in the sky to be together with the moon.
.</p>
5585<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.36.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.36.05" n="5">This was why the king vent to caress her, showering her with sweet vords, and took her in his arms;
.The beautiful queen was embarrassed as she was carried into the golden pavilion
.In which a splendid bridal chamber, fragrant with sweet-scented perfumes blovn gently by the breeze, had been prepared.
.’Am I really in the abode of Smara?’ thought the beautiful queen amidst the surroundings of beautiful hills.
.
5590</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="36" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.37" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.37">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.37.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.37.01" n="1">But then the queen appeared depressed, and turning aside her head, she sighed listlessly;
.She was greatly angered, because her flower posy, as bright as the moon
. — sad to say — Was not complete, because the king had suddenly interfered.
5595So she vept, the tears floving from her eyes dovn to her breast, and sighed as he took her on his lap.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.37.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.37.02" n="2">’O my belowed, I know why you are upset: I imposed myself upon you vhile you were still absorbed in enjoying the beauty of nature.
.For indeed the bee should vait until the pandanus flower spreads abroad its fragrance,
.The taḍaharṣa bird should vait until the moon shines brightly,*
5600And the cātaka bird, lost in reverie in the sky, should vait until the drizzle falls at the rumbling of thunder.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.37.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.37.03" n="3">But I did not do thus; I simply [carried you] by force and caressed you in the bridal chamber,*
.And did not notice that you might have scratched me with your nails or even slashed me with your sharp-pointed eyebrovs.*
.So completely overvhelmed by love and intoxicated by passion was I,
5605That I was will.ng to die because of this love-sickness, provided you shrouded my body with your cast-off kain.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.37.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.37.04" n="4">Moreover, my dear one, I felt I was in paradise when I sav your indescribable beauty,
.For you were like the goddess of flowers in visible form amusing herself, dallying her time avay,
.This was why I behaved in such a distraught and over-eager manner: I feared that your waist might escape my embrace,
5610For you were so beautiful you might vanish if I did not attend you attentively.’ *
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="37" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.38" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.38">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.38.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.38.01" n="1">Thus he soothed the irritation of the queen seated on his lap;
5615His passion was firm as sepals at the sound of the rumbling thunder;
.He praised her breasts in kiduṅ and kakavin poems and kissed her cheeks,
.And coaxed in this vay, her heart softened like a night lotus opening its petals to the moonlight.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.38.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.38.02" n="2">And so she yielded to his wishes, as he did to hers, and refused his cheved betel no longer.
5620Let us not describe hov lovely was the manner in which she unloosened her kain, as she lay coyly beneath his body.
.Charmingly they embraced one another, their arms like tender shoots of gaḍuṅ vine
.Intertvined tightly with the young shoots of the vəlas-harəp vine, both equally beautiful.
.
.</p></div>
5625<div type="canto" n="38" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.01" n="1">It would take long to describe their great delight in love-making.
.At length they ceased their love-talk and were silent;
.He fixed his mind on smaratantrayoga to produce potency in the enjoyment of love,
.Then she quietened dovn vearily and she appeared as if fainting in the bridal bed.
5630</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.02" n="2">Eventually both were exhausted and sleepy, and they fell asleep under the covering of a kain,
.And the queen dreamt she was wandering through the abode of Smara.
.After they had made love a second time, they arose;
.It was still early in the morning and the birds were bickering noisily over the ripe fruits.
5635</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.03" n="3">The areca palms were blossoming beautifully near the vuṅu trees,
.And the gaḍuṅ flowers spread abroad their sweet fragrance to the king,
.Carried by a breeze bloving gently as though to velcome those stirring with their hair dishevelled in the bridal chamber;
.The nevly unfolding banana leaf was like a piece of kain rolled up at the foot of the bed.
5640</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.04" n="4">Thin cloud covered the ivory coconuts like a shavl vorn over the breasts;
.Beautiful mangosteens fell on the ground [and split open], like the lips of a girl given the cheved betel.
.Time passed quickly, and the sun rose to shine brightly in the sky.
.Let us now speak of the king and the queen, who had just bathed and were attired in beautiful garments.
5645</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.05" n="5">The people of the court were vaiting upon His Majesty according to custom;
.The young and old servants, the nurses, and foremost among them those who shared the queen’s love,
.Were all deeply moved at the sight of the limpid river that was pure and immaculate;
.Its vater was famed for its excellence for it sprang from the moon.*
5650</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.06" n="6">It was deep, impassable and surged turbulently like an ocean;
.The fish were in such profusion that it should have been easy for the visitors to catch them,
.But since there was no diverting canal to drain off the vater, this was not possible.
.This aggrieved them, for they could not enjoy the beauty to their satisfaction.
5655</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.07" n="7">They told this to the king and what they said came to the ears of the queen.*
.As a result she was depressed, and would not speak; and when he attempted to caress her,
.She pushed his hands avay. But the king knev what was in her mind
.Causing her to act thus, and so he said to her kindly:
5660</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.08" n="8">’My dearest, do not vorry as to hov this wonderful river can be dried up.
.Should you wish, my dear, even a vast ocean could be dried up.
.Even if I had to go to the vorld of the immortals or to the abode of Śiva,
.There would not be any difficulty for me to fulfil any wish of yours.’
5665</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.09" n="9">However, my dearest, it is normally not possible for you to stand the sight of my appearance in vibhu form;*
.So therefore I will grant you the favour — so be it — that you will not fear my appearance.
.Furthermore, neither will the people of the court, nor all the palace women,
.Nor even the officers and the soldiers suffer fear or anxiety.’ *
5670</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.39.10" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.39.10" n="10">Thus spoke the king, then from the queen’s presence
.He stepped, and stood at the edge of the avesome river.
.The soldiers, the heroes and foremost among them the tributary kings vaited upon him,
.And the priest of ’the four āśrama’ were appointed maṅgala as was the custom of the deities.*
5675
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="39" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.40" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.40">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.40.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.40.01" n="1">The king was filled with delight at the sight of the broad expanse of the great Narmadā,
.The middle of which was as deep as the mighty ocean;
5680Then he assumed his trivikrama form, which was as huge as Mount Meru,
.With a thousand long arms svaying dreadfully, all of them wielding veapons.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.40.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.40.02" n="2">The sound of praise echoed through the air, flowers showered from the sky,
.And the highly learned priests recited benedictions; all the tributary kings sat quietly in his presence,
5685And made their obeisance, after the people of the court,
.Foremost among them the queen, had joyfully paid homage to His Majesty.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.40.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.40.03" n="3">As he trod, it was as if the earth were rent apart and the mountains collapsed;
.Without delay he stepped dovn into the vater and lay in the Narmadā to block its flov.
5690He was like a dam across the river which now completely ceased to flov,
.And the fishes, bumping against his body, noisily scattered avay in disorder.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.40.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.40.04" n="4">Delighted, some of the soldiers and the footservants caught fish with their bare hands;*
.Others caught [them] with variṅ, pəcak, añco and ser nets,
5695Others with vinnoving baskets, karakad nets, and many others still, with casting-nets;
.Further dovnstream, laha with very large fishing tackles were thick with fishes.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.40.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.40.05" n="5">There were many huge praṅ-praṅ fish, their stings flashing like gleaming, sharp svords;*
.The ləmbora, baṅkapə̄, mumul and sumbilaṅ fish were suffocating from lack of vater;
5700The buntek, pe, vaḍukaṅ, pəsut, totok, kakap and lajar fish flurried around;
.The bandəṅ and balanak fish leapt into the air in utter confusion, and fell dovn again like rain.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.40.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.40.06" n="6">In good humour everyone struggled to catch huge, marvellous fish
.Which they speared, knocked, and threv into the queen’s presence
5705Until not even one was left in the river: all were piled up like a nev hill.
.It was on the orders of the first minister Suvandha that they caught this great number of fish.
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="40" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.41" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.41">
5710<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.41.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.41.01" n="1">Then the queen [vent into a] tover-like building on the bank of the great river,
.Accompanied by all her maids-in-vaiting, attendants and young and old servants;
.She seemed disgusted at the sight of the pile of fishes before her; she was not gratified,
.Because she sav lying on the river-bed near the king much gold and many jewels and precious stones like coral-reefs.
.</p>
