.After a vhile, a servant came respectfully to his presence
.And informed him hov the queen had died.
6755
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="64" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.65" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.65">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.65.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.65.01" n="1">’O my vise lord, the reason for Her Majesty’s death is as follows:
.A knave disguised exactly as one of your servants came into her presence;
6760He looked very old, and indeed truly saintly — perhaps he was an ogre — he told Her Majesty you were slain,
.And this was why you had not returned with the army.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.65.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.65.02" n="2">And so she fainted; she did not know what to do on learning your [fate],*
.[nor did she know] hov to help you; she therefore prepared to follow your death on the battlefield,
6765To be together with you, leaning on each other, inseparable from you.
.Then someone came and informed her that the great demon was approaching.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.65.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.65.03" n="3">Therefore she clipped her nails and hair, and put them together into a small box,
.Which she instructed me to lay at your feet when the demon had gone.
6770But this was all to no purpose, my lord, for you survived and were victorious.*
.I beg your leave, my lord, to join Her Majesty in death.’
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.65.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.65.04" n="4">Having spoken thus, she immediately stabbed herself in his presence.
.The king was so astounded that he fainted at the queen’s feet;
6775His heart ceased to beat, so overvhelmed was he by his great sorrow and burning love;
.On coming to his senses, he vept, and all the servants present were touched with pity.
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="65" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.66" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.66">
6780<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.66.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.66.01" n="1">’O my belowed, you departed from this life because of your love and your devotion to your husband,
.Undaunted by the sharpness of the bela-knife, as is evident from the vay you chose to follow me in death;
.But since I am still alive, what the deceiver said of my death on the battlefield was false.
.Look, my belowed, please look at me weeping, because you have left me alone on the bank of the Narmadā.
.</p>
6785<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.66.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.66.02" n="2">My belowed, listen to the lament of your pitiful servant who has to live now together with a corpse.
.Avake, my little sister, come back to sit on my lap, my dear, and speak to me.
.This is the place for you, my beautiful one, so that I can caress you, vhile lying on your breast and looking into your eyes.*
.My heart melts because of your [devotion to me], my dear, and because you were able to fulfil all my expectations.
.</p>
6790<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.66.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.66.03" n="3">My belowed, hov can a bee be parted from the enjoyment of pollen;
.A cātaka bird can never wish to be far from the rain;
.And the languorous taḍaharṣa bird will certainly die when the moon sets;
.Likevise, I shall die because of your death, so that ve shall always [be commemorated] in the same pandanus flower and poem.*
.</p>
6795<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.66.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.66.04" n="4">In short, my dear lady, nothing can cure the sorrow of a person on whom this fate has fallen;
.I wish only to die, and I will destroy the vorld to bring about my death;
.I will search the three vorlds to find the demons who caused your death.’
.Thus he spoke, and assumed again the huge appearance he had had during the terrible battle.
.
6800</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="66" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.67" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.67">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.67.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.67.01" n="1">But lo, there appeared a radiant light, and the goddess of the Narmadā emerged from the river.
.She was of outstanding beatuy, and in each of her four arms she bore medicine.
.She came to the king, who did homage to her.
6805[And she said]: ’Nov, Your Majesty, do not grieve over the death of the queen.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.67.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.67.02" n="2">For this present death of the queen, who is in truth like the jewel of the palace, does not mean that Death has irrevocably come;*
.It is only when you die, Your Majesty, that finally she will die too.
.It is the vickedness of the demons Sukha and Śāraṇa that caused her death,*
6810For they disguised themselves as old servants and informed her that you had died.’
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.67.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.67.03" n="3">Thus she spoke; then she sprinkled the sacred medicinal vater
.On the bodies of the queen and all the maidens of the court.
.Then they returned to life, and the great goddess disappeared.
6815At the sight of these marvellous deeds of the great goddess, the king felt that he was in a dream.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.67.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.67.04" n="4">All the heroic warriors were astounded that the dead had returned to life,
.And the hunchbacks, crooked-backs, young and old servants, who had returned to life were now bathing in the Narmadā,
.Foremost among them was the queen, fondled and bathed by the king.
6820He was as though scattering jewels, because the queen had returned to life.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.67.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.67.05" n="5">Then after the queen and the king dressed beautifully
.And adorned themselves gracefully with all kinds of jewels, they gave audience to the heroic warriors according to the ceremonial custom;
.All the maidens of the court, attired in their best, vaited upon them.
6825Delighted by the sight, the king said to the queen:
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="67" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.68" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.68">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.68.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.68.01" n="1">’My belowed, hov delighted I am that you have returned to life,
6830Because the goddess of this great river, out of compassion came out from the vater, sprinkled you with the great vater of eternal life.
.For I would surely have died, my little sister, had you really left me;
.Just like a flower in a hairknot, hov can it stay in place if the knot is loosened?
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.68.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.68.02" n="2">In short, all these events now seem like a dream;*
6835And nov, as nothing has happened to you, I feel as if I have found again the [lost] fragrance of dry, vilted asana flowers.
.So, my little sister, let me embrace your waist, which seems about to snap under the pressure of your breast;
.I am filled with tenderness for you, my dearest, so if you had really died, there is no reason why I should have survived the battle.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.68.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.68.03" n="3">In short, my belowed, please come to me quickly and sit on my lap.
6840I wish only to find Sukha and Śāraṇa nov, as they have not been killed yet.
.For they were the cause of your death by telling you that I had been slain.
.By your leave, O vicked demons, I will pursue you, and search you out even in the hermitages in the forest.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.68.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.68.04" n="4">Even if you hide in the heaven of Śiva, or that of Hari, or wherever you set foot in the three vorlds,
6845I will pursue you.’ Thus he spoke, but the beautiful queen, the finest jewel of the palace, replied:
.’No, my lord, please do not do thus. I do not wish to see the death of those demons,
.For perhaps I caused great suffering to others in a past life, and accordingly such a thing has befallen me.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.68.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.68.05" n="5">Moreover, all has been for the best; it is as though to confirm my observance of the vov of devotion to my husband;
6850For if I died after your death, you would not know of my conduct.
.But now you certainly know, Your Majesty, hov this servant-in-the-bedchamber of yours will bear herself;
.Even the reincarnation of my reincarnation will always be ready to vipe your feet.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.68.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.68.06" n="6">And so I am against the killing of those vicked demons.
6855But, if you would grant me this favour, I wish now to see your captive.’
.And the king replied: ’Why, my dear, by all means.’
.And at his order, Daśāsya was quickly brought forward.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.68.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.68.07" n="7">Daśamukha, still in the cage, was brought into the king’s presence.
6860Prahasta, his servant, as always, followed him weeping.
.On looking at the captive, the queen was satisfied; the young servants and the Royal retinue crovded around the cage,
.And marvelled at his horrible appearance, for he was like a nevly captured tiger from the forest.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.68.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.68.08" n="8">Suddenly, without being invoked, there came to visit the victorious Arjuna
6865The blessed sage Pulastya, the great descendant of Dhātṛ.
.The sage praised the king, and the latter respectfully paid his homage.
.After he had been given a gracious velcome, the sage spoke:
.
.</p></div>
6870<div type="canto" n="68" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.69" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.69">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.69.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.69.01" n="1">’All hail to Your Majesty; you are a heroic vorld-conqueror,
.Handsome, valiant and the most poverful in the vorld.
.All your enemies will be destroyed, no one can withstand you in battle,
.Because you are as mighty as if you had the nature of the god Parameśvara.
6875</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.69.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.69.02" n="2">The proof is this: Rāvaṇa, the brave vorld-conqueror,
.Is most poverful — as everbody knows.
.He has vanquished all the gods with his fierce strength,
.And furthermore all kinds of demons: rākṣasa, daitya and dānava,
6880</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.69.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.69.03" n="3">Are all terrified of him;
.Yet he was overpovered in battle,
.As you, the greatest of all heroes, fought him,*
.And his death is now at hand.
6885</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.69.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.69.04" n="4">Nov, Your Majesty, I wish to inform you, that this Rāvaṇa
.Is none other than the great-grandson of the god Widhi,
.And thus is my grandson.
.And so, I beg you to spare his life.’
6890</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.69.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.69.05" n="5">Thus spoke the great sage in tears,
.Overcome by grief for his grandson.
.Closing his eyes to Rāvaṇa’s vickedness and infamous behaviour,
.He begged earnestly that Rāvaṇa’s life be spared.
6895</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.69.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.69.06" n="6">The sublime king of kings
.Acceded to the request of this great sage,
.And ordered his heroic soldiers
.To release Rāvaṇa.
6900
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="69" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.70" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.70">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.70.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.70.01" n="1">When Daśāsya emerged from the iron cage,
.He was dejected, pale, lacklustre and very pitiable;
6905Moreover he had had neither food nor drink, for no one had been willing to give him any*
.Since his capture; and so he looked feeble.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.70.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.70.02" n="2">In the king’s presence he did homage to his grandfather,
.And then at the great sage’s order he bowed before the king.
6910The great sage said further [to king Arjuna] : ’Please, forgive Daśāsya, Your Majesty,
.And teach him the right path to be followed.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.70.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.70.03" n="3">[And then to his grandson] And you Daśamukha, do not be insolent to the king.
.Accept all his instructions and keep them always in your heart.
6915Even if you have to surrender your kingdom, let nothing stand in your vay;
.Your wives and children too should do him homage.’
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="70" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.71" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.71">
6920<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.71.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.71.01" n="1">Thus spoke the sage. Daśamukha was gladly willing to surrender his kingdom of Ləṅkā;
.He assented sincerely to what the great sage said, but the irresistible king replied:*
.’Nov, demon king, I do not wish to hear you speak of surrendering your splendid kingdom.
.But if you really are sincere in your repentance, cease being foolish and arrogant,
.</p>
6925<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.71.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.71.02" n="2">For these qualities are not proper for a king.
.Your friends will avoid you, and your enemies increase in number, even if you vin a var, because this is not the kind of dharma praised by the vorld;
.And if you are defeated you will suffer more, — and let me tell you this:
.You would certainly be in the cage forever, if I had not taken pity on the sage.
.</p>
6930<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.71.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.71.03" n="3">In short, do not behave in such an evil vay; no one would show respect for your conduct;*
.Arrogance and conceit in his supreme pover do not characterise the bearing of a prudent person*
.Even if I have to die, I shall be steadfast [in my dharma], provided it is for the velfare of the virtuous people;
.For a king will certainly tall, if he does not do thus.
.</p>
6935<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.71.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.71.04" n="4">In truth a king should do nothing except for the good of others; *
.He should be compassionate tovards all and comfort those in grief and need;
.For this indeed is the reason why a monarch rules over hosts of great heroes;
.If he does not do thus, people will censure him and regard him as no better than those who fall into hell.*
.
6940</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="71" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.72" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.72">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.72.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.72.01" n="1">Dasānana, you must cease doing infamous deeds,
.Be foolish no more; but be virtuous; killing excellent kings without reason
.Must be stopped. This is what I wish for as a token of your surrender,*
6945For there is no vealth more precious to me than the velfare of the vorld.’
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.72.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.72.02" n="2">Thus spoke the king, and Daśamukha was delighted. The great sage spoke:
.’Your Majesty, your wish is most excellent, proving that you are in truth a pre-eminent king;
.For indeed a king should not be negligent of his duty to protect the vorld;
6950And abowe all he should extend his protection to the hermits living in the wooded mountains.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.72.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.72.03" n="3">The steadfastness of mind of the ascetic should also be the characteristic of the mind of an excellent priest, as well as that of a supreme king; *
.The beauty of his realm is his retreat, just as the mountain [to the ascetic];
.The vicked and the evil-doers are tempters who bring confusion;
6955They fill the whole vorld as the goddesses [come to bring temptation to the ascetic] in the hermitage.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.72.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.72.04" n="4">However, the difficulties [in dealing with the vicked] are not the same as those faced in dealing with goddesses,
.For vhile the latter all disappear and take flight if the ascetic disregards them,
.It is the nature of the will.ins to increase, if no action is taken against them.
6960Accordingly, a king should not be outvitted by them.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.72.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.72.05" n="5">As to the merit of a king who is able to conquer evil,
.He is regarded as being as poverful as an incarnation of Wiṣṇu, and will rule as a vorthy protector of the vorld.
.Even in his seventh reincarnation, he will surely still be a great king;
6965Even if he did not need to return to this vorld, being a sublime person, he would be able to do so, — there is no doubt of this.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.72.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.72.06" n="6">For it is to such a king that one directs one’s inmost thought in reciting incantations and concentrating one’s mind; and through him that one makes one’s covenant in the depths of one’s mind;*
.For the king thinks what a great sage thinks, and he says what a great sage says.
.Truly, he is the parent of the three vorlds, the life of all creatures;*
6970The goal that the king pursues is indeed no different from that which a priest sets his heart on.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.72.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.72.07" n="7">This means, that the dharma you have chosen is a proper one, therefore carry it out, and have no anxiety;
.You must be unvearying in your struggle to overcome evil,*
.And if you overcome it, this is the best vay for you to reach heavenly bliss.’
6975Thus spoke the great priest, and the great heroic king Arjuna replied:
.
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="72" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73.01" n="1">’O great sage, your vords are indeed most excellent and contain a great mystery;
6980But this highest truth was of no use to me, when I intended to die in battle;
.Moreover [it is already pre-ordained that] a priest who is an incarnation of Wiṣṇu, and is famous for his courage, will be the cause of my death,*
.And only then shall I return to the heaven of Śiva to enjoy the godhead of Īśvara.’
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73.02" n="2">Thus were their deliberations; let us tell no more of them. We will tell now of Rāvaṇa.
6985He begged the king to visit the splendid kingdom of Ləṅkā
.Together with the sage, so that the whole country could pay homage to them;
.But king Kārtavīrya refused and rejected this request, the great Rāvaṇa then said no more.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73.03" n="3">Then king Kārtavīrya addressed the sage:
6990’As for the kings and heroic Warriors who were slain in battle,
.Please revive them now — this is the favour I ask of you,
.And as for the fallen demons, revive them as well.’
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73.04" n="4">Thus spoke the king, and the sage consented wholeheartedly.
6995Rāvaṇa was delighted to hear the king’s vords.
.Soon after the great sage was silent, rain suddenly poured dovn from the sky as though it had been squeezed;
.And the rain revived all the fallen heroes, so great was the magical pover of the great sage.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73.05" n="5">The elephants, horses, chariots and all kinds of veapons were all returned to their former state, in perfect condition.
7000Likevise, the gongs, drums and everything on the battlefield, as well as the ranks of musicians.
.After they had been returned to their former state, they came into the presence of the king of kings,
.And the demons bowed respectfully to Rāvaṇa.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73.06" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73.06" n="6">We tell no more of this. After they had made friends with one another, the sage departed;
7005Then Rāvaṇa, after taking leave of the king, set out to his ovn kingdom.
.The king and the queen were delighted
.That the perfect sage had revived the fallen heroes.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73.07" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73.07" n="7">We tell no more of this. After some time the king finally set out for his palace,
7010Accompanied by the hosts of tributary kings, and soon they reached Mahispati.
.Some happily recounted hov the king had vanquished his foes,
.Others told hov the king in his dreadful form had blocked the flov of the Narmadā.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73.08" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73.08" n="8">It would take long to describe them. We now tell of the king of the Hehayas:
7015The vorld had prospered; the vicked, evil-doers and rascals trembled in fear,
.And the demons were frightened and terrified because they had witnessed the king’s might,
.And because he incessantly pursued and searched out all those infamous creatures.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.73.09" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.73.09" n="9">He practised divine vorship assiduously, ever bestoving vealth on all [in need];
7020Night and day made no difference to him, for he was completely devoted to his dharma.*
.And so the Lord Buddha was well pleased to behold him from the Void,
.And all the gods and virtuous men praised his deeds.
.
.</p></div>
7025<div type="canto" n="73" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.74" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.74">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.74.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.74.01" n="1">Thus ends the versification of the tale that begins with the story of Daśāsya;*
.It is called the Triumph of Arjuna, a well.known story that has been told again and again.
.This is the poetic composition of one whose parab is Tantular,*
.Who is undeviating in his actions; ignorant of the subtleties of the Art, he nevertheless joins those in the poetic trance.*
7030</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.74.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.74.02" n="2">And the reason why he has vritten this poem and devoted his heart and mind to joining those who compose poetry*
.Is to praise lord Wiṣṇu, who is regarded as Buddha in His visible form,
.For Daśamukha and even Arjuna, both supremely poverful in battle,*
.Were slain in the past by the famous incarnations of Wiṣṇu, the blessed.
7035
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="74" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.75" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.75">
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.75.01" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.75.01" n="1">All the arrows fired at the vicked souls were poverless to harm them;*
.Only the arrows of lord Wiṣṇu were able to destroy them, and at their deaths they were purified,
7040And so reached the abode of Hari as a mark of great favour.
.And at the sight of their masters fallen on the battle-ground, all the evils attendant upon them vanished.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.75.02" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.75.02" n="2">This [namely to honour lord Wiṣṇu] then is the reason why the versification of this epic story has been the goal that this poet longs for,*
.And not because he — a foolish and ignorant man — is sufficiently well.versed [in poetry] to serve the king,*
7045For hov, without having mastered both exoteric and esoteric knowledge, could he satisfy his master’s mind?
.This is why he reached out for his pen, used the vriting leaves as a sun-shade, and counted the blossoming flowers.*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.75.03" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.75.03" n="3">And so far as this inexperienced Tantular is concerned, he is not in the least deterred by derision of others,*
.Nor does he care about any criticism of his conduct: he will persist in attempting to fulfil his aspiration.
7050It is clear that his verses cannot be used to comfort a sullen lady in the bed-chamber,
.But Tantular is not grieved by censure, nor is he delighted by praise of his virtue, … (?)*
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.75.04" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.75.04" n="4">He is indeed a foolish, impudent poet, who does not know hov to compose a poem;
.He is moreover not conversant with vords, nor skilled in the literary expression, metrical rules or prosody, nor is he of outstanding quality.*
7055His work is far from being vorthy to be taken, and later be kept in the temple of books,*
.For the thought behind his work is not based on revelation; it is like gaḍuṅ vine trying to reach for the moon.
.</p>
.<p xml:id="arjunaVijaya_02.75.05" corresp="#arjunaVijaya_01.75.05" n="5">There is no doubt vhatsoever that his work will constantly be censured, reproved and laughed at by the great poets;
.But he is undeviating in his action in sending a poem vritten in the petals of the fragrant pandanus flowers.
7060In short, when he has reached the peak of his attempt to vrite poetry, and the nagasari flowers have withered,*
.The only One [that there remains] for him to long for is One whose epithet is ’The Spirit who is present in the Scripture’.*</p></div>
.
.<!--<div>NOTES TO THE TRANSLATION
.1,1 For comment on this stanza see Chapter 6 (esp. Section 6.3). Referring to this stanza, KBW 4: 126 (= ONW: 386) renders pramāna as ’familiar with’; and Soevito-Santoso (1968: 106-9) renders it ’creature’ or ’being’. Pramāna is a well.known term in Javanese mysticism. It has been discussed at length by Zoetmulder (1935: 216-9), Gonda (1952: 159-60) and Soebardi (1967: 609-10). The definition of this term is given in Cabolek 8,(33) (see Soebardi 1967), through the mouth of the god Ruci: uripe kan sarira / permana puniku / tuṅgal aneṅ sarira / naniṅ datan milu suka lan prihatin (This permana is the life of the body; it is one with the body, but it shares neither the joy nor the sorrow of the body). And the doctrine that the god Parvatarāja is the life of all pramāna is extremely reminiscent of Cabolek 8,(35): uripiṅ permanêku / muripan iṅ Suksma nəṅgih (the life of the permana derives from the Suksma). Just as Suksma, for the author of the Cabolek, is the Supreme Deity, so Parvatarāja is also the Supreme Deity for Tantular.
70651,2c-d
.It is possible to regard Yavendra as singular, (i.e. ’the king of Java’), but mukhya saṅ Paməkas-iṅ-Tusta ’the foremost among them is P.’ in 2d makes no sense unless Yavendra is regarded as plural. Hhis corroborated by the occurrence of srī Yavarāja in Nag. 6,4c and 17,7c in a plural sense, preceded by sakveh ’all’.
.For Paməkas-iṅ-Tusta, see Section 1.2.
.1,3a The translation ’to vrite a lengthy story’ for maṅdavākən kathā is rather uncertain. The usual meaning of mandavākən is ’to make something longer’, and in this context the vord is probably used in viev of the fact that the kakavin version of the story of Arjuna Sahasrabāhu is much longer than the prose version (kathā). However, in the light of mamañjaṅ kakavin which means ’to recite kakaviṅ (KBW 4: 301; cf. amañjaṅi in ONW: 330), maṅda-vākən kathā could simply mean ’to recite or to read, the story’.
.For cumataka ’to have the audacity’ see Notes 36,2d.
70701,3b In the translation I have regarded the arealis suffix in vintaṅ-vintaṅa as having a concessive meaning. However, it is also possible to regard this arealis suffix as indicating ’hope’, and so to translate this line ’may [this vriting] be like a little star to [the vritings] of those who are as the moon [in the vriting] of poetry’, which implies that ’even if this vriting is only like a little star in comparison to the vritings of the great poets, I shall be satisfied’. Such comparison, in a slightly different form, also occurs in Sut. 148,3d-4c:
.lvir saṅ hyan sasi rakva purna paṅapus nira n anuluhi rat /
.bheda
.mva
.ṅ
7075daməl i ṅhulun kadi pataṅga n umibər i lemah
.(the perfection of their composition is like that of the moon illuminating the vorld; mine is different: it is just like a firefly flying [close to] the ground).
.1,3c For suddha ’to reduce’ see KBW 3: 154; for rna ’debt’ see KBW 1: 697. Panuddha-rna is probably a Javanese rendering of the Sanskrit rna-sodhana ’payment or discharge of debt’ (SED: 1082).
.1,3d-4c
.For a discussion on the historical personalities mentioned in this passage see also Section 1.3. Krom (1910; 1914b) has identified Ranamaṅgala as raden Sumirat mentioned in Par: 29,25. Berg (1962: 113) suggests that Ranamaṅgala was a ’substitute king’ of the kapancatathāgatan kingdom of Sirihasari-Majapahit, who was ’door Rājasanagara zelf plechtig, d.i. ritueel, met de vervanging belast vas’. However, is is perhaps strange that Tantular does not mention anything of this exalted position of his master (that is, if Ranamaṅgala was known as a ’substitute king’ to his contemporaries), since he seems to have felt a need to justify his master’s appropriateness as the maṅgala, i.e. ’patron’, of his poem (4c), as is evident from the invocations of Ranamangala’s father (4a) and mother-in-lav (4b).
70801,4a From the historical context, brātratmaja ’brother’s son’ must mean ’the son of the half-brother’. This half-brother of Rājasanagara has been identified by Krom (1910) as Sotor mentioned in Par: 29,24. Since the name ’Sotor’ does not occur in any contemporary document, Berg (1954: 194) suggests that it derives from Sonder, the name of the hino of Majapahit mentioned in OJO 84. An objection, but probably not a serious one, to this suggestion is that if graphology and linguistics, as Berg argues, have played a part in this change from ’Sonder’ to ’Sotor’, then ve would expect that the older name (that is the inscription name) should be Sotor, and the later Sonder. Grapho-logically it is easier for an ’o’ (taliṅ-taruṅ) to become ’e’ (talin) by losing its taruṅ than vice-versa, and linguistically the nasalized form is usually the more recent one (see Poerbatjaraka 1932: 189-98). Another possible identification for Sotor is Īsvara, the hino of Majapahit mentioned in OJO 85. This could have been Sotor’s abhiseka name. His father’s name is recorded in the Ferry Charter (JFC 1: 108) as Cakresvara, although in Par: 27,13 he is called Cakradhara (see Krom 1931: 384). It may not be a mere coincidence that Rājasanagara’s sister, who was to be Sotor’s besan, was called Īsvari (Nag. 5,2; see Krom 1931: 385; Noorduyn 1969: 542).
.Since Tantular must have known the family of his patron well. to translate rakva in 4a, and elsewhere, by ’it is said’, indicating that the author’s infor-mation is secondhand (see JFC 2:5), would be misleading. ’Nov’ or ’mark you’ is clearly more appropriate in many cases (cf. Teeuw and others 1969: 149).
.1,4b Pigeaud (JFC 2: 9-10), referring to Zoetmulder (1950: 204), translates təkvan by ’naturally’. Johns (1964: 538) rightly notes that according to Zoetmulder it should be rendered by ’further, moreover’. Berg (1962: 290; 1969: 411) renders tekvan by ’merkvaardigevijze’ or ’mirabile dictu’. Taking into account Berg’s remark (1962: 298) that ’… de juiste nuance van dit
.soort voorden is moeilijk te treffen …’, I am of the opinion that ’further, moreover’ fits well here, and elsewhere in the present kakavin (e.g. 10,10a; 31,1b; 31,15a; 43,3a; 44,2a).
.The use of təkvan here indicates that Tantular considered the relationship mentioned in this line more important than that mentioned in 4a. This is quite understandable, since Ranamaṅgala’s mother-in-lav was by birth of higher rank than his ovn father.
70851,5 a Since rənə̄n also means ’vell-known’ (ONW: 465), this line can be translated: ’the beginning of this story is well.known to those accomplished in poetic arts’. If this translation is right, ve may perhaps interpret ’the well.known beginning of this story’ as the episode related in the kakavin Harisraya (see Section 1.4). The main theme of the Harisraya is referred to in stanza 1,6.
.1,7b umidhyani is not listed in any published dictionary. KBW 3: 512 (= ONW: 538) gives vidhi ’command’ and some other meanings, none of which fit this passage. However, in KBG: 507 ’tuduh’ is listed as the Balinese equivalent of vidhi occurring in Ram. 6,194d. Nov, in Arj. 24,2d anuduh-nuduhi means ’to point out; to shov’, and in New Javanese nuduhi may mean ’to shov; to tell; to inform’. Hence my translation ’to tell’ for umidhyani, and ’without the knowledge of’ for tan vidhi niṅ (Arj. 23,2d).
.1,10a Mahltala is a puzzle here. In Sanskrit it always means ’the surface of the earth; ground’ (SED: 803). However, since ve read in 1,8a that Sumāli ’emerged into the vorld of mortals’ from the undervorld (pātala; 1,6d), it seems not likely mahltala in this line means ’the surface of the earth’. The corresponding passage of the OJ Utt. reads: humiṅsor muvah mareṅ pātala ’he returned to the undervorld’. Probably there is some confusion here between mahltala, and mahātala ’name of the 6th of the 7 lover vorlds under the earth’. And so mahltala can mean both ’the surface of the earth’ (see 9,3c; 39,3a; 45,13a; 59,11b) and ’the undervorld’ (see 1,10a; 40,4c; cf. Notes 8,12d). This argument is corroborated by an occurrence of mahltala as a place name in Kor: 200,19 which is said to be the abode of bhatāra Bāsuki, a serpent king (Svellengrebel’s emendation to Mahātala, therefore, is probably not necessary).
.1,10c The usual meaning of abhiseka ’anointing; consecration’ (SED: 71) does not fit here. KBW 1: 456 (= ONW: 34) translates the abhiseka of this line as ’assuming a beautiful appearance’, and JNW 2: 706 gives biseka ’adorned, beautified’. This meaning probably derives from the fact that during a consecration ceremony one is always adorned beautifully.
.1,11a The corrupt reading of y1 (sastra hajə̄ṅ) is included in the Variae Lectiones, not because it is a possible reading of the archetype, but because this corrupt reading is responsible for the rise of an esoteric doctrine in a later period. This corrupt reading is caused by a loss of ’ṅ’ (cecak) in saṅ and ’y’ (peṅkal) in stryāhajə̄ṅ. The reading of this line in y1 is thus: ndan san pandit a vidyacitta vihikan kāryanya sastrāhajə̄ṅ. As it stands, it can be
7090translated ’and the vise sage knev of the purpose (i.e. the meaning?) of the sastra hajə̄ṅ’. Since hajə̄ṅ (or hajəṅ), hayu and ar ja or arə ja are synonymous in Old Javanese (cf. rahajəṅ, rahayu and raharja in New Javanese), sastra hayu or sastra arja may be used instead of sastra hajə̄n. And in Arkm. 1,8-10 indeed ve read: sastra harjendra, sastra cəta arjeixrat and sastra ceta. And according to the Arkm., this sastra cəta is a book containing the teaching about: purvaka niṅ dumadi, vasana niṅ dumadi, yun in jiva muksa (the beginning of creation, the end of creation, the wish for [or: ’the beauty of’ for ayu nm?] final emancipation). To the present day Javanese this teaching of sastra cəta or sastra harjendra is known as ’ṅelmu sastra jendra’ (see Dreves 1966: 356-7; Note 52). In some parts of Central Java, there is even a mystical sect which calls itself ’Sastrajendra’ (see Supomo 1964).
.1,13d Instead of tan gə̄ṅ krodha, yhas taṅgcṅ kodha. It is from this copyist’s error that Wibhīsana is known to the present day Javanese as Koda-vibisana. There is no doubt that this error was already present in the manuscripts used by Yasadipura when he vrote the Arkm., for ve read in Arkm. 3,9: vus sinuṅan nama nira Koda-vibisana (and he was named Koda-vibisana); and in Arsy. 2,3-4: semana vus sinuṅ aran // saṅ Koda-vibisanêki (then he was named Koda-vibisana).
.1,16d
.- 17a The choice of the reading magalar is not quite convincing. The variant magalā seems to be closer to the reading of the OJ Utt: makakāla, but the latter too is far from certain (Zoetmulder (1958: 19) lists three variants for makakāla). Magalar is probably a variant of magelar (cf. kambaṅ - kəmbaṅ; sambah - sembah); aṅgəlar means ’to perform (a ritual, a sacrifice)’ (see Teeuw and others 1969: 313).
.Śivāgni is merely another name for Agni, the god of Fire (see KBW 3: 226; Krom 1923: 38-9; Gonda 1932: 286).
7095In
.Kor:
.160,20 ve read that
.Rāvaṇa’
.s asceticism is performed by Duryo-dhana: sāksāt sari Dasānana tiṅkahnyâṅlarani sariranya, tendasnya pinu-kahnira, pinakapamūjānira ri saṅ hyaṅ Śivāgni.
71001,17c
.The usual meaning of āscarya in Sanskrit is ’strange; wonder; aston-ishing’ (SED: 158); in New Javanese it means either ’astonished’ or ’delighted’ (JNW 1: 91). Contextually both meanings fit here. However, since ve read in the OJ Utt. that Brahmā was delighted by Rāvaṇa’s asceticism (atyanta sukha ni ambeku, Zoetmulder 1958: 20,3), I translate āscarya in this passage by ’delighted’.
.Teeuw and others (1969: 139) translates āscarya occurring in Siv. 35,Id by ’perplexed’. In the context of the story, ’delighted’ seems more appropriate: since Śi va had explained to Yama why Lubdhaka was brought to heaven instead of to hell, there is no reason why Yama should be perplexed ’to see hov Sahara has become the equal of the gods’. Yama should have been delighted at the outcome of the story, as should everyone.
.1,18c-d
.Although the phrase (dū bhagyaṅ would be the most natural to begin a direct speech to velcome a visitor (cf. 12,1a), I take the direct speech
7105as beginning from sembah in 18d. This is because the phrase masahur sembah is, as far as I know, unknown in Old Javanese, as well as in New Javanese. The closest phrase is Malay berdatang sembah which can mean ’to say respect-fully’, but this does not mean ’to ansver; to reply’. But even if masahur sembah is acceptable as a phrase which means ’to reply reverently’, hyaṅ mami ’my God; my Lord’, would be inexplicable, if this phrase did not belong to a direct speech.
.1,21b kətikaṅ (also occurs in 4,6a; 45,8a) or ketika occurs neither in the dictionaries, nor in Zoetmuder’s book on the language of the Ādip. (1950). It appears to be an emphatic particle, perhaps derived from a combination of kəta and ika (cf. tika: ta and ika, Zoetmulder 1950: 24). This particle already occurs in one of the earliest Old Javanese works, the Bhīsmaparva (see Gonda 1936: 42; 43). It also occurs in Nag. 16,3b and, in a slightly corrupt form, in 16,2b, but all the previous editors and commentators have failed to recognise it as such (see e.g. JFC 2: 33, and other suggestions referred to by Pigeaud there).
.As transcribed in JFC 1: 13, the text of Nag. 16,3b reads: i gurun i bāli mukya kavnaṅ parānaktikā. There is no doubt that it should read: i Gurun i Bāli mukhya kavinan parāna kətikā. For Nag. 16,2b the manuscript reads: apituvin ajña hajya tan asiṅ parānantikā. For the slightly corrupt form parānantikā, I propose an emendation to parānaktikā, which graphologically is not impossible. In fact, instead of suraktikaṅ (i.e. sura kətikaṅ, Arj. 45,8a) ve read surāntikaṅ in manuscript A. With this minor emendation, Nag. 16,2b reads: apituvin apia hajya tan asiṅ parāna ketika. Syntactically, the structure of Nag. 16,2b and 16,3b are thus the same as Nag. 16,1c: vənaṅ ika yan pakon nrpati siṅ parāna to kunan. In these sentences, ketika occupies the same syntactic position as ta kunaṅ, which is known as an emphatic particle (see Zoetmulder 1950: 196; cf. Notes 43,1c).
.1,21c Although the meaning of kaveni given here seems to be beyond doubt, its etymology is difficult to ascertain. KBW 3: 453 (= ONW: 557) lists it under veni and translates: ’invited’. Zoetmulder (ZS: 21) gives ’attracted to; feel attracted to’. My translation ’to have an inclination tovards’ is based on Zoetmulder’s rendering.
.1,25a Referring to kagamanan in this line KBW 4: 792 (= ONW: 162) gives ’varned? favoured?’. In this context the latter is more likely. Probably it is related to the Sanskrit gamanlya, which means ’accessible, approachable; to be followed or observed’ (SED: 348).
71102,2a KBW 4: 799 lists gamyosadhi, referring to this passage, but gives no explanation. Juynboll in ONW: 162, apparently regarding it as a compound: gamya and osadhi, gives ’potent medicine’. In the context it does not make any sense. Probably it should be regarded as a Sanskrit compound: gamya and sadhi. SED: 1140 gives sadhis as ’the end or goal of any movement, the place where it comes to rest’. Gamyosadhi thus could mean ’to go to one’s destin-ation’. It seems to be the equivalent of aṅadisthāna which occurs in the
.corresponding passage of the OJ Utt. However, this would imply that all the gods vent to the tongue of Kumbhakarna, instead of the goddess Sarasvatī alone (in the OJ Utt. Sarasvatī goes alone).
.2,6c-d The translation is tentative. The exact meaning of jagatpramāna here is difficult to ascertain, and its position and function in the syntax is not at all clear (for pramāna see Notes 1,1).
.3,1-9 For comments on this passage, the reader is also referred to Section 5.1.
.3.1a lvir … sakala is an expression which occurs fairly often in Tantular’s works, as well as in the Nag. (see JFG 5: 257). In the present work, this expression is usually translated by ’exactly like’ (cf. KBW 3: 136), although, depending on the context, ’in visible form’ (e.g. 1,10d: lvir devi sakala), and simply ’like’ are not rare. In this phrase sakala seems to be interchangeable with vords such as sāksāt and rūpa (thus ve read: lvir Mrtyu sakala (3,2d), besides kadi Mrtyu rūpa (5,3c) and lvir Mrtyu sāksāt (7,7b)). Sometimes sakala also occurs by itself in this meaning, either post-positionally (e.g. 55,3b: Mrtyu sakala; cf. 59,8b: Mrtyu tulya; both similes are used for flaming veapons), or pre-positionally (e.g. 20,2a: sakalêsvara; cf. 12,2b: sāksāt Paramesvara).
71153,1c Since the poet is still engaged in describing the outer part of the city here, aṅalun-alun ’vavy; rolling’ is better than another possible reading an alun-alun (i.e. the alun-alun yard looks like an ocean).
.3,2a indranlla ’sapphire’ is mentioned as one of the navaratna ’nine jewels’. However, as Svellengrebel (1936: 232) has noted, the Kor. in fact lists ten jewels, not nine. Since here indranlla is mentioned separately from the nava-ratna, it is probably not to be included in them, and accordingly should be omitted from the list of the navaratna in Kor: 50,12-9.
.3,6c-d The translation of this passage is very tentative. The difficulty lies in the simile lvir byoma mapalih. The phrase lvir … (m)apalih also occurs in Nag. 4,Id (i.e. lvir sudevy apalih) referring to the queens of Daha and of Jīvana. A slightly different phrase occurs in Nag. 48,1c (i.e. baṅun rva niṅ Rati). Since this phrase is also used in connection with the same queens of Daha and Jīvana, the two phrases probably have the same meaning, namely: ’like a pair of Rati’. However, in the case of lvir byoma mapalih in this line, the translation ’like a pair (or: tvo) of firmaments’ is not likely, for there is only one natar to be compared. Hence my translation ’like the second firmament’.
.An alternative translation is ’like the sky being divided into two halves’ (cf. Nag. 68,1c: tevek niṅ Yāvabhūmy apalih), perhaps referring to the cloudless sky when the sun is about to set and the full moon to rise: a pale blue in the east, and fiery red in the vest.
.3,10c The usual meaning of tan kavulatan is ’cannot be seen; not visible’.
7120However, the literal translation ’the army quarters were not visible’ does not seem to fit the context. Hence my translation ’does not appear to be …’.
.4,Id The usual meaning of digjaya in Sanskrit is ’the conquest of various countries in all directions’. In this line digjaya seems to be a synonym for vəkas niṅ mahāsakti which occurs in 4,1b. In fact in Old Javanese, or at least in the Arj. (cf. 16,Id; 42,6d; 68,1a), the usual meaning of digjaya is closer to New Javanese dikdaya, namely ’poverful; invincible’ (JNW 1: 579; Gonda 1952: 233).
.4,2b The reading and the translation of anohaṅ are both far from certain. But other alternative readings, anoh an and anoha ṅ, do not offer a better solution. For anohaṅ I take the base form to be tohaṅ, probably related to tvaṅ (via toaṅ). Atvan means ’respectful’.
.4,2c-d Since palaṅka can mean ’throne’ (KBW 4: 239; ONW: 349), line 4,2c might be rendered ’then he seated himself on the throne …’ However, since the throne par excellence, the sihhāsana, is mentioned in the next line, such a translation is hardly likely.
.Gonda (1952: 97) is of the opinion that the New Javanese palanki ’palan-quin’ is derived from Portuguese ’palanquim’, which ’vas borrowed from the East’. It is more likely that palaṅki derives from the Old Javanese palaṅka. However, the more common vord for ’palanquin’ in Javanese is jampana. It was in a jampana that Rājasanagara made his appearance from the private quarters of the kraton (Nag. 84,1c: sobhâbhra pinikul in jampana). According to Navanatya: lib (see JFC 1), a palanquin was put not far from the lion-throne (tan madoh lavan jampana saṅ prabhu katirame niṅ siṅhāsana).
7125Wastrârja,
.si
.ṅhasana and suraga are probably parts of the tata pura (palace ceremonial order) similar to the ones mentioned in Navanatya: 17b, namely mahābhūsana, paliṅgihan amparan saha pramadani-kasur-kasuran mvaṅ pata-rana (i.e. grand attire, amparan-floor with small mattress made from carpet (= suraga?) and patarana (= siṅhasāna, i.e. throne?)).
.4,4c In Sanskrit yaksa is a term for a class of semi-divine beings, attendants of Kuvera, the god of vealth. In the OJ Utt. Gomukha is called simply a yaksa. That Tantular uses the expression aṅyaksarūpa ’to have the appearance of a yaksa’ to describe Gomukha, is in accordance with the common usage in this kakavin, namely that yaksa is more or less a synonym for rāksasa ’demon’ as in New Javanese, Sundanese and Balinese (see Gonda 1952: 134). It is remarkable that vhile Rāvaṇa is called ’the king of the yaksa’ several times in this poem (e.g. 4,12d; 6,19a; 52,6a; 70,1c) Waiśravaṇa is never so called.
.4,5c It is not incongruous to translate bapaṅku by ’our father’, since both Rāvaṇa and Waiśravaṇa are the sons of Wisrava. However, since in 10,9c Nandi addresses Rāvaṇa as bapaṅku, and here ’my (our) father’ cannot be meant, I prefer to regard bapaṅku here also as merely a form of address to Rāvaṇa. Both yayi and bapaṅku in this line refer to Rāvaṇa (see also 42,5a; 47,6a).
71304,7a Most of the manuscripts read təlasanâbuddhi murkhâvamana, which is not impossible. However, the minor emendation təlasana ṅ buddhi murkhâ-vamana is both intelligible and gives a better poetical effect, for this runs parallel with matəguha riṅ buddhi karunyacitta in 4,8b.
.4,7d Cf. Daniélou (1964: 136); ’Kubera is the companion and friend of Śiva and, as such, is called God’s friend (Īsa-sakhi)’.
.4,8d In KBW 1: 263 ve read selvan means ’go along with’, and salaku selvan is given as a synonym for salakvadulur and sakon paran. Sakvan saparan occurs in various works in the same sense as sakvan selvān in this passage (see Teeuw 1946: 82).
.4,11b lLvâmbek’ occurs repeatedly in the Arj. (12,1c; 47,5b; 52,5d; 67,3d), always in direct speech, and in most cases where a hero is addressing an enemy he wishes to attack or to kill. In such cases the meaning suggested in KBW 3: 710 (’be assured; make yourself at ease’) does not fit the context. The expression seems to be very close to New Javanese siṅ jəmbar səgarane ’have a heart as vide as the sea’, in the sense of ’be magnanimous; I beg your pardon’ (cf. JNW 1: 880).
.4.1 Id Syntactically this line is rather difficult. In the translation, I take bhataresvara … musuh as an independent clause inserted into the main clause ṅvaṅ tar kavedya. Such a construction, however, is not common in Old Javanese. And, moreover, even if it were possible, an arealis suffix is needed, probably affixed to bhatāresvara, to indicate the concessive modality. However, the second possibility, namely that bhataresvara is the sārana of nvaṅ, is grammatically also unacceptable: instead of -nya ve would expect -ṅku, unless ve regard -nya as having the same function as the New Javanese -ne. Moreover, Rāvaṇa had abused the god Īsvara just a fev lines before, so it seems unlikely that here he considers Īsvara his protector.
71355.2 I accept van der Tuuk’s suggestion that abal-abalan (KBW 1: 425; see especially: surake ambal-ambalan; cf. JNW 1: 181), primarily means ’repeat-edly’. However, Zoetmulder’s reading: balâbala-bala ndah …, is not im-possible, and in this case this line may be translated ’The soldiers, the weak and the strong ones, were crovded together; they were all kinds of …’.
.5,8b KBW 2: 495 quotes the whole line, but does not give any explanation. The usual meaning of dəliṅ given in various dictionaries (KBW; ONW; JNW) is ’to open one’s eyes’. This does not seem to fit the context. However, in JNW 1: 596, ve also find that dədəliṅ is a synonym of pideksa ’handsome and bravny’. It is interesting to note that in New Javanese slang, melek ’to open one’s eyes’ can also mean ’beautiful; handsome’, especially for a young man or woman.
.5,9a prakopa means ’anger, rage, vrath’. In this line, therefore, it may simply mean ’the furious one’, referring to Rāvaṇa himself; and the men-
.tioning of his veapon as sy amogha seems to corroborte this interpretation (cf. amoghasakti 18,9c; 56,1a). However, I agree with van der Tuuk (KBW 4: 79) that prakopa is also used as a proper name in this kakavin. This is clear from 17,7c and the subsequent stanzas, where this demon fought the battle against the Ayodhya army, and eventually was slain by the king of Ayodhya (18,3).
.6,1a An alternative translation (’When the marvellous Rāvaṇa himself had set out, the rear-guard began to march’), is less likely. Ry aṅkat is a stereotype occurring in almost all kakavin. In the context ’then he departed’ is better than ’vhen he departed; at the time of his departure’ (see also 17,1a; 54,3a; cf. JFC 5: 153-4).
7140In Old Javanese the base form laku may be used to form verbs with the basic meaning of ’to ask’ and ’to valk; to go’ (ONW: 479-80). But in no Javanese dictionary does it occur with the meaning ’as; like’. However, in Bahasa Indonesia, selaku is used in this sense (cf. pindah ’to move’ and pinda ’to be like; to resemble’; see Berg 1969: 448; Teeuw and others 1969: 152).
.6,1b ratha kuda mahulu rvā hastivadana is far from certain. Ratha kuda is probably a compound, which means ’cart dravn by a horse’. Mahulu could mean either ’having a head’ or ’having something in front’. Could it be ’a horse with two elephant-heads’? Or simply: ’the cart was dravn by horse(s) and two elephants’? Another possibility is: ’the cart was decorated with the two elephant-heads’. As fancy seems to play a part here, it is difficult to decide between one possibility or the other.
.6,1c This line is reminiscent of Tap. 103,16 sqq., in which Kālarudra, i.e. Bhatāra Guru in his demoniac form, wished to consume the entire vorld (mahyun manadaha sahisi nin bhuvana; see also Arj. 46,1b: kadi Kālarudra maharep mamaṅana bhuvana).
.6,3a-b
.It is not impossible to read: ’Guntur mumbul, gunuṅ rug, vukir alas aṅalih; lvir umbak anasut/tiṅkah niṅ rāksasâtyadbhuta bala …’ (The erup-tions burst upvard, mountains collapsed and wooded hills moved, [because] like surging vaves were the movements of the terrible demon army of Ləṅkā as they marched out. But let us not describe their advance; the demons …).
71456,5c The expression … baṅun atuluṅ svānânəmu lara probably derives from a collection of animal stories, such as the Jataka (cf. Notes 6,6-7), but I have been unable to trace its source. If such a story does not exist, however, Tantular might have derived this theme from the story of a Brahmin who helped a tiger bitten by a serpent. The Brahmin was filled with pity for the tiger, and he revived it. Once the tiger was alive again, it devoured the Brahmin (see Hooykaas 1931: 144-46).
.6,6-7 This passage, in only slightly modified versions, is also known from at least two other Old Javanese works, namely the Tantri Kamandaka (Hooykaas 1931) and the Slokāntara (Sharada Rani 1957).
.Tak
.:
.38,14-2
71502 reads:
.Ikan mrga mañjaṅan kidaṅ, vehana pva ya mās, tan padon iriya (6a); kunaṅ kahyunya, uvakəna riṅ alas, vehana māṅsaa dukut, antyanta ika sukhanya (6b). Maṅkana ikaṅ vānara, vehana ratna bhūsana, tan tusta buddhinya (6c); amaneka taru, mamāṅsaa sarva phala juga kahyunya, tusta ika manahnya (6d). Maṅkana sūkara vijuṅ, suṅana pva ya sugandha lepana, tan tusta manahnya (7a); kunaṅ kahyunya yan umuṅgv in pacaryan, banəran tustâmbəknya juga (7b).
.This passage has been translated into Dutch by Hooykaas (1931: 38).
.Slok: 50,6 sqq. reads:
.Ika
7155ṅ mrga, kidaṅ mañjaṅan, tan pinakasukha niṅ tvasnya ika yan vehana mās mvaṅ bhūsana (6a); kunaṅ ika yan pinakasukha niṅ manahnya, yan hanêṅ alas akveh dukutnya hayu, mvaṅ alaṅ-alaṅ, ramban-rambanan, yeka jənək m manahnya (6b). Maṅkana ikaṅ vānara, yan vehana sahana niṅ ratna mūlya, tan pinakasukhanya ika (6c); kunaṅ yan umulat irikaṅ vvah-vvahan mənduh pada matasak, yeka magave sukhanya (6d). Maṅkana tekaṅ və̄k, tan sukha ika de niṅ sarva sugandha (7a); kunaṅ ikaṅ magave sukha ri tvasnya, paṅemeh rikaṅ pacaryan durgandha, yeka manukhani cittanya (7b).
.This passage has been translated into English by Sharada Rani (1957: 92-3).
.Hooykaas (1929: 132) suggests the Tantri Kamandaka dates from ’before 1500, probably in about 1000 (A.D.)’. In the light of evidence from the Arj., ve may conclude that the Tantri Kāmandaka, or an older version of it, must have been in existence when Tantular vrote the Arj. The terminus ante quem of the Tantri Kāmandaka can thus be put at 1379, i.e. the date of the completion of the Arj.
.6,7d KBW 3: 166 (= ONW: 642) gives sot in this line as ’inherited disposition’, which I find rather difficult to fit into the context (see also 21,6d). The primary meaning of sot is ’curse’ (JNW 1: 795), and sot an ’because’ is probably derived from this meaning, i.e. ’through the curse of’. This is comparable to the use of Indonesian berkat ’blessing’ as a conjunction or preposition which means ’because’ (cf. English: thanks to; oving to). I take sot niṅ as a variant of sotan.
.6,8b For YogandhT and Wiṣṇu see p. 24.
71606,8d
.The reading of this line is uncertain. Zoetmulder’s text reads: Cakrāsya Krodhabhajragada Parasu balâbalân alahana. Since balâbalân alahana does not seem to make any sense, I read it as Bala-Abala-Anala hana. For the justification of the choice of readings of the proper names, see the List of Proper Names.
.6,14d Waktrāsya
.does not occur in the list of the officers enumerated in 6,8c-d. Could it be a copyist’s error for Cakrāsya?
.7,6b The Sanskrit names of the two demons mentioned here (i.e. Tusta and Sārana) are Suka and Sārana. The Ram. and OJ Utt. still have these spellings (see KBG: 539; Zoetmulder 1958: 25), but it is not clear from these text editions vhether they originally occurred in the manuscripts or vhether they have been quietly adjusted to Sanskrit spelling (such practice is quite usual in the Old Javanese text editions, and in most cases is justifiable; see p. 89). In any case, Suka and Śārana are the most common spellings in all good manuscripts of the Arj., and therefore I accept them as the readings of the prototype of the kakavin, and most likely as the usual spellings in Tantular’s time. The reading ’Tusta’ is therefore preferable to the variant dusta ’vicked’. It seems that in Tantular’s days, this demon was no longer known as Śuka ’parrot’, but as Suka (i.e. sukha) ’happy; bliss’. And ’tusta’, as ve have mentioned in p. 4, is a synonym of sukha. The change from suka to sukha and from sārana to sārana is quite understandable. In Javanese pronuntiation, there is no difference between a palatal and dental sibilant, nor between an aspirated and non-aspirated consonant. In Javanese ortho-graphy, there is not even a symbol for ’kh’.
71657,7d The translation of this line is rather uncertain. The difficulty is partly structural and partly semantic. It is not very clear vhether there should be a semi-colon after vijña. If vijña here means ’to know’, which is probable, then the semi-colon is not required, and the remainder of the sentence is the object of vijña (thus an ’inhoudszin’, see Zoetmulder 1950: 176). The line accordingly is to be translated: ’It was not out of fear …, but because he knev that …’.
.The semantic difficulty concerns the vord tumaha, which means ’to reflect; to mind’, and so ’to be concerned for’ or ’to be afraid of’. Both meanings are uncertain in the context, because from the subsequent story it is clear that Rāvaṇa is neither concerned for, nor afraid of his brother. Or is it possible that tumaha refers not to Rāvaṇa but to Prahasta? This seems unlikely unless the following vords (saṅ Dasāsyêṅ kaka) are used for metrical reasons in place of i kaka (ni) saṅ Daśāsya.
.8,7c The objection to the adopted reading (i.e. ’… bhūmi kampa, acala makasulayah, siṅ katub …’ is that acala should be preceded by a definite article (v, tikaṅ). An alternative reading is: ’…bhūmi kampā cala, maka-sulayah siṅ katub …’ (’… but the earth shook and moved, and anything they struck collapsed and was reduced to dust…’).
.8,8d
.strl
7170(sa)kendran ’women of heaven’ is a Javanese equivalent of su-rāṅgana ’women of the gods’. They are the ’eternally young women who are the courtesans of the dancers of heaven’ (Daniélou 1964: 305).
.8,11a ’sahana sirêṅ’ is unidiomatic. The reading of ’y’ (i.e. sahana nirêṅ) is probably better. The different reading, however, does not affect the trans-lation (cf. Notes 26,3c).
.8,12b Literally: ’by the incessant [showers of] all kinds of veapons the vater of the sea was hot as if being boiled’.
.8,12d The translation is rather uncertain. Probably in prose this line would read: ’bək ghor sampun pada tumedun tekêṅ bhūtala …’ (With a terrible boom they descended to bhūtala, and the terrified serpents were in uproar). However this implies that the bhūtala ’the surface of the earth’ is the abode of serpents, which, in Indian cosmogony, is unacceptable, since the serpents live in the undervorld (Daniélou 1964: 308; see also Notes 40,4a-b). Or is it possible that bhūtala can also mean ’undervorld’? (cf. Notes 1,10a: mahitala).
.9,2d It seems to have been a common belief in those days that thunderbolts and other natural calamities struck only the vicked. See e.g. Nag. 1,4c-d: ’lindu ṅ bhūmi kətug hudan havu gərəh kilat aviletan m nabhastala / gun-tur taṅ himavān ri Kampud ananā ṅ kujana kuhaka māti tan pagap’.
717510,4 It is not certain vhether nisphala ’useless’ and bhagna ’broken’ refer to the pover of Rāvaṇa’s father, who is also the father of Waiśravaṇa (as adopted in the translation), or to Rāvaṇa’s bhakti ’devotion’ to his father. The key vord here is mahardhika, which can mean ’very prosperous; very poverful; a great sage’ (SED: 794; cf. New Javanese mardikeix rat ’vise or very poverful man’ (Gonda 1952: 309). This passage probably refers to the belief that a son is an all-important element in the attainment of eternal bliss in heaven, as vividly dramatised in the story of Jaratkaru (Adip: 24,3 sqq.).
.10,5b manembuṅ ave ha tīrtha, literally: ’ask [you] to give vater’. The position of kita in this sentence is rather confusing. If metrical considerations may be put aside, probably it should read: dhrstə̄pama n panəmbuṅ, kita aveha tlrtha ’if one who is suffering from thirst asks for vater, you should give it to him’.
.10,10b In viev of the fact that the god Indra does not occupy an important position in the Old Javanese pantheon, this line may be translated: ’Indra and other gods were not allowed…’. However, the translation adopted here (i.e. ’Indra, foremost among the gods’) is at least corroborated by a passage in 13,4-5, where Rāvaṇa related this episode to Wedavatī. Thus Rāvaṇa said: ’bhatāra Suranātha tovi juga tan vənaṅ yə̄mara’ (’even lord Indra is not allowed to visit’).
.10,11c It is curious that Nandīsvara is here said to have a monkey’s head. Nandi is the bull of Śiva, and he is most commonly shovn in the form of a bull lying dovn before the image of Śiva. As Nandikesvara he is represented in human form, but still with a bull’s head (see Daniélou 1964: 220).
.10,13a rumoh vit ikaṅ G. may be translated ’to destroy the trees of Mount G.’ (ONW: 478 mistakenly lists roha for roh, although the meaning given
7180there, ’to destroy’, is correct, cf. KBW 1: 690). However, ’to desroy the trees’ does not fit the context. In the corresponding passage of the OJ Utt. ve read: Ya ta matan nyan rohakən taṅanya kālih siki buṅkah nikaṅ Kailāsagiri (Zoet-mulder 1958: 24; sikî instead of siki is probably a better reading). Rumoh and n rohakən taṅanya convey the same idea, and vit can be used as a substitute for buṅkah, i.e. ’base’.
.10,20b anuramya is not known from the Javanese dictionaries (KBW; ONW; JNW). My translation ’delighted at’ is based on SED: 37, anu-ram, which can mean ’to be fond of’.
.10,21b Structurally this line is rather forced. In prose it would probably read: i gaganya honya movi suda, tales nikâkveh, literally: ’in the dry-fields there were movi, suda and plenty of tales tubers.
.ll,2c-d
.It is not certain what kind of building is a bvat siṅhāsana raṅkaṅ. Teeuw and others (1969: 47) suggest that raṅkaṅ ’vere ordinary dvelling-houses, of rectangular ground plan …’. However bvat siṅhāsana raṅkaṅ is certainly not a dvelling-house, for Tantular says in 2d that here was the place for the anchoress to ’anisakən huyaṅ’ (literally: ’to cool off the heat’, hence ’to refresh herself’). The building was enclosed with wooden valls. Soevito-Santoso (1968, Notes 14,2b) rightly argues that tətə̄ cannot mean ’lyrics’ as given in ONW: 245, and accepted as such by most scholars. He suggests that tətə̄ is either ’eaves’ or ’vall’. The latter is more probable. Zoetmulder (ZL: 128) gives ’a vall or partition of a pavilion’ and says further that ’people vrite kakavin on it’. However, the building is not wholly enclosed, at least one side should be open, in this case: the side from which one can look at the beauty of the sea (kalaṅvan iṅ pasir).
7185ll,3b-4b
.Although, apart from kagaməlan, there is hardly any lexical prob-lem, the exact meaning of this passage is not very clear, and its relation to 11,3a, the main clause, on which the whole passage depends, is even more obscure.
.Kagaməlana
.is ka passive arealis of aṅgaməli. As in New Javanese (see JNW 2: 618), in Old Javanese gaməl seems to have two basic meanings: (1) ’to hold’ (e.g. 40,1 Id: aṅgaməl susu) and (2) ’to play musical instruments’ (e.g. 31,13b: magaməl mrdaṅga). Neither meaning makes sense in this context. The in passive of aṅgaməli occurs tvice in the Sut., i.e. asavaṅ ginaməlan i kalaṅvan (Sut. 88,4d) and lvir ginaməlan iṅ akuṅ (Sut. 89,1b); in both passages ’to be absorbed in; to be captivated by’ seem to be the best rendering. Probably there is a slight semantical change here, from ’to hold’ or ’to hold fast’ to ’to hold one’s attention’ or, in passive, ’to be absorbed in’ (cf. guməgə̄ ’to hold’, which can be used in either physical or mental sense).
.11,4d The variant reading of F (i.e. panapakika) is not impossible. Zoet-mulder (ZS: 340) considers it an active verbal noun of tapak ’to set foot on’. However, the verbal noun of sapa ’to curse’ seems better contextually, because in this episode Rāvaṇa is cursed with death by Wedavatl.
719012,1 c-d An alternative translation is: ’But I beg your pardon, my Lord, for here you will find neither fruit nor food, nor even beautiful scenery to visit’. However, since in 10,20-2 ve read hov the demons enjoy various fruits and food offered by the hermits, this possible alternative is rather unlikely.
.12,2d Literally ’delight of this hermit’.
.12,4b rumta, literally ’your beauty’, is often used as a term of endearment for a belowed one. See for instance 41,5d; 36,3a, and some doubtful cases where both the original and the secondary meanings are possible, e.g. 12,7b; 41,4a (see also Notes 65,2c).
.12,4d
.An alternative translation, ’on account of your resemblance to the goddess …’, is equally acceptable (cf. JFC 5: 155, sub reh).
719512,5b The exact meaning of this simile is not very clear. The ideal waist for a beautiful maiden seems to be one about ’to snap’ under the veight of full breasts (avarna pəpəsa təkap iṅ payodhara, 67,2c), yet slim and tender (lvir pəpəs aṅgaluṅgaṅ araṅin, 32,9b). The metaphor ’young asoka leaves’ is probably used to evoke the tenderness and the softness of the waist.
.12,6b The common vord used in New Javanese for kamaga is kəcəlik (see JNW 1: 281; JNW 2: 520), which means (1) ’disappointed’ (see also ONW: 422); (2) ’to be fooled’. The former is probably derived from the latter meaning. In this line the poet means to say that the bees came around her calves, for they mistook her shapely calves for pudak flowers. Pudak, i.e. pandanus flower, is a favourite metaphor for maiden’s calves (see Notes 21,3b-d).
.12,6d
.For vival ’to move avay’, so ’to free oneself; to slip’, see JNW 2: 46. Another meaning of vival (see ONW: 543), probably also related to the first meaning, is ’to be disappointed’. This line therefore can be translated: ’as though to disappoint those intending to embrace you [for you will be moving like the breeze]’.
.12,7b The meaning abuhaya is here not certain. Van der Tuuk quotes this line in KBW 4: 338, but does not give any note. However, he gives ṅajap2 ’to pine for’ for a quotation from the Arv., and Teeuw (1946: 134; 249) gives ’vaiting faithfully’ for abuhaya which occurs in Bhom. 44.3b. Syntacti-cally it is not easy to determine vhether it is the moon which was pining for the moonlight (as given in the translation here), or the anchoress. In the latter case this line could be translated: ’because you pine for the moonlight [the moonlight, therefore, descends upon you]’.
720012,7d The translation is very tentative. Səkar is a synonym of kəmbaṅ ’flower’. In New Javanese, however, səkar is a krama vord for kəmbaṅ as well as
.temban
.’song; poem’. The krama form might derive from the close similarity between kəmbaṅ and temban, but it might also be possible that the use of səkar for temban is derived from the fact that Old Javanese poets used flowers, especially the petals of pandanus flowers (e.g. 74,5b: akirim kakavin i dala niṅ pudak sumar), to compose their poems, probably before they vrote them on more durable material. Hence my translation ’poem’ for səkar. Jinaha is even more uncertain. Van der Tuuk lists this vord under jaha (KBW 4: 34), but does not give any explanation. In JNW 2: 378 ve find a verb: an jaha, which is said to be more or less a synonym of ambələt. Nov, bələt (JNW 2: 721) is related to bulət, pulət, gulet, as well as vilət, which has the basic meaning of ’round; circle’ (cf. Malay: bulat). In Old Javanese amilət (e.g. 20,3d; 32,3c) means ’to intertvine; to tvine around’. From this last meaning, it is possible that amilət and añjaha acquire a nev meaning, namely ’to arrange flowers in a vreath; to compose a flower arrangement’, and later ’to compose’ (cf. Greek: anthologia). And so in New Javanese vilət (JNW 2: 55) is related to music and beauty in general. However, there is an objection for regarding jaha as the root for jinaha. In a hypothetical sentence like this one, ve would expect to have an arealis form for the verb, and so instead of jinaha, jahan or jahanen would be grammatically more acceptable (cf. Zoetmulder 1950: 150-1). It is more probable, therefore, that the root is jinah, which is a Javanese counting unit of ten. A small problem here is that instead of the more idiomatic piraṅ jinaha, ve have pirêkaṅ jinaha. However, as Zoetmulder (1950: 26) has pointed out, even in the language of the Adip., il and ikaṅ can have the same function (e.g. buntut niṅ kuda and buntut nikaṅṅ kuda). This line thus could literally mean ’hov many tens of poems are not enough’. It may perhaps be added here that the vord ’to count’ in Old Javanese usually can be used to denote ’to admire [beauty]’, e.g. 21,3d: aṅituṅi paṅjrah iṅ sekar; Nag. 17,Id: laṅə̄nya yênituṅ; Har. 2.13b: amilaṅ pasir vukir (amilaṅ is derived from vilaṅ, a synonym of ituṅ, and not from milan, as Teeuw (1950a: 95; 1950b: 8) suggests.
.12,10a Literally: ’And so I became old[er], my body grev, and I became a maiden’.
.12,12a Dosê ṅhulun stands for dosa ni ṅhulun.
720513,2d The translation ’the completion of ascetical exercises’ for antātapa (metri causa for antatapa?) is no more than conjecture. An alternative reading is: anindyaguna sakti vīra, sədəṅ antukantâtapa, which may be translated: ’[I am] blameless in virtue, pover and bravery, [and therefore I am] ap-propriate to be the attainment of your ascetical exercises’.
.13,7a-b Berg (1962: 102-3) has rightly pointed out that in Javanese stories the abode of Wiṣṇu is the heaven to which fallen heroes return (mantuk in Haripada).
.13,9a It is interesting to note that this somevhat uncontrolled outburst, which to the Javanese of today would seem rather strange coming from an anchoress,
.does not occur in the OJ Utt. That Tantular puts such crude vords in this curse shovs that the idea of alus and kasar, ’a pair of concepts central to this priyayi vorld-viev’ (Geertz 1969: 232) is probably a relatively late phenom-enon among the Javanese, developing more or less hand in hand with the emergence of the speech levels noko and krama.
.13,9c For sevya, SED: 1247 gives ’to be vaited upon or served or obeyed; a master; to be enjoyed carnally’.
721013,11b The corresponding passage of the OJ Utt. is followed by the story of the re-birth of Wedavatī, nda tan pasaṅkan garbhayoni, kavuluku rin setra juga sir a (she was born not from the vomb, but from the ploughing of the field). Hence she was to be called Sītā.
.14,1c For sakala ’precisely like’ see Notes 3,1a. An alternative translation, taking into acount that sakala may mean ’all’, is: ’where king Māruta ruled over all deva niṅ pura’. In this case, deva nin pura, literally ’the gods of the palace’, may mean ’the kings’. However, it is more likely that deva niṅ pur a is a Javanese equivalent of Sanskrit puradevatā, i.e. ’the tutelary deity of a tovn’ (SED: 635).
.14,2c-d
.The exact meaning of Salah dadi kadi dadi niṅ mamañcana is not certain. Salah can be either an adjective meaning ’vrong’ or a verb-stem meaning ’to lay dovn’. Dadi has various meanings, one of which is ’becoming flesh’. For this passage, the OJ Utt. has matemah-təmahan ’become; to change to another form’. Probably Salah dadi here is a synonym of matəmah-təmahan.
.Kadi dadi niṅ mamañcana is reminiscent of episodes in which the goddesses were sent dovn to the vorld in various disguises in an attempt to interrupt the ascetical exercises performed by the herous of many kakavin (see e.g. Arv. 1,6-4,9; Sut. 43,1-52,11).
721517,1a The name Banaputra (’son of an arrow’) does not occur in the Utt. There the king of Ayodhya is always called Anaranya. In the epic stories, Krpa, who was born from an arrow-shaft (see Adip: 125,14-26; 135,11) is the most appropriate person to bear this name. Since there is no relation vhatso-ever between Anaranya and Krpa, an explanation, if there is any, has to be sought elsewhere. One possibility is that the change of name took place in the oral transmission of the story. As ve have noted (see p. 25) the accepted name for Anaranya in Old Javanese is (H) aranya. Nov, aranya means wilderness; forest’, and so it is a synonym of vāna. Since bana may replace vāna in spoken Javanese (see JNW 2: 644; Gonda 1952: 250), it could also replace its synonym, aranya, thus giving the first step for the rise to the form banaputra ’son of the forest’. Banaputra is probably a hyper-correct form of Banaputra.
.17,2b For təgal gogrha see p. 60.
.17,4d There seems to be little doubt that kārun generally means ’with; at
.the same time’ (ONW: 117; Teeuw 1946: 161). Yet it is notevorthy that kārun seems always to occur in descriptions of battles, and one cannot but feel that in some cases, including this one, ’destroyed; broken to pieces’ is contextually not impossible.
.18,3b The usual meaning of deles is ’vick of lamp’ (see KBW 2: 489; JNW 1: 592), made of a piece of cloth or string. ’The string of the bow’ for dələs niṅ laras, therefore, would not be too far-fetched.
7220Episode 8: It has been said in Section 4.3 that from the poetical point of viev, episode 8 (20,1-38,10) is the most important addition that Tantular has made to the original story of the OJ Utt. In this episode ve find the most lyrical verses, which are more personal in nature than the epic part of the kakavin. Although many metaphors and similes are no more than stereotyped phrases which recur again and again in various kakavin, yet the whole episode has formed an entity that is distinctly Tantular’s. As can be expected, the lyrical verses constitute the most difficult part of the present kakavin, or indeed of any kakavin. Zoetmulder’s thesis regarding the need for Notes accompanying any translation of Old Javanese works (Zoetmulder 1935: Stelling XII) may now to some extent be disregarded as far as the epic parts of a kakavin and parva are concerned, but with regard to the lyrical parts, this thesis is as valid now as it was 35 years ago. The reader will see that in the translation of this episode quite often an uncertainty in the meaning of a particular vord will obscure the meaning of the whole line; on the other hand, it also often happens that, although there is no lexical difficulty vhat-soever, I have to admit that I can hardly comprehend the exact meaning of the whole passage, let alone translate it. Hence the reader will note that most of the translations of this episode are qualified as ’not certain’, ’doubtful’, ’tentative’, or ’conjectural’.
.20,1b nora tan followed by a verb in arealis form is probably the equivalent of Indonesian: tidak boleh tidak ’there is no doubt; certainly’.
.20,3c An alternative translation: ’like the beauty of the sea and of the mountains during the beautiful fourth month multiplied by one thousand’.
.21,3b-d Arguing against Poerbatjaraka’s translation of Smar. 39,5a, Berg (1969): 470) states that jaṅga is a synonym of pudak ’pandanus flower’. It is clear from this passage that jaṅga and pudak are two different kinds of plants. The occurrence of the vords lun ’shoot, tendril’ and aluṅ ’to have shoots; to stretch like shoots’ indicates that janga is a kind of vine. Poerbatja-raka, therefore, is probably not vrong to equate janga with gaduṅ. In fact, JNW 2: 433 mentions jaṅga as a synonym of gaduṅ, and so does ONW: 159 and 201. In the kakavin both gaduṅ and janga are often said ’to tvine around a tree’ (e.g. 20,3d; 34,10d), or ’to reach to the sky as if wishing to tvine themselves around the moon’ (e.g. 74,4d; 32,13c). Hence gaduṅ and jaṅga are frequently used as comparisons for luṅayan ’arms’ (e.g. 12,5d; 37,2c;
.40,11c; 22,9b). Pudak, on the other hand, is used as a comparison for shapely calves, as Berg has rightly pointed out (e.g. 33,2c; see also Notes 12,6b). It is rather doubtful, therefore, that jaṅga is derived from Sanskrit jatiga ’leg’. Whether janga is related to a religious establishment called jaṅgan (see p. 66) is not certain.
7225Nor is it clear hov both jaṅga and luṅayan in New Javanese have become synonyms for gulu ’neck’, or hov gaduṅ also has become a metaphor for ’neck’. We read for instance in Pranatjitra 2,94c, a passage describing the beauty of the heroine of this beautiful Javanese romance: aṅluṅ iṅ gaduṅ kan jaṅga (her neck is as beautiful as the young shoots of a gaduṅ vine). On the other hand, it is notevorthy that in Arkm. 22,2b, which corresponds to this line of the Arj., Yasadipura says: jaṅgâluṅ luṅ lvir luṅayan iṅ aṅave. This indicates that Yasadipura still used the vords luṅayan and jaṅga in their Old Javanese meanings.
.21,3c ’gəmuh ni’ instead of ’gəmuh rC?
.21,4b kahidepani is an unusual grammatical form. Probably it should read kahide pana, i.e. ka passive arealis of aṅhidepi, thus ’to be regarded; to be thought’, which is justified by the occurrence of de ’by’ after this vord. See however a similar construction in 41,2d: ’ulih niṅ hyaṅ ṅuny âmutər’, ika hidep niṅ vvaṅ alaṅə̄. Could it be that kahide pani stands for (il) ka hide pa ni?
.21,5b The exact meaning of amalihi kuṅ nira is difficult to ascertain. A similar phrase also occurs in 38,5b: amalihi lulut naresvarl. The phrase seems to be used to denote a (group of) person(s) superior in rank to the various kinds of servants, as can be seen from the use of pakamaṅgala and karuhun, i.e. ’first of all; foremost among them’. Probably it is the equivalent of New Javanese selir. In New Javanese sumelir means ’be in favour with a person; close to distinguished person’ (JNW 1: 825), which is not unlike the person(s) referred to as saṅ amalihi kuṅ. It is interesting to note that saṅ mamarvani lulut (amarvani is a synonym of amalihi) occurs in the inter-polated passage (see Variae Lectiones 63,8b: Canto B,2d). Nov, in New Javanese mamarvani would become mamaroni, and the simple nasalised form of mamaroni is either mamaro or maro. Is it possible that the New Javanese vord for ’co-wife’, i.e. maru (JNW 2: 479) has its origin in this phrase?
.21,6a As Berg (1969: 413) has pointed out, tambvaṅ not only denotes the rising of the moon, but the whole period during which it shines in the sky. Hence my translation ’as beautiful as the bright moon’ for are ja kadi tambvaṅ iṅ vulan (cf. 37,Id).
723021,6b What the expression ’like scattering crystals’ really means is not at all clear. A similar phrase occurs in a similar situation in 66,4 (himper maṅure manik, i.e. ’like scattering jewels’), but this too cannot help to clarify its exact meaning. In the context, these expressions seem to be used to indicate the king’s happiness as he vatched the queen. And so it might have the same meaning as an expression occuring in KBW 3: 296 (kadi amaṅgih sphatika riṅ saroja, i.e. ’as though finding crystals in the lotus’).
.21,6d The translation is very tentative. Although the vord besur occurs fairly often in various kakavin, its meaning is still not clear. Teeuw (1950) translates it by ’korzelig’ (crabbed; crusty? Har. 15,4c) and ’unvilling’ (Har. 27,3d). Pigeaud gives ’have enough; recalcitrant’ (Nag. 24,2b; JFC 5: 419). One of the synonyms and meanings given in JNW 2: 704 is bosən, that is ’have more than enough; fed up; bored’, and KBW 4: 953 gives, inter alia, ’satisfied’. In the present kakavin, bəsur occurs not less than four times (21,6d; 32,13a; 33,8d; 71,7d), but except in the last occurrence (71,7d) its exact meaning in the context is difficult to ascertain (cf. Notes 71,7d).
.22,1a Cf. the remarkably similar construction of Arv. 7,1a: byātītan saṅ hanêṅ āsrama scdəṅ aṅivə̄ dhyāna lavan samādhi (’let us tell no more of him absorbed in his reflection and meditation’). In fact, one of the unused manuscripts (Cod. Or. 4069; see p. 84) as an identical reading with Arv. 7,1a. The copyist of this particular manuscript was no doubt influenced by the reading of the Arv..
.22,1b-d For the month Kārtika, or labuh kapat, as the ’month of beauty’ see p. 57.
.For comments on the scenery of the countryside, depicted by the poet in the following episodes, the reader is also referred to Section 5.2.
723522,2a As far as I am avare the vord aṅdusun does not occur in any other kakavin published so far. In New Javanese dusun is a krama form for desa (Sanskrit desa), and in Old Javanese the two vords are synonyms (cf. kaladesa and kaladusun, KBW 2: 225). Since in Old Javanese desa usually means either ’village’ or ’countryside’, it would not be vrong to render aṅdusun as ’to go to the countryside; to wander through the will.ges’, which is in accordance with what the king and all his followers did. However, in KBW 2: 458, beside andusun ve read anəpi, and in KBW 2: 722 for nepi van der Tuuk gives ’to the edge; to the coast’. Could it be that in this line aṅdusun means ’to go to the banks [of the Narmadā]’?
.22,5c The translation of this line depends on the meaning of goñjoṅ. Van der Tuuk quotes the whole line in KBW 4: 689, but he does not give any explanation. Referring to this place ONW: 180 given goñjoṅ as ’piece of cloth’. However, if goñjoṅ is a kind of clothing, goñjoṅnya meṅas does not seem to make sense, because meṅas usually means ’to turn back’ or, for a host of soldiers or animals, ’to flee in the opposite direction; to flee in all directions’ (see 10,14b; 50,1 Id). JNW 2: 549 gives, inter alia, pambarep ’the first born; the eldest child’ as a synonym of goñjoṅ. Nov, in JNW 2: 678 ve read that babarəp iṅ baris means ’the vanguard of the army’, and so lembu goñjoṅ may mean ’the cov(s) used as a vanguard’, thus ’leader of the covs’. KBW 4: 789 also gives abaṅ as a synonym of goñjoṅ. So, ’red covs’?
