.22,5d The presence of camel (ustra) in fourteenth century Java is confirmed by Prapañca in Nag. 59,7d. As Pigeaud has commented, camels were probably
.imported from India to be used in Royal processions (JFC 4: 158). For the will.gers who were accustomed only to the sight of covs, buffaloes and goats, the sight of horses, camels and elephants must have filled them with wonder.
.22,7c It has been suggested in p. 40, that vvat gantuṅ marga stands for vvat gantuṅ it marga. Grammatically, … n mārga or mārganya would be a better construction (cf. makaran-karaṅ susu instead of makaraṅ karaṅ ṅ susu in 32,10c).
724022,7d Although there is hardly any linguistic problem in this line, the significance of the simile: ’lvir ke cap in …’ is not clear. If the translation given here is correct, and I cannot see any alternative, this simile indicates that, to a certain degree, a girl enjoyed the freedom of choosing her ovn husband. However, if her parents wished to give her in marriage to another boy (aṅuvahi svāmi?), all she could do was only mutter or ’tut’ (kecap) as a sign of her disappointment. Other passages which are of interest regarding relationships between young girls and boys are </p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="23">and 31,15d.
.22,8c Although ’to turn around’ for amaṅsul is not impossible, ’to bark (of deer)’ is contextually better; see KBW 3: 635; Sut. 16,5b; cf. pavaṅsil in Wrttasañcaya 93c (see Kern 1875).
.22,8d This line is but an echo of Tantri Kāmandaka: 38,17 (see Notes 6,6-7).
.22,9c The translation is tentative. Andul is the name of a tree with red campaka-like flowers (JNW 1: 19). Hence the comparison with gisi-gisi, i.e. ’gums’. However, comparison with the teeth of a smiling girl would perhaps (to us?) evoke a better picture, rather than to her ’red gums’.
7245Although there are no lexical difficulties in the remainder of the line (for aṅalap sor, see Teeuw and others 1969: 311), the interrelationships between aṅasə̄ ’to press onvard’, harsa ’delight’ (or New Javanese ar sa ’villing’?) and cumbu ’affection’ are not clear.
.22,9d ’Lotus’ no doubt refers to ’blue lotus’ or ’vater-lily’ which is usually used as a comparison for beautiful eyes (see 12,6a; Ingalls 1965: 164).
.22,10c ’… lvir leme-lemes i ləməs niṅ teṅah’ is a play on vords. The vord ləmes in Old Javanese seems to have several meanings: (1) ’soft; tender’; (2) ’slender; slim (for waist’); (3) ’tendril; young shoot of vine’ (e.g. ləmcs iṅ velas-harəp, 37,2d); (4) a kind of silk’ (see KBW 3: 773; JNW 2: 148).
.22,11b ’The scene was still, with no trace of visitors ..is a favourite cliché to describe a deserted hermitage or desolate place (cf. Teeuw and others 1969: 146). See however Notes 23,4.
.22,1 1d-23,1d What types of buildings are represented by raṅkaṅ (22,1 Id), nyāsa (22,12a) and mahanten (23,1c) is not certain (see pp. 53-4; Teeuw and others 1969: 47; for nyāsa see also Notes 25,5d).
725023,2c In Sanskrit cāraka means ’spy’, but in Old Javanese this vord is normally used to denote ’servant’ (see 67,7d; ZA: 301). It is not impossible that the three people mentioned in this line were the servants of the king who came there with the Royal procession, but the expression in 23,2d: tan vidhi niṅ bapênduṅ seems to imply that they were young people from the neighbouring will.ges. There is probably a ’confusion’ here between cāraka and caraka. One of the meanings of caraka in Sanskrit is also ’spy’, like cāraka, but caraka also includes among its meanings ’wanderer; wandering religious student’.
.23,4 So the hermitage which has been described as ’… still, with no trace of visitors …’ is after all not deserted? Or is the poet describing two different complexes, namely: āsrama (22,11a) and tapovana (23,1a)? This seems to be unlikely for in Old Javanese these two vords are interchangeable (see p. 66).
.24,2b-d
.There seems to be no doubt about the reading of the manuscripts for ’… təkap in aisan …’; nevertheless the correctness of this reading is doubtful, because ’aisan’ is metrically impossible. For lack of a better alter-native (dasan or dhasan are orthographically possible, but no such vords are known), I take the reading of the manuscripts: aisan, i.e. ’north-east’ (from Sanskrit aisānī; see ONW: 106; sub als any a).
.25,3 A small, but interesting, sociological insight: priests came to ask for (aminta) milk, and laymen had to buy (atuku). A normal thing, no doubt, which is why the poet mentioned it almost casually.
725525,4d For jaṅgan and tasyan see pp. 65-6.
.25,5d Although …i harəp aṅalun-alun (’in the courtyard which was as spacious as the alun-alun yard’), which is the reading of all manuscripts, is possible, i harəp in alun-alun ’in front of the alun-alun yard’ seems to be a better reading, (i harcp niṅ alun-alun would be the best reading, but this is metrically impossible). The mentioning of alun-alun in connection with a temple-complex seems rather strange but when a pckən ’market square’ is mentioned in 25,6d, and then a comparison to a purasabhā ’palace-court’ in 16,Id, alun-alun would not be out of place.
.The nyāsa ’building’ (where the king had a rest before entering the dharma?) is situated outside the dharma itself, which is evident from Sut. 91,3b-d:
.praptên dharma kaboddhan adbhuta ri heṅnya nyāsa gə̄ṅ sobhita / ṅkā tôṅgvan nira yan paṅantya ri datəṅ saṅ srl narendrātmaja
.(They came to a marvellous Buddhist dharma, with a great and beautiful building outside; there they halted to vait for the arrival of the prince.)
726026,2b The two main temples mentioned here are a Buddhist (26,4b) and a Śivaite one (31,5a). The model for this temple-complex is probably that of Kagənəṅan (see p. 64).
.26,3b lurah usually means ’valley; chasm’ (ONW: 505; JFC 5: 315). So, ’the valleys of the mountains’ for lurah niṅ vukir? However, according to KBW 3: 668 lurah is also a variant of rurah, which means ’region’ (KBW 1: 713), so lurah niṅ vukir could mean ’mountainous region’ or simply ’moun-tains’. Cf. lurah niṅ jalanidhi (32,4c), which seems to be a Javanese variant of abdhidesa (23,3d).
.26,3c Should pinrih sira be amended to pinrih nira? (cf. Notes 8,11a).
.26,4a What exactly was a vipra in Tantular’s time? In Sanskrit (SED: 972) vipra means ’learned man’ (especially in theology), such as: sage, seer, singer, poet,priest. Commenting on Nag. 8,4b Pigeaud (JFC 2: 22; JFC 4: 14-5) asserts that vipra are ’brahmanical Wishnuites’, and commenting on Nag. 81,2 he states that they were ’… foreigners or of foreign (Indian) extraction and considered by birth the native Javanese clergy’s superior’ (JFC 4: 259). The first assertion, namely that vipra were Wiṣṇuites, is not completely in accordance with Pigeaud’s ovn remark in JFC 4: 9 that in the Nag. ’the vord brahmana is not used’ and that ’vipra has taken its place’. Since in Nag. 1,5c (see also Nit. 4,96) vipra is mentioned beside ksatrija, vaisa and sudra to form the well.known division into four castes, there seems to be no reason to doubt that vipra denotes ’brahmin’ in general. This is in accordance with the fact that the priest whom the king addresses as vipra in this passage is referred to as mahābrāhmana in 31,5a. Likevise the sage Pulastya, the grandfather of Rāvaṇa, is referred to as vipra (70,1a), mahāvipra (68,5a), brāhmana (72,2c) and mahābrāhmana (72,4a). And this is further corrobo-rated by a passage in Kor: 32,28 which reads: vipra ngaran iṅ saṅ brahmana.
.Pigeaud’s second contention, namely that vipra were foreigners or of foreign (Indian) extraction, is based on a very weak argument (i.e. Nag. 93,Id?). From the fact that one vipra is said to be of Indian origin, it does not follow that all vipra should come from India, just as the presence of a certain srl Buddhādhitya, a Buddhist monk, in the kraton of Majapahit (Nag. 93,1b), should not be interpreted as indicating that all Buddhist priests were of Indian origin.
7265The nature of the relationship between vipra and the three religious groups (rsi saiva sogata) is not very clear. Probably vipra is closer to the rsi group than to the Śivaites and Buddhists. In Nag. 10,3a rsi and vipra are men-tioned together, and in Nag. 81,2b vipra is mentioned preceding rsi in the enumeration of the four caturdvija. And in the present kakavin, the sage Pulastya, who was referred to as a vipra and a brahmana, is also referred to as paramarsi (72,1a) and even viprarsi. In fact, according to Kor: 48,7 vipra is one of the three groups which form the rsi (Kaliṅanya … vipra, bhiksu, surūpa, nāma saṅ rsi, mankana pva ya kan sinaṅguh tiga ṅaranya…).
.Kern (1919: 182) has suggested that a vipra and a rsi differ only in that the former does not live in a hermitage, whereas the latter does. From the
.various data available, it appears that Kern may well be correct and one could perhaps go further and remark that the teachings of the vipra and those of the rsi were probably not greatly dissimilar. This would explain why, although in the religious grouping in those days, three groups, namely the Rsis, the Śivaites and the Buddhists, were usually mentioned (cf. Notes 30,1-2), only the vipra, the Śivaites and the Buddhists had pahoman ’offering-place’ in the Royal compound of Majapahit (Nag. 8,4c).
.It is remarkable that it was a vipra whom the king asked for an explanation of the meaning of the temple-complex, especially when ve take into account that this temple-complex had a Buddhist and Śivaite temple. The same vipra, in the subsequent cantos, was also to expound the religious teachings and the main tenets of the Arj. to the king. As ve have noted in p. 82, it was in a karsyan establishment that Rājasanagara held the only discussion on religious matters reported in the Nag. Probably the message of the karsyan group was more acceptable to the Javanese nobility of the past than were the teachings of the Śivaite and the Buddhist religious groups.
.26,4b Since the vord kusala and dharmakusala both denote ’religious buildings’ (see JFC 4: 263; ZS: 350), it is difficult to ascertain vhether boddhadharmākusala is metri causa for boddha-dharmakusala or stands for boddhadharma ṅ kusala (thus ā — a plus v; cf. Teeuw and others 1969: 146).
727026,4d Bodhyagrimudrā, i.e. the mudrā of ’the first visdom’ is the mudrā of Wairocana (see Lim 1964: 336-7; Soevito-Santoso 1968: Notes 31,10c). It is interesting to note that the variant bodhyasrimudrā which occurs in several manuscripts is very close to one of the three possible Sanskrit equiva-lents for a Japanese mudrā called chi ken-in, namely bodhasrimudrā (Saunders 1960: 102). In fact, Saunders (1960: 235) suggests that instead of bodha- it would be better to read bodhi-. The choice of bodhyagrimudrā is corroboated by the occurrence of this mudrā in the Sut. (32,10c; 139,9b).
.27,1-2 This passage contains what was apparently Tantular’s fundamental belief. A more sophisticated formulation of this belief also occurs in Tantular’s later kakavin, the Sut. (139,4d-6d). This teaching of the oneness of Buddha and Śiva, as formulated by Tantular in the Sut., has been the subject of various papers by numerous scholars, the first of them, and still one of the most important, having been vritten by Kern (VG 4: 149-77) almost a century ago. A (slightly) different translation of the passage of the Sut. from the existing translations (e.g. VG 4; Zoetmulder 1965b; Soevito-Santoso 1968) is given in p. 7. A hypothesis concerning Tantular’s religious belief has been proposed in Chapter 6.
.27,1a Aksobhya pūrva stands for Aksobhya (r)i pūrva; cf. ’… ri daksina’ (1b). For this arbitrary use of the locative preposition (i, ri) see Teeuw and others (1969: 147). For a comment on the arbitrary use of honorific titles, such as hyaṅ, sri, for metrical reasons see p. 41.
.27,1c The usual name is Mahādeva (cf. Dhatrdeva, Harimūrtideva). The variant reading of F (i.e. Māhadeva) is thus not impossible. It is notevorthy
.that in this kakavin Sanskrit Brahmā is often spelled as Brahma (e.g. 1,23a; 1,24a; but also Brahmā, at least once, 43,2b). Could it be that the Javanese vriters at that time had ’corrected’ the spellings of proper-names such as Brahma and Maha to Brahma and Maha because they considered such spellings applied to feminine proper-names only?
727527,Id Berg (1962: 267) seems to imply that vara-Ratnasambhava (which is Berg’s emendation for mar a rakvasambhava occurring in Nag. 16,2d) is the equivalent of Wiṣṇu. In viev of what Tantular says in lines b and d, such a contention is difficult to sustain (cf. JFC 5: 437).
.27,2b Or: hyaṅ Buddha rakva kalavan Śiva, rājadeva (i.e. the god Buddha and Śiva, [both are equally] kings of the gods)? Syntactically, such a reading (and its translation) is not impossible. However, as far as I am avare, Buddha has never been directly connected with the gods (deva), and so the appelation ’king of the gods’ as applied to Buddha is therefore doubtful.
.27,2c It is perhaps of some interest to note that whereas the vord sama ’same’ is used in this line (kālih samêka), the vord tungal ’one’ is used in Sut. 139,5d (bhinnêka tuṅgal ika). Several possibilities may be proposed here:
.(1) The different formulation in the two kakavin is of no significance because whereas in this line Tantular is speaking of Buddha and Śiva (i.e. the individual Deities who are merely manifestations of the Highest Reality), in the corresponding passage of the Sut. the poet is speaking of Jinatva and Śivatatva (i.e. the reality that is Buddha and the reality that is Śiva).
.(2) Acceptance of a translation, and an interpretation, proposed by Soevito-Santoso (1968) of bhinneka tungal ika could solve the problem. According to his translation (i.e. ’they are indeed different, but they are of the same kind’) tuṅgal ’of the same kind’ could be regarded as a synonym of sama ’same; similar’. The question is — putting aside the religious and philosophical problems inherent in the subject matter — vhether tungal can rightly be translated by ’of the same kind’. In New Javanese, tuṅgalé indeed means ’of the same kind’ (although tungal, normally also means ’one and the same; to share with another of the same thing’), but it is very doubtful if such usage was common in Old Javanese. As far as Tantular’s works are con-cerned, tungal normally means ’one’ (see Arj. 1,16d; 18,1c; 40,6a; and except for Sut. 139,5d, Soevito-Santoso too normally translates tungal where it occurs in the Sut. by ’one’, e.g. Sut. 48,6a; 53,5b; 96,1c; 134,1a, and even 139,5c).
7280(3) There was a development in Tantular’s religious beliefs. At the time he vrote the Arj. he believed that Buddha and Śiva were sama, in the sense of ’equal’, but later, during the decade after finishing the Arj. and the composition of the Sut., he undervent a change of viev and concluded that Buddha and Śiva were not only ’equal’, but the two deities were indeed turigal ’one and the same’.
.It is not certain vhether saṅ pinakestidharma should be plural (as given in the translation) or singular (thus ’the goal one longs for in the religion’). The meaning of dharma in this expression is also not very clear. It may well refer to religious buildings, i.e. temple-complexes. If this is the case, saṅ pinakesti is here used in the sense of hyaṅ inisti (Nag. 1,1d), which is the Javanese equivalent of istadevatā, that is ’tutelary deity’ (see p. 80). The line then may be translated: ’both are the same, they are the tutelary deities of the temple-complexes’.
.27,2d The translation is far from certain. There are several problems in this line which cannot be satisfactorily solved:
.(1) Is dharma slma a copulative or determinative compound? The former possibility is corroborated in Nag. 79,1a (i.e. dharma mvaṅ slma), and the latter likevise so in Nag. 31,2a (ikaṅ Kalayu dharmaslma).
.(2) What is the exact meaning of tuvi yan here? ’moreover’, ’even’, or simply ’and’?
7285(3) Accepting dharma slma as a determinative compound, do ve have two establishments (i.e. dharma slma and dharma lepas) or only one (i.e. dharma slma lepas). In the Buṅur inscription (Kern, VG 7: 17-53), Buṅur, which is called a dharma slma in the second part of the inscription, is repeatedly referred to as dharma slma lepas in the first part.
.(4) Most manuscripts read: ’… yan ləpasādvitiya’. If this long ’a’ is not merely a feature of the spelling convention (it is customary to lengthen a vovel which is already long by position, see p. 39) the translation should read: ’in the dharma slma and even in the dharma lepas they are second to none’. Such a reading would imply that in the dharma lepas Buddha and Śiva were normally not ’second to none’.
.The reading given in the Text and the translation adopted here suggests the conclusion that the dharma slma is none other than the dharma haji (i.e. Royal dharma) described by the poet in 28,2, after describing the dharma lepas (i.e. free dharma). But then another problem arises, namely, why is it that Kalayu, a dharma slma mentioned in Nag. 31,2a, is not included in the list of the dharma haji in Nag. 73,3-74,1. This seems to imply that dharma slma is not a dharma haji. However, it should be noted that Kalayu is not the only Royal dharma not mentioned in the list, which Prapañca specifically called ’dharma haji vīlaṅ saptaviṅsa’ (i.e. ’the tventy-seven Royal dharma"’; see Krom 1919: 296). These temple-complexes were perhaps the most im-portant in those days, but it certainly does not include all the Royal temple-complexes then existing.
.28,1-29,2 These five stanzas have been translated by Bosch (1918); a summary of this passage, based on Bosch’ translation is included in JFG 4: 244 (see p. 63).
.28,1b As far as I am aware, this is the only place where the word bhūdāna ’land-gift’ occurs in Old Javanese works. As Pigeaud (JFC 4: 224) has remarked, this is an unusual word (a technical term?). The meaning, however, seems to be beyond doubt.
729028,2b Cf. Nag. 73,2d: ’tumusê satus nira heləm’ (to pass on to all their descendants in the future).
.28,2c It is difficult, in these two lines, to decide whether dharma means (1) law; religious duty, or (2) temple-complex (cf. Notes 27,2c). The translation, therefore, is not certain. In my translation I have taken the former meaning in 28,2d, and the latter in 28,2c. But there is no strong reason why the reverse could not be correct.
.29,1a An alternative translation: ’However, this is not the reason why one who fulfils the duty of liberality is loved’. Still another possible alternative is: ’However, such is not the vay one who practices the duty of liberality conducts (de) himself, so that he is loved by the whole vorld’ (cf. Bosch’ translation).
.29,2a sudharmêṅ para is a variant of dharmapara (72,9b). SED: 511 gives dharmapara as ’intent on virtue; pious; righteous’ (cf. dharmapārāyana, 31,3d; JFC 5: 367).
.29,2b The difference between dāna, atidāna and mahātidāna is described in Skam.: b27-a29. Dāna, according to the Skam., is the first of the sad-paramita, i.e. the Buddhist six transcendental virtues which are the most important if one is to reach Buddha-hood (Skam.: a27: kapaṅguhan i kahyanbuddhan).
729529,2d The reading ’mahāvisesa katəmun’ is uncertain. In the context katemun must be an arealis form. However, the correct form of passive arealis of anəmu is either katəmva (ka passive) or təmun, in passive. Since the reading ’mahāvisesaka temun’ is not likely, the only possible alternative is ’mahāvisesa (ṅ)ka təmun’ (cf. Notes 21,4b; see also Teeuw and others 1969: 150, Notes 24,3c).
.30,1-2 To support his arguments that a kuti is a Buddhist establishment, van Naerssen (1937: 452-4) has quoted, and discussed, 30,1d-2b. For a dis-cussion on the religious establishments mentioned in this passage, the reader is also referred to Section 5.3.
.This passage, 1c-2d in particular, is reminiscent of Rājapatigundala 15a-b (see JFC 1). Several points of interest are discussed here:
.(1) Instead of tan kaparahê para (1c) ve read repeatedly in Raj. 15b of tan kavaraha de nin sarat. The former derives from parah ’to approach; to intrude; to attack’ (cf. 22,6a; 50,6d) and the latter from avara (Sanskrit āvara?) ’to obstruct; to hinder’ (cf. kahavara, 36,1c). The ideas conveyed in these two passages, however, are the same.
.(2) The strictly preserved allocation of property according to religious persuasions (1d-2b) is also expounded in Raj. 15b, unfortunately in a somevhat corrupt form. With some emendations (cf. JFC 2: 123), it should read: [saṅ rsi hamūktiha] karsyan, sa [ṅ] yogīsvara hamūk-tiha kabrāhmana[n], (hamūktiha kasevan), saṅ Seva hamūktiha kasevan, saṅ boddha hamūktiha kaboddhan, tan Salah candaka, tan Salah hamūktiha. The following translation is slightly different from that given in JFC 3: 133: ’The rsis are to enjoy the karsyan, the yogis are to enjoy the kabrahmanan, the Śivaites the kasevan and the Buddhist the kaboddhan. No one should commit the sin of taking [possession of] and enjoying [the property of another group]’. That in the Raj. ve have kabrāhmanan in addition to the three religious establishments mentioned in the Arj. is understandable, since vipra (= brāhmana) may be regarded as a separate group (see Notes 26,4a).
7300(3) The translation of aṅalap by ’to take possession’ (JFC 5: 102) is rather uncertain. The vord alap may be regarded as a synonym of candak, which occurs in the abowe passage of the Raj.. However, KBW 1: 289 seems to suggest that in connection with a piece of land aṅalap could mean ’to raise tax’. Thus voṅ aṅalap (e.g. JFC 1: 125) probably denotes ’tax-collector’. Hence an alternative translation for 2a: ’… who should be given tasyan and [the right] to raise tax on kalagyan’.
.(4) ’to make a mistake in this respect’ for salaha para is a too free trans-lation. A more literal rendering would be ’… for you to make a mistake in intruding’. But it seems that, in the context of what has been said, the priest meant to say that the king should take care that none of his subjects should trespass on the property of a religious group to which he did not belong. In Raj. 15b ve read: eliṅa kanta nira sovaṅ-sovaṅ, ’one should always remember (i.e. respect?) the borders of each property’.
.30,2d The translation of this line depends on the meaning of mahābala. Normally, this vord means ’very poverful’, the meaning which I have adopted here. However, if this meaning is given to mahābala, the use of datəṅa in this line is inexplicable. Datəṅa would be easier to explain, if mahabala here could be rendered as ’great army; great soldiers’. And this is not impossible, even though the dictionaries only give ’very poverful’, because bala means either ’pover’ or ’army’. In this case, the priest seems to be saying that ’if the king has made a mistake in this respect, the curse will affect not only the king himself, but also his great soldiers’.
.In viev of the expressions: prāptêṅ mahāvahsa (28,2b) and tekên tus ika (30,3d), there is another possibility, namely that mahabala is metri causa for mahābāla (bāla means ’child’ thus ’great descendants’?). If this argument is acceptable then this line may be translated: ’and even your descendant — be careful (i.e. mark my vords?) Your Majesty — will surely fall into distress’.
.30,4 This stanza undoubtedly derives from a religious quotation which vas
7305vell-known at that time, but unfortunately I have not been successful in tracing its origin, nor its occurrence in any other Old Javanese work.
.31,Id Nit. 4,6b gives similar advice: mvaṅ devasthana tan vinursita rubuh vaṅunən ika paharja səmbahən (’and you should restore the fallen temples at which the faithful no longer vorship, maintain them and vorship at them’).
.31,2b Although the general sense of this line seems to be clear, the translation is only tentative. The phrase tan kasalahêṅ vlra is not easy to comprehend, let alone to translate. In translating tan kasalah by ’without exception’, I accept Zoetmulder’s suggestion (ZS: 239) but this is not wholly satisfactory. Normally, kasalah is the ka passive form of sumalahakən ’to blame’ (see Zoetmulder 1950: 49), so it is probably not impossible to translate the line as ’I shall be firm in following these precepts so that I shall not be blamed by the heroes’. However, a similar phrase occurs in Sut. 76,2d: tan kasalahêṅ kavi, which in the context cannot be translated ’be blamed by the poets’. Another possibility is that the vord Salah here refers to salah-para which occurs in 30,2c. The phrase tan kasalahêṅ vlra thus means tan kasalaha-para de niṅ vlra, i.e. ’the heroes will not intrude in the temple-complexes’.
.31,2c-d
.The reading (and therefore the translation) is not without ambiguity, since much depends on the meaning or klrti and kārya (for their various meanings see JFC 5: 179; 180). This passage is reminiscent of Nag. 82,1b-c. For dhairya ’steadfast; constantly’, Nag. 82,1b reads: nora sandeha ri tvas nira ’there is no doubt in his heart’. For maklrtya, Nag. 82,1b has: umulahakən klrti (or klrtya?) ’to work for glory; to win merit’, and for manuka ṅ dharma Nag. 82,1c reads: agave (sad) dharmakusala ’to establish dharma’. Only the vord kārya has no equivalent in this passage of the Nag.. Although makīrti is normally used intransitively (cf. akirti, Nag. 17,Id; 29,2b; Siv. 14,Id), it is not uncommon to have a complement for this vord, Siv. 1,1b maklrtya kakavin ’to win the merit of vriting a kakavin’, and probably Bhar. 1,6a maklrtya sakakala ’to win the merit of composing a sakakāla’ (see Berg 1969: 42). In both examples the meaning of maklrtya could shift to simply ’to compose a literary work’. Hence maklrtya kārya ’to win the merit of doing religious works’ may mean ’to perform one’s duty (in religious works)’.
731031,4a an dāna ’to practice liberality’ would be a better choice than an dhana (dhana means ’vealth’, and dāna ’liberality; alms-giving’). It is not far-fetched to suggest that the poet used dana for metrical reasons, and that the later copyist(s) mistook it for dhana (cf. adara for adhara in 31,16b).
.31,5b It is remarkable that the poet deliberately ’steered’ the king avay from the Śivaite temple, simply by using a familar stock-phrase: tan varnan sira. It is clear that Tantular did not wish to describe the Śivaite temple, or to tell hov wonderful was (that is if the vord adbhuta in 5a is not a mere stop-gap; see pp. 40-1) this Śivaite temple. Even if our hypothesis on Tantu-lar’s persuasion (see Chapter 6, especially p. 80) is right, there is no doubt that he is closer to Buddhism than to Śivaism.
.31,7a-b
.An
.alternativ
7315e for 7a is: ’Soon they came to a peerless rest-house which was as beautiful as the palace’. However, in this case tiṅkah-tiṅkah i gopuranya would be an incomplete clause, for it would imply that it is the gopura ’gate’ which is compared to vaixuntur. Since vaṅuntur is an open square in the Royal compound (see p. 52), such comparison does not make sense.
.31,9b-c;
.16b
.Not even the reading, still less the translation, of sāmyādijurvā-segəh (9b), slma mvaṅ kuvu nātha (9c) and parasāmyajurvakuvunātha (16b) is certain, due to our still inadequate knowledge of the Old Javanese social structure.
.For sāmya, which occurs in the Nag. several times, Pigeaud gives ’commoner’ (JFC 5: 277; cf. KBW 3: 349). Such rendering is doubtful. As can be seen from the passages where the vord sāmya occurs in the Nag. and the Ar’]., it seems to have been used of a group of people with some significant position. Along with the other State officials they were allowed to enter into the king’s presence, when he gave an audience to his subjects. Nag. 41,3b, for instance, says: samasta parasāmya riṅ Kadiri Jaṅgalômarək amuspa rin purasabhā. It is not likely that ’all the commoners of Kadiri and Janggala’ came to the audience-hall to pay homage to the king. It is more likely that they were a group of people with some pover in the will.ge communities. This is corroborated by the fact that in many inscriptions para same refers to a group of people who received orders from the ruler who issued the charter.
7320It is not impossible to regard jurvâsəgəh as a compound, denoting ’people who are in charge of serving food’ (cf. juru aṅladosakən, JNW 2: 389; juru bhojakārya ’cook’, Sut. 22,6b).
.Syntactically in slma mvaṅ kuvu nātha ve may have slmanātha and kuvunātha, or slma, kuvu and nātha. This is due to the fact that the position of mvaṅ and other connective vords in an enumeration of things is not fixed in kakavin. Sometimes it precedes the last thing mentioned in the enumeration (e.g. 31,10b: tumpəṅ səkul mvaṅ hulam), but it not seldom follows the first mentioned in the list (e.g. 31,1 Id: tampo mvaṅ paṅasih kilan). As in many other cases scansion is the paramount consideration in this respect. And so a choice between either one or the other possibility is not easy to make. Slmanātha and kuvunātha are not impossible, for ve have slmapati in at least one Old Javanese work (see JFC 4: 372), and Kuvunātha in Nag. 76,3b (although it refers to a place name). Nevertheless the interpretation ’slma, kuvu and nātha’ is probably a better one. Although slma and kuvu normally denote territorial units, these terms are also used to refer to the chiefs of such territories. Thus instead of the more usual form of akuvu for ’kuvu-chief’, kuvu in this sense occurs in various kakavin, e.g. Sut. 86,10c: kuvu mvaṅ sāmyâkveh marək; Sut. 118,3c: kuvu juru sāmya kasihan ya; Nag. 40,4d: dapur mvaṅ kuvu juru tumamêṅ sāmya; Nag. 83,5b: mantri sabhumî Java juru kuvu len adhyaksa sarvopapatti. [On the basis of the abowe discussion, Pigeaud’s emendation of kuvu juru (Nag. 40,4d) to juru kuvu (see JFC 2: 57) is not acceptable. Neither juru kuvu nor kuvu juru are compounds, but enumerations of things].
.The translation ’vaited dutifully’ for atuṅgu dharma is no more than
.conjecture. Dharma is, again, a problem here (see Notes 27,2c; 28,2c). In the translation I have adopted its primary meaning, i.e. ’lav; religious duty’, hence ’dutifully’ (via: according to the dharma). However, its second meaning, i.e. ’religious establishment; temple-complex’ is also not impossible, ’atuṅgu dharma’ may have its literal meaning ’to guard the temple-complexes’, and probably is used to refer to persons who are in charge of the supervision of the temple-complexes. They are of high-born families called amātya (see Nag. 74,2: nā taṅ dharma baji… kapvâmātya nipuna taṅ vineh matuṅgva).
.Instead of -âdhara, read -âdara ’respectively; humbly’ (cf. an dhana for an dāna, Notes 31,4a).
732531,1a I assume that ri harep, which normally means ’in front of; before’, in this line has the sense of the Sanskrit mukhya ’foremost (among them)’.
.31,14a The variant reading of ’y’, i.e. vəki, is perhaps better than niki as given in the Text. The phrase veki sə̄k ’chock-full; over abundance’ occurs several times in this kakavin (e.g. 24,2a; 31,17c; 38,6b), and this meaning fits well here. In Javanese orthography one can easily make a mistake in vriting vəki for niki. In this case, the line is to be translated: ’No one was absent, the place was chock-full, yet all were filled to repletion …’.
.31,14c For the vord balabur occurring in this line ONW: 402 (— KBW 4: 1002) gives ’unseasonal rain, e.g. rain that falls in the dry-season’. So could bras balabur mean ’rice cultivated in the dry-season’? However, JNW 2: 728 lists bəlabur as a synonym for bañjir ’flood’ or beleber ’overflov’, and KBW 4: 1002-3 gives kagunturan as a synonym for kabalaburan (and guntur is, inter alia, a synonym of bañjir; see KBW 4: 647; JNW 2: 540). JNW says further that bəlabur is normally used in reference to the overfloving or the over-abundance of food. Since this meaning fits the context better than that given in ONW: 402, it is adopted here. Another simile used in connection with the over-abundance of food is guntur-lavan sāgara, i.e. ’flood (or vaves?) and the sea’ (e.g. 34,1 Id).
.31,15a The reference to piṅit ’seclusion’ in this line is rather strange, for in the next stanza (16), ve read that the king distributes gifts to those attending the ceremonial meal. It is more likely that the king would retire to his private quarters only after the distribution of gifts.
.For sumalah, JNW 1: 820 gives among other meanings ’to give up pover; to renounce the throne’. Hence my translation ’… the responsibility [of commanding the army] was entrusted to …’ (cf. sinalahan makəmit in KBW 3: 236).
733031,16c Suvastra ’fine clothing’ probably refers to kain. This was the gift a king most commonly bestoved on his subjects during a tour in those days (see JFC 4: 78).
.32,2a The same temple-complex is described again in Tantular’s later kakavin (Sut. 13,1-2). In the Sut. the statue of Gana is said to be situated
.under the gate, and that of Wiṣṇu on the north side. This is in accordance with the position of Wiṣṇu in the Śivaite pantheon.
.32,2b It is probably better to regard kalasan as a derivative of alas ’jungle’ (thus: ’overgrovn by scrubs’, so ’neglected’) than as a derivative of kalasa ’covered’ (cf. ONW: 120).
.32,4b Since the temple-complex, of which the restoration is described in the preceding two stanzas, is a Śivaite one, there is nothing unusual in the fact that only kasogatan and karsyan are mentioned in this line.
733532,4c For lurah in jalanidhi ’region of the sea; coastal area’, see Notes 26,3b.
.32,5a The translation ’… the sun shines brightly upon the equally bright sea’ is probably too free, but the significance of the simile in a more literal translation (i.e. ’the sun shines brightly like the radiance of the sea’) is not clear to me.
.32,8b Or ’sand’ for natar (cf. Notes 34,5b), and so: ’…as rain spraying on the sand’?
.32,8d ONW: 481 gives malaga as either ’fighter; warrior’, which is adopted here, or ’to fight’, which is also not impossible (thus: ’… ran as if to fight the vaves’).
.32,9c Although Zoetmulder (ZL: 152-7) has collected numerous passages in which anak-anakan pudak occurs, the exact meaning of this phrase is still difficult to determine. Hence ’to drav pictures on a puppet made of pandanus flowers’ is only tentative. However, an alternative translation ’to drav pictures of puppets on petals of pandanus flowers’ seems unlikely, since the relation of anak-anakan is closer to pudak than to tika. This is clear from the occur-rence of anak-anakan pudak (Sut. 58,6a; cf. anak-anakan rum niṅ pudak (Sut. 66,4b)), as well as pudak anak-anakan (even: pudak anak-anakan pənuh tika, Ghat. 11,14b; cindagânak-anakan tinulis tikâpənəd, Ghat. 10,9d). The former (i.e. anak-anakan pudak) seems to suggest that the phrase denotes a doll or a puppet made of pandanus flowers, and the latter to suggest a certain kind of pandanus (cf. pandan vvari; see Teeuw and others 1969: 50). In the case of the latter (i.e. pudak anak-anakan), it is interesting to note that in Sanskrit a phrase tarunaketaka ’young pandanus’ is also known (see Ingalls 1965: 507).
734032,9d I take nya in hajə̄ṅnya as referring to the girl. However, this is not certain. It could refer to tika (thus: ’the beautiful picture she drev’) or to anak-anakan pudak (thus: ’the beauty of a doll made of pandanus flowers’).
.32,10 The translation ’jumping from one rock to another’ for makaraṅ-karaṅ (10c) as suggested by Zoetmulder (ZL: 94; see makaraṅ-karaṅ in 32,8c) is
.less likely here, since the whole stanza forms an ’extended comparison’ (see Teeuw and others 1969: 153, Notes 32,3). In the first line a girl is compared to a sprite, whose beauty is said to be coming from the sea; in the second line her hips are identified with the vaves, in the third her firm, beautiful breasts are identified with the reefs, and in the last line her frightened vhim-pers are identified with thunder. But the comparison does not stop there. In the third line the poet continues by describing hov her lover’s ’ship of passion’ is vrecked on the ’reefs’ of her breasts (for jumahatakəna see Teeuw and others 1969: 153). A similar comparison occurs in Sut. 83,5: ’san līlârja mahākaraṅ susu baṅun dunuṅən iṅ aṅikət pralapita / mombak lvlr i təṅahta dūra n ika tan paṅarəmakəna rāga niṅ rimaṅ’ (’your breasts are as graceful and splendid as reefs to be visited by those vriting poetry [karaṅ is a favourite spot for a kavi to vrite his poem; ZL: 91], and your hips are like vaves which will certainly cause the passion of the lovesick to "flounder"’).
.32,1 1d-13d It is not uncommon to find a dramatis persona in a kakavin composing a short poem usually to express his deep love for his sweetheart before the enjoyment of their love (cf. Zoetmulder 1957: 61-4). In Sanskrit poetics, this kind of mood is called vipralambha-srṅgāra, i.e. ’love-in-separa-tion’, which portrays love tinged with grief (see Ingalls 1965: 15).
.32,12b The comparison to bhramara ’bee’ for the male lover is most ap-propriate, since bhramara also denotes ’lover; paramour’; and is always considered as masculine (see Ingalls 1965: 300).
734532,12c Or ’… to the shore [sitting] on the back of an elephant rock’? For karaṅ liman see Notes 33,6a-b.
.’denta vinava’ is an unusual passive construction. Even if ve allow it as a poetic licence for vinava denta, it is still not very common. The more usual form is either vinavanta or kavava denta (see Zoetmulder 1950: 50-2).
.32,13a Depending mainly on the meaning of besur (see Notes 21,6d), the translation given here is not certain. An alternative translation is: ’O you, who constantly sent me beautiful poems, hov recalcitrant you are, you have made me many promises, yet have failed to appear’.
.33,1a Zoetmulder (ZL: 188) has rightly suggested that paṅhrət is part of a building, though he is not sure exactly which part it refers to. In New Javanese the vord paṅərət is still used to denote ’cross-beams of a roof, abowe the valls and halfvay to the top of the roof’ (JNW 1: 427, sub: kərət; cf. KBW 1: 107-8). But the problem is: hov can one vrite a poem on the cross-beams? Surely ve cannot imagine this poor girl climbing the vall to vrite dovn her lamentation on the cross-beams! I have no solution to offer, except to note that in New Javanese there is a metaphor which is reminiscent of this phrase, namely lsvarane nurut usuk’ (literally: ’his voice follows the rafters’), to describe a singer’s melodious voice. Could it be that ’vriting poems on the cross-beams’ is a metaphor for ’vriting beautiful poems’? Be that as it may, it seemed to be commonplace in those days for a poet, or a
.would-be-poet, to vrite dovn his lamentation (sambat; also vilāpa or pralāpa) on part of a building which is mostly made of wood (Galestin 1936; see also Notes ll,2c-d). Some of these poems even bear the parab ’pen-name’ of the poet (see e.g. Nag. 32,4b-c; cf. JFC 4: 95; Berg 1969: 366).
735033,2b Literally: ’… blinking repeatedly like the eyebrovs of one smitten with love’.
.33,3c The usual meaning of susur ’quid’ (ONW: 640; JNW 1: 803) does not make sense here. Probably susur here means ’edge; fringe’ as in Malay or Indonesian. Sinusur turut-turutan thus means ’to be edged with stripes’ (for turut ’stripes on the clothing materials’ see KBW 2: 598). Another possibility is that susur is a variant of New Javanese jujur (cf. susul and jujul, JNW 1: 806), which means ’to baste’ (JNW 2: 415; cf. dalujur, JNW 1: 594; dalujur is derived from dujur, and dujur is a variant of jujur; cf. dalan and Malay jalan; udan and Malay hujan). Sinusur turut-turutan thus means ’to be basted with striped materials’.
.33,3d This line is of interest from the economic point of viev (see p. 53).
.33,6a-b
.This realistic description of a karan liman will dispel any doubt that this kind of rock has an appearance of an elephant. We even read in Devaruci 1,6d (see Poerbatjaraka 1940): karaṅ moga katvnalan, kadi esti-vana madyus (a rock suddenly emerged and looked like a bathing elephant); and in Devaruci 1,7c: karaṅ brajagən aruhur, kadi liman anjrum katon (a huge and lofty rock was like an elephant kneeling in the vater).
7355A similar passage occurs in Sut. 85,1 1c-d: ’lor-vetanya karaṅ liman kinasut in ryak asəmu gərəh iṅ labuh kapat / ghorânəmburakən vvay iṅ tasik avarna maṅuliṅa tuməṅha rin tavaṅ’ (To the north-east was an elephant rock beaten by the vaves with a sound like thunder in the fourth season; and the vater was sprayed back into the ocean [from the trunk of this] dreadful elephant rock which looked like [an elephant] looking up at the sky).
.33,6c Aṅhañut, the primary meaning of which is ’to drift along the current’, is often used in the general sense of ’to perform death rites’ (KBW 1: 368; Teeuw and others 1969: 149). However in most cases the relation with the sea or the river (i.e. ’to allow the current to carry along the body’) is still obvious. And so ahañutan is to be understood as ’to perform the religious rite of committing suicide by jumping into the sea’. The closest New Javanese equivalent is ṅañut tuvuh (JNW 1: 39), but the vord is used to denote ’to commit suicide’ in a more general sense.
.33,8d The reading of this line is far from certain. Neither … saka rîri ya (’despondency’ for hi see Teeuw 1950: 93) nor sakarîri ya (’all which are left behind’?) are quite satisfactory, and tan bəsur again poses an annoying problem (see Notes 21,6d and 32,13a). Probably tan bəsur refers to the fact that their love has not yet been fulfilled.
.34,1c According to the calculations based on the Balinese system, the fifth hour of the day is 1.30 p.m. (i.e. 450 minutes after about 6 a.m.; see Friederich 1959: 154; Teeuw and others 1969: 147, Note 5,4b; Covarrubias 1937: 102). According to Pigeaud’s calculation, which is based on the Indian system, it is about 4 p.m. (i.e. 240 minutes after midday; see JFC 4: 63; also JFC 3: 66; 67). There seems to be little doubt that a reckoning based on the Balinese tradition is more satisfactory for calculating the time given in kakavin than one based on the Indian system. This is evident from the fact that, as far as I know, there never occurs in any kakavin a mention of, say, the 10th hour or the 13th hour of the day, which ve would expect if the day (and night) were divided into 30 muhurta as in the Sanskrit system (see Kern 1919: 67; SED: 825). Accordingly, all hypotheses proposed by Pigeaud (JFC 4: 63; 155; 157; 307) concerning auspicious and unpropitious times based on refer-ences to time in the Nag. are highly doubtful.
.34,5b The usual meaning of natar ’courtyard’ and its other possible meaning, as suggested by Berg (1969: 512), i.e. ’mat’, do not seem to make sense here. Contextually, it seems to mean ’the banks’ or ’sandbank’, probably through ’level; level ground’ as in Malay (see datar, MED 1: 167; natar, MED 2: 801).
7360A similar use of natar occurs in Sut. 90,4: ’Ndak sampun halivat sirê təgal-təgal arata sayojanâlva katəmu /…/ pintən ṅganya huvus kagunturan i mini karana ni natarnya n aṅrəs i suku’ (’now they passed through a flat vasteland of a yojana in area …; perhaps flood (or lava?) had passed through here in the past, and so [the sand on] the level ground caused a somevhat painful sensation (New Javanese: ṅəres) to the feet …’).
.34,5c ONW: 119 ( = KBW 2: 243) lists kalakā for kalakah occurring in this line, and gives ’vater’ as its meaning, which, for lack of a better alter-native, has been adopted here. A possible alternative given in JNW 1: 490, i.e. ’bamboo enclosure’ (cf. kinalakah in ONW: 119) is less likely; another possibility is that kalakah is a variant of galagah, i.e. ’reed’.
.34,7b The translation is conjectural. Literally: ’seen from dovnstream, the illusory images of their movements avoke the passions [of the onlookers]’.
.34,7c Referring to this passage, KBW 3: 307 gives sayat as ’broken’. Hov-ever, the significance of the comparison ’… like a broken palace’, or, as given in the translation here, ’… like the palaces cracked’ is not at all clear. Nor does any possible alternative give a better picture, e.g. kadhātvan, instead of kadatvan (dhātu: ’substance, element’), and ’many’ for sayat, instead of ’broken’ (cf. Kor: 140,24: sayat ṅaran v akveh ’sayat means many’).
.34,10c I take nyū danta ’ivory-palm trees’ as the object of amilət ’entvine’. However, if this is so, kalavan nyū danta jaṅgâmilət is a rather forced, unusual structure. In prose it would normally read: kalavan nyxi danta vinilət iṅ jaṅga.
736534,10d An alternative reading is to place the comma after tapovana, and so
.translate the line: ’On the slope there was [a building] like a hermitage, its tover-like structure was like [that of] a hamlet in a picture’.
.35,1a I take asuji here as variant of masuci ’to cleanse; to vash one’s self; to bathe’ (see JNW 1: 851). Contextually it is better than ’to dress in em-broidered kain (tapih suji)’ as suggested by Zætmulder (ZL: 140-1; cf. KBW 3: 301), because in the previous canto, the poet describes the bathing scene in the river. It is also notevorthy that in Sut. 147,10b Z reads asuji and Soevito-Santoso reads asuci.
.35,1b Is maṅə̄-maṅen a doubling of anen or two separate vords with more or less the same meaning?
.35,1c The alternative translation (’the vater floved sviftly from one rock to another, like vaves just about to break’) is syntactically not impossible, and poetically gives a more evocative picture, but since 35,1b-c forms an extended comparison (see Notes 32,10), I consider such translation less likely.
737035,2c Is nāgasari masuhun the name of a certain kind of nāgasari flower (Mesua ferrea) or simply ’nāgasari flowers suitable for head decoration’? (səkar suhun is a flower for head decoration; ONW: 640).
.35,3d What kind of flower is rājasūnv asusupan (literally: ’a prince with [flower] hairpin’)?
.35,4a raras nira, literally ’her beauty’, refers to the queen (cf. rum nira, 35,5d; rumta, Notes 12,4b).
.35,4b asoka is one of the best known flowers in the kakavin. It occurs in almost all kakavin, where nature is described. Asoka sāmaja ’elephant asoka’, however, does not occur in other sources, neither is it to be found in the Javanese or Sanskrit dictionaries. It is retained however in Malay as angsoka biram (MED 1: 35). Biram is a synonym of gajah ’elephant’.
.36,2c The use of a tadaharsa bird as a comparison for the king is rather strange, because this vord denotes the female of the species, the male being called cucur (see KBW 2: 643; Teeuw and others 1969:147). However, in New Javanese cucur and kedasih (a contraction from tadahasih, which is a synonym of tadaharsa) are no more than synonyms. Kedasih is even considered by some as the male əmprit gantil bird (JNW 1: 522). In New Javanese kedasih, or cucur, is no longer connected with the moon; its voice is considered as ominous of disaster. But in Malay cucur is still known as a night bird, a kind of owl (MED 1: 238), although it is puṅguk (New Javanese kokok-beluk) which is especially connected with the moon. This puṅguk owl is regarded by the Malays as a symbol of hopeless passion; sometimes also of presumption in daring to hope to win the moon (see MED 2: 287). In Old Javanese literature tadahasih and cucur are closer to this Malay puṅguk than to Javanese kedasih and cucur. They are always described as weeping
7375sorrowfully before the moon has risen (see e.g. Ghat. 12,3b; Arv. 18,1 Id; Siv. 5,1c). The Sanskrit equivalent of this kind of bird is the cakora (red partridge, Pedrix rufa), which is supposed to live only on moonbeams (Ingalls 1965: 272; 499).
.36,2d As in Sanskrit literature, the cātaka (crested cuckoo, Cuculus melano-leucas or jacobinus) is always connected with rain. This bird refuses to drink except from rain-clouds. The cātaka is used by the Sanskrit poets as an example of pride, nobility and the tragedy of faith. Usually it represents the poet himself, who cannot live without a generous patron (see Ingalls 1965: 301; 364). Such ideas were probably also common among the Old Javanese poets. Hence cumātaka, i.e. ’to behave like a cātaka bird’, is very often used by a kavi at the beginning of his work (see e.g. cumataka in 1,3a). It probably has the meaning of ’to pride himself’ (so my translation ’to have the audacity’, cf. New Javanese cumantaka, JNW 1: 250), or ’to beg for the favour of a generous patron’.
.36,3a Since it is not likely that sekar in this line refers to the posy of fragrant flowers mentioned in 35,4, I take valat səkar as a compound (a synonym of valātkāra, from Sanskrit balātkāra ’by force; vehemently’?) referring to the way the king carried the queen to the golden pavilion (35,5).
.36,3b The expression ’apraṅən i luṅid i tuṅtuṅ i halts’ is reminiscent of Ram. 12,38:
.Nā
7380halista
.malaris ya larasta, mvaṅ matanta taji-tulya tajəm ya, len hidepta mahaləp helaranya, ilā celekta ya upas upamanya
.This passage has been translated by Hooykaas (1957: 284) as follows:
.Thy eyebrows are as sharp as if they were the bow; the eyes are as sharp as the spurs of fighting cocks; and they reflect the lustre of their feathers; thy cohl can be compared with their poison.
.Hooykaas’ transliteration of hidep ’eyelash’ by hidep ’reflection; thought’ might be merely a slip of pen, but it has resulted in a curious mistake in his translation. The following translation differs slightly from that of Hooykaas:
7385Your finely-shaped eyebrows are your bows;
.your spur-like eyes are the arrowheads,
.and your splendid eyelashes are the flight-feathers;
.as for your collyrium, this is comparable to the arrow’s poison.
.’malaris’ is a synonym of ’luṅid’, both mean ’sharp’; as a description for eyebrows, they are similar to New Javanese ñjalirit (JNW 2: 404) and ñjahit (JNW 2: 379), and have the sense of ’finely shaped’ (ZL: 176). In this sense, malaris is even used to describe shapely calves (e.g. 21,3d: ’… akəter i vetis nirâlaris).
7390In the metaphor here, halis is thus to be indentified with the bow, in particular the bow of Kama, the Love god (see Ingalls 1965: 164).
.36,4d Thus ’inattentiveness; carelessness’ for silih? Cf. amrih silih ’to try to outvit’; kasilib ’taken by surprise’ (Teeuw and others 1969: 319).
.38,5d
.’The vater sprang from the moon’ is in accordance with the Indian idea that the moon is ’the vessel of divine ambrosia drunk by ancestors and gods yet ever filled again’. The sphere of the Moon is the reservoir of rain vater. As such, the Moon is the lord of plants, the deity protecting all vege-table life (see Daniélou 1963: 98-100).
.38,7a ’… and what they said came to the ears of the queen’ is, admittedly, too free and too conjectural a translation, but contextually a better translation would be hard to propose. The difficulty lies in the unintelligible expression: təka hirəṅ (’come black’?). For the abowe translation I read hirin (a synonym of samlpa which may be translated by ’presence’) instead of hiren. But this is only a very slight possibility, because orthographically ri and re are very different letters. Orthographically təkahirəṅ is very close to təkapirəṅ. In New Javanese kapircṅ means ’to be heard’, but it is doubtful vhether this form existed in Old Javanese. In any case the element tə- would be inexplicable. If none of the abowe suggestions is possible, probably we have to take the reading of y, that is təka marək, and this line is therefore to be translated: ’they told this to the king, and then they came to the presence of the queen’.
739538,9a I take vibhu ’poverful’ (ONW: 540) in its primary meaning, i.e. ’far-extending; all-pervading’ (SED: 978). In this sense it perhaps has a similar meaning to trivikrama as it occurs in various Old Javanese works. In Sanskrit literature trivikrama is a special form of Wiṣṇu, that is when he encompasses the three vorlds. In ancient Java this connection with Wiṣṇu was no doubt still known, as it is clear from Bhar. 8,1 on the occasion when Krsna shovs that he is an incarnation of Wiṣṇu (mintonakən krama nira n tuhu Wiṣṇumurti / līlātrivikrama makāvak ikaṅ triloka). In many other kakavin, including Tantular’s, however, trivikrama is often used without any connection with Wiṣṇu vhatsoever (e.g. 39,1a; 62,1a). As in New Javanese (see JNW 1: 661, sub: tivikrama), trivikrama simply means ’a huge, expansive body which is assumed by a mighty person to show his great super-natural pover’. In this meaning, trivikrama may be regarded as no more than a synonym of vibhū (see also Notes 62,1a-b).
.39,9d Based on the information from KBW 1: 144, it is possible to regard aksaya as a modified form of saṅs ay a ’anxiety’, and niraksaya would therefore mean ’without any anxiety’. Another alternative reading ’… tan gumirisina nirâksayêṅ manah’ is less likely, firstly because gumirisina nira is an impossible form (gumirisin is an intransitive verb; to be used transitively it needs a preposition, e.g. 14,2d: gumirisin i saṅ mahâsura), and secondly because the usual meaning of aksaya ’undecaying’ (SED: 3) does not fit the context.
.38,10d
.As Pigeaud has noted in JFC 4: 194-5, the original Indian meaning of caturāsrama, i.e. the four stages of human life (brahmācari, grhastha, vānaprastha and bhiksuka) was also known in the Majapahit Court. This is evident from the occurrence of this technical term in OJO 79 and OJO 83. However Pigeaud maintains that the caturāsrama mentioned several times in the Nag. does not refer to this original meaning, but it is used to denote ’a collective name (associated with the ancient quadripartite classification) for certain religious communities connected with the common people and country life’. In the context of this episode, neither of these meanings fit. The fact that the mention of caturāsrama in this passage refers to the performers of the trivikrama ceremony indicates that this group was highly esteemed by the king. This is not likely if caturāsrama included people who were still in the brahmacāri or grhastha stages, let alone if it referred to ’certain religious communities connected with the common people and country life’. Nov, in KBW 1: 619 we read of a caturāsrami serving as a collective name for the brāhmana, rsi, saiva and sogata, and thus as a synonym for caturdvija which has been discussed in Notes 26,4a. This interpretation seems to be the most appropriate, at least in this context.
.39.4 Some of the devices for catching fish mentioned in this stanza are already listed in the ONW, namely: variṅ, pəcak, karakad (under karakah) and jala, all of which are some kind of net. Of the other devices: añco is a square net (JNW 1: 10); ser is a landing net or bamboo sieve for fishing in shallow vater (JNW 1: 755; 1: 803, sub seser); susug is a kind of trap or basket made of bamboo (JNW 1: 807; cf. Zoetmulder 1958: 19,10 surpa pva ṅaran in susug ’sūrpa (vinnoving basket) is the name of susug’); laba is some kind of trellis-work made of thin bamboo strips used for fencing off part of the river or sea so that fish can be caught easily (JNW 2: 78-9); pacikur is not listed in JNW, but KBW 4: 47 lists this vord as the name of some kind of fishing-tackle. The mentioning of palva ’boat; ship’ in 4d is strange, to say the least, for Tantular has not referred to the existance of any kind of boat in the river before. And the occurrence of ati ’very’ preceding palva makes it most likely that we should have an adjective, or even a verb (cf. Teeuw and others 1969: 312) instead of a noun. And so instead of atipalva I read ati malva, i.e. ’very large’.
740039.5 Most of the fishes enumerated in this stanza have been listed in the ONW. Of those unlisted in this Old Javanese dictionary, sumbilaṅ is a kind of sea-fish with a poisonous sting (JNW 1: 875), pe is a kind of ray (JNW 2: 170); totok is a kind of sea-shell (JNW 1: 651); lajar is listed in KBW 3: 747, and vadukan in KBW 3: 527 (which refers to New Javanese dukaṅ (see JNW 2: 353) and Malay badukaṅ (see MED 1: 99), that is ’catfish’).
.40,2a Makara ’vater-elephant’ and caviri ’monster-head’ (its variant is cavintən; see however JFC 2: 54) are usual figures in a temple (see Teeuw and others 1969: 48: 312).
.40,3a Since in this stanza the members of the family of the god are mentioned, ləmbu suddha ’white bull’ here refers to Nandi, the vehicle of Śiva, which is ’white as snow, with a huge body and soft brown eyes’ (Daniélou 1963: 219-20).
.40,3d Saisuka is not known in the Sanskrit dictionaries. The vord is related to sisu, which primarily means ’child, infant’, and is also known as one of the names of Skandha or Kumara, who was one of the sons of Śiva (SED: 1076).
.40,4a-b Badava
7405ṅ
.-nala
.’Fire-emanating Turtle’ and Urāgarāja ’king of serpents’, who is also called Ananta-bhoga, are known in Old Javanese cosmogony as the base and the foundation of the vorld, and the island of Java in particular. Hence the mention of dasar i vəkas Hi mahltala in 4c. For a very thorough discussion on Badavaṅ-nala see Hooykaas 1964: 103-17 (in which he quotes and translates 4a); see also Svellengrebel 1936: 296-7.
.40,5b ’to vear’ for an go would not be posible, for the form should be akan go. So I take aṅgo as a nasalised form of go, which is the root of gogo ’groping in the vater’ (see KBW 4: 807; JNW 2: 626, sub: gogo).
.40,5c For galigiran, JNW 2: 627 (under gigir) gives: iṅkaṅ taksih vətah ’which is still intact’. Olər-oləran probably also has the same meaning. The base vord is ulər, which, among others, is used as a classifier for banana. … pisan arəjôlər-oləran, thus literally means ’beautiful bananas of many ulər’.
741040,7a arəmuk means ’crushed’. Is this to be understood as ’to strike pearls on stones to test their quality’?
.40,3d Cf. Covarrubias 1937: 116: ’…Often the favourite bathing-place is a shallow spot in the river where men on one side, women on the other, squat on the vater … scrubbing themselves with pumice-stone that removes superfluous hair and invigorates the skin, or rubbing their backs with a rough stick or against a large stone placed there for the purpose’, [italics are mine].
.40,11c Or: ’his numerous arms were like trees on a slope, and the arms which fondled her resembled shoots of the gaduṅ vines’?
.41,Id The simile ’rivals the lightning issuing from the moon’ is probably developed from the belief that the rain comes from the moon (see Notes 38,5d).
.41,2b Literally: ’your waist is like vaves which will vreck the passion of the onlookers’. For the meaning of aṅjahatakəna see Notes 32,10.
741541,2d amutər ’to churn’ refers to the samudramanthana episode ’the churning of the ocean’, narrated in Adip.: 31-4. In this episode it is told that when the ocean was churned by the gods and the demons, the goddesses Sri and Laksmī sprang from the vaves. The goddess Sri is the goddess of beauty (see Daniélou 1964: 261), hence the expression putus niṅ lituhajə̄ṅ ’the topmost of beauty’ in 2c.
.41,4a-d rumta
.your beauty’ in 4a and 4d are both used to denote second persons, the former for the queen, the latter for the king (see Notes 12,4b).
.41,6d Although this line is structurally closer to 6c (and thus refers to the demon soldiers) than to 6b, I take this clause as dependent on the vord liṅga (6b), which is in accordance with the reading in the OJ Utt. (Zoetmulder 1958: 25,21 ’… kāñcanaliṅgapratima inilvakən saparan ikaṅ Rāvaṇa’.
.41,7c Poerbatjaraka (1933: 26) reads tegal ayun, which occurs in Nit. 1,10d as təgal ayū n, and considers tegal ayū stands for təgal layū (cf. VG 9: 24). Since ayun is a common vord for ’battle’, and tegal papraṅan ’battlefield’ occurs several times in this kakavin (51,6a; 57,6d; see pp. 60-1), I take the correct reading of this vord to be tegal ayun, i.e. ’uncultivated land suitable for use as a battlefield’.
742042,6b Or: sinivî Magadha sakala, i.e. ’ruled throughout the kingdom of Magadha’ ?
.43,1c For the punctuation ’… lagana kunan, mon ikaṅ …’ instead of ’… lagana, kunaṅ mon ikaṅ ..see Notes 1,21b.
.43,Id For niscita, SED: 561 gives, among other meanings, ’one who has come to a conclusion, or formed a certain opinion; … certainty’. This line is thus literally to be translated: ’It is not certain, I am sure, that I would be slain ..
.44,3b Since atigas can only be either intransitive or reflexive, i.e. ’to cut off one’s ovn head’, paratrâtigas can only mean ’to commit suicide’. The signi-ficance of the simile (i.e. ’as useless as the death of a medicine-man committing suicide’) is not clear to me. For a description of a Balinese bahan, which no doubt is the spiritual descendant of the Old Javanese valyan, see Covarrubias 1937: 349 sqq.
.44,4b ’arrogant’ for vruh-vruh is no more than conjecture (cf. 70,3b). Mahâsura is used here in the second person, and musuh refers to Arjuna.
742544,4c-d The episode referred to by the poet in this passage is the Adip.: 44, in which Wiṣṇu asked Garuda to be his mount.
.45,7d The reading pva ta n (as emphatic particle) is admittedly unusual. If we take the more common reading of pva tan, the line may be translated: ’I am certain that Arjuna will not be able to kill me in battle’.
.45,9b The translation ’chariot of my chariot’ implies that vimāna vimāna ni ṅvaṅ stands for vimāna ni vimāna ni ṅvaṅ. But even if this is the case, the phrase is still ambiguous. Kern (1919: 63) has noted that a form such as peka niṅ peka, found in Nag. 18,1c, is an idiom denoting ’a number of servants’. On the other hand, Poerbatjaraka (1924: 222) argues that such an
.expression would mean ’servants of servants’, which is adopted here. If Kern’s suggestion is right here, this line is to be translated ’and so he is just like [one of] my chariots’. However, since Rāvaṇa is known to have had one vimāna par excellence, namely the Puspaka (see 10,7), such a translation is less likely than the one suggested here.
.45,12a ’paran in hrdayâtiguhya’ is literally: ’the goal of my heart which is most secret’.
743046,1b This line is reminiscent of Tap. 103,16 sqq. (see Notes 6,1c).
.46,5a Does ’the monkey-field’ refer to a təgal inhabited by monkeys or one merely frequented by them? Another possibility is that pravaga is not derived from Sanskrit plavaga ’monkey’, as given in ONW: 389, but is a variant of vaga (cf. pralambaṅ - lambaṅ; prasətya - sətya in New Javanese). According to JNW 2: 69 vaga (which is derived from Sanskrit bhaga) is a synonym of pavadonan, that is ’vulva’. Nov, the krama vord of pavadonan, i.e. paestren also means a type of cultivated təgal, usually near a river (cf. JNW 1: 94). A similar expression is alas vadon ’female forest’, which is used to denote ’thicket’ as against the alas lanaṅ ’male forest’ to denote ’great forest’ (JNW 2: 81, sub: lanaṅ).
.46,7b In Old Javanese parva is used as a technical term referring to a prose work with epic contents (Ensink 1967: 1).
.46,9b For sasadhara mapalih see Notes 3,6c-d.
.46,11c As malaga can also mean ’fighter; warrior’ (ONW: 491), instead of vlra suyasa malaga, the phrase may be read vlrasuyasamalaga, i.e. ’bold, famous warriors’.
743547,3a The reading of F, ’vimānânila’ instead of vimānâkila, is not impossible. In this case this line is to be translated: ’… circled over the Hehayas in his celestial chariot which flev like the vind’, which is an appropriate description for the chariot Puspaka. On the other hand the phrase vimānâkila is not unknown from other sources, e.g. Bhom. 96,13.
.47,4c bhinna il kena is literally ’those affected were destroyed’.
.48,1c What is the function of da in huniṅan da? Does it stand for nda, an emphatic particle, or is it to be read huniṅanta?
.49,1a It is interesting to note that in the lakon (vayang repertoire), Su-mantri is the childhood name of Suvandha.
.49,6c The reading ’… asva dvīpa len turaṅga’, i.e. ’horses, elephant and horses’ is not certain. Probably this line should read: mevivv aṅasv (or aṅ asv?) advlpa len turaṅga, i.e. ’thousands of them attacked on their elephants and horses’.
744049,13d hampru is ’bile’ (JNW 1: 168), but, like pyah which means ’liver’ (or ’heart’) as well as ’stomach’ (KBW 4: 23), in Old Javanese it probably also denotes ’stomach’.
.50,10b ’… amran tulalay ika tugəl…’ is syntactically rather forced. Probably it stands for ’amraṅ ṅ tulalay, ika tugəl’, or ’amraṅ tulalay nika, tugəl’. The meaning, however, is quite clear.
.50,12b There is no doubt that ’falling diamonds’ for hlrapata is lexically correct, but in the context it does not seem to fit well. This implies that either the parvatâstra is to be understood as ’mountain of diamond veapons’, or that kira in Old Javanese might have the meaning of ’rock; stone’.
.51,4b ’Mārīcêki pəjah de Kaliṅgapati …’ would be grammatically better (cf. 51,4a: … pəjah de Sūryaketu), but it is metrically impossible.
.51,5b ’… trees entwined by vines’ is conjectural, but vvit iṅ taru lata ’trees of vine trees’ is a strange expression, unless it is to be understood as ’trees to support the vines’.
744551,12b The seventh month of the Javanese calendar ( = Māgha in Sanskrit) coincides with the months of January-February (JFC 5: 24). This is the month when the rain falls heavily and daily in Java, so that according to folk-etymology ’Januari’ is derived from lhujan sehari-hari’, that is ’rain daily’.
.52,5b I take paṅlampū as the equivalent of Malay terlampau, i.e. ’excessively; too bad!’ (cf. KBW 3: 722; Berg 1969: 444). However, paṅlampū may also be regarded as an imperative form (see Zoetmulder 1950: 168) of aṅlampū ’to go on; to carry on’, and therefore it is not possible to translate this line by ’now come on, you vorthless king …’.
.52,6a KBW 4: 505 quotes this passage, but gives no comment. The trans-lation of maṅadu mindê narapati ’to strike the king’s heads one against the other’ is conjectural, but in the context seems appropriate. The literal trans-lation, i.e. ’to make the goats fight the king’ is unintelligible. Another possible literal translation is ’to make the two kings fight as goats’. It is on this possibility that I base my translation ’to strike the king’s heads one against the other’, since this is hov goats fight.
.53,1-4 In this canto, through the mouth of the first minister of Mahispati, the poet expounds the ranayajña ’battle-sacrifice’, which is a favourite theme for Sanskrit as well as Old Javanese poets (see Zoetmulder 1957: 58; Teeuw and others 1969: 150). Tantular himself again alludes to this sacrifice in Sut. 114,2.
.54,1-55,1 There is no doubt that samaratha (54,1c), ardharatha (54,3a), atiratha (54,3b) and mahāratha (55,1b), referring to different persons as they do, denote certain ranks in the heroes’ hierarchy, but the relative status
7450of these ranks is not clear. In fact, with the exception of mahāratha ’great warrior’, these vords do not appear in the dictionaries. The degrees of the respective heroes are indicated by sama ’common’, ardha ’half; semi’, ati ’very’, and maha ’great’.
.54,Id An alternative translation: ’calmly he performed the sacrifice on the battlefield, recited incantations, and was willing to die at the hands of the demon king’.
.57,3a maṅsulakən normally means ’to return’ (transitive verb), but ’to return the king’, or even ’to return to the king’, does not fit the context. Probably this vord is the equivalent of New Javanese mbalik (vaṅsul is the krama form of bali; and balik is a variant of bali) i.e. ’to go over to the enemy’s side’, or Malay membelakangi ’to turn one’s back’.
.57,4a The stroke of two is 9 p.m. (see Notes 34,1c).
.57,6b nrpati rāja rāja is a rather curious phrase. Is nrpati different from raja? Or is one of the two no more than a stop-gap?
745557,7b It is very unlikely that surasena here means ’the host of the gods’ as in 7,3b, because there is no mention in the present kakavin, nor in any other source that I know of, that Arjuna Sahasrabāhu had an army of gods at his command. Probably the name is derived from Sanskrit Sūrasena, who is known as one of the sons of Kārtavīrya (SED: 1086). For metrical purposes, it was changed to Surasena, and eventually became Surasena (cf. dāna - dhana; Notes 31,4a).
.57,8b The usual meaning of mihat, i.e. ’to look at’ does not fit the context, because the simile ’like a lion wishing to see an elephant’ is not strong enough in the context. There seems to be a shift of meaning in this vord: to see - to look at - to face - to oppose (e.g. 58,Id) - to do battle. In this simile, Arjuna is compared to the lion and Rāvaṇa to the elephant, and this comparison implies that Arjuna is superior to Rāvaṇa (thus Ingalls 1965: 300: ’It is proverbial that the lion kills the elephant in combat … and the poets are prone to laugh at the elephant for his Dutch courage when faced with the lion’).
.57,8c It is notevorthy that the phrase tan pasaṅkan inucap (literally: not because he is mentioned) occurs tvice in the present kakavin (see 67,8a), on both occasions referring to divine sages, who apparently do not live in this vorld.
.58,5 This passage contains the prophecy of the death of Rāvaṇa at the hand of Rāma with the help of Sugriva, the king of the monkeys, as narrated in the Rāma stories.
.59,2c-d
7460An alternative reading is ’… mvaṅ bhaktya niṅ rat kabeh ṅkānê jə̄ṅ nira Rudramūrti, …’ (’besides the devotion of the people to the feet of
.the god Rudramūrti’). However, this is less likely, since the following clause, i.e. kahidəp saṅ maṅkana lvir nira would be an incomplete one.
.59,8d ’… become ocean and mountain .. is to be understood as ’sea of blood and mountain of corpses’, which is a common stock-phrase to describe the great casualties among the combatants (see e.g. 17,7b: ṅ lvaṅ baṅun parvata sava, rudhirâdres banun sagarâlva; 50,1b; 6,12a-b).
.60,2d jalanidhi matsya is to be understood as ’ri jalanidhi matsya …’ (cf. suku niṅ gunuṅ for ri suku niṅ gunuṅ; Teeuw and others 1969: 146). This interpretation is, I believe, better than regarding the phrase as a Sanskrit compound (i.e. ’sea-fish’) because nya in varinya refers to the sea. kadi pāvakôsnâṅalun is literally ’like raging hot fire’.
.61,4d
7465The reading ’… puh mar an ..is better than ’puh mara ṅ’ (with mar a as an emphatic particle), for mar occurs several times denoting ’weak; poverless; exhausted’ (c.f. 60,5d: mar puh tiba).
.62,
.1a-b The comparison with the god Tripurântaka ’the destroyer of the Triple city’, i.e. Śiva, when the king assumed his trivikrama form, clearly indicates that to the poet trivikrama is no longer regarded as the special form of Wiṣṇu (cf. Notes 38,8a).
.62,4a ’… mihat n ton …’ is a curious phrase, since both verbs have the meaning of ’to see; to look at’. In the translation only one of the two appears. However, it is probably not too far-fetched to render mihat as ’to appear; be visible’, comparable in sense to Indonesian ’nampah’. If this is the case, the line may be translated: ’Dasavaktra was enraged, and he appeared furious at the sight of …’.
.63,3 d ’tinaṅgəh kədo’ is literally ’has been varned, but was stubborn’.
747063,5d kinehan (from keh) is an unusual vord. In Old Javanese instead of keh, kveh is usually used. In the sense in which it is used here (i.e. ’to be done by many people together’), however, kinabehan (from kabeh) is more usual (see ONW: 113).
.63,8 In </p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="63">we find the most significant difference between the Balinese and the Javanese versions of the present kakavin. In the Javanese version (y), </p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="63">ends with 63,7 and then begins with a nev canto which has no counterpart in the Balinese version. Thus instead of two stanzas (i.e. 8 and 9), y has two cantos of 14 stanzas. Considering the unreliability of the reading of y, there seems to be little doubt that two cantos have been inter-polated into the Javanese version, rather than that the Balinese version has lost two cantos. Such being the case, I put this interpolated passage in the Variae Lectiones, rather than in the body of the Text. The problem of interpolation in Old Javanese works, the OJ Ram. in particular, has been discussed by Hooykaas (1955), and it would be too far from the scope of
.the present Notes to the Translation to discuss it here. The following remarks are made, nevertheless, because they are relevant to the editing of this interpolated passage:
7475(1) The interpolator still had a mastery of rules of metre, long forgotten by the Javanese (cf. Poerbatjaraka 1926: 5). This is evident from the correct scansion of every line throughout the interpolation. Several long syllables seem to be forced, e.g. pvā, māti, ṅūni, but as we have noted in pp. 38-9 this feature is not at all unusual in the present kakavin, or in any other kakavin.
.(2) The language is still passable as Old Javanese. There are, to be sure, some signs of possible ’neologisms’, such as valiṅ ira instead of valiṅ nira, nuṅsuṅa instead of manuṅsuṅa (see B,4c and 63,8b), but such forms are not uncommon in many Old Javanese works. The omission of the connective particle ’n’ in a possessive construction is not rare in this kakavin and the same vord nunsuṅ occurs even in a tvelfth century poem (Har. 27,4c).
.It is thus not easy to prove that this passage is an interpolation, apart from the fact that it occurs only in the Javanese manuscripts. Nevertheless, the following arguments may, perhaps, be used to support this contention:
.(1) In this passage the name Sukhasārana is used to denote only one demon (A,Id) as in the New Javanese version of this story, whereas in the other parts of this kakavin, it appears to indicate two demons (see Notes 7,6b) as in Sanskrit literature.
.(2) In A,7c-d we read that the king and the queen will return to the vorld of Wiṣṇu: Arjuna will assume his form as Wiṣṇu, and Citravatī as the goddess Sri. In the other part of this kakavin Arjuna says that he will return to the abode of Śiva (72,Id). And Tantular indeed compares Arjuna more often to Śiva than to Wiṣṇu. In the New Javanese version, however, Arjuna is regarded as an incarnation of the god Wiṣṇu, and his wife as an incarnation of the goddess Sri.
7480The contents of the passage themselves are not important to the sequence of the narrative, for they are only a ’repetition’ of what will be told in </p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="64"> However, for the sake of completeness this passage is presented and translated in this edition in full. Since it is almost impossible to reconstruct a definite Text based on the readings of the Javanese manuscripts (see Section 7.3) the text included in the Variae Lectiones and the translation offered below are only tentative:
.(Canto A)
.1 Let us tell no more of what happened to Daśāsya after he was captured by the king of kings; we tell now of queen Citravati, who was left on the bank of the Narmadā. A demon came bringing her nevs that the king had fallen in battle. This vicked demon was called Sukhasārana, and had disguised himself as a virtuous man.
.2 And so [all the women of] the court cried aloud like the sound of the
7485vaves of the sea,
.and the queen, foremost among them, was perplexed, speechless and sorrowful;
.she was dazed, languorous, trembling, exhausted and looked as if drained of life.
.Then she fainted, and no longer heard the lamentations of the servants and nurses who came to her aid.
.3 Soon after she revived, she decided to go to the place where the king had
7490fallen in battle;
.but the demon stopped her, telling her of the approach of the demon king who was going to carry her off — thus spoke the demon, pretending to be
.truthful and faithful. And so the queen cut her hair and nails
.4 to be placed at the feet of the ruler of the Hehayas.
.Such were her instructions to her servant who was sent to the battlefield. Thereupon the queen at once rose and prepared to follow [the death of] her husband,
7495for she had no desire to live on; she unloosened her hair, and took a sharp gleaming dagger in her hand, [saying]:
.5 ’O my king, O my belowed one, please take heed of my lamentations for
.you,
.you, who like the god Harimūrti in battle, are feared by all daitya, yaksa and asura,
.who are the god of the flower garden descended to the earth so that
7500I could serve you [read: kahadəp?] in the fragrant bed-chamber, for all impurities are cleansed from the body when one sleeps under one coverlet with you.
.6 now you have been slain by a vicked, arrogant demon,
.although not because of his might, but because of your wish to fly [to
.heaven] and to leave your body. In short, my Lord, I wish to join you
.in heaven — this certainly is my wish — or wherever else you go.
75057 O my dearest, please awake, and let us vanish together to the sky,
.to be greeted by the eagle, the great mount of heroes who fall in battle, and together we will wander over the three vorlds at ease and live happily
.in the splendid, magnificent vorld of Wiṣṇu; you will assume your beautiful form of the god Wiṣṇu, and I that of Sri, the great goddess.’
.8 Thus she spoke, then with her gleaming dagger she quickly stabbed herself in the heart, and her blood spurted high, gushing beautifully in
.a sparkling bright colour. Then the queen did homage to the sani (?),
7510vhile vashing her face with the blood, which was like flowers strevn on her hair and breast.
.9 She was in deep meditation, performing the sunyayoga (i.e. the yoga to reach the Void?),
.and had concentrated her mind on the ’three-minds’ as taught by the perfect yogi.
.And so she died; the jewels (?) quickly and beautifully followed (?) flower petals suddenly rained dovn at the same time, as though falling from the sky.
.(Canto B)
75151 On the death of the queen who now lay on the floor (?) of the blooming
.asoka flowers,
.all the beauties of nature around the banks of the Narmadā looked dazed and perplexed:
.the ivory bamboos stripped off their sheats and sighed pitifully;
.the thunder rumbled softly as though weeping painfully and sorrowfully;
75202 the sun was dimmed by clouds, a rainbow formed in the sky, and light
.rain drizzled upon the mountains, and the [brilliance of] lightning that brightened the darkness looked
.subdued (?) because of the queen’s death. Moreover, all the maidens of the court followed the queen in performing the act of bela,
.foremost among them were those who shared the king’s love with the queen, they fell at her feet.
.3 At the sight of what happened [the servant who had been sent to the king
7525by the queen?] would gladly have joined [those who performed bela], and therfore she quickly departed to pay homage [metri causa for seva?] to the king[’s body] and then join
.in death those she loved. Let us not tell of her journey; we now tell of king Kārtavīrya [according to the metre: Krtavīrya!], who returned [to the bank of the Narmadā], accompanied by the dreadful warriors of the Hehayas with their possessions and chariots.
.4 He followed the same route through the impassable wooded mountains, and soon reached the bank of the Narmadā, where the queen was lying
.dead.
.Before he set out to var he had told her [that on his return] he would like
7530her to velcome him with loving eyes, but now he found she was no longer as he had left her: she was dead, her appearance was pitiful and pale.
.5 The young and old servants, nurses, albinos, hunch-backs, the kuñja vere
.all lying dead.
.And so the king was amazed and speechless at the sight of the dead, and all the officers were struck dumb.
.Then came to the king’s presence the servant sent by the dead queen, saying:
753564,2a-b
.An
.alternative reading: ’Ya hetu nira yan ta mar kapati…’. The translation of ’… tan vriṅ ulaha ruməṅə̄ naresvara / ulih niṅ atuluṅ …’ is far from certain, but a better alternative is difficult to suggest.
.64,3c It is not easy to decide vhether the vord viphala ’useless; of no avail’ refers to the deed of the queen, or to the victory of the king. Contextually, both readings are possible. If the latter is correct, this line is to be translated: ’And so, although you survive and are victorious, this is of no purpose’.
