.65,2c The translation is tentative. I take manis-manista ’your sweetness’ simply as a synonym of ’rumta’, which, as we have seen in Notes 12,4b, is used as a term of endearment for the belowed one. Kvan could mean either ’command’ or ’place’ (Teeuw 1946: 82), and although Zoetmulder favours the latter, which I have adopted here, as the appropriate meaning (see ZA: 297), the translation ’command’ (thus: ’where is your command’, i.e. ’Com-mand me …’) contextually is not impossible. Another reading: ndl kukvān i manis-manista (taking kukvān as a derivative of kuku ’nail’, thus ’scratching’) is likevise not impossible. Scratching with sharp nails and biting with teeth are standard practice in sexual enjoyment as described in Sanskrit literature, and nail wounds were borne with pride, and even became a criterion for social distinction (see Ingalls 1965: 200).
7540The second part of the line is even more uncertain. I assume avijāṅdələ̄ stands for avijaṅ and aṅdələ̄, which admittedly is a very weak assumption, hence the translation ’fi am] lying on your breast and looking into (?) your eyes’.
.65,3d lsapudaka salambaṅ in lanə̄’ (salambaṅêṅ lanə̄ is probably better; cf. Teeuw and others 1969: 315) is an expression indicating the wish to be always together. People used to vrite lambaṅ ’poems’ on the petals of pudak flowers (see e.g. 74,5: akirim kakavin i dala niṅ pudak sumar; see also Notes 12,7d).
.66,2a Literally: ’For it is not the arrival of the [real] death, the death of the queen who was the jewel of the palace’.
.66,2c In this passage, the Old Javanese text could give the impression that Sukhasārana is the name of a single demon, as in the New Javanese lakon (cf. Notes 63,8). However, from a passage describing the fight between Rāvaṇa’s army and that of Waiśravaṇa, we have strong reason to argue that Tantular is cognizant of the fact that Sukhasārana is a copulative compound representing the names of two demons, i.e. Sukha and Sārana (Sanskrit: Suka and Sārana; see Notes 7,6b).
.66,4d For ’himpər manure manik’ see Notes 21,6b.
754567,2a The exact meaning of sariravāhya (’physical body’?) in this line is not at all clear. Probably, the following clause (i.e. ’baṅun …’) is a Javanese rendering for a phrase the author has assumed to be Sanskrit.
.67,2d yak pəjaha (’I shall die’) does not fit the context, for after the queen had been revived, there is no reason why the king should have had any wish to die. Probably it should be read yat pəjaha (which graphologically is not impossible, the letter’t’ being rather similar to ’k’), i.e. ’if you had really died’.
.68,3c Is anlaga a verb (’to fight’, thus literally: ’by you, who fought most valiantly’), or can it also be a noun (’fighter’, thus: ’by you, the most valiant fighter’)? Cf. malaga, Notes 32,8d.
.69,1c An alternative reading is: apituvi tan pabhoja, bañu dūra hana n masuṅa (’moreover he had no food, and it was not likely that anyone had given him vater’). However, since ma-bhoja-bañu is analogous to New Java-nese manan-ṅinum or Indonesian makan minum, I prefer to read the text as a ma- form of the compound bhoja-bañu.
.70,1b The reading maṅgəh n ūnin which is adopted here is not certain. In this reading I take ūnin as a passive arealis form of Tini. Another alternative reading is maṅgəh ṅ ūni n (’his vords were firm …’), and although maṅgəh ṅūni n (’he was firm before …’) is not an impossible reading, contextually it is less acceptable.
755070,2a gavayakənana is an unusual form; the only possible interpretation is as a passive arealis of gumavayakən, but then gavayakəna would be the more accepted form. Or should it be emended: gavayakəna ya?
.70,3a The translation of this line is far from satisfactory. The key vord is hiniriṅan (a passive form of maṅhiriṅi), which normally means ’to be accom-panied’. However, I can make no sense of hayva tātan (’do not you not …’) hana hiniriṅan (thus: ’you have to be accompanied’?) in the context here. Accordingly I take hayva as referring to Rāvaṇa’s evil conduct (buddhi mūrkhâvamana) mentioned in 70,Id, and take hiniriṅan as derived from hirin (a variant of irin), which is related to New Javanese eriṅ ’to show respect’, thus ’to be respected’.
.70,4a Should ’ulahakənā lencC be read ’ulahakənâlena’, or be emended to ’ulahakənânlend’ ?
.70,4d
.Literally: ’… people will censure him as imitating those who fall into hell’.
755571,1c dhana panuṅkul is literally ’vealth to be used as a token of surrender’, that is, vealth given by the conquered to the conqueror.
.71,3a The syntactic function of the vord paramapānditôttama is not at all clear, and the translation of this line, therefore, is not certain. If this vord is dropped, there is no ambiguity in meaning, namely the conduct of a king in ruling his country is no different from that of the tapa practiced by an ascetic.
.71,6a-b
.The translation of these two lines is very tentative. I render sinamaya as it is given in various dictionaries. Zoetmulder (ZH: 4) suggests that samaya in sinamaya is related to samadhi (cf. New Javanese kaya - - - kadi), and sinamaya therefore to be rendered as ’to imagine in the depths of one’s mind’. In the context such translation is not impossible.
.’the king thinks what a great sage thinks’ for hidep nira tikâṅhidəp is conjectural, but a better alternative is hard to propose.
756071,6c The notion that a king is ’hurip in jagat kabeh’ is strongly reminiscent of the phrase in 1,1a namely that srl Parvatarāja is 1 hurip iṅ sarvapramānêṅ jagat’. This leads us to a conclusion that — at least to Tantular — the king and the ’Lord of the Mountains’ are two different manifestations of one and the same deity. This idea has been discussed at some length in Chapter 6.
.71,7b Cf. the formulation in 71,2c: apan krama ni saṅ narendra juga tan palə-paləh i karaksan in jagat. Thus tan bəsur is a synonym of tan pale-paləh ’negligent’? (for tan bcsur see Notes 21,6d).
.72,1c The ’pandita Wiṣṇumūrti’ who is to be the cause of Arjuna’s death is Rāma Bhārgava, who is also known as Parasu Rāma. According to Pigeaud (1967: 184; cf. p. 16, Note 21) the feud between Arjuna Saharabāhu and Parasu Rāma is used as the theme of a tvelfth century kakavin, Arjuna Sahasrabāhu. In the Purānic story, Parasu Rāma was known as the sixth incarnation of Wiṣṇu. He was born as the fifth son af Jamadagni, who was deceived and killed by king Kārtavīrya and his sons. Single-handed, Parasu Rāma destroyed all the males of the royal blood (see Daniélou 1964: 170-2). This episode is related briefly in Adip.: 3.
.72,9b Nir don taṅ dina ratri is literally ’night and day are of no purpose [to him]’. The idea is that the king did nothing else, either by night or by day, than devote himself to the dharma.
.73,1 a-b For a comment on this passage see Section 1.2. The reading abuka ’to begin’ (literally: ’to have … as an opening’, i.e. ’to have … as a begin-ning’) is not without doubt. One may argue that the whole kakavin is in fact derived from the ’Daśāsyacarita’, because the first part of the Utt., in other vords the source of the Arj., is no more than the story of Rāvaṇa before his encounter with Rāma. To render abuka by ’give rise to; lead to’ as given in ONW: 406, however, does not fit the context. Could it be a copyist’s error for kathâdbhuta, i.e. ’wonderful story’ (cf. Sut. 148,1a: Nāhan tântyan ikaṅ kathâtisaya Boddhacarita il inikət ’Thus ends the versification of the most wonderful tale, the story of Boddha’).
756573,1c For a discussion on the name of the poet, Tantular, see Section 1.1.
.73,Id lnda tan tular ika ri gatinya’ is a pun, serving as a gloss to explain the meaning of the name the author had probably chosen for himself as his pen-name (parab). The rendering of tan tular by ’unsverving’ or ’undeviating’
.is in accordance with Zoetmulder’s suggestion (see Teeuw and others 1969: 14). Berg (1969: 66-7; 368, Note 42) argues that tantular is a synonym of prapañca, which means exactly the opposite of the meaning given here. Berg’s arguments, however, are not acceptable. He is right in arguing that tan tular is a synonym of tan cala, but he is mistaken when he contends that tan tular is also a synonym of cañcala, because tan cala is the negation of cañcala (cala and cañcala are more or less synonymous; see SED: 391 and 382). The Sanskrit equivalent of tan tular is drdha (thus Ram. 24,165: drdha tan tular aṅən-aṅənya tan cala). It is interesting to note that in the Bunur inscription the grantee, dyah Parih, has been given the dharmasima of Buṅur by Rāja-sanagara on account of his kadrhabhkatin to the latter’s niece, the wife of Tantular’s patron. Could it be that there is some connection here, namely that Tantular ’the unsverving one’ was the pen-name of dyah Parih, who was renovned for his ’unsverving loyalty’ to his master?
.Berg (1969: 67) has amended migu (which he renders as ’restless’) for milu. Milu ləṅəṅ is, in my opinion, contextually quite appropriate. The occurence of milu in this phrase is similar to tumut aṅapilaṅə̄ occurring in 73,1a or milv âmarna ri kastavan nrpati occurring in Nag. 94,1b.
.Comparing the phrase ’tan vruh i rusit niṅ aji’ with Sut. 148,4c ’… turuṅ vruh in aji sakatha’, we may assume that aji in this phrase refers to aji sakatha, i.e. the Art of narration. Here I take sakatha as being derived from Sanskrit samkathā (SED: 1125). However, it might also be possible that sakatha is derived from samkata, which means, among other things, ’impassable; dan-gerous’ (SED: 1125), and it is thus the equivalent of Javanese rusit (KBW 1: 746). The phrase ’rusit niṅ aji’ is also used to describe a beautiful person, probably via ’[her beauty] as hard to perceive as Art’ thus ’[her beauty is] indescribable’ (see KBW 1: 522, sub niraksara). Hence my translation ’the subtleties of the Art’ for rusit nin aji in this line.
757073,2a-b
.For a comment on this passage see pp. 10-1.
.73,2c-d
.This passage refers to the future death of Arjuna at the hand of Rāma Bhārgava or Parasu Rāma and that of Dasamukha at the hand of Rāmacandra, the sixth and seventh incarnation of Wiṣṇu respectively (see Daniélou 1964: 170-5).
.74,1 This stanza is puzzling. If it is related to the previous one, then durāt-maka in line 1a must certainly refer to Dasamukha as well as Arjuna. In the epic literature, this might not be surprising, for both Dasamukha and Kārta-vlrya are considered evil in the Rāmāyana and Mahābhārata cycles. However, it is hard to understand how Tantular, as a poet who has vritten a kakavin extolling the deeds of Arjuna Kārtavīrya, could say that his hero was a will.in. The only plausible explanation is that although the poet does not explicitly exclude Arjuna Kārtavīrya from the evil imputation, only Dasamukha is meant here. This suggestion is corroborated by the use of bāna ’arrow’ as the veapon that is to slay this durātmaka ’the vicked soul(s)’, which agrees with the story of Dasamukha’s death, but not with that of Arjuna, since the latter
7575vas slain by Rama Bhargava, whose usual veapon was an axe (hence his name Parasu-Rāma, i.e. ’Rāma with the axe’).
.74,2a For parvacarita see Notes 46,6b. Here it refers to the parts of the OJ Utt.
.74,2b Although ṅhulun (’I; me’) is used here, for the sake of consistency I have used ’he’ in the translation, since in the other parts of this passage Tantular uses the third person pronoun.
.74,2d Although the literal meaning of the metaphor asoṅ karas is clear, i.e. ’to have vriting leaves as an umbrella’, its significance is not apparent, except that it denotes the poet’s activity of vriting a composition. A similar case is aṅituṅi paṅjrah iṅ səkar, literally: ’to count the blossoming flowers’ (see P. 37).
.74,3a In KBW 1: 296 we read the following quotations: ’kolug tan vikan ya ri pinaṅka nin kevəh’ and ’kolug tinaṅaran [?] tan uniṅga kevəhnya’, which indicates that kolug can mean ’does not know the origin of hardship; ignorant of hardship’. So, an alternative translation is: ’And so far as this Tantular is concerned, he is ignorant of hardship, for he is not in the least deterred by the derision of others’.
758074,3d tādana means ’beating; striking; chastising’ (see SED: 441; ONW: 223), but it does not seem to fit the context. Other possible readings, buddhitā dhana or buddhitâdhana, likevise do not make sense.
.74,4b vruh iṅgita is the Javanese equivalent of Sanskrit iṅgita-jña (SED: 164), which means ’understanding signs; acquainted with the gestures of another; skilled in the expression or interpretation of internal sentiments by external gesture’.
.74,4c In Old Javanese kahañan normally means ’to be captured’, especially in reference to girls from a defeated state captured by the victor (see e.g. KBW 1: 374). It is doubtful vhether this meaning is appropriate here. In New Javanese ṅañaṅ means ’to bid for’ (JNW 1: 39), hence my translation ’to be taken’ in the sense of ’to be purchased’ for kahañaṅ. It is interesting to note that the Old Javanese vord for ’to attack’, or ’to win a possession’ is anuku (e.g. 4,13c; Nit. 2,2d: uttama niṅ hinuttama dhanôlih iṅ anuku musuh), which is derived from suku. Anuku, however, can also mean ’to buy’, although in this case the vord is derived from tuku. Probably there is a tenuous semantic connection between these vords: suku — hañaṅ — tuku.
.74,4d The reading ’… buddhi nirâgama …’ does not make sense. For nirāgama, SED 540 gives: ’not founded on revelation’, which I adopt here. Admittedly the function of buddhi in the syntax is not clear.
.74,5c-d
7585Although there is no lexical difficulty in these two last lines of the poem, the exact meaning of the whole passage is not clear, and the translation
.of 5c especially is no more than conjecture. Another possible translation of 5c is: ’In short, when the withered nagasari flowers at the peak [of …?] arouse poetical trance’. For ’Scripture’ as a rendering for ləpihan tanah see Svellen-grebel 1936: 212. Saṅ sūksmêṅ ləpihan tanah, the god who is present in the scripture’, however, is not necessarily the goddess Sarasvatī as in the case of Kor: 9,6 (cf. Svellengrebel 1936: 226). It could be any deity, invoked by the poet especially in its capacity as the god of beauty (see Zoetmulder 1957: 64-9). In this particular kakavin, it might as well be srī Parvatarājadeva, the Lord of the Mountains, whom Tantular has invoked in 1,1a.
.NEW JAVANESE RENDERINGS OF THE ARJUNAWIJAYA
.As Pigeaud (1967: 241) has rightly stated, the Arj. was much appreciated by Surakarta poets of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. This is evident from the repeated renderings of this poem into New Javanese.
.The Arjunavijaya kavi miriṅ
7590The oldest rendering that has come dovn to us is vritten in a type of metre, usually called kavi miriṅ (see Pigeaud 1967: 237-8). The dates of the com-mencement and the completion of the vriting of this version are recorded in chronograms occurring in the first and final cantos respectively:
.Arkm. 1,1a-b:
.Purva
.nire
.ṅ
7595makirtyeṅ agñeṅ maprabvatmajeṅ Javeṅ Surakarta / ri Isnen piṅ volulas Dulkijah tuhun Wavu trus karna svareṅ rat
.(At
.the command of the Crovn Prince of Java in Surakarta, the vriting of this poem has been commenced on Monday, 18th Dhū’l Hijjah of the year Wavu, 1729 (1803 A.D.).
.Arkm. 73,1a-2a:
.Pralabda niṅ anereh riheṅ Sabtu / tabəh sana vimba nira ṅ catur / Warigalit Sakban riṅ mansa kanəm / ri tuhun Jimakir kalisaṅara // sakala riṅ sudda tri viku tuṅal
7600(The completion of the vriting (?) [of this poem] is on Saturday, at the ninth hour of the fourth day of the vaxing of the moon, Warigalit, Sha’bān, the sixth [Javanese] month, in the year Jimākhir, 1730 (1803 A.D.).
.The name of the pujaṅga who composed this version of the Arj. occurs in the following quotation (Arkm. 73,2b-3d):
.Kan
.tincdah
.vadyaji juru-nitra / makirtya rin katarjunavijaya / lagu magcṅ rikaṅ bahasa jarva // sireka mas Yasadipureṅ ar an / kan inutus manulad riṅ pustakadi / abdi carik sira Sastrataruna / kagəṅan sri mahanarpatiputra
7605(His Majesty’s servant, the vriter, who has been ordered to compose the tale of Arjunavijaya in ’great verse’ in jarva language, is mas Yasadipura; the one who has been ordered to copy this book, which belongs to the Crovn Prince, is scribe Sastrataruna).
.Since, according to a biography vritten by his descendants, Yasadipura I died on 20th Dhū’l ka’idah 1729 (= 14 March 1803 A.D.; see Soebardi 1967: 51), the Yasadipura mentioned in the abowe quotation of the Arkm. must be Yasadipura II. This argument is further corroborated by a quotation from the Arjuna Sasrabau of Yasadipura II (51,22-3).
.The Arjuna Sasrabau of Yasadipura II
.Sixteen years later, Yasadipura II revrote this kavi miriṅ version of the Arj. in macapat form. This macapat version has been discussed breifly by Poerbatjaraka (1964: 137).
.The dates of the commencement and the completion of this macapat version are recorded in the first and final cantos respectively:
7610Arsy. 1,1:
.Purva niṅ reh pandon in mamanis / makirtya riṅ agña prabvat-maja / ri Surakarta mandireṅ / Javi saananipun / piṅ patbəlas Rcspati Manis / Jumadilaval hasta / gatitaña nuju / Jimakir sevu kalavan / pituṅ atus catur maṅka palupi / prabhu Sahasraboja
.(At the command of the Crovn Prince of Surakarta, Java, the vriting of this poem, which begins with Dandaṅgula metre, has been commenced on Thursday Ləgi, 14th Jumādā ’lūlā, at 8 o’clock, Jimākhir 1746 (1819 A.D.). As regards the story, it is about king Sahasraboja).
.Arsy. 51,22:
.Pi
7615ṅ rolikur Raməlan Jimakir / Kemis iṅ jam sangeñjaṅ sampurna / nireṅ kaṅda panitrane / Arjunasasrabau / lek iṅ kasa rovəlas ari / sənkala məksih samya / lan duk vivitipun …
.(The vriting of the Arjunasasrabau poem was completed on 22nd Ramadan, Jimākhir, on Thursday, at 9 a.m., on the 12th day of the vaxing of the moon, the first [Javanese] month, the same year as the commencement of the vriting …).
.That the vriter of this macapat version was Yasadipura II is clear from the following quotation (Arsy. 51,22-3):
.…ṅuni pan sampun jarva // naṅiṅ məksih lagu niṅ kakavin / nulya iṅ maṅkya karsa rinampas / sinalinan lalagone / iṅkaṅ səkar macatur / kan anavuṅ sakiṅ kakavin / aṅgəgəmət in kanda / baraṅ laṅənipun / abdi jən sri naraputra / mas ṅabehi Yasadipura piṅ kalih …
.(It [-the poem] had been vritten earlier in jarva language, but the metre was still that of kakavin. now the Crovn Prince wished to change the poem completely into macapat verse. The author who composed [the nev poem] from the kakavin and made a close study of the story with all its beauty, was mas ixabehi Yasadipura II, His Majesty’s servant).
7620The Arjuna Sasrabau of Yasadipura I
.However, Yasadipura II was not the first pujaṅga who rendered the Arj. into New Javanese. This is clear from the following quotation (Arsy. 51,24):
.duk vaune pan sampun / ginupiteṅ juru panaṅgit / ri vus sckar macapat / karsane saṅ prabu / kapiṅ tri Pakubuvana / kaṅ tinuduh sira ṅabehi Yasadi / pura iṅkaṅ kapisan
.(In accordance with the wish of His Majesty Pakubuvana III, it [= the Arj.] had earlier been rendered into macapat by a vriter. This vriter, ordered by the king to do this, was ṅabehi Yasadipura I).
.Neither Poerbatjaraka (1964), nor Pigeaud (1967), nor Soebardi (1967), mentions that Yasadipura I too had made a rendering of the Arj. in New Javanese. This is probably due to the fact that there seems to be no trace of the macapat version of Yasadipura I in the Libraries of the University of Leiden and Museum Pusat, Jakarta. It is nevertheless clear from the abowe quotation that Yasadipura I had rendered the Arj. into macapat verse during the reign of Pabubuvana III (1749-88 A.D.). In other vords, this macapat version had been vritten at least 15 years before the vriting of the kavi miriṅ version.
7625The conclusion that the kavi miriṅ of the Arj. was vritten some time after the macapat version (of Yasadipura I) accords with Poerbatjaraka’s arguments that the kavi miriṅ versions of the Devaruci and the Rama derived from the macapat versions (Poerbatjaraka 1964: 143-4; see also Pigeaud 1967: 238).
.The Arjuna Sasrabau of Sindusastra (see Palmer van den Broek 1868)
.Sindusastra, a pujaṅga who flourished during the reign of Pakubuvana VII, also vrote a book based on the story of Arjuna Sasrabau in macapat metre. The date of the vriting of this version is 1829 A.D. (i.e. 1245 Arabic year or 1757 Javanese year; see verse 1,1). However, this version contains much more than the stories of the kakavin. A comparison of the corresponding passages of this version with the Arj. clearly shovs that the vriter, Sindusastra, was not acquainted with, or at least did not make use of, the Arj. Its source, according to Poerbatjaraka (1964: 161) is the Serat Kanda. This version of the Arjuna Sasrabau cycle, therefore, belongs to a different tradition than the kakavin version.
.A thorough study of these different versions of the Arjuna Sasrabau cycle in New Javanese would no doubt be of some significance for increasing our still indaequate knowledge of the transitional period between Old Javanese and New Javanese literature. It is obvious, however, that such an undertaking falls outside the scope of the present study.
.</p></div>-->
7630
. </div>
. <div type="commentary" xml:id="arjunaVijaya_03">

7865Rājaparvata,
.75-7, 81; see also: Lord of
.the Mountains. Rājapatigundala, 2.
.Rājasanagara,
.3, 8, 9, 12, 14, 45, 73-4,

.Rāma Bhargava, see: Paraśu Rāma. Rāmāyana

. <!--<div>LIST OF PROPER NAMES OCCURRING IN THE ARJUNAWIJAYA
.The following abbreviations are used in this list:
7935A: Arjuna; B: Bāṇaputra; R. Rāvaṇa; W: Waiśravaṇa; n: a (proper) name; Skt.: Sanskrit (see Macdonell 1954; Monier-Williams 1960; Sə̄rensen 1963); Skt?: not in the dictionaries mentioned in Skt.
.Abala 6,8d; Skt. ’weak’, n; here an officer of W.
.Agada 6,8d; Skt. ’free from disease’; here an officer of W.
.AiRāvaṇa
.5,3b; Skt. n of Indra’s elephant.
7940Akampana 5,7a; 6,13b; 17,6b; 51,2a; Utt. a son of Sumāli.
.Aksobhya 27,1a; Skt. one of the Dhyāni-Buddhas; here he is equal to Rudra, his position is in the east.
.Amararāja
.60,3d; Skt. ’king of the gods’, n of Indra.
.Amitābha
794527,1c; Skt. one of the Dhyāni-Buddhas; here he is equal to Mahādeva, his position is in the vest.
.Amoghasiddhi 27,Id; Skt. one of the Dhyāni-Buddhas; here he is equal to Harimūrti, his position is in the north.
.Anala (1) 40,2c; Skt. ’fire’, the god of fire.
.(2) 6,15b; 18,6d; 51,4c; Utt. a son of Mali.
.(3) 6,8d; an officer of W.
7950Anaranya 16,Id; Utt. the king of Ayodhya; in the Utt. only this name occurs; in the Arj., this name only occurs once, and he is frequently referred to as B; in New Javanese versions only B occurs (see p. 25).
.An
.īla 45,16b; Skt. anila ’vind’ or nīla ’dark-coloured’? here an officer of R.
.Antaka 47,4d; Skt. ’death’, n of Yama.
.Arjuna (Sahasrabāhu) 20,1c; 42,Id, 4a and passim (episodes 8-12); Utt. the king of Māhismatī; here the hero of the kakavin, the ruler of Mahispati.
7955Arjunavijaya 73,1b; ’The Triumph of Arjuna’; title of the present kakavin; Skt?
.Arka 21,4c; 46,2d, 5d; 57,1c; Skt. ’the sun’.
.Arthesvara 4,10d; Skt? ’lord of vealth’; = W.
.Aruna 38,4c; Skt. ’the sun’.
.Asuji 22,1b; Skt. Āsvayuj, n of a month.
7960Ava
.ṅga 42,6c; 50,11a; 52,1a, 3b; 54,1a; Skt. Waṅga? here a tributary of Mahispati: see Sūryaketu.
.Avanti 42,6d; 50,11b; 51,2b; 52,2a; 54,3b; 54,4b; Skt. n of a country; here a tributary of Mahispati; see Candraketu.
.Ayodhya 16,1c; 17,3b; 18,9c; Utt., n of a country; see B.
.Bajra 6,8d;
7965Skt. vajra ’thunderbolt’, n; here an officer of W.
.Bajramusti 5,3a; 6,13a; 17,6a; 45,15a; 50,8c; 50,9d; Utt. Wajramusti, a son of Mālyavān.
.Bala 6,8d; Skt. ’strength’, n of a demon; here an officer of W.
.Bāṇaputra
.17,1a, 4a; 18,1a, 3a, 6a, 8c (episode 7: Skt? ’son of an arrow’? ’son of the forest’? (see Notes 17,1a); here the king of Ayodha; see Anaranya.
7970Baruṇa 3.10d; 8,12c; 14,3b; Skt. Waruna, lord of the sea.
.Bāyu
.42,7b; Skt. Wāyu, god of the vind.
.Bhlmaka 17,3a, 8c, 9c; a tributary of Ayodhya; Skt?
.Brahma 1,23a; 4,5b, 8a; 43,2b; 59,7b; 61,6a; Utt. Brahmā, the great-grand-father of R; the Creator; see Dhātr; Jagatkarana, Padmayoni, Prajapati, Widhi (see Notes 27,1b).
7975Brahmāstra
.51,1 Id; 56,2b; 58,6c; 59,9c; Skt. Brahman’s missile.
.Buddha 1,1b; 27,2b; 72,9b; 73,2b; Skt.; here he is equal to siva (27,2b).
.Cakrāsya 6,8d;
.Skt? ’wheel-mouthed’; here an officer of W.
7980Candrahāsa
.4,12b; 61,7b; Skt. ’moon laugh’, n of R’s svord.
.Candraketu 42,6d; Skt. n of various kings; here the king of Avanti, a vassal of A.
.Citracāpa
.7,3b, 4d, 5d; Skt. ’having variegated bow’, one of the Kauravas; here an officer of W.
7985Citravat
.ī 21,1a; Skt. ’adorned with paintings’, n; here the wife of A; throughout episodes 8-12 she is simply referred to as ’the queen’.
.Citrāyudha
.7,3b, 4d, 5d; Skt. ’having variegated veapons’; one of the Kauravas; here an officer of W.
.Dhanapati 4,4c, 9b; 14,3c; Skt. ’lord of vealth’, = W.
7990Dhanarāja
.7,7a; 45,11c; Skt? ’lord of vealth’, = W.
.Danda 45,16b; Utt. a son of Sumāli.
.Dhanendra 4,13c; 6,8a; 8,1b, 9c; 9,2a; Skt? ’lord of vealth’, = W.
.Dhanesvara 1,7a, 14c; 2,8c; 10,1a; 13,3b; 45,18c; Skt. ’lord of vealth’, = W.
7995Dharmaghosa 42,7a; Skt. n; here the king of Kaliṅga, a vassal of A.
.Dasamukha 3,5d, 7d; 4,3d and passim; Utt. ’ten-faced’, = R.
.Dasānana
.14,4b; 42,4c; 46,3a and passim; Utt. ’ten-faced’, = R.
.Dasapati 17,2d, 6c; a vassal of B; Skt?
8000Daśāsya 1,17d; 2,8d;
.4,2a and passim; Skt. ’ten-faced’, = R.
.Daśāsyacarita
.73,1a; ’the story of Daśāsya’; the name of the first part of the Arj.? Skt?
.Dasavaktra 1,16c; 2,6b; 10,3d and passim; Skt. ’ten-faced’, = R.
8005Dhātr
.1,17c, 24b; 3,11c; 27,1b; Skt. ’creator’, n of Brahmā; in 27,1b he is equal to Ratnasambhva, his position is in the south.
.Dhātrja
.67,9b; Skt? ’son of Dhātr’; here refers to Pulastya.
.Dh
8010ūmrāksa 5,1a; 6,13b; 7,5c; 17,5d; 45,16b; 51,3a; Utt. a son of Sumāli.
.Durgā
.62,6a; Skt. ’the inaccessible or terrific goddes’, n of Umā.
.Durkāla
.(1) 6,8c an officer of W;
8015(2) 18,6d an officer of R;
.Skt. Duskāla ’bad or all destroying Time’, n of Śiva.
.Durmukha 45,16b; Utt. a son of Mālyavān.
.Dussāsana
.6,8c; Skt. Duhsāsana ’difficult to control’, one of the Kauravas; here an officer of W.
8020Gadipati 17,6b; Skt. Gada? n of a district; here a vassal of B.
.Gajendramukha 3,8a; Skt. Gajamukha ’elephant-faced’, n of Ganesa, son of Śiva (god of visdom, remover of obstacles).
.Gana 3,8d; 32,2d; 42,2d; Skt. ’troops of demi-gods attendant of Śiva, under the rule of Ganesa’; here = Ganesa.
.Ghorabala 42,7b; Skt? ’of a frightful pover’; here the king of Sinhala, a vassal of A.
.Girindra 10,13a; 13,5b; 63,2a; Skt. ’lord of mountains’.
8025Giripati 61,1b; Skt. ’king of mountains’.
.Girirāja
.42,2a; Skt. ’king of mountains’.
.Giriputrikā
.40,3a, 10b; Skt? ’daughter of the Mountain’; = Umā.
8030Girisutā
.13,5d; Skt. ’daughter of the Mountain’, = Umā.
.Gokarna 1,15a; Utt. name of the mountain where R did penance.
.Gomukha 4,4c; (episode 2) Utt. an envoy of W.
.Hari 12,12d;
803513,1c, 6c, 10a; 45,10c; 67,4a; 74,1c; Skt., n of Wiṣṇu.
.Harim
.ūrti 1,6d; 7,2d; 27,1a; Skt? ’incarnation of Hari’; here n of Wiṣṇu; in 27,Id he is equal to Amoghasiddhi.
.Harthesvara 8,7b = Arthesvara.
.Hastivaktra 40,3a; Skt. ’elephant-faced’, n of Ganesa.
8040Hehaya 20,2c; 42,Id; 45,10d and passim; Skt. Haihaya, n of a race; Arjuna is the supreme ruler of this race.
.Himavan 10,20a; Skt. the Himalayas.
.Indra 3,10d; 5,7a; 10,10b; Skt. chief of the gods; here he is only an in-significant deity (but see Notes 10,9b); see Amararāja, Sakra, Suranātha, Surendra.

.Narmadā,

.ālaya 12,1a; the abode of Isvara; Skt?
.Parasu 6,8d; Skt. ’axe’, n; an officer of W.
.Parvatarāja
.1,1a; Skt. ’mountain-king’, n of the Himalayas; see also Girīndra, Giripati, Girirāja (also Giriputrikā, Girisutā), Himavan, Meru, Sumeru, Parvatendra; here Parvatarājadeva, n of the deity invoked by Tantular as the istadevatā (see Chapter 6).
8110Parvatendra 56,4b; Skt. ’Lord of mountains’.
.Pārvat
.ī 10,12d, 13d; Skt. n of Umā.
.Pasupati 3,10a; 40,10b; 41,5b; 46,8d; Skt. ’lord of animals’, n of Śiva.
.Pasupatidhana 15,4a; n of a sacrifice performed by Māruta; Skt?
8115Pavana 6,15b; Skt. ’vind’, so synonym of Anila, a son of Mali in Utt.?
.Praghasa 45,16d, 51,4a; Utt. a son of Sumāli.
.Prahasta 4,3c; 6,2b; 10,4a; 42,4c; 44,1a; 62,11b; Utt. a son of Sumāli; here the first minister of R who was very loyal and always gave him good advice (see p. 44).
.Prajapati 42,6c; 63,2b; ’lord of creatures’, n of Brahmā.
.Prakopa 17,7b; Skt. ’violent anger’; here n of an officer of R.
8120Pulastya 1,5c; 67,8b; Utt. son of Brahmā, grandfather of R and W.
.Puspaka 7,1c; 59,11a; Utt. n of W’s chariot seized by R.
.Rāghava
.19,2; Skt. ’a descendant of Raghu, especially n of Rāma-candra’.
.Rāhu
81254,12c; Skt. n of a demon who is supposed to seize the sun and the moon and thus cause eclipses.
.Ranama
.ṅgala 1,3d; the patron of Tantular (see Section 1.3).
.Rati 40,9b; Skt. n of Smara’s wife.
.Ratih 11,Id; 30,3b; see Rati.
8130Ratnasambhava 27,1b; Skt. one of the Dhyāni-Buddhas; here he is equal to Dhatr, his position is in the south.
.Ravana 1,5d; 1,14c and passim; Utt. the ’villain’ of the story; see also Dasamukha, Dasānana, Daśāsya, Dasavaktra.
.Rudra 8,2d, 8b; 10,2b; 27,1a; Skt. n of Śiva; in 27,1a he is equal to Akso-bhya, his position is in the east.
.Rudram
.ūrti 42,5d; 57,3c; = Rudra (cf. Harimūrti).
8135Rudrasara 58,6c; 60,5c; Skt? ’Rudra’s arrows’.

.18,8c; 51,1 Id; Skt? ’Rudra’s arrows’.
.Sahasrabāhu
.Utt. ’thousand-armed’; see Arjuna.
8140Sahasrabhuja 42,2b; Skt. ’thousand-armed’, n of Wiṣṇu, of a gandharva (but not of A?); here n of A.
.Saisuka (1) 40,3d; = Skanda, son of Śiva? see Notes 40,3d.
.(2) 46,11c; 51,7c; 57,2a; n of a prince of Kaliṅga.
.Sakra 8,9a; Skt. n of Indra.
.Sambarta 15,Id; Utt. Māruta’s teacher.
8145Sambhu 12,11c; Utt. n of a demon who killed Kusadhvaja.
.Saṅhati 45,16d; Utt. Saṅhādi, a son of Sumāli.
.Sa
.ṅkha 10,6a; Utt. an officer of W (see p. 23).
.Sa
8150ṅkara 40,3d; Utt. n of Śiva.
.Sārana
.7,6b; Utt. Sārana, an officer of R; see Notes 7,6b.

.Sindhu or sindhu? 35,1c; Skt. ’the Indus, river, sea’.
8155Si
.ṅhala 42,7b; 46,10a; 51,4c; 52,2c, 6c; Skt. n of a people and their country, Ceylon; see Ghorabala, Kardha.
.Śiva 27,2b (here he is equal to Buddha); 3,5d; 10,16b; 32,2d; 38,8c; 60,3d; 67,4a; 72,Id; Skt. the Supreme Deity of the Śivaites; see Īsvara, Jagat-guru, Pasupati, Rudra, Sankara, Tripurāntaka, Trirājyāntaka.
.Śivāgni 1,17a; Skt?; the god of Fire; see Notes 1,17a.
.Śivasadā 26,4d; one of the most important deities in Saivasiddhanta; here he is equal to Wairocana.
8160Smara 3,5c; 11,Id; 20,3b; 21,4d; 35,5d; 38,2d; 41,5b; Skt. god of love.
.Sobhendra 17,6a; Skt. Saubhāyana (indra)? n of a warrior-tribe; here a vassal of B.
.Sodha 46,11b; 50,10b; 51,7c; 52,1b, 3a; 57,2a; 61,8a; Skt. saudha ’great house or palace’; here n of prince of Magadha.
.Subala 46,11c; 61,8b; Skt. n of various persons; here n of prince of Kaliṅga.
.Subha
8165ṅga 18,6d; Skt. ’easily broken’; here an officer of R.
.Sukesa 1,9a; Utt. father of Sumāli.
.Sukha 7,6b; Utt. Suka, an officer of R (see Notes 7,6b).
.Sukhasārana
.42,1c; 66,2c; 67,3b; Utt. Sukasārana, n of two oficers of R (see Notes 7,6b; 66,2c).
8170Sumāli
.1,2a; Utt. maternal grandfather of R.
.Sumanāgra 18,6d;
.Skt?; here an officer of R.
.Sumatta 45,16c; Utt. Matta or Unmatta? both sons of Mālyavān.
8175Sumeru 42,2a; 45,15a; 46,2b; = Meru.
.Supārsva
.5,5a; 45,16b; 50,7c; Utt. a son of Sumāli.
.Suptaghna 6,14c, 17b; 45,16d; 51,4c; Utt. a son of Mālyavān.
.Suranātha
818013,4c; 14,3a; Skt. ’lord of gods’, n of Indra.
.Surasena (1) 7,3b; a proper name?
.(2) 57,7b; an officer of A. Skt? (see Notes 57,7b).
.Surendra 10,6d; Skt. ’lord of gods’, n of Indra.
.Surpanakhā
81851,12d; Utt. R’s sister.
.S
.ūrya 59,3c; Skt. ’the sun’.
.S
.ūryaketu 42,6a; 51,1c, 4a, 12c; 54,26; Skt. ’having the sun for a flag’, n of a king; here the king of Avaṅga, a vassal of A.
8190Suvandha 22,3a; 39,6d; 47,1a; 51,3a; 56,1b, 3a; 57,1a, 6a, 7d; the first minister of Mahispati; Skt? (see p. 46).
.Taladhvaja 40,9b; n of a river (?) where Rati usually vent to amuse her-self? Skt? (see Berg 1969: 117).
.Tantular 73,1c; 74,3a author of the Arj. and the Sut (see Section 1.1; see also Notes 73,1).
.Trikuta 3,1b; Utt. n of a mountain, where Ləṅkā was situated.
.Tripur
8195āntaka 40,9d; 62,1b; Skt. ’the destroyer of the triple city’, n of Śiva.
.Trirājyantaka 43,1c; Skt? = Tripurantaka.
.Trivighna 18,6d; an officer of R; Skt?
.Umā 10,9d; Utt. n of the wife of Śiva; Skt., see Durgā, Giriputrikā, Girisutā, Īsvarī, Pārvatī.
.Uragarāja
820040,4b; Skt? ’lord of serpents’.
.Usinara
.14,1b; Skt. Utt. Usirabīja, n of a mountain where Māruta performed sacrifice.
.Wairocana 26,4c; Skt. one of the Dhyāni-Buddhas; here he is equal to Śivasadā, his position is in the centre; (Utt. n of grandfather of Kumbha-karna’s wife; see pp. 43-4).
.Waiśravaṇa 1,8c, 9b; 6,13a, 15a, 17c; 7,1a; 10,4d (episodes 2 and 3); Utt. half-brother of R; he is also known as Kuvera, the god of vealth; see Arthesvara, Dhanapati, Dhanarāja, Dhanendra, Dhanesvara, Lokapāla, Wisravaputra.
8205Waktrāsya 6,14d;
.an officer of W; Skt?
.Wallabha 17,2d, 5d; Skt. n of a city in Gujarat; here a tributary of Ayodhya.
.WedavatI 11,1c (episode 5); Utt. n of anchoress, daughter of Kusadhvaja; in Arkm. (15,4) adopted daughter of Wrhaspati; after her death she incarnated as Citravatī.
.Wəkas-i
8210ṅ-Sukha 1,4a ruler of Majapahit, at the time Tantular vrote his two kakavin (see Paməkas-iṅ-Tusta).
.Wela 17,3a, 6c; Skt. Wella, n of a tovn; here a tributary of Ayodhya.
.Wibh
.īsana 1,13d, 16a, 21a; 3,11a; Utt. R’s brother; see Notes 1,13.
.Widhi’ 2,Id; 68,4a; Skt. n of Brahmā.
8215Wikata 6,13b; a son of Sumāli.
.Wir
.ūpāksa 6,15b; 17,6b; Utt. a son of Mālyavān.
.Wiṣṇu (1) 3,11b; 4,10c, 16d; 45,8a, lib, 13a; 58,4d; 73,2b-,Utt.-, here he is always regarded as the arch-foe of the demons; see Hari, Kesava.
.(2) 6,8b, 15c; OJ Utt. (not in Skt. Utt.) an officer of W (see p. 24).
8220Wiṣṇumurti 43,1c; 71,5b; = Wiṣṇu (cf. Harimurti); pandita Wiṣṇumūrti 72,1c; = Rāma Bhārgava.
.Wisrava 1,5c, 13c; Utt. n of a sage, R’s father (see Notes 1,11a).
.Wisravaputra 1,8d; = W; Skt? ’son of Wisrava’.
.Wisvabajra 42,6b; 50,10d; king of Māgadha, a vassal of A; Skt. Wisva-vajra?
.Wrhaspati 12,9a; Utt. n of a sage, Wedavatl’s grandfather.
8225Yajñagopa 45,16c; Utt. Yajñakopa, a son of Mālyavān.
.Yama 14,3b; 42,7a; Utt. the god of death.
.Yavendra 1,2c; ’the kings of Java’; (see Notes 1,2).
.YogandhI 6,8b, 15d, 17b; Utt. Yvagadhipa, an officer of W (see p. 24).
.LIST OF METRES OCCURRING IN THE ARJUNAWIJAYA
8230Asvalalita: </p></div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="35">(see Nag. 36; Siv. 5).
.Bhramaravilasita: cantos 15, 25 (see Bhom. 87; Sut. 13).
.Indravajra: </p></div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="49">(see Siv. 22).
8235Jagaddhita: cantos 11, 21, 32, 36, 40, 53, 65, 67, 74 (see Nag. 1; Siv. 1).
.Jagatnātha
.*: cantos 20, 30, 33, 42, 64, 71 (see Nag. 22; Siv. 10).
.Kalə
.ṅəṅ
8240an:
.cantos 14, 16, 24, 38 (see Siv. 8).
.Kilayu-manədə
.ṅ
.:
8245cantos 3, 46, 73 (see Nag. 32; Sut. 14).
.Kusumavilasita: </p></div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="37">(see Siv. 18).
.Madhulenda: cantos 9, 57 (see Nag. 41; Siv. 27).
.Mattaraga: </p></div>
8250<div type="canto" rend="met" n="55">(see Nag. 37; Bhom. 22).
.Praharsini: </p></div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="19">(see Nag. 5; Bhom. 24).
.* In the list of metres made by Teeuw and others (1969: 35; </p></div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="10">, this metre is called Wirat Təbu Sol or Kaləṅəṅan, which is also the name of another metre (Siv. 8; Arj. 14 etc.). Since in the MS. A this metre is called Jagadnātha, the same as it is called in Zoetmulder’s unpublished text of the Sut. cantos 5, 8, 18, 22, 29, 44, 55, 72, 92 and 116, to avoid any possible confusion with the metre occurs in Arj. 14 etc. I prefer to use this name-
8255Prthvītala: cantos 13, 63 (see Nag. 14; Siv. 25).
.Rajani: </p></div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="69">(see Nag. 33; Bhom. 32).
.Sandyakara: </p></div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="60">(see Nag. 35; Sut. 2; 143).
8260Sārd
.ūlavikrīdita: cantos 1, 7, 18, 29, 31, 34, 39, 44, 47, 51, 56, 59, 62, 66, 72 (see Nag. 3; Siv. 2).
.Śikharim: cantos 41, 52 (see Nag. 15; Siv. 31).
.Sragdharā:
.cantos 4, 8, 17, 22, 43, 50, 54, 61, 70 (see Nag. 13; Siv. 28).
8265Suvadanā:
.cantos 6, 26 (see Nag. 13; Siv. 4).
.Upajāti:
.</p></div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="2"> alternating pattern of Upendravajra and Indravajra (see Keith 1956: 419; cf. Siv. 22).
8270Upajāti:
.cantos 12, 68; alternating pattern of Indravaṅsa and Waṅsastha (see Keith 1956: 419).
.Wasantatilaka: cantos 5, 10, 23, 27, 45, 48, 58 (see Nag. 34; Siv. 7).
.Wansastha: </p></div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="28">(see Nag. 23; Siv. 11).
